Title: When it's about authentic news, print has an edge
Content: Being educated is no guarantee against falling prey to fake news . Are you really sure those apparently sound bits of medical advice you received as forwards would pass muster with your doctor? Yet, we do often forward these in the belief that we are doing a good deed to our friends and relatives.Clearly, where you get your news from matters, since you can't possibly be expected to yourself verify and authenticate every bit of 'news' you receive. This is where the print medium has an edge over other media. A newspaper once printed is for posterity, lakhs of its copies available to the public for as long as they wish to preserve it. That means we can't - unlike other media - just erase our mistakes and pretend they never happened. So we check every bit of news we put in the paper, because credibility is the currency we deal in.The Times Group and Dainik Bhaskar Group have launched Kaun Banega, Kaun Banayega , to ensure you don't fall prey to the fake news malaise. C ommenting on the initiative, Sivakumar Sundaram, President - Revenue, BCCL, said, "Fake news is a modern-day malaise brought on by social media. It ranges from the silly to grave 'forwards' having repercussions that affect the social, economic and cultural fabric of nations. As gatekeepers of the truth and as a leading newspaper company, The Times of India takes on the responsibility of educating people on the need to follow real news and not forwards. This is being done in an engaging and humorous manner through a series of films titled Kaun Banega, Kaun Banayega. We are happy to partner with the Dainik Bhaskar Group to jointly drive this initiative. "Girish Agarwal, Promoter-Director, Dainik Bhaskar Group, said, "Sharing a common responsibility, two of the largest media houses in the country have decided to come together to spread awareness on the menace of fake news. We will continue to work together on this issue and others of citizen and national importance."

Title: India tests nuclear-missile from undersea pad
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representational photo.

NEW DELHI: India tested its nuclear-capable K-4 submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM), designed to have a strike range of 3,500 km, from an undersea platform in the shape of a submersible pontoon off the coast of Andhra Pradesh on Sunday.

Though there was no official word on the test of the ‘strategic missile’, which will equip the country’s nuclear-powered submarines, sources said the solid-fuelled K-4 was test-fired for a range of around 2,200 km “successfully” in the Bay of Bengal around noon on Sunday.

“Though K-4 has been tested a few times before, this was the first time it was fired for a long range. The problem of the missile tilting after emerging from under water has been resolved,” said a source.

India’s solitary nuclear-powered submarine with ballistic missiles (SSBN), INS Arihant , is currently armed with K-15 missiles with a strike range of 750 km. The Navy also operates another nuclear-powered submarine, INS Chakra, acquired on a 10-year lease from Russia , but it does not have nuclear-tipped missiles because of international treatises.

INS Arihant had become fully operational in November 2018 after completing its first ‘deterrence patrol’ to complete the country’s long-awaited nuclear triad or the capability to fire nuclear weapons from land, air and sea. India for long has had the land-based Agni missiles, with the over 5,000 km Agni-V inter-continental ballistic missile now in the process of being inducted, and fighter jets jury-rigged to deliver nuclear weapons.

But INS Arihant gives the country’s nuclear deterrence posture much more credibility since SSBNs are the most secure, survivable and potent platforms for retaliatory strikes. Though INS Arihant’s K-15 missiles are currently dwarfed by the well over 5,000 km range SLBMs present with the US, Russia and China, the K-4 missiles will add much more teeth to the follow-on submarines.

The K-4 missiles are to be followed by the K-5 and K-6 missiles in the 5,000 to 6,000 km range. The 6,000-tonne INS Arihant, which is propelled by an 83 MW pressurised light-water reactor at its core is to be followed by INS Arighat, which was launched in 2017. The next generation of nuclear submarines, currently called S-4 and S-4*, will be much larger in size.

Title: Muslims from Pakistan, Afghanistan & Bangladesh too got citizenship: Nirmala Sitharaman
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Union minister Nirmala Sitharaman. (PTI)

CHENNAI: Pointing out that states cannot refuse to implement the Citizenship (Amendment) Act as “that is against law and the Constitution”, Union finance minister said here on Sunday that as many as 2,838 Pakistanis, 914 Afghans and 172 Bangladeshis had been given citizenship in the past six years. Reeling out statistics issued by the Union home ministry, the finance minister added that 391 Afghans and 1,595 Pakistanis had been given citizenship in the past two years. “Obviously, they include Muslims too,” Sitharaman said, while adding that 566 Muslims from Pakistan , Afghanistan and Bangladesh were given citizenship since 2014. Participating in a discussion organised by the Chennai Citizens’ Forum and New India Forum, Sitharaman said, "Political parties can make a political statement by passing resolutions against CAA in the assembly, but states cannot refuse to implement it." She said there was an attempt by the opposition to distort the truth and create fear about the CAA. “Every question that the opposition raised in Parliament about the CAA was answered… The CAA is to offer citizenship and not to deny citizenship to anyone,” Sitharaman said. The Citizenship Act of 1955 continues to remain in force and citizenship will continue to be given to people if they fulfill the conditions under the four categories — birth, descendency, registration and naturalization. “Just by bringing in changes and amendments does not make the existing categories go away,” she pointed out. Sitharaman said the people who have been granted citizenship are the ones who had come to India from the then East Pakistan, which later became Bangladesh. “People like them had to be given citizenship and hence the amendment to the Citizenship Act,” she said. She said the condition was very pitiable in camps where Sri Lankan Tamils live. “Political parties raising the issue for not granting citizenship (to Sri Lankan Tamils) will not talk about these. No human rights organisation will speak about them. Since 1964, more than four lakh Sri Lankans have been granted citizenship. Sri Lankan Tamils living in camps, around 95,000 of them, too will be given citizenship in the coming years,” she said. Clarifying that the CAA had nothing to do with the National Register of Citizens (NRC) and the National Population Register (NPR), Sitharaman said the NRC had been implemented in Assam as per the directions of the Supreme Court. “There have been no talks about the NRC being implemented across India and whether the process will be the same as done in Assam. There have been no talks at all.”

Title: Eye on China, South gets 1st Sukhoi squad with BrahMos
Content:
Image of Sukhoi-30 fighter aircraft used for representational purposes only. (ANI)

#WATCH Water salute being given to the SU-30MKI fighter aircraft at the induction of the 222 ‘Tigersharks’ fighter… https://t.co/dPALOh1YWd — ANI (@ANI) 1579503449000

Chief of Defence Staff Gen Bipin Rawat, Air Force Chief RKS Bhadauria and DRDO chairman G Satheesh Reddy witness Su… https://t.co/gB6t0aIP0k — ANI (@ANI) 1579502261000

NEW DELHI: India now has a new lethal weapons platform to keep a ‘strategic eye’ over the Indian Ocean Region (IOR), especially the Bay of Bengal, as well as carry out ‘long-range precision strikes’ against hostile aircraft carriers or other high-value targets by day and night in all-weather conditions in the region.The IAF will commission a squadron of Sukhoi-30MKI fighter jets, especially modified to carry the 2.5-tonne air-launched supersonic BrahMos cruise missiles, at its Thanjavur airbase in Tamil Nadu on Monday. Primarily tasked with a maritime strike role, these Sukhois will be “a huge addition to IAF’s operational capabilities”, Air Chief Marshal Rakesh Kumar Singh Bhadauria said.BrahMos director-general Sudhir Mishra told TOI, “It’s the realisation of our dream to provide IAF with a formidable and much-desired capability to strike from long standoff distances on any target at sea or on land with pinpoint accuracy.”The new Sukhoi squadron, nicknamed ‘Tiger Sharks’, will be commissioned with four to six fighters at Thanjavur on Monday, and will induct its full complement of 18 fighters by the end of the year. With a combat radius of almost 1,500 km without mid-air refuelling, the Sukhoi will combine with the 290-km range BrahMos missile to constitute a formidable weapons package.Tiger Sharks is the 12th squadron of the fourth-generation ‘air dominance’ Sukhois but the first one to be based in south India after the first 11 were deployed on the western and eastern fronts, from Halwara, Pune, Jodhpur and Sirsa to Bareilly , Tezpur and Chabua, to cater for Pakistan and China.The deployment at Thanjavur is clearly in response to China’s fast-expanding strategic footprint in the IOR, with Beijing now also looking to establish additional logistics facilities in the IOR after setting up its first overseas military base in Djibouti on the Horn of Africa in August 2017, while also using Karachi as a regular naval turnaround facility.Just last month, Navy chief Admiral Karambir Singh had confirmed that Indian warships recently drove away a Chinese oceanic research vessel , Shi Yan-1, after it was found acting suspiciously near the strategically-located Andaman and Nicobar archipelago. There are seven to eight Chinese warships, including submarines, present in the IOR at any given time, he said.The Navy already operates its Poseidon-8I long-range maritime patrol aircraft, which are packed with sensors and weapons to detect, track and destroy enemy submarines, from its INS Rajali base at Arakkonam in Tamil Nadu.Armed with the BrahMos missiles, which fly almost three times the speed of sound at Mach 2.8, the Sukhois will further add to this deterrence over the high seas right up to the Malacca Strait. “The capability of the missile, coupled with the high performance of the Sukhois, will give IAF strategic reach and allow it to dominate over land and sea. The Sukhoi-BrahMos package can also be used in surgical strikes to destroy terror camps across the Line of Control with Pakistan,” said an official.With IAF having inducted 260 of the 272 twin-seat Sukhois contracted from Russia for around $15 billion, 42 of the fighters are to be eventually armed with BrahMos missiles. With India joining the 34-nation Missile Technology Control Regime (MTCR) in June 2016, which “removed the caps” on the range of the missile developed jointly with Russia, plans are also afoot to develop an extended range BrahMos with a 450-500 km range. The MTCR basically prevents the proliferation of missiles and drones over the range of 300 km.The IAF also plans to upgrade its entire Sukhoi fleet with more advanced avionics, radars and weapons to further bolster their combat capabilities. Detailed talks are currently underway with Russia and HAL for the mega project, as was earlier reported by TOI.In Video: South India gets Sukhoi-30MKI fighter jets squadron as ‘strategic eye’

Title: 5 crore form 18,034km-long human chain in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Villagers form a human chain on boats in Bochaha block in Muzaffarpur district on Sunday

PATNA: Over 5.16 crore people participated in the 18,034-km long human chain in the state to create awareness about conservation of water and increasing green cover, prohibition and the adverse impact of social evils like dowry and child marriage, said chief secretary Deepak Kumar.

The human chain, the third of its kind in the state, was formed by the state government under its ‘Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali’ campaign. A little over 57.76 lakh schoolchildren from Class I to IV also took part in the human chain but on their respective campuses. Besides, 43,445 prisoners also formed human chain inside the jail premises, he said.

Chief minister Nitish Kumar , who joined the human chain along with deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi , assembly speaker Vijay Kumar Choudhary and ‘Water Man’ Rajendra Singh at Gandhi Maidan, thanked people for their record participation. Though the human chain was officially formed from 11.30am to 12pm across the state, people had lined up on the streets much before the event started.

Seven choppers and over 100 drones were used to cover the event. The representatives of Limca Book of Records and Indian Book of Records were present to assess the length of human chain, which was claimed to be the longest so far across the globe. Anjani Kumar Singh, the adviser to CM, said the representatives of Guinness World Records were also invited but they expressed their inability to come due to some technical reasons.

The chief secretary said two human chains were earlier formed in 2017 and 2018. Over 3.5 crore people had participated in 11,292km-long human chain in 2017 while the 2018 human chain was over 14,000km long. “The 2020 human chain has exceeded both the previous events both in length and participation,” he told the media.

Two people, including a government school teacher, died due to cardiac arrest while taking part in the event in Darbhanga and Samastipur districts. While Md Dawood was a teacher at Urdu Middle School, Dighiyar under Keoti block in Darbhanga district, one Reshma belonged to Jitwarpur in Samastipur district. The chief secretary said ex gratia of Rs 4 lakh will be paid to the next of kin of each of the deceased. In the case of the school teacher, his family would also be provided post-retiral benefits. He said both the persons died due to suspected cardiac arrest.

Beaming over the grand success of the event, Nitish said, “This human chain is unique in its kind and a part of ‘Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali’ programme. We will continue to work in mission mode and achieve the target. People barring age and religion have participated in this human chain in large numbers, which shows they have become conscious about the issue.

“This is for the society. If I do some mistake, criticize me as much as you want. But for ‘Jal-Jeevan-Hariyali, everyone should come together and support it.”

Rajendra Singh presented a kalash filled with water to Nitish on behalf of his organization Tarun Bharat Sangh. Nitish said people of Bihar deserved the appreciation and not him.

Atul Bagai of United Nations Environment Programme lauded the efforts being taken in Bihar regarding protection of environment.

Title: How Tolly celebrities help their kids beat exam blues
Content: The party season is over, and everyone is back to the grind. February and March are the months when children have their boards or annual examinations. So, the stress levels, both for children and their parents, are obviously high. The children are already anxious about their performance, so parents are providing mental support to make them feel confident. CT spoke to a few Tollywood celeb parents to know how they help their children deal with examination stress. Read on...My son, Ankan Rishav Chakraborty , is in Class XI and there is some examination stress at the moment. As a mother, I try to make him understand that it is his responsibility to study well. I want him to have a great future. I am not interfering at all. Parents should be supportive instead. I try to be with him as much as possible before his exams. I insist he listens to music or meet his friends to unwind. The best thing is to make your children feel responsible for their actions. Too much of monitoring and guidance do not help. Rather, it is important that they know what to do and when. As for my daughter, Rishona, I would never want her to be stressed. She is in Class II now. I guide her as much as possible.My daughter, Hiya, who is in Class XII and will appear for her boards next month, gets paranoid before her exams. I keep telling her not to take stress, as that does no good in the long run. My wife is a teacher. She helps Hiya make a study timetable so that there is enough time to revise every subject. She also assists her in revising. I always try to make the situation light by providing assurance and emotional support. The other thing I monitor is whether she is getting enough sleep, as that is very important. Both my wife and I try to make Hiya understand that appearing in exams and getting good marks are just a part of life and not life itself!My wife and I don’t add on to Brishtisnata’s examination stress. We are comparatively cooler than other parents as our anxiety will only increase her stress. Since childhood, we have tried to make her a responsible child, be it in her studies or other things. In fact, I remember, taking her out for dinner when she didn’t score well just to prove that marks are not the end of the world. We give more importance to becoming a sensible and compassionate human being than being scoring high marks in exams. Brishtisnata has a habit of studying late at night, so we make sure she gets eight-nine hours of sleep. She watches films before exams to unwind and we have no issues about that. We always try to identify her strengths and interests. Accordingly, we try to build her self-esteem. The most important thing is to have a healthy conversation with her, so she feels confident and happy!Abhimanyu (Chatterjee) is in Class X now and has his board examination in February. I try to reduce the stress as much as possible. I’ve always taught him to put in 100 per cent effort. If this does not bring positive results, he should accept failure and move on. Secondly, I encourage him to take breaks in between his studies and do whatever he feels like, except fiddling with the phone! Thirdly, I advise him to not ask his friends how many times they have revised as each student has his or her own way of preparing. I only coordinate with his class teacher if I have any doubt regarding his studies and never with any parent, as it doubles my stress. I make sure Abhimanyu meditatates and does yoga before exams. Proper sleep and right diet too are necessary to remain stress-freePraneel (Basu) will be in Class VIII this year and his annual exam is knocking on the door. But he is a bindaas kid, who doesn’t take much stress about studies. He wants to be a cricketer. At times, I get paranoid because of his casual attitude. But gone are the days when parents used to scold their kids if they didn’t study. Now, I make Praneel realise that basic education is required to be a cricketer too. I always tell him that to maintain this lifestyle, courtesy his mother, he needs to earn. I am not the type of person who will call up his friends’ mothers to discuss or compare. At times, I do nag him to study, but not to a great extent. Every child is different and so are their study habits. But I do give him tests at home and take him out to eat if he does well. That’s how I encourage him. I believe in destiny, so whatever is destined for my son will happen. But, he should put in his best effort.Prachyadeep, is in Class XI. Since childhood, we have inculcated in him that studies are not only about scoring high marks in examinations. Rather, it is more about enriching one’s self. So, the fear of not scoring high marks is not there in my house. Sunday is a holiday for my son. The stress of running from one coaching centre to another is something he is devoid of. That apart, I tell him to keep the study table clear as too many books make you feel stressed. My wife is part of the WhatsApp group of my son’s school, but she only passes on the messages to him that are necessary from him to know. That keeps the stress at bay. Another thing we consciously do is never show our tension in front of him before examination as that only makes things worse.

Title: Kerala mosque turns venue for Hindu wedding
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Sarath Sasi of Kappil Kizhakku, Kayamkulam and Anju Ashok Kumar tied the knot on the mosque premises, with a H... Read More

ALAPPUZHA: The over 100-year-old Cheravally Jamaat Masjid in Kayamkulam on Sunday hosted a Hindu wedding on its premises, complete with a vegetarian feast – including two payasam -- for 4,000 people. People cutting across religions attended the event while the jamaat committee met all its expenses.

Sarath Sasi of Kappil Kizhakku, Kayamkulam and Anju Ashok Kumar tied the knot on the mosque premises, with a Hindu priest leading the rituals. The couple later entered the mosque and sought the blessings of chief imam Riyasudeen Faizy.

Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the wedding was as an example of unity from Kerala . “Congratulations to the newlyweds, families, mosque authorities and people of Cheravally,” he said in a tweet.

“The committee also gave Anju 10 sovereign gold and Rs 2 lakh as wedding gift besides home equipment like TV and fridge,” said Nujumudeen Alummoottil, secretary of Cheravally Muslim Jamaat Committee. He said he knew Anju’s father personally, and wanted to help the family after the father passed away.

Nujumudeen said Anju is also the first woman to enter the mosque. “All religions teach people to love and care for others. Those lessons led to this wedding,” he said.

He had received an application from Bindu, wife of late Ashok Kumar, seeking help to conduct the wedding of her 24-year-old daughter Anju in October last year. “When I shared the application with committee members, all of them came forward to arrange facilities for the wedding. Bindu is staying in a rented house with her three children. We decided to conduct the wedding as per Hindu rituals on the mosque premises,” he said.

“I have a jewellery shop in Kayamkulam and I knew Anju’s father Ashokan, who was a goldsmith. He died of cardiac arrest at the age of 49 on March 14, 2018 after dropping his son Anand at Kayamkulam Boys High School for his SSLC examination and his son wrote the exam without knowing about Ashokan’s demise. I had visited the family then after reading about it in the newspaper. I had also extended some help then,” he said.

Both Anju and her sister Amritha had stopped their studies after completing Plus-Two due to financial constraints. Anand is pursuing higher secondary education now.

On Sunday, Bindu was lost for words to express her gratitude to the committee. She and her husband had sold their house and land in Kayamkulam around 17 years ago owing to financial constraints and they were living in rented houses since then. The unexpected demise of Ashokan came as a shock. “I have joined a private firm as cleaner for a salary of Rs 7,000. The rent of our present house near Cheravally temple is Rs 2,500 and we are somehow meeting our monthly expenses. I did not have any other means to conduct the wedding that I sought Nujumudin’s help,” she said.

Title: Nadda likely to take over as BJP president today
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

NEW DELHI: BJP working president J P Nadda is set to take over as party chief replacing Amit Shah on Monday in the presence of top party functionaries.

Senior functionaries including Union ministers and those from states are likely to arrive at the BJP headquarters to file nominations in support of Nadda, whose ascension to the top post was awaited since Shah became home minister last year.

Nadda's decades-long experience in the organisation, starting from student politics, proximity to the RSS and clean image are seen as his strengths. His tenure as in-charge of the party headquarters will also come handy in running the party since he is known to workers directly.

Senior BJP leader Radha Mohan Singh, who is in-charge of the party's organisational poll process, said nominations for the national president's election will be filed on January 20, and a contest will take place the next day if required.

BJP has the convention of electing its president with consensus and without any contest, and there is little possibility that it will be any other way this time. The election of a new president will end Shah's tenure of over five-and-a-half years during which BJP expanded its footprints across the country .

Title: Flight takes 12 hours to make 45-minutes trip to Bagdogra
Content:
Passengers of flight SG 3321 wait at the lounge on Sunday

KOLKATA: Passengers booked on a morning SpiceJet flight to north Bengal on Sunday had a harrowing time after the 45-minute journey from Kolkata to Bagdogra ended up taking more than 12 hours — at least an hour more than what it takes for a train, like Darjeeling Mail, to reach New Jalpaiguri from Sealdah under normal circumstances. During the period, flyers had to sit in the aircraft for over two hours, waiting for it to take off, before being asked to wait at the security hold area of Kolkata airport for several hours. The reason cited by the airline for the delay was low visibility at Bagdogra airport and inadequate operating crew.The flight — SG 3321 — was slated to take off at 6.05am on Sunday and land at 6.50am. It finally reached the destination around 7pm on Sunday.Most of the 78 passengers booked on the flight had reported to the airport by 4am since the boarding time was scheduled at 5.45am.However, the boarding kept getting delayed and the flyers were finally allowed to board around 6.30am.It then took off from Kolkata. However, halfway into the journey, the flight turned back as crew members announced that the aircraft was unable to land due to poor visibility at Bagdogra. It landed in Kolkata at 7.15am. “We were told the flight will resume its journey once the situation got better and we were seated inside as it stood on the tarmac for two hours, till 9.30am. Then an announcement was made that the flight had been delayed and the aircraft was taken to a parking bay and we were asked to get off,” said Sharmishtha Mondal, one of the passengers.Once they had alighted, passengers were sent text messages about the flight being delayed further. “First, we were told the flight will take off at 11.45am. Then we received another message, informing us that the revised timing was 3.20pm and lastly, there was a message that said the flight would take off at 5.20pm. All the while, the reason they cited was bad weather in Bagdogra. However, we personally checked from people staying in Bagdogra and north Bengal that the weather had improved from 9.30am itself. In fact, a Vistara flight had landed at Bagdogra at 9.37am on Sunday,” Mondal added. A resident of Baruipur, Mondal had started from her home at 1am and had been waiting at the airport since 3am.The flight finally took off at 5.45pm and reached Bagdogra around 6.45pm, by when it had already turned dark and the flyers who had expected an early start to their vacations rued the loss of an entire day.“We had planned to reach Bagdogra early and had a car waiting outside the airport to take us to our hotel in Darjeeling. We had planned a day trip around the hills on Sunday itself, but the flight delay ruined all our plans. I overheard the crew members saying that the pilot who was flying the aircraft in the morning was no longer available and they had to send for a pilot from Jabalpur,” said Mondal’s husband Subhasis Baidya, a sales manager with a car showroom in the city.SpiceJet, in an official statement, blamed the delay on bad weather and inadequate operating crew. The airline referred Flight Duty Time (FDT) Limitations — a stipulation laid down by the Directorate General of Civil Aviation — that prescribes every flying crew member, both in the cockpit and the cabin, to take mandatory off duty after their official schedule, irrespective of whether they fly.“The flight had to return to Kolkata due to bad weather in Bagdogra. As the visibility increased, the operating crew crossed their FDT Limitations for the day. A fresh crew was required to operate the flight. The flight operated at 5.20pm. SpiceJet apologises for the inconvenience caused due to the delay,” said a SpiceJet spokesperson.

Title: 72 students from Bihar to attend ‘Pariksha Pe Charcha’ with PM Modi
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

PM Narendra Modi

PATNA: Altogether 72 students, including 35 girls, from Bihar have been selected to attend the third edition of ‘ Pariksha Pe Charcha 2020’ programme to be addressed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi at Talkatora Stadium in New Delhi on Monday.

Students of Classes IX to XII were selected through short essay competition organized the ministry of human resource department in December 2019 for schools affiliated to the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) and Kendriya Vidyalaya Sangathan. Over 1.3 lakh schoolchildren participated in the competition and 2,000 have been selected to participate in the event.

Of the 72 students from Bihar, 22 are from Patna, followed by seven from Samastipur, six each from Kishanganj and Begusarai, five each from Darbhanga and Muzaffarpur, four in Purnia, three each from Bhojpur and Khagaria, two each from Araria, Vaishali, Munger, Saran and Bhagalpur and one from Nalanda. The selected students have reached Delhi along with 20 schoolteachers.

Vishal, a Class X student of Kendriya Vidyalaya at Kankarbagh in Patna told this newspaper over phone from Delhi that it would be a great opportunity to interact with the PM. “I would get valuable tips from the PM about the board examinations,” the boy, who had written an essay on ‘Balance is beneficial’, said.

Vishruta Sinha, a Class XII student of Kendriya Vidyalaya Bailey Road said the interaction would help build up her confidence. “I would like to ask how to maintain cool during board as well as other competitive exams,” she said.

Among the students from Patna, 15 are from various branches of Kendriya Vidyalaya, three from Open Minds A Birla School and one each from Gyan Niketan, St MG High School, Infant Jesus Academy and New Era High School.

Meanwhile, city schools have made arrangements to show the live telecast of the interaction session in their respective schools for students of Classes IX to XII.

Title: Kolkata: Early-morning fire guts wellness centre in Kankurgachhi building
Content:
The charred interior of the wellness centre; firemen battle the flames on Sunday

Almost the entire first floor has been gutted

The stretcher used to bring down an ailing woman from the second floor of the building and the ambulance sent by the local police station

KOLKATA: A fire at a building in a building at the Kankurgachhi intersection on Sunday morning left residents — mostly senior citizens — panicked and a paralysed woman panting for breath till she was rescued by neighbours. The fire that broke out inside a beauty and wellness centre revived memories of a more devastating one at the same spot 13 months ago.Vinod Bansal, president of the seven-storey Kashi Niket, was in his fourth-floor apartment when he noticed the fire. “Around 8.15am, there was a stench of burning. We had had a horrific time just 13 months ago when a fire inside a commercial area on the first floor leapt till the fifth floor and burnt a portion of our house. That fear forced me to run downstairs to investigate. I found thick smoke billowing from the beauty and wellness centre on the first floor,” Bansal recounted.Security guards had, by that time, alerted the fire brigade and fire tenders soon reached the spot. “The challenge was to evacuate the elderly persons. It being a Sunday morning, many of them were still asleep and we didn’t know who was aware and who wasn’t. Even my kids were asleep,” Bansal added.The biggest concern for the residents was a paralysed woman with her residence just above the seat of fire. “Her husband passed away and her children stay overseas. We decided to bring her down on a foldable, canvas stretcher. We had called up the police station, too, and they sent an ambulance. She was brought down and shifted into the ambulance, but she was feeling breathless by then,” recounted Pinaki Narayan Ganguly, another resident.Ganguly’s parents-in-law stay in the same building and they needed to be shifted out as well.“My mother-in-law is 77 years old and my father-in-law turned 85 some months ago. Me and my son took them up to the terrace. Being a COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) patient myself, I was finding it difficult to breathe. But there was no way I could go out,” Ganguly said. His son Rahul, whose wedding is on Wednesday, kept rushing them out and helped with the general evacuation.While the beauty and wellness centre is closed on Sundays, residents called up two of their staffers, who then rushed to the spot. Firefighters broke the large glass panes to allow the smoke to escape. For the next two hours, five fire tenders kept battling the blaze, which gutted almost the entire commercial space on the first floor.“Primarily, it seemed that the fire originated from a short circuit. We are waiting for the fire brigade to find out what exactly happened. The building does have fire-safety arrangements, like sprinklers, so we need to know how the flames spread inside the commercial space despite that,” Bansal said.

Title: Bihar: Magadh University Students’ Union election on March 6
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

GAYA: The much-delayed Magadh University Students’ Union elections will be held on March 6.

As per the election schedule released by the university, the election process will begin on February 24, the date on which the draft electoral roll is to be published. The draft will be published separately for all 19 constituent colleges and the headquarters-based postgraduate departments.

Objections would be invited against any anomaly in the draft electoral roll on February 25. The same evening, the final electoral roll will be published after disposing off the objections. Nomination papers will be accepted on February 27 between 10 am and 3.00 pm. Scrutiny will be done the same day after the expiry of the nomination period.

Candidates can withdraw their nominations on February 28. Voting and counting of votes will be held on March 6. Voting will end at 3pm and the counting will begin half-an-hour after the polling process ends.

The election schedule has been made only for college and department-level office bearers. Neither the schedule, nor the methodology (direct or indirect) has been released for the election of the central-level (the entire university in which all registered students and research scholars participate) union election.

Asked about the election of the central union comprising all colleges and PG departments, registrar Sidnath Prasad Deen said, “It is for the committee constituted to decide the modalities of election to take a call in the matter.”

A sizeable number of students believe that with nine months of the academic year 2019-20 gone, the union elections have become virtually meaningless and it was no more than a ritual. In any case, only unit level elections are being held. Instead of holding election for only two months, the university must notify a permanent election calendar whereby elections are to be held immediately after the last date of admission, feel majority of the students.

Title: Solar panels atop Patna’s government buildings reduce power bills
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Several government buildings in the city, including divisional commissioner’s office, have cut down energy bill by 70-80% after installation of solar panels last month.

“Solar panels have not just cut down the power bill, but have also set an example to store and consume renewable sources of energy,” said Patna divisional commissioner Sanjay Kumar Agarwal.

He added, “The solar panel atop divisional commissioner’s office is capable of producing 45 kilowatt of electricity. Even though there weren’t many sunny days after the installation of solar panel in mid-December, there has been a major reduction as far as energy bill is concerned. This month’s electricity consumption at the office was 950 units, of which 800 units were covered by solar panels.”

Talking about energy consumption during summer, he said, “Solar panels are sufficient even when the weather is hot and electricity consumption is more due to the use of air conditioners and fans. In fact, we are expecting a 100% reduction in electricity bills in the coming months. Since summer days are sunny, the panel will store more solar energy.”

Aimed at promoting renewable source, altogether 23 government buildings across the city were identified for installation of solar panels. As part of Patna Smart City Limited (PSCL), 10 solar rooftop panels have so far been set up in the city – one each at DM’s residence, divisional commissioner’s office, Indira Gandhi Planetarium, Bihar Rajya Police Parivahan Mukhyalay and Sachchidanand Sinha Library and four at Bankipore Girls’ High School.

PSCL sources said Bihar Renewable Energy Development Agency (BREDA) has already conducted surveys of the remaining locations. “The project, which entails an expenditure of Rs2.45 crore, is targeted to be completed in two-three months,” a PSCL official said.

Altogether 181kW solar panels have started generating electricity at DM’s residence, divisional commissioner’s office and Bankipur Girls’ High School. “While solar rooftop panels on the four buildings of Bankipore Girls’ High School have capacity of 125kW, panels at the divisional commissioner’s office and DM’s office can produce 45kW and 11kW of electricity, respectively,” the official added.

Title: Nepal’s Mahottari district too joins the show
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

A large number of people from neighbouring Nepal formed about 5km-long human chain under the limits of Matihan... Read More

PATNA: The human chain formed on Sunday was not only confined to the state, but also transcended the country’s boundary.

A large number of people from neighbouring Nepal formed about 5km-long human chain under the limits of Matihani Nagar Palika in Mahottari district of the nation. The people led by its mayor Hari Prasad Mandal joined hands with the officials and the residents of the villages close to the Nepal border in Madhubani district to show their solidarity in protecting the environment.

Harlakhi MLA Sushanshu Shekhar, senior ADM Durganand Jha and officers of the local police station played an important role in inspiring the people from neighbouring country to be part of the human chain. Senior ADM Jha said people from Mahottari district in Nepal actively participated in the human chain along with the residents of border district in Bihar . Jha, who is posted in Madhubani, was leading the human chain programme in the district.

The residents from both sides exchanged pleasantries and offered Mithila’s ‘paag’. The personnel of Nepal police, known as ‘prahari’, were also present on the occasion. “This shows our close relations with people of Nepal,” the senior ADM said.

Title: Roads wear festive look as people join hands for noble cause in Bihar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

People braved intense cold and brief spell of rain to participate in the human chain in the district

PATNA: People in large numbers participated in the human chain across the state on Sunday to promote Jal Jeevan Hariyali campaign of the state government and its drive against liquor, dowry and child marriage. Here’s how people in different districts joined the noble initiative:

Bhagalpur: People braved intense cold and brief spell of rain to participate in the human chain in the district. Bhagalpur DM Pranav Kumar, SSP Ashish Bharti and other officials took the lead to form 360km-long human chain on 26 earmarked roads in the district. Though the exact number of people participating in the human chain could not be ascertained, sources said more than five lakh people joined the noble cause. Schoolgirls made ‘rangolis’ on roads and major roundabouts in the town areas. Schoolchildren, social activists, professionals and businessmen were seen actively participating in the programme at different places. Some members from the business community and NGOs distributed chocolates and sweets among the schoolchildren.

Nalanda: More than 12,98,000 people, including schoolchildren, teachers, businessmen, doctors, officials and even homemakers participated in human chain in CM Nitish Kumar’s native district Nalanda. Officials said the rough length of the human chain in the district was 553km. Schoolchildren at different places gave message of Jal Jeevan Haryali by wearing green dresses and drawing beautiful messages on roads and walls throughout the district. Differently-abled people also participated in the human chain enthusiastically.

East Champaran: Around 13 lakh people, including children, elderly people, housewives, students, officials, farmers and daily-wage workers participated in the mega human chain covering at least 650km in East Champaran district. Thousands of girls and boys formed chain on NH-28, NH-28A, state highways and rural roads. School students, especially girls, raised slogans like ‘jal ki barbadi band karo’, “ped lagao and dahej lena dena band karo’.

Begusarai: It was a festival-like atmosphere in Begusarai with people joining the noble initiative in large numbers in the district. The main chain was formed along NH-31 with school students, NCC and NSS volunteers from various colleges and common people joining hands to form the chain. Both sides of 15km stretch between Lakho and Kapasia on the highway saw people joining hands in support of the campaign. Schoolchildren reached their allotted places chanting slogans. The human chain was formed on NH-31, NH-28 and Begusarai-Manjhaul-Rosera state highway. As per a rough estimate, the chain covered 300km in the district.

Sitamarhi: Five lakh people, including women and schoolchildren, members of NGOs, government employees, teachers, businessmen and common people participated in the human chain in Sitamarhi. The chain, the longest so far in the district, covered around 850km from Korlahia to Sonbarsa on NH-77 and Pupri subdivisional town to Dubba Ghat near Sheohar.

Khagaria: In Khagaria district, at least 6,85,000 people from all walks of life, including students of private and government schools, formed a 240km-long chain. Altogether 476 magistrates and police officers were deployed under the supervision of DM Anirudh Kumar and SP Meenu Kumari to make the event a success.

Madhubani: The roads wore a festive look since morning despite not-so-sunny weather conditions. Large number of men, women and children, including school students, Jeevika members and Anganwadi sevikas, started lining up on roads since morning. Madhubani DM Shirsat Kapil Ashok said 1200km-long chain was formed in the district.

Gaya: As per DM Abhishek Singh, at least 20,01,389 people participated in the 516km-long human chain in the district. He said 170km-long chain was formed on the highways and the remaining 346km on other roads. Senior officials, government employees, teachers, students and common people joined the human chain.

Nawada: Thousands of people, including schoolchildren, formed the human chain in the district. Private vehicles were used to bring people to roads from different villages. Nawada DM Kaushal Kumar and a host of officials from all government departments participated in the human chain.

Darbhanga: The human chain was organized successfully in the district with more than 23 lakh people joining hands covering an area of 641km. In an unfortunate incident, one Md Daud (59), teacher of Urdu Middle School-Dighiyar under Keoti block of the district, died due to heart attack. The incident occurred when Daud was on way to take in the event with school students. Officials took him to a nearby hospital, where the doctors declared him brought dead. DM Thyagrajan SM has assured all help to the bereaved family as per rule. He said under the provision of Bihar service code, one dependent of Daud will be provided government job on compassionate ground.

(With inputs from Kumar Rajesh in Bhagalpur, Farrukh Nadim in Nalanda, C B Pandey in East Champaran, Rajiv Kumar in Begusarai, S K Singh in Sitamarhi, N P Thakur in Khagaria, C S Jha ‘Azad’ in Madhubani, Abdul Qadir in Gaya, S B Sinha in Nawada and B K Jha in Darbhanga)

Title: US pharma companies get more FDA ‘warnings’ than Indian firms
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: The Indian pharma industry, which is rapped for poor manufacturing practices globally, seems to be cleaning up its act, at least in relative terms. American drug firms were issued 54 warning letters by the USFDA, while India — which had the distinction of getting most warning letters — stood second with 17 such notices in the year ended September (US financial year). China ranked third with 14 warning letters (see graphic).A company slapped with a warning letter is barred from introducing new products in the US, hindering its ability to increase sales in the world’s top pharmaceutical market. Earlier, emerging economies like either India or China topped the list. In the previous year, the US received 19 warning letters, while China got most at 21, and India had 15.Data integrity issues, which include inappropriate manufacturing practices and overlooking results while testing medicines, continue to dog the drug industry with 32 of 98 warning letters in FY19 citing the issue. In the previous year, 34 of 94 warning letters were due to data integrity lapses, which have a significant impact on drug product quality.Several domestic pharma companies have been hauled up by the US regulator over issues like lax documentation, overlooking test results and unhygienic manufacturing facilities with open toilet drains. Indian companies command around 35% volume share in the highly lucrative US generic market, valued at nearly $70 billion.“Common issues for manufacturing establishments around the world (including the US, India and China) include inadequate or poor quality systems implementation, data integrity issues, inadequate validation of various processes used in manufacturing or testing, and product contamination. In any region, some drug manufacturers meet US requirements, while others do not. When we determine that there are significant violations at a manufacturing establishment, we take appropriate action to protect the public health,” a USFDA official told TOI.The official added, “It is important to note that the number of annual inspections in any region or country may fluctuate year-to-year because some inspections occur on a routine basis, while others take place when the FDA is reviewing specific product marketing applications, or when the agency receives information about potential product manufacturing or quality problems.”In 2019, major companies — including Lupin , Torrent, Aurobindo , Strides Pharma, Cadila Healthcare, Indoco Remedies, Glenmark , Jubilant Life Sciences and Emcure Pharma — were issued warning letters for significant violations of current good manufacturing practice (CGMP) regulations. Typically, the action follows inspections and audits carried out by the US regulator.PwC India leader (pharmaceutical & life sciences) Sujay Shetty said, “Data shows the phenomena of warning letters spread across many countries, and not just unique to India. Indian companies hog the limelight, though they may have got lower number of letters (in other years). Also, the data speaks volumes about domestic companies investing effort and resources in upgrading quality systems in their facilities.”Commenting on USFDA audits, Sun Pharma managing director Dilip Shanghvi had said in a recent investor call, “Indian companies file large number of products, and as a part of their assurance to the US Congress, the USFDA has said that they will try and conduct as many pre-approval inspections as necessary. If we continue to be the largest filer of new ANDAs in the world, we will have a large number of inspections. As regulators see any kind of a risk in one inspection, they add as part of the inspection plan for future audits. Accordingly, the focus of USFDA inspections will continuously change, and it will help improve the quality of products for safety of patients.”

Title: Bihar: BERC chief exhorts SBPDCL to prevent power leakages
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

GAYA: Bihar Electricity Regulatory Commission ( BERC ) chairman SK Negi on Saturday exhorted officials of the South Bihar Power Distribution Company Limited (SBPDCL) to prevent leakages and avoid unnecessary burden on consumers.

The BERC chairman was interacting with stakeholders on the issue of tariff-hike proposed by the distribution company. Negi directed the power distribution company to open more counters and introduce innovative tariff collection mechanism. “Number of bill collection counters was insufficient,” the chairman said.

Tariff, according to DK Jain, former president of the Central Bihar Chamber of Commerce (CBCC) was already very high. “The distribution companies (discoms) cannot be allowed to penalise the genuine users for its own inefficiency and management deficit,” said Jain.

During the interaction, Vidyut Upbhokta Sangharsh Samiti opposed the move to put extra burden on power users on the basis of imaginary loss. A three-page representation submitted by the Sangharsh Samiti to the BERC chairman stated that the number of power consumers has gone up and as such the company was enjoying economy of scale.

Referring to the claims of discoms that distribution loss has come down, the Sangharsh Samiti alleged that demand for tariff hike contradicted their own claims. Instead of demanding direct hike in energy charges, the company has sought hike in fixed charges, thereby resorting to psychological one-upmanship.

The representation said that power tariff was much less in Delhi and some other states as compared to south Bihar and as such a downward revision was required. Delhi model must be implemented in Bihar. Proposed hike in meter rent has also been opposed by the Gaya power users.

Power distribution in Gaya, it may be recalled was outsourced to India Power, a private company, which was, in 2014 awarded franchise for 15 years. The franchise was cancelled four years later in 2018.

Title: Patna district tops with 27.8 lakh participation in human chain
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

NCC students make a long human chain in Support of Jal-Jivan-Hariyali movement against climate crisis,prohibit... Read More

PATNA: Braving chilling cold and inclement weather, thousands of people joined hands in Patna district on Sunday to give a message on the need to protect environment and fight against the social evils of dowry and child marriage . According to chief secretary Deepak Kumar, the maximum 27.87 lakh people joined human chain in Patna among the 38 districts in the state.

People from all age groups and sections of the society got up early in the morning and headed to the streets as early as 9am despite overcast sky and cold. Schoolchildren were seen playing drums at the entrance of chief minister’s 1, Aney Marg residence, while others were seen walking on the streets in groups with placards and slogans to raise awareness on environment conservation. As scheduled, people reached their designated spots across the district to be a part of the human chain formed across the state.

Vehicles mainly kept off the roads as the district administration had restricted vehicular traffic on several routes from 9.30am to 1pm. Those who preferred to stay indoors remained glued to TV screens at homes for getting updates on the human chain formation, the biggest for a social cause across the world, as claimed by the state government.

Rikki Renum, a second semester BBA student, praised the government’s step. “Water is wasted a lot in our society. It’s important to save it in order to save the country’s future,” she said. The student with a poster giving message to save water had formed a small human chain of her colleagues near Ashiana Mor.

Few motorists, however, complained of facing inconvenience due to traffic restrictions even though district administration and city police had made prior announcement about it.

Arun Kumar, who was going to Khagaul on a bike from Boring Road, said the government must take steps to address other major problems like unemployment. “There is no question that the human chain formation is a great initiative by the state government to make people aware about nature before time runs out, but there are some other important issues which must be addressed by the government,” he said.

While Arun lamented hassles in vehicular movement, several senior citizens lauded the district administration for better arrangements on the roads from safety point of view, due to which they joined the human chain in Khagaul and Danapur. While a long human chain was made all along the 5km-long Khagaul-Danapur road, another chain was formed right from Danapur railway station to Bihta through Neora and Sadisopur along the railway lines.

Title: 6 opposition legislators join human chain
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Human chain along with thousands of supporters

PATNA: Six legislators of opposition Grand Alliance participated in the Nitish government-sponsored human chain , triggering speculations about their possible change of loyalty before the state assembly election due in October-November.

Five of them are MLAs while the sixth is RJD MLC Sanjay Prasad, who was elected from Munger local bodies constituency. Prasad’s six-year term is to expire in July 2021. The five MLAs who participated in the human chain are RJD’s Maheshwar Prasad Yadav from Gaighat, Faraz Fatmi from Keoti, Prema Chaurasia from Patepur, Congress’s Purnima Yadav from Gobindpur in Nawada and Sanjay Kumar Tiwari alias Munna Tiwari from Buxar.

They participated in the human chain along with hundreds of their supporters. While Purnima joined the human chain along with her husband and JD(U) MLA Kaushal Yadav on the Patna-Ranchi national highway at Budhaul in Nawada, Sanjay Prasad took part in the event at Chakai in Jamui district.

Prema told TOI that she along with her supporters joined the human chain near Paswan Chowk at Hajipur while Sanjay Tiwari said he joined the chain at Jyoti Chowk in Buxar town. “I joined the human chain along with thousands of supporters at Gaighat,” Maheshwar told TOI over phone.

Similarly, Faraz joined the human chain at Karpoori Chowk near DMCH in Darbhanga town along with his father and former Union minister MAA Fatmi. Senior Fatmi is now a JD(U) leader.

Reacting over it, RJD spokesperson Chitranjan Gagan said, “The party has taken note of such MLAs, who took part in the human chain despite top RJD leaders like Lalu Prasad, Rabri Devi and Tejashwi Prasad Yadav regularly criticizing the event as misuse of public money.”

To a question, Prema said it was for a noble cause. “If I am in opposition, it does not mean that I should oppose even good works of the government. Moreover, the RJD had not issued any specific instructions to the MLAs not to join the state government-sponsored programme,” she said.

Tiwari also said Congress had not issued any instruction on the issue. “I joined the human chain after several intellectuals of my town approached me for the same. Being an MLA, how can I ignore the request of local people and that, too, for a good cause?” Tiwari said.

Title: 9 lakh Patna students, teachers take part in human chain
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Human chain to support Jal Jivan Hariyali movement (PTI Photo)

PATNA: At least nine lakh students and teachers from different schools and colleges, government employees, staff of private firms and even transgender participated in the human chain in Patna district on Sunday to promote the state government’s Jal Jeevan Hariyali mission and its drive against liquor, dowry and child marriage, DM Kumar Ravi said.

“Over 20.89 lakh people, including 2.6 lakh schoolchildren, participated in the human chain in Patna district alone,” the DM added. Six school bands performed at Gandhi Maidan and near Raj Bhavan during the human chain formation.

While student band members from Notre Dame Academy, Scholar’s Abode School and Pleasant Valley School performed near Raj Bhavan, the ones of Krishna Niketan, Muslim High School and Dhaneshwary Kanya Uchh Vidyalaya-Danapur performed at Gandhi Maidan.

Students in the age group of 13 to 25 years were seen holding placards with messages like ‘stop violence against women’, ‘beti padhao beti bachao’, ‘say no to liquor’, ‘Swachch Bharat’, ‘road safety’ and ‘save the trees, save the Earth’. Attractive posters and graphics were also on display.

Students also made wall paintings, rangolis and hung posters on the premises of their schools, calling for eradication of social evils and protection of environment. Some schools and colleges organised cultural events and competitions for students. School and college principals, teachers, non-teaching staff and even parents of the students participated in human chain.

At Kurji, Digha and Patliputra areas, students of Notre Dame Academy, St Michael’s High School, DAV Public School, Loyola High School, International School (ICSE and CBSE), Don Bosco Academy, May Flower, St Xavier’s College of Education and St Xavier’s College of Management and Technology joined the chain.

Students of St Joseph’s Convent High School, Bankipore Girl’s School, St Xavier’s School, Christ Church Diocesan School, Magadh Mahila College, B N College and Collegiate, NIT-Patna, Patna College and Patna Science College formed chain from Ashok Rajpath to Gandhi Maidan. St Xavier’s College’s Theatre Club staged a street corner play aimed at creating awareness against unchecked wastage of water, deforestation and on hazards of climate change.

Large number of students from Carmel High School, Baldwin Academy, St Karen’s High School, Gyan Niketan (Boys and Girls), Radiant International School, Open Minds A Birla School, Kendriya Vidyalayas, DAV BSEB, Patna Women’s College, J D Women’s College, L N Mishra Institute and A N College formed chain on Bailey Road.

Students of Dr D Y Patil Pushpalata Patil International School joined the chain wearing green saris. Some students of Bishop Scott and Shri Ram Centennial School dressed up as trees and spread awareness on environment.

Chairman of Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) Ashok Ghosh and a group of scientists formed the chain near Patliputra. Officials of BUIDCO, BREDA, BIA, BEA, BSRTC, Bihar State Women Commission and SDMA also participated in the human chain.

Title: NRC-CAA is black law for the country: Bhim Army chief Chandrasehekhar Azad
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad

MEERUT: “It is clear that the intention of the government - in the backdrop of the deaths that occurred in the violence of December 20 in the entire country - was wrong. The National Register for Citizens (NRC) and Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) are black law of the country. This law will hamper the unity and secularism of the country. The government should immediately withdraw the law,” said Bhim Army chief Chandrashekhar Azad .

Azad was in Meerut to meet the families of the deceased in the December 20 violence in the district. Please refused him to meet the families of the deceased and there and hence we had to meet them at another place in the district. He met the family at city is Hira Garden her.

“What happened in Meerut on December 20 was extremely horrific. According to what the families have told me here, it is clear that Hitler rule is on in the district. Most of those killed in the December 20 violence had got police gunshots. We have approach the high court in the matter for relief and the case will be heard on December 23. An investigation should be set up against the accused police personnel,” said Azad.

Azad further said that we live in a democracy and in a democracy everybody has a right to say what they believe in. “Nobody can be shot in the head in the name of democracy. The situation of UP was not such even at the time of Babri demolition and at the time when section 370 was scrapped,” said Azad.

Azad further tweeted from his account that he was not allowed to go to Meerut and hence he had to meet the families of the deceased outside only. Meanwhile, the legal team of Bhim Army will support the deceased, he said in his tweet.

Title: Surat: Infant dumped in dustbin was child of girl raped by minor brother
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

Title: FIR lodged in case of controversial hoarding on CAA
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Varanasi: Sigra police lodged an FIR against unidentified person after a controversial hoarding came up at Englishiya Line crossing near Varanasi railway station on Saturday.

The hoarding read, ‘Hindu dharm mein ghar vapasi karo... CAA, NRC se chhutkara pao (Get rid of CAA, NRC by returning to Hindu religion).’

Inspector Ashutosh Ojha on Sunday said an FIR under section 295A and 505 of IPC was lodged against unidentified persons on Saturday late night in this connection. Investigation has been launched in the case and those involved in putting up the hoarding would be identified soon, he added.

A lesser known outfit, Hindu Samaj Party, had placed the hoarding on the busy road.

Interestingly, the state vice president of the outfit Roshan Pandey had made a video viral on social media with his message in which he mentioned to have put up the hoarding. In his video, Pandey mentioned that he has put the hoarding in response to the protest being staged at Shaheen Bagh in New Delhi.

The hoarding, which also had photographs of some Muslim women wearing saffron pagdi, was removed by Sigra police on Saturday late evening.

The hoarding had come up in the city at a time when chief minister Yogi Adityanath, Union minister Smriti Irani and other leaders were here to address a rally in support of CAA at Sampurnanad Sanskrit University.

Pandey, along with his supporters, had also tried to stage a sit-in at Lanka to give a call for marching to Shaheen Bagh in Delhi on Saturday evening, when the Lanka police stopped them. They were taken in custody and were later released following initial interrogation, said inspector Lanka Bharat Bhushan.

Title: 64-year-old man succumbs to injuries
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Surat: A 64-year-old man succumbed to his injuries at a private hospital here on Sunday. The man had lost control over his motorcycle while trying to avoid a kite manja dangling over road near Mora Bhagal in Rander on January 7.

Jayanti Morkar, a resident of Palnpur Jakatnaka, had suffered multiple injuries in the accident. Morkar was going to Mora Bhagal market from his house on his motorcycle when the kite manja came in front of him. He lost control over the motorcycle and crashed into a road divider.

He was shifted to a hospital in a critical condition where he died during treatment. His family decided to keep the body in morgue since there was a marriage of a kin. The body will be cremated on Monday, a family member informed police.

Title: Truck rams into SoU board, ticket cabin
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Bharuch/Surat: A truck rammed into an information board near Statue of Unity and then into an iron grill and a pole installed for WiFi connectivity besides a counter for tickets in a parking lot near the flower of valley on Saturday afternoon. Hasti S Vora, an employee of SOU, Kevadia colony lodged a complaint against the driver of truck no. GJ 18- AX 8360 for irresponsible and reckless driving leading to damage of various infrastructure worth Rs 1.25 lakh. The errant driver however fled the spot. Kevadia colony police is investigating the case.

Title: 12 newborns were found abandoned in city last year
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Surat: In 2019 , altogether 12 abandoned infants were treated at two government hospitals in the city while the first month in the new year already saw three infants abandoned.

Of all the 15 abandoned infants, 11 are girls while four are boys, stated New Civil Hospital and Surat Municipal Institute of Medical Education and Research (SMIMER) records. Of those treated, 10 were provided treatment at the NCH while five were treated at SMIMER.

The figure includes infants found both dead and alive in the city.

In the current month alone, two male and one girl child were found abandoned in the city from different places like bushes, riverbank and dustbin. Majority of these infants were rescued by paramedics of 108 ambulance after being alerted by locals.

“The first callers play a major role in the rescue operation and prove themselves to be the biggest factor in the infants’ survival. On reaching, we provide emergency treatment on the spot to the infant after examining its condition and later shift them to the hospital,” said Faiyaz Pathan, programme manager of 108 ambulance service.

Doctors at the government hospitals inform that majority of the abandoned infants are admitted in critical condition and their initial care plays a crucial role in their chances of survival. These infants are admitted to Neonatal Intensive Care Unit and in some cases they are put on ventilator as well.

Title: 36-hour long Police Hackathon concludes
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: The Hyderabad police, along with the Telangana Innovation Ecosystem concluded the 36-hour long Police Hackathon at the Kotla Vijaya Bhaskar Reddy Indoor Stadium in Yousufguda on Sunday.

Theevent saw a turnout of 99 teams, out of which 31 teams were led by the girls. The teams included students from engineering colleges, employees at start-ups and other companies across the city.

The participants were tasked with developing applications and solutions using emerging technologies like Artificial Intelligence, machine learning and data analytics.

Project-D, the winning team, built a hardware prototype for curbing sound pollution. The team comprised four students from MJCET, who utilised machine learning to curb vehicular pollution.

The first runner-up prize was given to ‘Life of a Girl’, an app designed by students of IIIT Hyderabad. The app aims to prevent crime towards women and children.

“Four teams were short-listed for semi-finals. Among those, one team who came up with an innovative solution to prevent noise pollution was declared the winner. The teams had utilised machine learning, IoT (Internet of Things), Artificial Intelligence (AI) and sensors to find innovative solutions to address the problems,” said Jayesh Ranjan, Telangana IT Principal Secretary.

The winning team was awarded a cash prize of Rs 1 lakh and three runner-ups were awarded cash prizes of Rs 20,000 to develop and refine their ideas. The top 30 teams’ ideas selected as part of the hackathon will be given 6 months of mentorship support by the Hyderabad Police and WE HUB.

Anjani Kumar, Commissioner of Police, Shikha Goel, additional CP, crimes and other senior police officers were also present at the event.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: 14-year-old girl raped, accused arrested
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representational Image

Title: Enactment of Jamia, AMU police action leads to anxious moments
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

ddddd

Allahabad: A group of protesters with bandages on their forehead, bleeding nose and fractured hands, while holding placards against CAA and NRC in their hands, led to some anxious moments and confusion during the ongoing agitation against citizenship law at Mansoor Ali park in Roshan Bagh area on Sunday.

While the crowd at protest site initially believed that the protesters were really injured, the organisers later clarified they were enacting alleged police atrocities at Jamia Millia Islamia, Aligarh Muslim University and in Assam.

The group of youths was the centre of attraction since Sunday morning.

As they stood in front of the crowd, people addressing protestors kept pointing at them while narrating alleged police atrocities in Assam, AMU and Jamia Millia Islamia giving impression that they had been subjected to violence. Many people recorded videos, clicked pictures and shared it on social media.

However, later in the day, organisers announced that they were only enacting the Jamia and AMU incidents and none of them was really injured.

As the news spread, police received information about the development.

Cops told organisers that the enactment could create confusion and disturb peaceful atmosphere of the city.

Later, organisers asked the youths to remove their bandages. It was then that common protestors realised that they were not really injured.

“I was surprised to see that this was only an enactment and they were not injured for real”, said a volunteer at the dharna site.

General secretary of Congress (Allahabad unit) Irshad Ulla said, “This is a democracy and everyone is free to choose the way he or she wants to protest. The protesters wanted to inform people what happened at other places. It was their style of communicating.”

Meanwhile, women protestors from nearby localities took out a procession and reached the park. Holding placards against CAA and NRC, they shouted anti-government slogans.

SSP, Allahabad, Satyarth Aniruddha Pankaj said, “Peaceful protests are acceptable but organisers should not instigate people and test the patience of disciplined police force. Action will be taken if law and order is disturbed.”

Title: ‘Border fencing a hurdle for wild ass’
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The report said that wild asses would move across the international border in the past

AHMEDABAD: The International Union For Conservation of Nature has red-flagged the India-Pakistan border fencing, as a threat to the Asiatic wild ass population in the state. The ICUN report states that the fencing is preventing the wild ass from crossing over, which is part of its normal behaviour.

The IUCN Red List report, on the Asiatic wild ass, noted that “the International Boundary with Pakistan has been fenced thus restricting the possibility of wild ass movement beyond borders.”

The report said that wild asses would move across the international border in the past, adding that the wild ass population that was thriving in Pakistan in the late 1990’s, is now under a cloud as there have been no recent reports of its presence in Pakistan.

A senior officer said that in early the 2000’s there were reports of wild ass crossing to Pakistan from Gujarat and vice versa and the border in Banaskantha was a corridor.

In reply to a question by Anand MP Devusinh Chauhan, Union minister of state for home Kiren Rijiju stated that 60km of the fencing on the Gujarat-Pakistan border was incomplete and Gujarat and Pakistan share a 508km border, of which fencing is possible only on 340km.

Rijiju had said that the remaining 60km of fencing would be complete by March 2020.

Among other threats the wild ass faces in the Little Rann of Kutch, stem from increasing human activities. Land use patterns have changed since the Narmada Dam Project which resulted in the Sardar Sarovar canals all around the protected area. Uninformed release of Sardar Sarovar canal excess waters into the Rann is affecting the micro-habitat, the short grasslands, and is restricting the movement of wild ass and other species across the saline desert.

The IUCN also reported that the great India bustard also crosses over to Pakistan from Gujarat and Rajasthan, and raised alarm about their poaching in Pakistan, saying that it could lead to the extinction of the species in western India.

The Red List report for 2017 states, “Current levels of hunting may result in the extinction of even the largest western Indian population in the next 15-20 years.”

Title: Minor goes to meet Facebook friend, gang-raped by four at gunpoint in Amroha

This story is from January 20, 2020
