Title: Death of radio-collared tigress due to lack of monitoring, say wildlife activists
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: The death of E4, around 3-year-old radio-collared tigress in Chatgaon under Gadchiroli division, has refreshed memories of Jai , a dominant tiger which went missing from Umred-Paoni-Karhandla wildlife sanctuary due to lack of monitoring in April 2016.

This is the sixth radio-collared tiger which has died in Eastern Vidarbha Landscape (EVL) and third in Gadchiroli in the last three years. These tigers were collared by Wildlife Institute of India (WII), Dehradun, under the EVL project.

E4’s death has stirred up a debate on social media by wildlife activists and lovers who blamed WII and forest department for lack of monitoring.

The decomposed carcass of E4 was found in Chatgaon range under Gadchiroli forest division on Saturday. E4, which was radio-collared on March 1, 2019, was among the three sub-adult cubs of T49 tigress from Ekara Bhuj in Bramhapuri .

According to veterinarians doing the post-mortem, the carcass seemed to be over 20 days old. This indicates no monitoring was done for E4. Gadchiroli officials admit that they didn’t know about presence of tigress in their area.

Bramhapuri officials it seems did not coordinate with Gadchiroli officials.

“We have issued show cause to round officer and forest guard for negligence. The collar has been sent to WII,” said Gadchiroli deputy conservator SR Kumaraswamy.

Forest department uses data from radio-collars to know the dispersal routes, tiger behaviour, predation, population and ecology. According to WII scientist Bilal Habib, last GPS location of E4 was received on July 17, 2019, from Mendki. After that E4 was actively ground monitored through very high frequency (VHF) antenna. The last VHF was observed on September 27, 2019, at 4.15pm in FDCM area of Bramhapuri.

“We lost track of E4 after September 27. WII team tried to track the tigress every 15 days at strategic locations in Wadsa and Gadchiroli but to no avail. The distance between E4’s last location and the spot where carcass was found is 42km. More details will be available after retrieving data from the collar,” said Habib.

“Repeated appeals have bee made to streamline patrolling and wildlife monitoring system but it appears wildlife management has its own agenda. If radio-collared tigers can’t be monitored then the future is bleak,” said RR Sahay, former APCCF.

According to animal ecologist Abi T Vanak, just because it was collared doesn’t mean tigers won’t die. “We need to concentrate on keeping breeding populations safe. Collars also allow us to determine that tigers have died,” he said.

For wildlife conservationist Udayan Patil, death of E4 means loss of at least 15 tigers since it was a young breeding tigress. “It is not about an individual dying. It’s all about negligence. Doubts on collaring have been raised as such episodes have happened many times. Take for example Jai, Srinivas and other three released tigers after fitting collars. The data of Jai’s collar has still not been made public, not even under RTI,” he said.

“If a collared tiger is not tracked for so long, it means lack of monitoring and carelessness. There is no need to waste money on collars in absence of proper protection and tracking plan,” said conservationist Prafulla Bhamburkar.

Sarosh Lodhi of Conservation Lenses & Wildlife (CLaW) is of the view that when WII and forest department take credit for a radio-collared tiger travelling 1,700km, they should also accept the failures of such tigers dying due to “sheer negligence”.

According to honorary wildlife warden Vivek Karambelkar, two months ago a cattle kill was reported from the area where the carcass was found. “Neither camera traps were installed nor the area was scanned. There is dire need of capacity building of foresters in Gadchiroli,” he said.

Tiger poacher flees from custody

Yashwant Bobhate, 50, one of the main accused in poaching of a tiger on January 11 in Mudjha village in South Bramhapuri, escaped from forest custody on Friday. The news was kept under wraps by forest officials. Bobhate was under FCR till January 20. The accused jumped custody when he was taken for a medical examination. Deputy conservator Kulraj Singh said, “Police and forest teams have launched search operation for the accused.”

Title: Bhyrappa for lit exchange between Maharashtra and Karnataka
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kannada writer SL Bhyrappa (left) and veteran actor Mohan Aghashe

PUNE: Kannada writer SL Bhyrappa on Sunday said Pune was the cultural capital of Maharashtra and people of the city should indulge in exchange of literature.

A renowned literary critic and theatre personality, Bhyrappa was in the city to attend a ceremony organized by the Karnataka government, in association with the Kannada Sangha, Pune, to felicitate him at the Shakuntala J Shetty auditorium at Erandwane.

Addressing the audience, the Padma Shri awardee writer said, “Pune is the cultural capital of Maharashtra. One should learn the best from the Maharashtrian community and give them the best of Kannada. This would help in translation of more Marathi work to Kannada, and vice versa.”

He said, “My work has been translated to many languages, but the kind of love I’ve got from Maharashtra is unparalleled. The most interesting part is that though I have readers across all languages, the Marathi people have been the most critical. They do a critical reading of my work, which I appreciate as these are intelligent readers in Marathi.”

Hailing the warrior king Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj , Bhyrappa said, “Historically speaking, when Indian culture was being weakened, it was Shivaji who had first gathered strength and fought off the enemies. This inspired a lot of people to follow suit, particularly in the country’s southern part. This warrior spirit is intrinsic to Maharashtrian people and carried forward to whatever field they work in.”

He said three-fourths of the Indian freedom struggle was fought in Maharashtra. “All this reflect the warrior spirit of Mahrashtrians. This quality I admire the most and it is even reflected in the politics here.”

Veteran actor Mohan Aghashe, translator Uma Kulkarni and theatre personality BV Rajaram, among others, were present at the event.

Citing an experience from his film ‘Astu’, Agashe said, “Two major characters in the film are from the border and speak Kannada. One of the Kannada lullabies in the movie became popular in both states. I think art, literature, theatre and films are an integrating factor for all of us. Politicians may try to differentiate us, but we will stand united.”

Title: Gujarat CM Vijay Rupani Vijay Rupani kicks off pulse polio drive
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijay Rupani

Ahmedabad: Chief minister Vijay Rupani kicked off the monthlong polio immunization drive in Gandhinagar on Sunday. About 80 lakh children up to the age of five will be administered immunization doses by over 1.53 lakh health workers.

The CM said that there has not been a single case of polio in Gujarat since 2007 due to the government’s sustained and intensive drive to ensure immunization of all children under the age of five,

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Hit by tractor, farmer slips into cane belt, crushed
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose

BAREILLY: In a freak accident, a 47–year-old farmer was allegedly crushed in a sugar mill in Rajpura area of Sambhal district recently when he accidentally fell into the cane belt.

The victim was identified as Chiranji Lal, a resident of Dharmpur Tappa village in Budaun.

According to sources, the accident occurred on January 9, but the matter came to light only on Saturday when Lal’s son Lalaram approached police. Based on his complaint, police have registered a case against unidentified persons of the mill management under section 304A (causing death by negligence) of IPC.

According to Lalaram, he and his father had brought cane in a tractor trolley to the sugar mill on January 9 when the incident happened. After weighing the loaded cane, Lalaram started waiting in the queue while his father was standing near the cane belt.

Lalaram said that when he came back after unloading cane, he couldn’t find his father there. Meanwhile, other farmers present there grew suspicious that Lal had slipped into the cane belt. When they examined the CCTV footage, they found that he fell into the belt after a tractor had hit him. As more cane buried him before he could escape, the belt pushed him towards the crushers, he added.

Rajpura station house officer Amit Kumar said, “We have examined the CCTV footage. It appears that the farmer accidently fell into the cane belt.”

Meanwhile, mill management official Randheer Singh said that they have set up an inquiry to investigate how the farmer reached the cane belt. “We are examining the matter and strict action will be taken against the negligent official concerned,” he added.

Title: Braving morning chill, thousands in Kharadi play, paint, cycle and dance the Zumba
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kids and elders dance at Happy Streets in Kharadi on Sunday

PUNE: The morning was chilly and misty, but that was barely a deterrent for enthusiasm, as over 3,000 people joined the season’s first Happy Streets in Kharadi.

One flank of the South Main Road in Kharadi, which leads towards the EON IT park, was appropriated for Sunday’s Happy Street. As the winter sun filtered through on Sunday morning, people trickled in from nearby and far away places.

“I love the Happy Streets concept. It was held once near my house, and my family and I thoroughly enjoyed it. It is great to have an uninterrupted stretch of road to just walk, cycle or relax with all the activities lined-up,” said Ishika Ghosh, who drove to Kharadi with her son from Kalyaninagar.

A particular point of interest was the SWaCH outreach stall, where the organization collected old and used clothes, toys, shoes, e-waste and other items to recycle and reuse. SWaCH representatives also explained the collection-to-recycling chain to the attendees. Some visitors even arrived with bags of cloth or e-waste.

“A number of people delivered bags of recyclable waste, like their old clothes and shoes, and even their old electronic gadgets. We told them about our organization and our waste-collectors’ network across the city. We also told them about our new collection points,” said Vishal Devaki, a member of SWaCH collective, helping out in the outreach initiative at the stall.

A selfie and photo frames and an instant photo booth, set up a little further down the road by Nyati, were another big hit. Several attendees lined up to click photographs with their loved one and save the memories they created during the fun filled day. The wide traffic-free boulevard was a boon for pets and people alike.

Only traffic on the stretch were people on skateboards, roller-skates and bicycles. Some of them were brought by the attendees themselves, while others were hired on rent for free.

Besides the bicycles, children had a field day on the street, with everything from hula hoops to a life-size game of snakes-and-ladders. Children also had an opportunity to paint the streets with coloured chalks.

Meanwhile, energy reverberated off the main stage as Zumba and dance instructors took participants through a fun dance-and-exercise routine. Children, adolescents and their parents lined up in front of the stage to shake a leg to the routine for a while — a blend of Western dance to Indian-inspired forms, with some elements of Arabic belly-dancing— before heading down the street. “I loved the Zumba. It was an amazing routine. That was the first time I tried belly-dancing. It wasn’t easy, but it was fun,” said Swati Goyal, a local resident.

Happy Streets is an initiative of The Times of India, in association with the Pune police and Pune Municipal Corporation , powered by Nyati Group.

Title: MHRD asks AU to name members for search panel
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Allahabad: Ministry of human resource development ( MHRD ) has asked the Allahabad University authorities to nominate two members from the executive council (EC) to constitute a search committee for the appointment of a regular vice-chancellor of the university.

AU will soon publish an advertisement for the post and a three-member committee will select the candidate. The appointment will be approved by the President, who is also the Visitor of the central university.

As per practice, HRD ministry instructs the university concerned to nominate two members of the EC and send the names to the ministry.

Another member is added to the search committee which is nominated by the Visitor (President) and is called as Visitor’s nominee. This team of three members scrutinizes the candidature of applicants applying for the post of VC.

After interaction with applicants, the panel forwards the names of 3-5 shortlisted candidates to the Visitor who takes a final decision.

Now, that the HRD ministry has asked the university to nominate two members from the executive council, it is likely that AU will call a meeting of the council next week and decide the members who will be nominated to the search committee. Officiating VC Prof RR Tewari will decide the date of EC’s meeting and will preside over it.

Confirming the development, AU Registrar Prof NK Shukla said, “HRD ministry has asked us to send the names of two persons who will be nominated as members of the search committee. We will call a meeting of EC in coming days.” He added that the university would soon come out with the advertisement for the post of VC. “About a month’s time will be given to applicants to apply for the post after which the work of search committee will begin,” he said.

The post had fallen vacant after former vice-chancellor Ratan Lal Hangloo tendered his resignation on January 1 following allegations of corruption. He was under scanner over alleged financial and administrative irregularities.

He was facing charges of irregularities since 2016 and was also summoned by the National Commission for Women (NCW) over allegations of improper handling of sexual harassment complaints and lack of a grievance redressal mechanism for female students.

Title: Kolkata: PCR vans make cop response to crisis call 10 minutes faster
Content:
Kolkata Police has managed to bring down its response time to a crisis call to 10 minutes on an average

TimesView Something like this can be a huge psychological safety boost for citizens and act as a long-term deterrent against crime. There are logistical problems but it would be great if this can be replicated across the city.

KOLKATA: Kolkata Police has managed to bring down its response time to a crisis call to 10 minutes on an average, thanks to the 82 patrol vehicles staying on roads for 24 hours for 70-odd police stations across the city.In addition, patrolling by multiple bikes and local vehicles enables the police to press over 300 two-wheelers and four-wheelers into action to respond to the SOS received from various parts of the city. The sudden rise in both visibility and effective intervention by the police to a crisis is being attributed to the Police Control Room (PCR) vans introduced in the city last year.“The new PCR vans introduced in December are already making a difference. The vans are not only responding to crisis calls but also their GPS tracking and live feedback systems help both the Lalbazar central control and the divisional control room take the needed steps. As cops know that PCR vans are around in the city, they are responding quickly to such calls. There are 27 PCR vans on duty at any point of the day while total 60 vehicles are requisitioned for the purpose,” said a police officer.The PCR vans patrol the city in three shifts. Cops send back a vehicle to its base only when another vehicle arrives. Each division is allotted three PCR vans while divisional DCPs deploy the vehicles and assign their patrolling areas. If any van gets stuck somewhere, the control rooms get to know about it immediately with the help of the GPS, added the officer.Special Shakti jeeps for women cops, quick response teams, HRFS and RFS, vehicles of OCs and 10 bikes also patrol the city daily. The number of these vehicles goes up at night.The police at Lalbazar are strengthening their women Scooty patrol teams, the number of which is likely to increase to 33 from the existing 23. With the wireless section of Kolkata Police releasing maximum vehicles from various divisions, each police station is expected to have at least two motorbikes and two four-wheelers for effective patrolling. Cops said they are planning to respond in three minutes to calls from women in distress.

Title: Heart transplant hope for 21 at SMS hosp
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Jaipur: The first heart transplant at Sawai Man Singh ( SMS ) Hospital on Thursday has come as a ray of hope for 21 patients who have applied for it and awaiting for their turn to get a new lease of life.

The cardiologists have listed these patients as candidates requiring heart transplant that their heart is functioning below 20% of the capacity.

On Thursday, hospital doctors had retrieved a heart from a 25-year-old braid dead person and transplanted it into a 17-year-old patient suffering from heart failure. “The recovery of the heart recipient is satisfactory,” said Dr Anil Sharma, head of the department (cardiothoracic surgery).

Jaipur has become a prominent centre in the country for heart transplants as three hospitals — two private and a government — have already performed five heart transplants in the past four years.

According to the State Organ & Tissue Transplant Organisation (SOTTO), the waiting list of patients requiring organs transplant in web registry of Rajasthan Network for Organ Sharing (RNOS) are as follows: 320 patients for kidney transplant, 43 liver transplant and 21 heart transplant.

With increasing need of patients suffering from chronic kidney, liver and heart diseases, SMS Medical College has started preparations for expanding its facilities for organ transplant. While giving organ donation a major impetus, the hospital is constructing a multi-storey building near its Institute of Traumatology and Orthopedics (ITO) wing and a Centre for Excellence for Organ Transplant at one of the floors of the hospital building.

Title: Minor detained for raping 5-year-old girl

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Cops stop anti-CAA protesters in Shahjahanpur
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

SHAHJAHANPUR: Police on Sunday thwarted attempts of Congress and social organizations to assemble a gathering in order to stage an anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protest without taking permission of the district administration by preventing most of the protesters from reaching Shaheed Park here on Sunday.

Police took proactive measures by barricading sensitive spots to prevent protesters from outside the district from entering the city. The curbs were in place on Saturday itself, with police checking vehicles at sensitive spots. Hotel owners were asked to provide information about “suspicious” guests on their premises. A heavy force was deployed to patrol railway stations and bus stands.

In-charge of local intelligence unit CB Singh and his team made sure that all the sensitive information was gathered and shared with senior officials to tackle any untoward situation, if any.

As a result of the strict vigilance, only 250 protesters, mostly Congress workers, gathered outside Shaheed Park, which is almost opposite the party office, and shouted anti-CAA slogans.

Meanwhile, Tasneem Ali Khan, outgoing president of the Congress city unit who had planned to lead the protest, told TOI, “It was a protest called for the people of India against CAA. People of every community supported us. We were expecting nearly 10,000 people but police barricaded most of the entrance points. We wanted to take out a peaceful march from Shaheed Park to Clock Tower but police did not give us permission, citing that section 144 of the CrPC is imposed in the district. However, BJP, led by state minister and local MLA Suresh Khanna, was granted permission to take out a march in favour of CAA. We were discriminated. We are ready to face any action because we know that we didn’t do any wrong.”

Additional SP (City) Dinesh Tripathi said, “We ensured that peace was maintained during the protest and several protesters changed their mind after we informed them that the district administration had not granted permission for the protest. We are identifying people who joined the protest and will be booking them for violating section 144.”

Title: ‘Mentally tortured’ by aunt, girl sets herself ablaze in Shamli
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

MUZAFFARNAGAR: Unable to bear mental harassment by her aunt, a 17-year-old girl, a class XII student, set herself ablaze in Shamli on Sunday. She was rushed to a local hospital from where she was referred to a higher centre in Meerut as her condition deteriorated. According to the girl’s family, the victim was being constantly tortured by her aunt mentally over a personal dispute. The family also alleged that they had complained to the police on earlier occasions too but didn’t get any response

It has been alleged that the aunt used to call the girl “characterless” in front of her friends and classmates. She was also threatening to put up ‘defamatory’ posters of the victim in a bid to further malign her character. According to sources, the dispute over property between her uncle and her family has been going on for several years. The victim’s father was even arrested by Adarsh Mandi police but no action was taken against her uncle.

On Sunday, the girl locked the door of her room and set herself ablaze. After getting the information, area police rush to spot and rescued her after breaking the door. The girl’s father Rakesh said, "There is a property dispute between my brother and me. I was even arrested by police on the basis of my brother’s complaint but police have never taken any action against him. My daughter was being harassed by the aunt.”

Superintendent of police Vineet Jaiswal said, “The girl is out of danger. She is being treated in a hospital. The family members have filed a complaint. Action will be taken accordingly.”

Title: Just one ideology can’t decide India’s future, says Mohan Bhagwat
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat

BAREILLY: RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat said here on Sunday that just one organisation or ideology cannot decide the future of India. Addressing hundreds of RSS workers at an event at MJPR University, Bhagwat said that founders of the nation were from different ideologies. “But, they had one thing in common — nationalism, based on which they chalked out the roadmap for the Independent India,” he said. “No single organisation or ideology can decide the future of India. People from all walks will decide it. All our great leaders who struggled for Independence were nationalist. And the roadmap designed by the founding fathers of the nation is enough for the RSS to follow as our vision completely matches with that,” he said, quoting communist leader Rajani Palme Dutta, Rabindranath Tagore, Mahatma Gandhi and BR Ambedkar. However, he expressed disappointment over the current position of the country, saying that 70 years’ time was not a short period to develop the country on the lines of what our great leaders wanted to achieve. “Israel got independence with us. In its first 30 years of independence, the country faced as many as five wars and won them all. Today, Israel exports everything from grains to latest technology to world. Similarly, we have example of Germany and Japan that were completely destroyed after World War II. But today, Germany is among the top most nations in Europe,” he said. He said that as a nation, we can achieve the ultimate goal only with accepting others’ point of view those who have different ideologies than us. “Not only tolerance but acceptance of others’ point of view has always been our culture, ” he said. He further said that that merely changing the way of worship doesn’t mean that one is not Hindu now. “All those whose forefathers were Hindu are still Hindu. And keeping this in mind we should cooperate and coordinate with each other to make a future India,” he said. He also took a potshot at those who term RSS a fascist organisation. “Fascists always grab power, but we have always been away from it. Those people are running a propaganda to tarnish our image. Their history and their present, in fact, have exposed them. One should always remember that RSS will never end. Those who had tried to end us have now been wiped out,” he said. The RSS chief also denied reports in some newspapers about his support to two children policy. “It has been published quoting me that there should be two children policy, which I have never said. In my view, population is a problem but at the same time it can be developed into resources. After considering all aspects, there must be a policy by government with general consensus to implement on everybody. Only the government will decide what number of kids a family should have. By this (incident) it appears that some prejudiced minds have decided what is next on our agenda.”

Title: Day after marriage, 20-year-old woman ‘gangraped’ in Hapur
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

Title: AU to revive legacy, restart historical journal after 80 yrs
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Allahabad: Department of medieval and modern history at Allahabad University will soon relaunch its historical journal after a gap of 80 years.

Being started by head of the department of medieval and modern history Prof Yogeshwar Tewari, the journal will have papers contributed by eminent scholars and academicians.

“The historical journal was first published in early 1920s after Sir Shafaat Ahmed Khan succeeded LF Rushbrook Williams (founder of the department) as the department’s head in 1921. This prestigious journal was published annually till early 1940s after which it was discontinued,” Prof Tewari said.

“The journal was known for its content which was academically enlightening and helped a lot in the development of Indian historical thought which was in its formative years then,” he added.

The contributors of the journal included meritorious students of the department as well as professors and historians like Prof CB Tripathi, Prof BN Pandey and Prof DN Shukla.

The journal had a nationwide reputation and was widely read in the academic circles of not just India but in many foreign countries too.

After around eight decades, the journal is being revived to promote academic potential of the department.

“The historical journal is likely to be launched this month itself. The upcoming issue will include popular articles of previous issues and recent contribution of prominent academicians of the department,” Prof Tewari said.

Title: Govt to carry out Pattana Pragathi soon
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: After Palle Pragathi , a 30-day action plan to develop villages on sanitation and other fronts, the TRS government will implement Pattana Pragathi programme in towns and cities after the municipal elections.

Pattana Pragathi means city development. Finance Minister T Harish Rao said the TRS government will also give development budget to every urban local body on the lines of Rs 330 crore being given to 12,700 gram panchayats every month.

He stated that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao–led TRS government has spent Rs 900 crore to extend Aasara pensions to 40 lakh beneficiaries.

“Over 500 2-BHK units are being constructed in Toopran. Only the eligible and genuinely deserving homeless poor would be allotted these units.,” he told the voters.

Targeting the Congress and the BJP, he said the two parties were reduced to a state where they did not have candidates to fight the elections in many wards.

Title: Kashmiri Pandits organize march
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: Kashmiri Pandits in the city organized a march at the Vastrapur lake on Sunday to mark 30 years since they were forced to flee Jammu and Kashmir. Those who participated in the march urged the government to work out a time-bound social and economic package for displaced Kashmiri Pandits in their homeland. Carrying banners and raising slogans, dozens of Kashmiri Pandits marched along the periphery of the Vastrapur lake.

tnn

Title: Transport dept to conduct five-day enforcement drive to check vehicles flouting pollution norms
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Bareilly: The Regional Transport Department (RTO) will be conducting a five-day enforcement drive starting January 20 to check on vehicles flouting pollution norms.

The transport authorities said enforcement teams would be deputed at prominent locations to check vehicles.

Speaking to TOI, senior assistant regional transport officer (ARTO) of Bareilly, RP Singh said, “Directions have been issued to all regional transport departments to launch an enforcement drive to check on vehicles flouting pollution norms, from January 20. The drive will continue till January 25 during which focus will be on commercial vehicles.”

He added, “Vehicles will be checked whether the driver/operator has acquired vehicle pollution certificate and whether the vehicle has completed its 15 years. Such vehicles will be impounded and their registration certificate will be cancelled. The erring drivers will be given some time to get the registration done as per norms failing which their RC will be suspended permanently and will be irrevocable.”

As per the records maintained by Bareilly Regional Transport Office, around 30,000 commercial vehicles and lakhs of private vehicles are registered with the RTO department in the city.

The RTO Bareilly has declared January 31, 2020, as the deadline for vehicle users, who have 15 years old vehicles and not yet obtained new registration, to get vehicle registration renewed.

Transport department officials said that RTO had identified around 58,000 vehicles till August 2018, to be more than 15 years old. Of these, around 4,000 vehicle users have got RCs renewed so far.

Title: Alarming rise in stomach ailments recorded in city
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: Stomach ailments among the city’s residents have seen a sharp jump over the past three years. Unlike yesteryears, these ailments are now taking longer to cure, say experts.

The instances of stomach ulcers, liver infections, diarrhoeal diseases and rectal diseases have seen an increase of up to 40% in the city. The rise in stomach ailments can lead to further complications like liver failure and stomach cancer. These ailments are primarily caused due to eating habits and frequent consumption of unhygienic food.

“After eating out at weekends, many patients come with an acute bout of vomiting and diarrhoea. Many are seen to have repeated episodes of these problems. Moreover, these diseases could be cured within a short period of time earlier but now they require prolonged treatment,” said Dr Kona S Lakshmi, gastrointestinal consultant, Geneagles Global Hospital, adding the organisms that cause these diseases are becoming resistant to medicine.

Experts said that stomach ailments may be rising due to medical misuse of drugs as well. Speaking about the increase in rectal diseases, Dr Srinivas Kongara, consultant, Hitam Institute of Anorectal Diseases, Madinaguda said, “Having more processed food like pizzas, burgers and frequent consumption of outside food loaded with spices is causing increasing cases of constipation which leads to further complications like piles and fissures. These cases are rising at an alarming rate.” He suggested having home cooked food, cutting out on refined and processed food and adding more fibre, fruits & vegetables in the diet.

Increasing consumption of fast foods, deeply fried foods and possible contamination of food and water is a possible risk factor for increasing prevalence of gastrointestinal diseases including acidity/dyspepsia. “These also cause repeated infections in the intestines. In the long run, these can progress to irritable bowel syndrome, stomach ulcers and cancers,” pointed out Dr Moka Praneeth, consultant gastroenterologist, Medicover hospitals.

Title: Teacher murders wife, flees with two minor sons
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vadodara: A teacher from Anand murdered his wife, who too was a teacher in Chhota Udepur district, and fled with their two sons late on Saturday night.

According to police, the accused Mukesh Zala and his wife Alpa Zala (35) got into heated arguments on Saturday night over domestic issues at Gadh Boriyad village in Naswadi taluka. In a fit of rage Mukesh picked up an iron griddle and hit Alpa with it. Police said that the deceased’s throat was also slit by the griddle’s sharp edges besides injuring her head. After killing his wife, Mukesh fled from the spot taking his two minor sons, aged eight and six years, along with him.

Cops said that the killing came to light on Sunday morning when Alpa’s sister called her on her mobile phone, but the calls went unanswered.

The sister then called her neighbour asking to check on Alpa. When the neighbour entered the house, he was shocked to find Alpa lying in a pool of blood and informed her sister and father. They rushed to Naswadi.

Alpa’s father alleged that Mukesh and his daughter had been going through tension for past sometime and probably killed her for it. Based on the father’s statements, a case of murder was registered against Mukesh at Naswadi police station.

“The deceased’s kin stated that Mukesh used to get angry at her over petty issues and often checked her mobile phone out of suspicion,” said a police official.

Cops said that the couple, who got married in 2010, hail from Balasinor in Mahisagar district but were living in Anand as Mukesh works there. Alpa taught at a primary school in Khareda village in Naswadi and used to commute daily between Anand and Khareda. But, seven months back the couple had got a new house in Gadh Boriyad and Alpa moved there with the children.

Title: Pune: In Pimple Saudagar, a key underpass nears completion
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The underpass at Govind Garden chowk in Pimple Saudagar has been thrown open to the public, but civil works are ongoing. At the current rate, the entire project, which was opened in phases, is set to miss an already extended deadline.

After it failed to meet the first deadline in June 2019, the Rs 9-crore project of the PCMC — along the Nashik Phata-Kokane chowk BRTS route — was handed an extension until the end of 2019. The flyover has been opened for service, but there’s still work pending on its finishing and the service lanes.

The PCMC said the entire project will be finished by the end of January.

“A drainage line was identified in the vicinity of the work site. It has been marked for an overhaul. That is why there have been delays. Most of the project is complete — the rest will be finished in a month’s time,” said Sanjay Kashid, deputy engineer, PCMC.

The underpass connects Pimple Saudagar and Pimpri and saves people the trouble of taking a detour.

“The road has finally opened. But it’s still a kutcha one. It took a long time and in the past 20 months, we have been using the alternative arrangements put in place by the PCMC,” said Rohit Shinde, a resident of Pimple Saudagar.

Motorists here often resorted to making U-turns at broken medians and also at breaches along the corridor for a quick pass. The violations complicated the traffic situation and put lives at risk.

“One fails to understand why the PCMC did not think of this flyover at the chowk, when it opened the road in November 2015. It would have made life easier for everyone in the locality,” said Dnyaneshwar Oak, a resident of Rahatani.

Motorists said they have had to negotiate numerous potholes, broken roads, gravel and missing footpaths for nearly two years.

Officials from the PCMC have in the past cited several reasons for problems at the site — from bad planning to lack of sufficient funds when the stretch first opened in 2015.

Though the road provides a thoroughfare to all those going from Pimple Saudagar to Pimpri and vice versa, the rest of the civil works, including relayering of footpath, is still work in progress.

“The footpaths are a part of the smart city initiative and cabling is being carried out. The footpath will extend all the way from Nashik Phata to Kokane chowk,” said Kashid.

According to sources within the PCMC, the contractor is responsible for all the civil works in and around any infrastructure project and he has to ensure that roads are in good shape.

“Much of the road around a work site gets damaged due to use of heavy machinery, but it is clear that contractors have to fix these problems,” said a PCMC official.

An engineer at the site said in the case of Govind Garden chowk, both the PCMC and the contractor were not aware of what was beneath the ground and part of the delay was also because they found pipe networks and black cotton soil — two factors that forced them to do quite a bit of re-engineering.

Citizens, however, said they remain hopeful of improvements at the junction. “It definitely has been a long time coming. And we have no choice but to stay patient,” said Pramod Mane, a local resident.

He added: “The PCMC has to carry out numerous other civil works in the area. All of us hope that planning capabilities have improved.

Title: SP leader Akhilesh Yadav’s cousin gives Rs 5 lakh to family of deceased killed during CAA violence
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

BIJNOR: Dharmendra Yadav, Samajwadi Party (SP) leader and cousin of former chief minister Akhilesh Yadav , met family members of Suleiman and Anas - the two men who were killed in firing during anti-CAA protests in Bijnor’s Nahtaur town on December 20, 2019.

Dharmendra also handed over cheques of Rs 5 lakh to each of the grieving families on Sunday and termed both the deceased as “innocent”. The SP leader claimed that culprits will be punished if their government comes to power.

Suleiman’s uncle, Afzal Ahmed Usmani, confirmed that family members have received a cheque of Rs 5 lakh on Sunday. “We are thankful to Akhilesh Yadav. But, we will get justice only after the erring policemen who shot dead Suleiman is put behind bars.”

The ex-MP was accompanied by former state minister Moolchand Chauhan and Swami Omvesh, MLA Manoj Paras and Tasleem Ahmed. They reached Nahtaur on Sunday and met the family and gave them monetary support.

Addressing a press conference on Sunday, Dharmendra said, “We have come here on the instructions of party leader and former chief minister Akhilesh Yadav and met the grieving families. We have given them a cheque of Rs 5 lakh to each. Besides, a cheque of Rs 50,000 was handed to a man named Omraj Saini who sustained bullet injuries during the protests on December 20. Our party has been assisting all the victims in UP. Akhilesh Yadav will also come to west UP soon.”

Lashing out at the BJP government, he said, “The entire country knows that BJP has been playing divisive and politics of hate. The CAA is unconstitutional as Muslims were kept out of it. We are opposing it and will never accept it. Everyone knows how the protesters were framed in false cases. All cases against protesters will be revoked and the erring will be put behind bars if SP comes to power.”

Dharmendra also criticised the Congress for not doing enough. “Congress did nothing for the victims. They only paid lip service to those who died while our party is assisting the grieving families and providing monetary support to the victims,” he said.

Notably, protests against CAA turned violent in eight towns of Bijnor. Bijnor and Nahtaur were most affected. In Nahtaur, two persons were killed in firing. Cops later admitted that Suleiman was killed in police firing in self-defence during the protests while Anas was killed by stray bullet.

Title: 5-year-old lost during Sankranti snan waits to reunite with family
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Allahabad: Days after being separated from his parents during Makar Sankranti snan in Magh Mela, five-year-old boy Raj is still waiting to meet his parents. He was shifted to Shishu Bal Grih in Khuldabad on Sunday.

The kid was found at a ghat in Mela area under Jhunsi thana set up at the Mela. The police later brought Raj to the Bhule bhatke Shivir (lost and found camp) being run by family members of Raja Ram Tiwari at sector one in Mela compound.

“The kid was in a state of shock initially and was unable to tell his name for few hours. Later he told us he is the son of Dheeraj and Jyoti. However, he is still unable to recall the name of the place he came from”, said Umeshchandra Srivastava, convenor of the shivir.

Raj only remembers that his parents boarded ‘Rail gadi’ (train) and came to the Mela on Makar Sankranti.

“Since the day he was brought here at the camp, everyone in the Mela area was trying to make the kid happy, some offering chocolates others showing films on mobile”, said Tewari. But after a momentarily smile, there is long blank in his eyes, enough to tell his plight.

He was shifted to Shishu Bal Grih in Khuldabad on Sunday from Childline where he was handed over by Mela authorities on Saturday.

Talking to TOI, superintendent of Shishu Grah, Harish Srivastava said, “He only remembers his parents name and remains silent otherwise.”

However, pilgrims in Mela area were unhappy over the entire issue as they believe that had the bhule bhatke shivir being allowed to broadcast the message pertaining to name of the kid or his whereabouts on the very first day—as was being done in the early years—the kid could have met his parents by now.

The organisers of the Shivir were asked to stop their announcement on the very first day of the Magh Mela (January 10) when the contractor who supplied them with public address system and the basic infrastructure, withdrew the logistic saying that the mela administration has asked the same.

However, nodal officer, Magh Mela police, Ashutosh Mishra said, “We have decided that the announcements being made by the bhule bhatke shivir would start from January 20”.

Title: Rajasthan government to launch drive to screen people for TB, cancer
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: A massive campaign to screen people above 30 years for non-communicable diseases including cancer and tuberculosis (TB) will be launched in the state.The health department will send health workers at doorsteps across the state to check on the wellbeing of people aged 30 years and above.For the purpose, the health department will impart training to its workers who will perform the survey. The training will be completed by February 15 and after that the state government will kick off the survey.According to health department officials, the survey will be done as part of ‘Nirogi Rajasthan’, which has already been announced by chief minister Ashok Gehlot .ASHA workers will be roped in for conducting the surveys. They will ask people to fill Community Based Assessment Checklist (CBAC) form for early detection of NCDs and Tuberculosis (TB). Through CBAC, the health department will conduct risk assessment of the individuals on the basis of the information provided to the ASHA worker.Screening for diseases will be performed on the basis of risk assessment. If a person scores four or more and there are clinical symptoms of cancer or TB, he will be put in the category of high risk and will be screened for the suspected disease. Those suspected of cancer, they will be immediately referred to the early cancer detection camps.Screening for diabetes, hypertension and TB will be conducted on the risk assessment of above 30 people. Additional chief secretary Rohit Kumar Singh issued guidelines on Friday (January 17) to all chief medical health officers of the state about the survey and screening programme for NCDs and TB.Along with that, health department has decided to keep a data of all patients coming for treatment of patients. Health minister Raghu Sharma on Sunday, while inaugurating an urban primary health centre at Devi Nagar here, said the government was taking measures to prepare health card of each and every patient. He added that the health department would keep a data of all patients coming to the hospital so that doctors would be able to use it as case studies.

Title: Kolkata: PWD to check pipes under BT Road
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

KOLKATA: The state PWD is keen to check physically the underground Tallah-Palta water pipelines to prevent any leakage like the one that happened under B T Road near Tallah Bridge in April last year. The PWD issued a Rs 17.2 lakh tender last week to check the underground pipeline in a 100-metre stretch near the zone.

PWD sources said they will make a trench cut on the BT Road stretch to verify the underground pipelines. The trench cut, PWD engineers said, is a long narrow ventilation hole, which will allow them access below. The PWD officials have decided that those, who have experience in trench cutting for the last five years, will be allowed to apply for the bids. The work will start in a month, according to sources.

The Tallah Bridge demolition is likely to start in the first week of February while the construction of the proposed new bridge is likely to start in April. The trench cut verification may be done before the new bridge construction, sources said.

However, the April incident showed the complexities in dealing with water pipeline leakage below the BT Road. Several water mains under BT Road carry filtered water from the Palta water treatment plant to Tallah water reservoir and pumping stations. A KMC water supply department official said that at least five metres below the ground, four major pipelinescarry filtered water from the Palta to Tallah.

The KMC water supply team had taken several hours to repair the breach in the pipe in April last year. A trench had to be dug for workers to climb down and find the breach, which happened days after the civic body’s unsuccessful attempt to repair a water main under the Cossipore railway tracks.

While the Tallah Bridge demolition will not pose much threat to the underground pipelines, the construction of the new bridge will require a detailed mapping of the pipelines, according to sources.

“A physical verification is required and it has to be very specific,” said an official. Any breach or leakage which may require repair could lead to water crisis in various parts of north and central Kolkata, added the official.

Title: Group clash over rash driving by teenager
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Two groups clashed on Saturday night following a quarrel over rash driving by a 17-year-old boy in Gulshan Nagar. Police have booked members of both groups for rioting, unlawful assembly and assault in the matter.

Police said a 17-year-old juvenile was allegedly thrashed by six persons from his neighbourhood in a road rage case late on Saturday night. The accused have been identified as Santosh Chavhan, Chotu Wasnik, Pradip Yadav, Shiva Shahu and their two unidentified accomplices. While the accused from the juvenile’s group have been identified as Javed Ali, Bhai Salim Khan and two unidentified persons.

The juvenile, a resident of Gulshan Nagar, was driving a bike at high speed in the area on Saturday night when some people stopped him and asked him to drive properly. The people and the juvenile later got into a quarrel, following which Shiva slammed his head on the juvenile’s nose, leaving him bleeding.

Later, his elder brother came with four friends to resolve the fight. However, the accused attack them with sticks and stone . Both groups clashed and several persons sustained minor injuries. Both groups later approached Kalamna police station and filed counter complaints.

Cops said the accused had even earlier asked the juvenile to drive slowly in the area but he continued to drive rashly, which led to the incident.

Title: Bareilly: Woman gang-raped by husband’s ‘friends’
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representational Image

Title: Kolkata: Guard injured after fight with intruder
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Bhagabat Saha sustained wounds on his head and face

KOLKATA: An elderly security guard of a residential apartment on Moore Avenue in Tollygunge allegedly fought a man who had sneaked into the building and tried to snatch a cellphone from the guard when he found him loitering suspiciously on the premises on Sunday. The 65-year-old security guard, Bhagabat Saha, sustained injuries on his head and face as he held on to the man, half his age, by the throat, screaming for help. His cries alerted the residents, who came down and caught the accused.

“We then dialled 100 and cops came and arrested the man. He had badly injured Saha and had even tried to gag him and cut his cheeks and tongue,” said Santanu Chakraborty, one of the residents.

Cops said the accused, Biswajit Ghosh, claimed he had come to the building to meet a friend who was working as a plumber there. “But, according to Saha, there was no plumber by the name the man mentioned. Saha complained that Ghosh had tried to snatch his cellphone and had hit him with an iron rod when he protested,” said an officer, adding that Ghosh, who too sustained injuries, has lodged a complaint against Saha.

Title: Now, students of JNTU can report grievances online
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: After receiving several complaints from students and faculty members of affiliated colleges, the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University, Hyderabad (JNTU-H) has introduced online grievance redressal service through Academic Audit Cell Portal.

While the faculty members can register their grievances by logging in with their credentials, students have to use the newly-created ‘student corner’ option on the portal to report an issue. “The university has received various grievances from both faculty members and students of affiliated colleges/institutions on various issues. In this connection, to redress grievances and strengthen the grievance redressal mechanism, the university has initiated online grievance redressal service on the Academic Audit Cell Portal,” read a circular released by the varsity.

Apart from submitting their grievances, students can also view updates from time to time at the student corner on the portal. Further, the varsity also directed all college managements to be proactive and take the initiative to resolve the grievances raised by their faculty members and students at the college/institute level itself.

Meanwhile, students and faculty members welcomed the move and said having an online grievance redressal service is the need of the hour as most of their problems are not addressed by the college despite making several representations. They said that the varsity should now play an active role and ensure that all the grievances raised through the portal are addressed in a timely manner.

Title: UDH seeks legal aid to implement impact fee on bldg violators
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Jaipur: Before implementing the impact fee on violators of building bylaws, the state urban development and housing (UDH) department is seeking legal advice.

Recently, the department decided to impose an impact fee on illegal buildings to discourage the rampant practice in cities. According to the official, the UDH minister has given an in-principal approval to the government and asked it to prepare a legal frame work to implement the new law. “The draft has been discussed by senior authorities. Directions have been given to chalk out legal framework for its implementation,” said an official at town planning wing.

Once the concept is introduced, owners of commercial properties that violate building bylaws will have to pay penalty every year. But for residential properties, a one-time impact fee will be imposed. An official source said, “As per the preliminary discussions, the resident owners who will violate the bylaws will have to pay 1% of the district lease committee rate (DLC) one time. However, it is not finalised yet.”

Sources further said the state government will only implement the fee after the local bodies election as it might face protest from opposition parties and residents.

For the implementation of the fee, the department will also amend the building bylaws after the approval. An official informed, the Rajasthan High Court had earlier asked the government to discourage the practice of regularising illegal constructions and ordered to impose heavy penalty on such buildings. It was also directed to raze or seal the illegal construction. However, the state government filed a Special Leave Petition (SLP) in the Supreme Court challenging the high court order claiming it would involve largescale demolition.

The move is expected to curb the illegal practices in the city including zero setback construction, covering parking areas and open spaces. Sources said in the previous government, the department had constituted a four-member committee to frame rules and regulations for sealing and opening illegal buildings in all municipal corporations, urban improvement trust (UIT) and development authorities. However, the committee failed to function effectively.

Title: Kolkata: Boy robbed after threat to tell kin about girlfriend
Content:
The spot in Ranikuthi from where the incident was reported

KOLKATA: After targeting elderly residents and salaried professionals, conmen have now turned their attention towards school students, duping them of expensive gadgets and petty cash after threatening to inform their families of the teenage secrets they would like to keep to themselves. Officers of Netaji Nagar police station came across one such incident on Saturday when a 16-year-old boy returning home from tuition was stopped by two men who claimed to be relatives of a girl the boy had grown friendly with at the tuition. They threatened to inform the matter to his parents and made off with his cellphone and some cash.The incident was reported around 6.45pm when the boy was passing by a pond in Ranikuthi.“The men stopped him and said they knew the kind of text messages he sent the girl. They said since the boy hangs out with the girl against her family’s wishes, they would inform his parents about it. When the Class XI student pleaded with them to not to do so, they demanded money from him. On the pretext of checking his cellphone, they even took the gadget and fled the spot,” said an officer.It was only after the boy realised that he had been conned that he informed his parents and they lodged a complaint for the loss of a wallet containing Rs 600 and a cellphone worth Rs 9,400. “We have started a case of cheating and criminal conspiracy and are probing the incident. It looks like a case of cheating by conmen,” said an officer.Time and again, conmen have targeted a variety of people — from elderly residents to homemakers, and from salaried professionals to businessmen. But, cops said, targeting schoolkids is something that has cropped up recently.“These days, all teenagers have expensive gadgets, like cellphones, digital notepads and laptops, along with some money. Hence, they become easy targets,” said another officer.An officer said they have issued advisories asking citizens to be aware of conmen and not to give hand over personal items to unknown persons under any inducement or threat. “We are asking citizens to be more alert and parents to be more friendly with children so they do not freak out in the face of simple threats made by random persons. Teenagers, too, should be careful and if they feel threatened, they should talk to their parents or teachers and inform cops,” said an officer.

Title: Leopard keeps Smriti Van shut for over two months now
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

This is for the first time that public entry to the biological park has been prohibited for such a long period... Read More

JAIPUR: For more than two months now, the elusive leopard which has taken refuge inside the sprawling Smriti Van has kept morning walkers at bay.

Few residents, however, have even come forward and requested authorities to allow them entry to the park after signing an affidavit. However, their request has been turned down by the forest administration claiming it to be not ‘feasible’.

A senior government official, who regularly visit the park said, “If you visit Smirti Van once, its difficult to like any other place for morning walk in Jaipur. Now I go for a walk on my office premises, but it is nowhere close. Jhalana has been always the home for leopards since ages and human have encroached upon their space. It’s a challenge for the forest department to maintain a man-animal coexistence system. Having said that, a middle path still has to be found because the park cannot be close indefinitely.”

This is for the first time that public entry to the biological park has been prohibited for such a long period. The forest department has installed three cages in the park, but all efforts have been futile till now.

A forest official said the feline was being regularly tracked and after monitoring it movement, the department was deliberating a plan to open the park soon after imposing restrictions. “We recently inspected the park to track the movement of the big cat. At present, the movement of the female leopard is near MNIT and temple area. We are earmarking a track on which morning walkers will be allowed.”

The increasing population of leopards has resulted in shortage of space at Jhalana forest area in Jaipur. This indirect proportion has forced the big cats to venture out of the forest and into human settlements to look for new territories. A forest official said, “There are five to seven sub-adults at the park. The leopards that ventured out are also subadults. The area of Jhalana is 22 square kilometre and the big cat population is higher than its carrying capacity.”

Title: Civic body proposes 5 new wards, seeks public opinion
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijayawada: The town planning wing of the Vijayawada Municipal Corporation ( VMC ) has completed its exercise on delimitation of wards under its jurisdiction. The civic body has proposed that the number of wards be increased to 64, up from 59 at present.

The civic body has published ‘Form 1’, explaining the proposed new divisions in the city and invited residents and political parties to raise objections and suggestions.

The decision to increase the number of wards comes after municipal authorities conducted a detailed study and proposed that five new wards be created by dividing wards with high population density .

The population of Vijayawada city saw an increase after it became a part of the Amaravati capital region. The number of voters in the city is around 7.2 lakhs out of an estimated total population of around 12.5 lakhs.

Opposition parties, however, expressed unhappiness with the divisions proposed by the VMC. “It seems that VMC authorities worked as per the directions of the ruling party. We are unhappy with the way officials did the delimitation process. City population increased drastically in recent times but officials considered the 2011 Census for the process. This is not acceptable,” said Communist Party of India (Marxist) state secretariat member Ch Babu Rao.

Jana Sena official spokesperson Pothina Venkata Mahesh demanded the state government merge Jakkampudi and Kothuru Tadepalli panchayats with Vijayawada city. “VMC oversees sanitation and other core issues in Jakkamudi affordable housing colony, yet it is a separate panchayat. The civic body is constructing several affordable houses at Jakkmpudi, Kothuru Tadepalli and Shahbaad panchayats and the VMC is bound to take up sanitation there. The government should merge these villages with Vijayawada,” he said.

CPI(M) city secretary Donepudi Shankar demanded the VMC to extend the time for submission of objections and suggestions on new divisions.

The town planning wing of the VMC has given one week’s time for raising objections.

Title: BJP workers attacked by toll plaza staff over payment row
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Allahabad: A group of BJP workers was allegedly attacked by toll tax plaza employees following a dispute over payment in Lalgopalganj area under Nawabganj police station late Saturday night.

The BJP workers were returning in two buses from a rally of union minister Smriti Irani in support of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in Varanasi. Some office-bearers of the party from Pratapgarh were also in the bus.

Police have arrested at least 17 people involved in the attack and recovered three licensed guns from their possession. Over a dozen persons received injuries in the attack.

According to cops, as the buses reached the toll plaza on Allahabad-Lucknow highway in Lalgopalganj, one of the vehicles allegedly crossed the barricading without making payment while the other was chased and stopped by toll plaza employees.

After an altercation over payment, the employees called the locals from nearby villages. The toll plaza employees and local villagers attacked BJP workers and allegedly fired shots with licensed guns.

The BJP workers claimed that they tried to flee but were chased and assaulted in the fields. The attackers also damaged the bus.

On the complaint of BJP Kisan Morcha vice president Prakash Chandra Mishra of Pratapgarh, an FIR was lodged against 25 unidentified persons. BJP’s Pratapgarh district president Hariom Mishra also reached the spot and spoke to injured persons who were taken to nearby hospitals.

SP (trans-Ganga) Narendra Kumar Singh said 17 attackers were identified through footages and other sources and all of them have been arrested. “Three double-barrel guns have also been seized from the accused and efforts are on to identify other attackers,” the SP added.

Title: City receives 80mm rain in Jan, heaviest in 49 years
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The rains were caused due to western disturbance, and heavy snowfall in the hills of Uttarakhand and in Kashmi... Read More

Kanpur: The month of January, usually known for receiving scanty winter showers, has witnessed unprecedented rains this year. The city has so far received 80mm of rainfall, which is eight times more than the average rainfall for this month. The average rainfall for January in Kanpur is 10 mm.

The city had never witnessed such rain in past 49 years. According to data available with the Met department of CSA University, the city had never received 80 mm rainfall since 1971 in the month of January.

While the rain has not ended the winter spell, it has caused damage to winter crops such as pea, chickpea, pulse etc. Hailstorms at some places, especially in city outskirts, damaged crops leaving farmers in trouble.

Earlier, when light rains lashed the city in the first week of December, farmers were happy as showers were beneficial for the Rabi crop but heavy rains that pounded the city between January 15 and January 17, damaged the crops. The mustard crop, which was in flowering stage was also hit.

“We are maintaining weather data since 1971. According to the available data, the city has never experienced 80 mm of rainfall this month. In 2014, 67.4 mm of rainfall was registered on January 18, but this year it has breached the rain data”, said Agrometerologist at CSA University, Prof Naushad Khan.

“The heavy rains have caused damage to chickpeas, gram, lentil, pea crops which were in the critical vegetative stage. The earlier light rains had benefitted the crops but they suffered huge damage after the heavy downpour”, he added.

Prof Khan said the rainfall also caused damage to wheat and potato crops. “Plants died as the fields got flooded with water resulting in huge loss to farmers. Also, the wind speed in the past days was quite high which further added to the woes of the farmers. Rains will keep crop productivity low”, he said.

The rains were caused due to western disturbance, and heavy snowfall in the hills of Uttarakhand and in Kashmir was the reason for rains in the plains, Prof Khan added.

The Met department could not rule out the possibility of more rains in the coming days. In the case of another western disturbance, it can still rain again.

Meanwhile, the spell of extreme chill continued in the city as day temperature continued to remain below 20 degrees Celsius.

Title: Dasoju calls for case against Malla
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: All India Congress Committee spokesperson Dasoju Sravan on Sunday demanded that a case of corruption be registered against Labour Minister Ch Malla Reddy. He alleged that Malla had collected crores of rupees from aspirants to give TRS party tickets for municipal elections.

He also demanded that Malla Reddy be sacked from cabinet with immediate effect.

Addressing a press conference at Gandhi Bhavan on Sunday, Sravan played out some audio clips which suggested that Malla Reddy and his close relatives asked for money to give TRS party tickets. TNN

Title: Gujarat: Teachers get key tips from US trainers
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: For the first time in Gujarat , teachers in Vadodara will be trained by trainers from Georgia Southern University , USA.

STEM centre of excellence (CoE) from Georgia Southern University on Sunday kicked off a five-day training workshop for 40 teachers from different schools of the city at Urmi School.

Four professors of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) along with CEO Dr Paddy Sharma was present at the workshop which aims to provide module-based training to teachers both in practical as well as theoretical aspects. The trainers will help teachers understand STEM and how to use the modules for children from Class I to XII.

“It is a student-oriented approach. Starting from Vadodara, we are developing this concept in Gujarat and slowly we will be moving to other cities in the state so that it can reach to maximum children,” said Sushma Vij, who along with Meena Dodeja, is state coordinator for STEM. tnn

Title: Ahmedabad: Student joins ‘friendship club’, loses Rs 44,000
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A 21-year-old man, fourth-year student of a chartered accountancy (CA) course, on Saturday filed a complaint with Navrangpura police stating that he was cheated of Rs 44,000 by unknown persons of a ‘ friendship club ’ who lured him to date beautiful girls.In his FIR, the man, a native of Mehsana who stays in a hostel in Navrangpura, said that he was searching for an online friendship club on November 20, 2019, and found a contact number. He called that number. The man at the other end told him that he would have to pay Rs 1,000 for primary membership of the club.The student paid the money and sent the payment receipt to the man. “After a while, that man sent photographs of four beautiful girls and asked me to select one of them. I selected one girl called Neha whose number was given to me,” said the complainant.After that, the student called the girl who offered him packages of Rs 16,500 and Rs 32,500. The student selected the package of Rs 16,500 and again called Neha expressing his desire to meet her soon.But this time, he was told that Neha had obtained a premium package worth Rs 32,500 and if he wanted to meet her, then he would have to pay Rs 32,500. The boy did it and tried to contact Neha again who told him to meet her at a hotel on Ashram Road.But she imposed a condition that he would have to buy a special body cream worth Rs 40,000.This time, the student suspected something fishy and demanded his money back from the man whom he had spoken to the first time. The man told him to pay Rs 10,500 to get the money back.The student did as asked. But the man asked for Rs 10,000 more as GST to get the refund. Then the student realized that he was cheated.

Title: Student kills self over failed affair
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijayawada: A first-year student committed suicide by jumping into a well at Vamakuntla in Tiruvuru mandal in Krishna district after her boyfriend rejected her marriage proposal . The deceased was identified as Ramadugu Asrita (19), a BSc student in a private college at Tiruvuru.

According to Tiruvuru in-charge inspector, Asrita was in a relationship with one Yerramshetti Venu (24), an MTech student from the same village. Asrita had asked him to marry her after he completed his degree, but he turned down the proposal. Venu also rejected the alliance after her family members approached his uncle K Nagaiah, with whom Venu lives.

Depressed over his refusal Asrita committed suicide by jumping into a well.

Asrita’s parents lodged a complaint on Saturday. Cops launched an investigation and on Sunday morning, found her body in the well. The body was shifted to a government hospital for post-mortem. A case has been registered against Venu and Nagaiah for abetting suicide under Section 306, read with Section 34 of IPC, and the two have been taken into custody.

Title: Ahmedabad: FIR lodged for sending lewd messages
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

Title: 10 teams formed to crack charred woman case
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

BIJNOR: A day after a charred body of a woman was found in an orchard merely 500 meters away from Delhi-Pauri National Highway here at Gajraul village area, superintendent of police Sanjeev Tyagi has formed around 10 teams to solve the case. Around seven teams have been sent to neighbouring districts to check the record of the missing women.

It has become hard nut to crack for the police to identify the body. According to officials, autopsy of the body is being conducted and details will come out late on Sunday night.

City’s superintendent of police Lakshmi Nivas Mishra said, “We have formed around 10 teams. Out of them, seven teams have been sent to neighbouring districts with the aim to identify the woman. They are checking records of the missing women there.”

“In Bijnor , there are around 13 women who are reported to be missing. Prima facie, deceased woman was not among them. That is why police are checking record of missing women in neighbouring districts,” Mishra added.

He further stated, “Post mortem of the body is going on. We can ascertain the nature of the crime only after we get autopsy report. Woman was disfigured. But we have got a picture of her distorted face which we have circulated on social platform. We have appealed all persons to help the cops to identify her.”

The charred body of a woman in her mid-twenties was found in Gajraula under Bijnor city police station area, barely 500 metres away from the Delhi-Pauri national highway on Friday night. Police could ascertain the age only from one foot that escaped the fire. According to the police, the woman appeared to be from a well-to-do family as she wore gold bangles and earrings.

Police recovered two used and a live cartridge from the ashes. The accused used a wooden cot to burn the body.

The incident came to light on Friday evening when a local contractor reached the spot and saw the burnt body. He informed the cops.

In an identical incident on December 24, 2018, the body of a woman – most likely in her thirties -- was found burnt near a canal here in Mundhal village of Bijnor. Police had set up a probe to identify the woman whose entire body, except half of her arm, was burnt in the incident. She was burnt by pouring patrol. Police are yet to crack that case.

Title: 60-year-old man bludgeoned to death
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijayawada: Unidentified persons killed a man by bludgeoning in his head with a heavy object near Piduguralla in Guntur district on the intervening night of Saturday and Sunday. The deceased was identified as Potluru Venkateswarlu (60), a native of Janapadu village.

Piduguralla rural inspector said that Venkateswarlu was a washerman who worked in Brahmanapalli while his family lived in Janapadu. Venkateswarlu would visit his family on weekends and was attacked while returning to Janapadu on Saturday night.

On Sunday morning, locals identified Venkateswarlu’s body by the side of the road along the Addanki-Narketpalli highway and informed the police. Cops shifted the body to Piduguralla government hospital for post-mortem.

A case against unknown persons has been registered under Section 302 (murder) of IPC. Police said the motive behind the murder is yet to be ascertained. Family members said they did not suspect any person. Police added they are investigating financial issues, family feuds and other motives.

Title: Rajasthan: Couple accused of murder yet to be traced
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

JAIPUR: Dausa police is yet to trace the couple who killed a cab driver in Baswa police station area on Friday night. Police teams have been sent to various locations. The husband and wife have not gone back to their home in Panipat . Their mobile phones are switched since the time of the incident.

According to initial investigation, the driver was shot in the chest by a couple from Haryana after he refused to be a part of a kidnapping bid. Anil Chauhan, additional SP, Dausa said, “Our teams are looking for the accused couple, Ravindra and Seema, but they have not returned to Panipat till now. They switched off their mobile phones after dumping the bike in Bandikui.”

The deceased cab driver was identified as 35-year-old Vishnu Nath who hailed from Alwar . Police have in their custody Subhash, a common acquaintance of the couple and the deceased driver. However, he has not been able to provide any clues to the absconding couple’s location. Three months ago, Ravindra had eloped with a girl from a village in Dausa district . A case had been registered against him but was withdrawn when the girl who he had eloped with said she went willingly. Ravindra, Subhash and Seema had planned to kidnap this girl but when Vishnu refused to be a part of the plan, he was shot in the chest.

“The motive for kidnapping the girl is still unclear but it is a possibility that after withdrawing the case, she might have asked for money and Ravindra perhaps thought of killing her,” added the official.

Title: Gujarat: Businessman dies in road accident
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The SUV collided head on with a truck near Lasundra village

Vadodara: A businessman from Savli died and two others were injured after an SUV they were all travelling in collided head on with a dumper truck near Lasundra village on Saturday midnight.

Police said that the deceased Dinkar Patel (52), his son Parth Patel and the other two injured persons – Rushi Kapadia and Bhumi Bhavsar – were returning home after attending a wedding in Vadodara city . As their car passed Lasundra village, Dinkar slowed down as only one lane of the Vadodara-Savli road was functional due to repairing of a bridge. Kapadia told the police that at a sharp curve, a dumper truck coming from Savli side collided with their vehicle, which was moving at a slow speed. After the hitting the SUV, the truck driver rammed the vehicle into a tree.

While Kapadia suffered injuries on his face, Bhavsar injured her chin and right leg and Dinkar Patel got stuck in the car after the driver’s side got badly mangled. His son, Parth, however, survived unhurt.

An ambulance was called and the trio was taken to a private hospital where Dinkar succumbed to his injuries. Kapadia and Bhavsar are currently undergoing treatment.

The truck driver had fled the spot and is yet to be arrested. “We have informed the owner of the truck and will find the driver soon,” said a police official.

Title: PU students win nat’l khadi contest
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Over 100 designers had showcased over 400 garments

Vadodara: Students of city-based Parul University’s Institute of Design have won best khadi concept award at the recently held National Designer Awards hosted by Khadi Design Council of India.

Over 100 designers had participated and showcased over 400 garments at this national platform to innovate and visualize ways in which khadi could be developed into a global fabric through exports.

Three students of Parul University - Krima Patel, Nitya Dixit and Yukta Mehta – had showcased 23 of their garments during the event.

Their designs featured a perfect blend of both western and Indian couture bringing an essence of cultural integration. The designs were inspired by an ancient Japanese fashion, based on the ancient culture and western civilization, stitched together in a minimalistic way. The other theme was based on a conceptualization of India’s metro life.

“I am so grateful to have been able to get an opportunity to stand on such a grand platform and showcase our designs, with the insights from such significant pillars of fashion industry. I am thankful that our university gave us such a vital practical exposure,” said Krima.

In addition to the award that design students won, professor Palak Patel, vice dean of faculty of design, was also awarded for her efforts in mentoring the students.

“The students of design have been continuously bringing pride to our university by not only taking part in these competitions, but by also innovating sustainable solutions to impact the fashion industry,” said PU’s president Dr Devanshu Patel.

Title: Rajasthan: Four cops hurt in stone pelting by aides of defeated candidate
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: Four police personnel of Manhorethana police station in Jhalawar district were injured on Sunday noon after the protesting supporters of a defeated candidate for the post of sarpanch from Khathakhedi gram panchayat pelted stones at the police team that had reached the spot to convince the protesters to remove the road blockage.

The circle inspector (CI) and three other constables have sustained injuries in the incident. Police have booked at least 36 identified persons and some other unidentified ones under Sections 147, 332, 353, 336, 307 283 of IPC and Section 3 of SC/ST Act. Police have also detained five of them and arrested 37 others for breach of public peace under Section 151.

Circle inspector of Manhorethana police station Ajit Meghwanshi sustained severe injuries over his face and head after some persons from Sandas village pelted stones at the police team that had reached the spot to control the situation at Khatakhedi village, where around 100-150 villagers — supporters of a defeated candidate for the post of sarpanch from Khathakhedi gram panchayat — had blocked the road, said DSP, Manhorethana circle Durgaram Choudhary. Three other constables, Jitendra, Akshay and Surendra, also sustained minor injuries in the stone pelting , he added.
