Meghwanshi reportedly collapsed unconscious, was bleeding from his ears and was rushed to Jhalawar district hospital where he is undergoing treatment, while the three other injured constables were discharged after primary medical treatment, the DSP said. He added further investigation into the matter is underway.

Vijay Singh from Sandas village contested for the post of sarpanch of Khathakhedi gram panchayat but was defeated by Dayaram Prajapat of Madanpura village, following that the supporters of Vijay staged a road blockage in protest.

When one of the villagers of Khatakhedi village, identified as Ashok Mali, was going to Manhorethana to join the weekly haat (market) on Sunday morning, the Vijay’s brother, identified as Amar Singh and his two other aides identified as Tulsiram and Kamal Singh, allegedly thrashed Ashok and did not let him pass through the road. When the villagers from Khatakhedi and Madanpura heard of Ashok being thrashed, they assembled on Khatakhedi village road and blocked the traffic there.

On receiving the report of road blockage on Khatakhedi village, CI Ajit Meghwanshi along with the police team, reached the spot to convince the villagers, but while he was talking to the protesters, some of them suddenly started pelting stones at the police team, injuring the cops.

Title: Two held for cheating in Jaisalmer
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

JAISALMER: Ramdeora police station in Jaisalmer district arrested two for cheating people of Rs 9 lakh with the false promise of getting them recruited in the Indian Army.

SP Kiran Kung said that on January 14, complainant Sukhram (48), resident of Loharki in Jaisalmer district, informed them that his son Vikram and his brother’s son Virendra had gone to Nagaur. They wanted to prepare for the Indian Army.

Two agents, Mahendra Singh and Maharaj Krishnlal met the two boys and demanded Rs 12 lakh for getting them in the army. The boys told the agents that they should talk to Sukhram. The culprits spoke to Sukhram and told him that the two would get into the army if they received coaching at Ahadnagar. He was asked to give Rs 9 lakh which was paid to Mahendra Singh in front of three witnesses. The culprits dilly-dallied for a month and kept giving false promises to Sukham and the boys. Finally, a complaint was lodged.

Title: Komatireddy, A Revanth Reddy eye TPCC president post
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy. (Image taken from his Twitter handle)

HYDERABAD: The municipal elections have come as an opportunity and also a major challenge to two Congress MPs who are front-runners in the race for the president of Telangana Pradesh Congress Committee .

The AICC leadership is likely to go for a change of guard in Telangana Congress and the performance of party seniors in ensuring the victory of Congress in municipal elections would play a significant role in finalization of the candidate for the coveted post.

The present incumbent and Nalgonda MP N Uttam Kumar Reddy has himself announced that he is expecting to be relieved of the post after municipal elections.

Among those in the race are Malkajgiri MP A Revanth Reddy and Bhuvanagiri MP Komatireddy Venkat Reddy.

These two MPs are now working hard to ensure the victory of party candidates to impress upon the AICC leadership that they can revive the party and bring it back to power in the state during the next assembly elections.

Though both Revanth and Venkat Reddy said that municipal elections should not be linked to the selection of PCC president and that AICC leadership has its own parameters and surveys based on which it finalizes the candidate, senior leaders in the Congress said the performance of party leaders in urban local body polls will definitely play a crucial role in finalization of the TPCC chief.

Four municipal corporations and 9 municipalities are going to polls in Malkajgiri Lok Sabha constituency limits and 13 urban local bodies in Bhuvanagiri parliamentary constituency.

Both Revanth and Venkat Reddy have been sweating it out to ensure the victory of party candidates in the ULBs.

Prestige is at stake for the Congress, which wants to prove that it is the main opposition party and an alternative to the TRS in Telangana, and not the BJP as being claimed by the saffron party.

Title: 61-yr-old cheated of Rs 5.5 lakh
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: A 61-year-old man filed a complaint of cheating and cyber fraud with Bopal police alleging that some fraudsters, impersonating bank employees, got the bank details from him and withdrew Rs 5.50 lakh from his account.

In his FIR, Ragesh Thakore, a resident of Sterling City in Bopal, said he works with Gujarat Technological University (GTU) as civil engineer.

On October 25, 2019, Thakore got a call from an unknown number and was informed that his debit card was blocked as he did not update his KYC details. The person sent him a web link and as he began filling up form, he was asked to give his password so he shut that link. On October 26, he got another call. The caller introduced himself as a bank manager, and sought Thakore’s PAN card details claiming that he will update his KYC details. Then the man asked for the one-time password. Thakore sent that to the man and Rs 1.50 lakh was debited. Later, Thakor ended up losing Rs 4 lakh more to the online fraudsters.

Title: LLB student beaten up by eight over youth festival planning
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Deepak Patel was attacked at an eatery outside the hostel campus

VADODARA: A student of MS University’s science faculty was arrested and seven others booked for thrashing a law student outside the boys’ hostel campus on Saturday evening.

Deepak Patel, a first-year LLB student, told the police that Nitinsinh Barad, who was arrested, along with Jeet Zala , Shantanusinh Chauhan, Balraj Bhatti, Jay Thakor and three other unidentified persons attacked him at an eatery outside the hostel campus. According to Patel, the accused were seeking revenge of an earlier clash between two groups of students’ at the science faculty on January 17.

The Royal Group and the All India Students’ Association (AISA) clashed at the science faculty over organizing youth festival. Members of the Royal Group alleged that because AISA’s faculty general secretary candidate was defeated in the students’ election, they were creating hurdles in organizing the festival. Following the clash the two groups had reached Sayajigunj police station with cross complaints, but reached a settlement later on.

Patel alleged that the accused, who are affiliated with AISA, had harboured grudges against him regarding the January 17 clash and despite the settlement, they attacked him on Saturday evening. In his complaint, he stated that the group members beat him up with wooden sticks and iron rods.

As a crowd gathered seeing the melee, the attackers left the spot but threatened Patel not to come to science faculty again. Patel’s friend took him to the SSG Hospital from where he was discharged after primary treatment. On Saturday night, Patel lodged a complaint of rioting, assault and criminal intimidation at Sayajigunj police station.

Based on his complaint, Barad, a student of science faculty was arrested on Sunday.

Title: Congress should focus on economic crisis, not CAA: Senior Congress leader Jairam Ramesh
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Senior Congress leader Jairam Ramesh

KOZHIKODE: Senior Congress leader Jairam Ramesh has said that the Congress party should lead an agitation on the economic crisis gripping the country and not on Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA )/National Population Register ( NPR ) as people see it as a Hindu-Muslim issue and added that the party should not allow the society to be polarized.

Speaking on the sidelines of the Kerala Literature Festival (KLF) which concluded here on Sunday, Ramesh said that BJP was waiting for Congress to take up the lead in CAA protests and the party would fall into their trap if it does so.

“CAA is a very sensitive issue. We have to be very careful that it does not become an instrument of Hindu- Muslim polarization. BJP wants to keep the debate of CAA/NPR alive while the most important issue in the country today is economic crisis with inflation going up and growth coming down. Congress should lead an agitation on economic crisis and not CAA/ NPR because economic crisis is not a Hindu-Muslim issue whereas people see CAA/NPR as a Hindu-Muslim issue,” he said, when asked about the perception that Congress is not taking the lead nationally on the CAA protests.

Referring to the passing of the resolution by Kerala assembly against CAA, Jairam Ramesh said that the state government cannot override CAA and added that any resolution of the state on CAA may not pass the constitutional test.

“To the best of my knowledge, citizenship is in the central list and not on the concurrent list. If it was in the concurrent list, the state assembly can override it. Any resolution on CAA may not pass the constitutional test. However on NPR/ NRC, it is a separate issue,” he said.

Senior Congress leader Kapil Sibal had on Saturday, while participating in the KLF, said that no state can take the stand that it will not implement the CAA.

Ramesh said that the Congress party should also be careful not to fall into the CPM trap as well on the issue and added that the party cannot be led by the CPM.

“Congress party’s politics cannot be dictated by the CPM. It should not outsource its thinking and should think of its own. Left parties are relevant only in Kerala while Congress is relevant in 29 states and it has to fight the BJP. Pinarayi Vijayan looks only at Kerala politics. Sitaram Yechury looks at national politics but Yechury has more influence in the Congress that in the CPM. It is easier for CPM leaders to meet Rahul Gandhi than for Congress leaders to meet him,” he added.

Ramesh said that the only way one can deal with the unconstitutional CAA is by either Parliament passing a new law which will not happen unless Congress gets majority or Supreme Court striking it down.

He said that he was the first to approach the SC against the Act.

Asked about the role of regional parties in Indian politics, he said that Congress has to learn to deal with regional parties.

“Regional parties are a reality and they want respect. One of the mistakes Congress made in 2009 was that when the party got 210 seats it became very arrogant. There was no CMP in UPA-2 while there was CMP in UPA-1. The BJP is now making the same mistakes with regional parties as is reflected in breakup with Shiv Sena in Maharashtra,” he added.

Title: KTR a failure as a minister: Uttam
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: TPCC president N Uttam Kumar Reddy has charged TRS working president K T Rama Rao of indulging in ‘headline management' by making false and hollow claims of development.

“KTR is a failure as a municipal minister. The development in municipalities and municipal corporations came to a halt ever since TRS came to power. The existing infrastructure in urban local bodies was created by previous Congress governments. However, KTR has been making false claims of development and cheating the people with empty promises by giving big statements,” he said .

Many urban local bodies have no money to even bear operational expenses. No funds were allocated for construction of double-bed room houses for weaker sections in several ULBs, he said.

Title: BJP Mahila Morcha leader found dead near liquor vend
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kanpur: Body of a local BJP Mahila Morcha leader was recovered from near a liquor vend in Phaphoond police area of Auraiyya district on late Saturday night.

Police recovered the body from a eucalyptus orchard close to a liquor vend in Sallahpur village during late Saturday night hours, said inspector Akhilesh Jaiswal. However, a 16-year-old youth, who accompanied her, remained untraceable, Jaiswal added.

“Investigation at the crime scene and prima facie evidence indicating that she might have been strangulated to death. Whether she was subjected to sexual exploitation or not would be clear only after getting the autopsy report,” the inspector said. “On the basis of the findings and recoveries during the preliminary investigation, the police have registered a case in this connection and started a search to locate the whereabouts of the teenage youth who had accompanied the BJP leader”, he added.

The incident came to light when some locals spotted the dead body lying near a liquor vend and alerted the police, he further said.

The victim went missing on Saturday evening, and her father filed a missing person’s report with Phaphoond police station. She along with a local teenage boy had left the house at around 6 pm on a two-wheeler saying that she was going to her sister-in-law’s house in the neighbouring village.

Title: Rajasthan: Nominations for phase three of panchayat polls today
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

File photo of voters waiting for their turn at panchayat polls

JAIPUR: The filing of nomination papers for the third phase of panchayat elections to the post of 1,700 sarpanch and 17,516 ward panch, will be held on Monday. The third phase of panchayat polls is scheduled to be held on January 29.

State Election Commission, secretary, Shyam Singh Rajpurohit informed that for the 1700 gram panchayats and 17516 panches under 49 panchayat samitis, the candidates can file nominations from 10.30 am to 4.30 pm.

Rajpurohit informed that the scrutiny of nomination papers will be done on January 21 (Tuesday) from 10.30 am. Candidates will be able to withdraw their nominations till 3 pm on January 21.

The allocation of election symbols and the list of final candidates contesting elections will be published soon after the withdrawal of nominations.

For the third phase, polling will be held at 6712 polling stations across 49 panchayat samitis and the counting of votes (at panchayat headquarters) will be conducted immediately after the end of voting.

The election to the post of Upsarpanch will be held on January 30. In the first phase of panchayat elections, 81.51% voting was recorded in 31 districts of Rajasthan, where the elections were held on Friday. Hanumangarh recorded highest polling of 89.25%. In 36 of the 2,726 gram panchayats, the candidates were elected unopposed. In the first phase, polls were held to 2,726 gram panchayats under 87 panchayat samitis.

The second phase of panchayat elections to the post of 2333 Sarpanch and 22,593 ward panch will be on January 22. In this phase, there will be 8365 polling booths across 74 panchayat samitis.

In Jaipur, till the end of voting, 83.65% voting took place in Aamer panchayat samiti, 86.90% was recorded in Jalsu and 85.90% was registered in Maujamabad.

Title: BJP offers property tax sops in manifesto
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: BJP Telangana unit on Sunday released its manifesto for the forthcoming civic polls, promising ‘zero’ municipal tax for houses under 100 square yards. The party also promised citizens, who will vote on January 22 across the state and January 24 in Karimnagar, that there will not be any need to get ‘No Objection Certificate (NOC)’ for new houses to be constructed within 100 square yards. Also, NOC will not be needed for regularization of old houses as well.

Hitting out at the Telangana government in the state, BJP’s manifesto said, “Though the Centre is giving a lot of funds to the municipalities, TRS regime does not want to give credit to central government and not using those funds. Because of this, people were unable to get many benefits.”

The saffron party also promised that within 100 days property tax would be rationalised and they would initiate reforms to ensure that 100% taxes would be collected. In each and every prospective BJP-ruled municipality, the manifesto said a separate self-assessment system would be adopted to decide property tax.

It also said drainage system in municipalities would be improved.

With the support from the Union government, toilets would be built in all the houses, BJP said.

Title: Task force team seizes 10 red sanders logs, one held
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Tirupati: Continuing the offensive against smuggling of red sanders, task force sleuths along with Rapur police seized 10 logs of red sanders and arrested a smuggler near the Kadapa-Nellore border on Sunday.

Police said the smuggler, identified as Sangati Subbaiah (58) from Pangilir village of Nellore district, has been involved in several cases of red sanders smuggling.

Kadapa task force sleuths and Rapur police reached the area and found Subbaiah with another unidentified smuggler trying to move red sanders logs. Before police could catch them, one of the duo managed to escape.

Title: Three held for youth’s murder
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kanpur: Three persons were arrested in connection with a murder of 20-year-old Ateeq, a resident of Usmanpur Naubasta. Atiq was found murdered in Kalyanpur area on December 22, 2019.

Police stated that the three accused happened to be friends of the deceased and murdered him to rob him of his cash and other belongings.

The arrested persons were identified as Lalji Pandey and Rakesh Gautam of Shivli area of Kanpur Dehat and Om Narain of Chaubeypur area of the district.

SP West Anil Kumar said, “Ateeq, a resident of Usmanpur Naubasta, was a credit card agent. The three accused have confessed to their crime and revealed that they took Ateeq to Kalyanpur where they murdered him before robbing him of his cash and valuables. The police managed to nab them with the help of e-surveillance.”

Ateeq’s was found in a dried canal at Shatabdi Nagar in Kalyanpur police circle of the city on December 22.

Title: MoS railways inspects Jaipur station
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Jaipur: Minister of state, railways, Suresh Angadi on Sunday visited Jaipur railway station and was impressed with the cleanliness (swachhta) at the station while stating that the “station was of international standard.” He also said, “All stations across the country should keep up such standards.” He inspected the concourse area, waiting room, food stall, and executive lounge at the Jaipur railway station. TNN

Title: Pune: 11-year-old drowns in civic water tank while flying kite
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Enthusiactic kite flyers often climb up to terraces and water tanks to get the advantage of the wind and the h... Read More

PUNE: An 11-year-old boy drowned after he fell into an open overhead tank while flying his kite on the premises of the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s (PMC) water treatment plant in Vadgaon Budruk on Sunday afternoon.

The Sinhagad Road police said the boy and his elder brother had climbed the tank to fly kites when he slipped and fell into the tank which had no lid. “His brother raised an alarm after trying to search and rescue him,” inspector Sunil Takawale of Sinhagad Road police told TOI.

The police identified the deceased boy as Atharva Bapu Gore of Samarthnagar near Tukai temple in Vadgaon Budruk.

V G Kulkarni, head of PMC’s water department, told TOI, “The water treatment plant is surrounded by slums and people living there do not have direct road access to their dwellings. A part of the plant’s premises has been kept open for them to access their dwellings in Vadgaon Budruk areas. The PMC is developing a new thoroughfare for the residents and entry to the plant will be stopped once the facility is ready.”

According to the civic officials, as of now, entry to certain areas on the plant’s premises is restricted but some local residents frequently access these areas. Sometimes they quarrel and threaten the security guards when prevented from moving in the restricted areas.

The guards fear to prevent such elements from entering restricted areas following incidences of misbehaving and manhandling in the past.

“The security guards do not want to get roughed up by the locals. They try to stop people from going to these areas, but after a limit they do not force the issue out of apprehension,” a senior PMC officer, who did not wish to be named, said.

Inspector Takawale said Atharva and his brother Santosh had gone to the water tank for flying kites and were looking skywards while moving around when Atharva fell into the tank from an opening which had no lid. “Santosh then peeped inside the tank from the opening and made an attempt to search for Atharva, but failed. He then raised an alarm and local residents rushed to the spot,” he added.

Subsequently, the police and fire brigade officials reached the spot. The fire brigade officials entered the water tank and brought out Atharva who was motionless. He was taken to a nearby hospital where the doctors pronounced him dead, Takawale said.

Atharva was a sixth standard student of a local school, Takawale said. “Atharva’s father is a porter while mother works as a domestic help in the nearby societies,” he said.

Takawale said the water treatment plant area has an chain link fence but the residents of the slum near the plant cut the fence. It now has openings in many places and the boys entered the treatment plant area from one of them.

Title: Unnao man strangled to death for opposing molestation of daughter
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

Title: Secunderabad: Inefficient management of reservoirs leaves many thirsty
Content:
Representative image

SECUNDERABAD: Despite the population nearly doubling with the development of new residential areas in Marredpally , Sitaphalmandi, Padmarao Nagar, Tarnaka, Lalapet, Mettuguda and other areas of Secunderabad almost a decade ago, residents here are still suffering from a shortage of drinking water .As the Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB) has failed to prepare fresh proposals to enhance the capacity of existing service reservoirs and construction of new reservoirs to meet the demand, problems related to drinking water supply in Secunderabad have only intensified. “The existing service reservoirs were built in the 1960s, with a capacity of 45 million litres, when the Manjeera water supply scheme was launched. The population has increased since then and the areas are saturated,” said an HMWS&SB official. Officials said that the water board is unable to construct new service reservoirs and is supplying Godavari and Krishna water to the residents on alternate days.General manager, O&M Divison-VII (Marredpally), K Ragunandan Reddy said, “The water board has been depending on the existing infrastructure to supply water. Two new reservoirs have been constructed, one at Osmania University, with a capacity of 5 million litres, and another one at Lalapet with a capacity of 3 million litres. Depending on the necessity, they will be commissioned.”With the commissioning of the two service reservoirs, OU, Mettuguda, Tarnaka and Manikeswara Nagar, Lalapet and the adjoining residential areas would benefit, he said.“Though the officials have been claiming that they would supply potable water on a daily basis, they cannot do it due to lack of infrastructure,” said Sai Krishna, a resident of Tarnaka. “The slums and tail-end areas suffer the most as they receive water with low pressure. The water board has to put in more efforts to quench the thirst of every resident. Drinking water sources like Godavari and Krishna have received good inflows due to bountiful rains, and therefore, the situation is manageable at present,” said Pramod Reddy, a resident of Lalapet.

Title: Instances of sudden cardiac arrest on the rise; experts seek fitness incentives
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: A day after two city doctors died of sudden cardiac arrest, experts on Sunday said that instances of sudden cardiac arrest among unfit people aged below 45 are increasing, what with several such cases being reported among teens and students of late.

Stating that there is a need to incentivise fitness at all levels, they said that besides stress and poor lifestyle, ignoring health issues also plays a key role in deteriorating one’s health.

In order to make preventive health and wellness attractive to the people, experts said that incentives could be introduced in the upcoming budget. “Under section 80D of the Income Tax Act of 1961, taxpayers can claim tax deductions on health checkups and health premiums, preventive wellness, however, is still placed under a high tax bracket. This year, however, we hope the budget goes beyond providing tax deductions to those recovering after falling ill, and supports and incentivises those who take care of their own fitness. This can include fitness services such as memberships to gyms, fitness studios and commercially-run yoga centers,” said Sarvesh Shashi, founder of Sarva, a yoga and wellness ecosystem.

Data from the World Economic Forum indicates that over 77% of Indians would be below the age of 45 by the next decade. “However, despite having a sizeable population of young people, we are also the most unfit, with estimates suggesting that 1 in every 3 Indians is unfit and suffers from preventable lifestyle diseases. There is a need to look at the preventive aspect seriously. Workplaces need to incentivise healthy practices,” said Dr Sanjeev Singh Yadav, secretary general, Indian Medical Association, Telangana.

While some offices do encourage healthy practices like cycling to work and maintain gyms, more workplaces need to provide such options, say employees. “In my previous office, I used to play basketball but after I shifted to another office, there is no option for recreational activities in the office and since I spend most of my time in office, I started ignoring my health. It would be good if companies encourage employees to be physically fit,” said Surendra B, who works with a startup.

Title: Watch out! City has 24 accident-prone spots
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: The national and state highways authorities have found 66 accident-prone spots in Nagpur district. This was the finding of a study of road accidents in 2019. Of these, 24 are in Nagpur city alone.

While the study also revealed that rash and negligent driving has turned 47 spots into accident-prone ones, faulty road design was a major cause with regards to 19 spots becoming black spots.

According to Nagpur city traffic police data for 2019, the city witnessed 1,007 road accidents that left 250 dead and 1,042 injured. Roads under Nagpur rural police recorded 843 accidents killing 384 people and injuring 940.

During the study, it came to fore that despite reporting lesser number of road accidents in comparison to the city, rural areas have more number of accident-prone spots at 42.

Though the study failed to mention number of accidents occurred in these black spots, the study revealed that roads under Saoner and Umred police station jurisdictions have maximum numbers of accident-prone spots. Both the towns have seven black spots each. It was followed by Mouda, Kondhali and Hudkeshwar police stations with four black spots each. Roads passing through police station areas like Sonegaon, Butibori, Khaparkheda and Bhivapur have three black spots each.

The study also revealed that not only human negligence, but slow progress of developmental works like construction of flyovers, underbridges and road works too have contributed to several spots becoming accident-prone. As per the report, slow progress of flyover works in both Pardi and Kapsi too have caused black spots on the roads.

To eradicate accident-prone spots, the study has suggested both short-term and long-term measures. The agencies have suggested short-term measures like zebra crossings, warning boards, advanced signages, encroachment removal, rumbler strips, speed breaker etc.

According to an official, both NHAI (National Highways Authority of India) and state public works department (PWD) has succeeded in reducing the number of accident-prone spots identified in 2018. Of the 83 spots, these agencies have rectified over 70, the official added.

Number Accidents---Killed---Injured

City — 1,007---250---1,042

Rural---843---384---940

Accident-Prone Spots

City---24

Rural---42

Causes of Accidents

Faulty road designs---19

Negligence---47

Title: Pune Municipal Corporation pledges increased trash processing capacity
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Pune MUnicipal University

PUNE: The civic body is trying to increase the capacity of direct processing of garbage up to 1,700 tonnes by the end of this year, for which it is improving the necessary infrastructure.

At present, the civic body daily processes around 1,350 tonnes of garbage (dry and wet) at its plants (see graphic). Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) officials said new processing plants were being established and the old facilities would be restored.

“These projects are likely to become operational to the full capacity by this year. Many of the projects are supposed to completed by April. Once the plants start processing garbage at their maximum capacity, we hope open dumping of garbage will stop for good,” said Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of the PMC’s solid waste management department.

PMC officials said the civic administration stopped dumping garbage in the open at the Uruli depot from last week, a practice that was in place for nearly 25 years.

The officials said the civic body was planning to produce various bi-products, including electricity and bricks, from the garbage plants.

Citizens’ activists are, however, sceptical about the civic administration claim and said the should take “cost-effective” measures. “The existing projects are not working properly. How can one guarantee that the PMC’s new plan will become a reality?” asked Vivek Velankar of citizens’ forum Sajag Nagrik Manch.

“A properly planned waste management system can help a government earn money. But the PMC is not approaching the problem in the right way,” he said.

Title: Man’s charred body found Bulandshahr field, cops suspect he was shot dead
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

MEERUT: Days after the body of a Delhi resident was fished out from a canal, a charred body of a man, probably in his late 20s, was found in a field in Dibai area of Bulandshahr district on Sunday morning. Police suspect that the man was shot dead at some other place. His body was brought to the field and set on fire to conceal his identity.

On being informed, local police arrived at the spot and took charge of the body and sent it for postmortem. The report is awaited. Forensic teams have collected samples from the spot and investigation in the case has begun, said senior police officers.

“The body was found in a field near the highway in Dibai, close to Galibpur village. Prima facie, it appears that the victim was shot dead and later, his body was set on fire to conceal his identity. We are trying to ascertain the identity of the deceased and only then, further probe in the case will be possible,” said Bulandshahr SSP Santosh Kumar Singh .

The deserted stretches of western UP and its canals have for long been used as “dumping ground” for bodies. According to sources in police, criminals dump bodies in the canals and in deserted pockets, hoping they will decompose and identification of the victims will becomes difficult.

In May last year, a headless body of a 23-year-old woman, with her fingers missing and torso bearing several brutal injury marks, was found dumped in a cane field in Bulandshahr. Local police are yet to solve the case. A few months later, the body of a 25-year-old woman was found dumped in a sack in Bulandshahr’s Gulaothi area.

Title: Groups fight after polls in Alwar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Alwar: District police arrested 90 people after two groups got into a scuffle after the panchayat elections in Kathumar police station area. According to cops, the present sarpanch took out a procession without prior permission and got into a scuffle with the candidate who lost along with the supporters.

Title: Gujarat: Cold set to return on Thursday, says IMD
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The minimum temperature is likely to rise further to 13°C (File photo)

AHMEDABAD: With 2°C rise in minimum temperature , the city again experienced fluctuation in the cold on Sunday.

The minimum temperature is likely to rise further to 13°C, mentioned India Meteorological Department (IMD) forecast. This year, winter is marked by periodic rise and fall of minimum temperatures due to multiple weather factors in the region.

According to IMD website, Ahmedabad on Sunday recorded maximum temperature of 25°C and minimum temperature of 12.1°C. The maximum temperature was 2.9 degrees lower than the average and the minimum temperature reached the normal levels.

With northeasterly winds prevailing at lower levels over the region, there would be no major change in minimum temperature on Monday. Minimum temperature will rise thereafter by 2-3°C and then will fall by 3-4°C, mentioned the IMD forecast. The cold wave conditions in some parts of Kutch district on Sunday are likely to continue on Monday.

Naliya was the coldest in the state with minimum temperature of 4.6°C, followed by Keshod (8.2°C), Bhuj and Gandhinagar (9°C), Rajkot (9.2°C), Amreli and Surendranagar (10°C). Maximum temperature in majority of the weather stations was reported around 25°C to 26°C.

Title: Technical snag halts Metro train at Panjagutta station
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Metro rail passengers had to deboard at the Panjagutta Metro station on Saturday afternoon after the services on the Red line were briefly disrupted due to a technical snag. According to the Hyderabad Metro Rail Limited (HMRL) authorities, the services were disrupted at around 12.02pm when the train was enroute from LB Nagar to Miyapur .

In a statement, HMRL managing director NVS Reddy said, “The passengers were made to alight the train at Panjagutta Metro station. The train was coupled with the following train and pushed into the nearby pocket track, which is between Punjagutta and Irrum Manzil.”

“The Metro train service were restored at around 12.20pm on both up and down lines,” the HMRL MD added.

Taking into consideration the rush at Ameerpet (towards Miyapur), an extra train was introduced from Ameerpet and the crowd was cleared.

This is the second time in a month that Metro rail passengers have faced inconvenience. In a similar incident on January 7, heavy rush was witnessed at Ameerpet Metro station after services were disrupted on the stretch between Ameerpet and Raidurg due to technical snag. Nine trains were halted.

Title: Accused gives cops the slip, escapes from police station
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Tirupati: In an embarrassment to the Tirupati (Urban) police wing, a 24-year-old youth accused of theft managed to escape from Tiruchanoor model police station near Tirupati on Sunday afternoon.

According to Tiruchanoor poice, the accused, identified as Nagaraju (24), is a native of Anantapur and was taken into custody by Tiruchanoor police in connection with a tractor theft case.

Local police had shifted Nagaraju to Tiruchanoor police station for questioning. Sources said that on Sunday, Nagaraju used a ventilation opening in one of the bathrooms to escape while the police were sleeping. A few minutes later, police realised that Nagaraju was missing and launched a search.

Efforts to apprehend him continued till late in the evening but were futile, said the police.

Title: Delay in hiking renewal fee of 15-yr-old cars raises concerns
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: Members of auto and motor vehicle unions have raised concerns after the transport department’s proposal to hike the renewal fee of old vehicles as per Motor Vehicle Act 1988 has been put on hold by the state government for six months. The unions have said that the delay in hiking the renewal fee will allow vehicle owners to continue using old vehicles instead of scrapping them.

The RTA had sent a proposal to the government in August 2019 to increase the renewal fee of 15-year-old vehicles along with green tax and late fee to discourage vehicle owners from using old vehicles. “The decision to hike the fee is still pending with the state government,” said U Yadagiri, general secretary, Shakti Auto and Goods Drivers Unions.

Once the hike is implemented, renewal charges for cars will go up by 10 times. “While the existing fee for a four-wheeler is Rs 1,270, after the hike the amount will go up to Rs 10,000. This excludes green tax of Rs 535 and late fee of Rs 500 every month. Similarly, two-wheelers will have to pay Rs 2,000 instead of the existing Rs 600, apart from green tax of Rs 285 and late fee of Rs 300 every month,” said Sathi Reddy, auto union member. tnn

Title: Family duped of Rs 1.34 crore
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: A resident of Ghatlodia on Sunday filed a complaint with the Sola high court police alleging that he along with his 24 relatives were cheated of Rs 1.34 crore by online fraudsters who promised them job and resident visa of Canada.

In his FIR, Rohit Sharma, 42, who runs transport business, said that he had seen an advertisement on internet in November 2018. He found a contact person through that website and called him up. On enquiring, the contact person, who introduced himself as Niraj Gupta, told Sharma that his firm could provide accommodation for persons who want to go to Canada either on work permit or on students’ visa for which he would charge around Rs 4 lakh.

Along with Sharma, his 24 relatives decided to migrate. Then, Gupta, told Sharma to pay money in eight different accounts. Sharma deposited Rs 98.33 lakh between February and October 2019. Gupta had also met Sharma in person and took Rs 36 lakh from him. Later, Gupta sent offer letters of various companies and visas but they turned out to be forged.

Title: 20-year-old Sikh student murdered in Nottingham city centre
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Arjun Singh. (Image courtesy: Nottinghamshire Police)

A 20-year-old British Sikh student has been murdered in Nottingham city centre.

Arjun Singh, a student at Nottingham Trent University, died on Sunday, 19 January, after being assaulted near the Slug and Lettuce pub in Long Row, in Nottingham city centre, just before 4am on Saturday night. The bar and restaurant, which opened in September 2019 following a £450,000 refurbishment, is open until 3am on Saturday nights.

Singh was rushed to the Queen's Medical Centre following the attack but died of his injuries on Sunday. Nottinghamshire Police have now launched a murder investigation.

Pete Knowles, who delivers newspapers in the area, told local newspaper, The Nottingham Post , that he saw the ambulance speed off as he was doing his newspaper delivery.

“All I saw was someone on the floor with a blue blanket over them. There were two ambulances that came and then police cars,” said Knowles.

The area was cordoned off all day on Sunday as crime scene investigators searched for evidence. “A team of detectives are working hard to establish the circumstances. Police are eager to trace two men who fled the scene on foot following the incident,” a police spokesman said.

"This was a serious assault which has resulted in a young man losing his life,” added Detective Inspector Richard Monk.

“Our thoughts with Arjun's family and friends and we would ask that people respect their privacy at this very sad and difficult time. We need to hear from anyone who may have dash-cam footage, including taxi-drivers who were in the area of Long Row West and Angel Row at the time, or any mobile phone footage of the incident. It is really important that if anyone has any information that could help the enquiry, no matter how small it may be, they come forward immediately,” Monk added.

Friends told TOI that Singh’s family was completely distraught.

Students from the Nottingham Trent University Sikh Society and the University of Nottingham Sikh Society, as well as members of Sikh Youth UK and the GAD Gym at Guru Arjan Dev Ji Gurdwara Derby, will hold a vigil at 5pm on Wednesday at the spot where the attack happened.

Title: CPM to hold nationwide campaign against NPR
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: CPM would hold a countrywide boycott campaign against the proposed National Population Register ( NPR ) by asking people not to respond to questions that could lead to the preparation of the registry, CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury said here on Sunday.

“These enumerators will have two sets of questions. One for census and the other NPR. People are free to choose not to reveal NPR questions. There is nothing illegal in doing so. Such refusal doesn’t entail any legal action. Rather it would push the government to a tight spot,” he said in a news conference at the AKG Centre here. While the questions relating to census may be answered, the questions related to the NPR must not be. Census-Yes. NPR-No, would be our motto, Yechury said.

The Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA) was part of a grand design leading to NPR and NRC and hence the party central committee which concluded here on Sunday asked the central government to repeal the law that targets minority communities, especially Muslims, he said.

The party, Yechury said, would continue to give all support to the anti-CAA agitations springing up in various corners in the country. But it would not lead the agitation from the front. “Given the multitude of people who assemble in the fight against CAA, it’s better no single political party try to appropriate the agitation. Let the protest continue like this. We would lend them all support they need,” Yechury told reporters.

The central committee demanded of the Centre to withdraw the directions given to state governments to construct detention centres.

The committee, said Yechury, expressed strong disapproval of the statement made by the chief of defence staff, Gen Bipin Rawat that “de-radicalization” camps were needed for people, including young children who are being radicalized, particularly in Kashmir.

Title: Pune : Woman loses over Rs 8 lakh to online matrimonial fraud
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 44-year-old woman was duped of over Rs8 lakh by a man with whom she chatted for over two months after his introduction as a United Kingdom resident on a matrimonial website.

The woman transferred the amount between August 13 and 19, 2019, for paying custom fee for a gift the man, who she though her would-be groom, had sent from the UK. She had approached the cyber police in September and lodged a complaint with the Uttamnagar police on Saturday.

The woman had set up a profile for herself on a matrimonial website in 2017. In June last year, a man sent her a text message, saying that he liked her profile. The two decided to tie the knot in October, 2019. In August, the suspect told her that he would be sending her ‘Shagun’,” senior inspector of Uttamnagar police Sunil Pandhakar said.

“On August 13, the woman received a call from a man identifying himself as Raj Sharma — a customs officer from Delhi airport — and told her to pay Rs45,000 as customs duty for her ‘Shagun’ parcel. Over next three days, the woman transferred additional Rs5.55 lakh to him. “On August 19, the woman’s ‘would-be groom’ told her that he was in Scotland and his debit card was not working. He asked her to transfer Rs2 lakh and the woman obliged,” he said.

She, however, became suspicious when a woman posing as an Reserve Bank of India official demanded Rs3.2 lakh as fee for transferring the money from the ‘Shagun’ parcel to her bank account. “The woman called her ‘would-be groom’. When he insisted on paying the fee, she became suspicious,” he added.

Title: Take care of your heart this winter
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: That morning breathlessness after a short jog is not just the age - your heart could be giving you signals to slow down if there are symptoms like chest pain, giddiness and swelling in legs.

City-based cardiac experts point out that they record more cases of heart failure — the condition where the heart is not able to pump adequate blood across the body — during winter months. The doctors thus caution more care for existing cardiac patients.

Dr Sunil Thanvi, a city-based cardiologist, said that cardiac issues rise by about 20-35% during winter months compared to other times of the year. “The blood vessels get constricted in the cold, prompting a rise in blood pressure and heart rate. Rich food in winter is another reason. In earlier times, people were physically active enough to easily digest those adadiya with ghee but today it’s adding to the risk for those who already have cardiac condition,” he said.

This year’s winter was different with a sharp rise and fall in minimum temperature. Has that affected the pattern of cardiac cases? City-based experts said that there is rise in heart failure cases compared to heart attacks.

Dr Jayesh Prajapati, head of cardiology department at UN Mehta Institute of Cardiology & Research Centre, said that winter is marked by complaints of coronary spasms and complications such as acute coronary syndrome.

Title: Polio vaccine administered to over 5L children
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: As part of the Pulse polio Day observed on Sunday, health authorities in Hyderabad administered oral polio vaccine to 5.122 lakh children below 5 years of age in Hyderabad district.

As many as 11,200 teams were deployed and 2,800 booths at Raj Bhavan, Shishu Vihar and the DMHO office besides other places were set up for the programme. Further 134 mobile teams were pressed into service to cover children in high risk groups. The entire health staff, volunteers, ASHA workers, anganwadi workers, mahila mandal members, child welfare departments, NGOs, nursing students and teachers participated in the programme. Vaccination centres were set up in schools, anganwadi centres, bus stations, railway stations and in residential areas.

Title: Pulse polio drive held across 3,000 booths
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Chittoor collector Narayana Bharat Gupta administers polio drops

Tirupati: A pulse polio immunisation drive was held at over 3,000 immunisation booths across Chittoor district on Sunday.

Chittoor district collector Narayana Bharat Gupta along with Chittoor MP N Reddeppa administered polio drops to children and launched the programme at the district headquarters on Sunday morning.

Addressing reporters, Gupta said the pulse polio immunization drive is held by the Union government across the country every year in January with an objective to eradicate polio from the country.

Elaborating on the measures taken by the district administration this year, Gupta said about five lakh children under the age of five are set to receive pulse polio drops during the drive.

Meanwhile, Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams additional EO AV Dharma Reddy launched its pulse polio immunisation drive at Tirumala on Sunday morning, He later, administered polio drops to children.

Speaking to the reporters, Dharma Reddy stated that the TTD has set up 25 polio immunisation booths and urged people to make use of the drive.

Title: Legal brakes on vehicle testing centre at Dandu Malkapur
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: The Advanced Vehicle Inspection and Fitness Centre, being constructed at Dandu Malkapur between Hyderabad and Yadadri-Bhongir, is stuck in a legal limbo. After hitting several roadblocks in the past nine years, the high court has ordered that work be stalled until further orders, as some people are claiming that the land belongs to a mining company.

“Earlier, no contractor was willing to come forward and take up works, as part of the land on which the testing centre was being constructed was under conflict. The transport department’s plans to inaugurate the centre in May last year also failed, even though tenders to finish work were called twice. And now, there is a stay order from the high court after some people claimed that the land belonged to a mining company,” said M Dayanand, general secretary, Telangana State Auto and Motor Welfare Association.

The one-of-its-kind facility can test over 300 vehicles daily — trucks, RTC buses, auto-rickshaws, school and college buses, cabs and goods carries — and enable them obtain computerised fitness certificates. It is being constructed by the transport department to eliminate human interference and curb corruption and other illegal practices during vehicle fitness checks.

Regional Transport Authority (RTA) officials said that they were just one step away from starting operations at the Advanced Vehicle Inspection and Fitness Centre. “Almost all the work required to commence the centre is complete. Allegations stating that the land belongs to a mining company are not true. We will inaugurate the centre once the stay order is lifted,” said C Ramesh, joint transport commissioner, RTA.

Title: Guarding the guards: Upholding justice for soldiers of Indian Army
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Major General AB Gorthi during his days in the army. He played a crucial role in ensuring that those responsib... Read More

SECUNDERABAD: Twenty years after his retirement from the Army in 1990, Major General Ananta Bhanu Gorthi is happy with how he discharged duties in a role that required him to be fair and just.

When he joined the Indian Military Academy in 1956, the 23-year-old from Parvathipuram in Andhra Pradesh, was advised to be part of the Judge Advocate General (JAG) department due to his law background. A Judge Advocate General provides legal advice in court martial cases.

“You are a born marksman,” he was told when he shot bang on the target during his NCC days in college. And this held true throughout his army life. But more than the weapon, his career in the army was about ensuring that law was followed and not allowing it to be misused. Judge Advocate General advises the jury on decisions it should take on individual court martial cases.

The Directorate of Military Intelligence (DMI) had bust a spy racket involving Indian Army officers and men working for the Pakistan Army in 1978. It was Gorthi who pointed out that under Section 18 of the Army Act, the President had powers to terminate their services. Those involved in the spy case denied their role but based on the evidence that had been gathered, they were terminated. The Supreme Court also upheld it.

Gorthi also played an instrumental role in a case related to Operation Blue Star. After the Sikh mutiny in the Indian Army was put down, authorities were contemplating on what should be done with the mutineers.

Gorthi who had risen to become the deputy Judge Advocate General at the headquarters in Delhi, analysed the situation and said those who first misled more than 900 Sikh soldiers had to be identified.

“In the Army, one obeys commands. So it was possible that many just obeyed and joined the mutiny, perhaps not even realising the enormity of the situation,” the 86-year-old told TOI at his residence at Sainikpuri.

Nearly 80 ‘ring leaders’ were separated and given a prison term and terminated. The rest of the soldiers were removed from their parent unit and dispersed into the others after making them realise their mistake. “There was one most important thing that we had to understand. The soldiers were men who were fit and could use weapons. By terminating them, there was a possibility of them turning into terrorists, as they knew how to fire. The issue had to be sensitively handled,” he recalled.

After being appointed the Judge Advocate General, AB Gorthi founded the Institute of Military Law at Kamptee near Nagpur in Maharashtra.

After his retirement from the army, he also served for five years as a member of the Central Administrative Tribunal. Now, at 86, AB Gorthi, does what he loves doing most — swimming and playing golf.

Title: Why it’s important to fix the safety latch in the bull run
Content:
An overkill of jallikattu and the resultant fatigue of participating bulls, and safety risk to people due to e... Read More

CHENNAI: In 2017, it took a week-long, massive — but a leaderless — protest on the Marina promenade to bring jallikattu back from a ban. Now over-enthusiasm to conduct the sport everywhere is threatening to kill it, again.Since the beginning of the Tamil month of Thai on January 15, at least 25 jallikattu events have been conducted in different villages in Tamil Nadu, including the season’s biggest draws at Alanganallur and Palamedu. At each event anywhere between 350 and 700 bulls were made to participate. The Alanganallur jallikattu had to be extended by another 30 minutes to ensure that all registered bulls had their run. The final count was 739. At Vadamayilapur in Pudukottai, nearly 850 bulls were pushed in on Saturday.Lining up 700-800 bulls for a single event is pure avarice. Stretching jallikkattu till the hot months of April and May is invitation for another ban.At jallikattu, a bull gets to run only 50m, and it is over in a couple of minutes. But before it exits the vaadivasal like lightning, the animal is made to stand in queues, at times for more than eight hours. They eat and drink little, but pee and poop more, all the while waiting inside narrow enclosures.Organisers of jallikattu events should never forget the reasons cited by the Supreme Court to ban the event in 2014.Keeping the ‘species’ best interest’ at the centre, the Supreme Court pointedly referred to Sections 3 and 11 of Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (PCA) Act, and said, "they confer no right on the organisers of jallikattu or bullock-cart race, but only duties, responsibilities and obligations, but confer corresponding rights on animals." Citing Article 51A(g) of the Constitution, the court said it cast fundamental duties on every citizen to have "compassion for living creatures".Bulls cannot carry the so-called performance without being exhausted, injured, tortured or humiliated. Bulls are also intentionally subjected to fear, injury — both mentally and physically — and put through unnecessary stress and strain for human pleasure and enjoyment, it said.The PCA Act draws inspiration from the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) guidelines and lists as non-negotiable the animals’ right to freedom from hunger, thirst and malnutrition; freedom from fear and distress; and freedom from physical discomfort. A bull made to stand for hours in the holding area, ahead of its run, and a bull that is driven across the state and made to participate in events well after Pongal, is squarely covered by these freedoms.Instead of risking another ban on jallikattu by falling foul of court rulings, organisers should do at least three things this season. One, the number of participating bulls should be limited to only a couple of hundred. It would also give breathing time for tamers and organisers to take good care of the animals. Two, there shall be statewide registry of jallikattu bulls, and a cap on the number of events a registered bull can participate in a year. Jallikattu events featuring unregistered bulls should be declared illegal and violators should be punished. Three, jallikattu shows should be over by February-end, and not extend till the summer months. Stringent curbs on jallikattu being organised at non-traditional locations and temples can ensure the number of events is limited.An overkill of jallikattu and the resultant fatigue of participating bulls, and safety risk to people due to events in non-traditional ill-equipped venues is a perfect recipe for embargoing the sport. If organisers refuse to wake up to this, the state government must put its foot down and do the needful to save the tradition, sport, bulls and people — all in one stroke.

Title: Gujarat: 26-yr-old woman teacher elopes with Class VIII boy
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Cops in Gandhinagar fell in a catch-22 situation when a state government employee approached them with a complaint that the 26-year-old woman class teacher of his 14-year-old son had gone missing taking his son in tow. The man, who works at Udyog Bhavan in Gandhinagar said the woman had seduced his teenage son, who studies in class VIII and taken him away with her. The boy had gone missing from 4pm on Friday, and the classteacher was also missing.

A police official said the woman teacher had been too intimate with the allegedly missing boy for around a year, and the school authorities had recently rebuked them. “As their relationship was unaccepted, they left their homes on Friday,” he said. It was rare to find a case of a woman teacher eloping with her teenage student, the official added.

An FIR for elopement under Section 363 IPC has been registered with Kalol city police in Gandhinagar district . The complaint stated the teacher is a resident of Darbari chawl in Kalol town.

“When I reached home at around 7pm, I found my son missing. My wife told me he had left home at around 4pm. We searched for him in the neighbourhood and among relatives, but couldn’t trace him,” claims the teenage boy’s father in the FIR. “I went to the teacher’s house but they were not there,” the man stated.

Inspector K K Desai of Kalol city police said the missing duo could not be traced as they were not carrying cellphones.

Title: Pune: Pillion rider dies after bike skids and car runs over her
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A 56-year-old pillion rider was killed after she fell off the motorcycle and was run over by a speeding car on the road towards Akurdi railway station in Nigdi Pradhikaran on Saturday evening.

The Nigdi police have identified the deceased woman as Saraswati Suresh Shinde of More Vasti in Chikhali. Shinde’s son, Ganesh (37), has lodged an FIR with the police.

The police said Ganesh and his mother were driving towards Akurdi railway station on their motorcycle. When they reached Nigdi Pradhikaran around 6.30pm, their motorcycle skidded at a section where road repairs were ongoing. “Ganesh and his mother fell off the motorcycle,” said an officer from the Nigdi police.

He said the driver of a four-wheeler, just behind them, was not able to halt in time and the car’s wheel ran over Saraswati Shinde’s head, killing her on spot. Her son escaped with minor injuries.

Ganesh Shinde was not able to note the vehicle’s registration number. “We have started collecting CCTV footage to identify the car,” the officer said.

Mechanical engineer killed in accident

A 25-year-old mechanical engineer, returning from a German language class, was killed after his motorcycle was hit by a Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) bus. The accident happened on Friday afternoon in Bhosari MIDC.

The police have identified the deceased as Kartik Vijayan Konjupurambil of Bhosari.

An officer said Kartik fell down on impact and his head came under the PMPML bus. The police have registered an offence against the PMPML driver for negligent driving.

Title: Three arrested in Kolhapur for selling fake Army exam question papers
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The Kolhapur police on Sunday arrested three people for allegedly selling fake question papers of the Common Entrance Exam for recruitment into the Indian Army on Sunday.

The action was taken jointly by the Southern Command’s military intelligence liaison unit, the Pune cybercrime cell, and the Kolhapur crime branch in the early hours of Sunday. The suspects have been booked under IPC sections 420 and 34.

Police said the question papers recovered did not match the originals and so, the recruitment exam was held as scheduled on Sunday.

The suspects are residents of Satara and Kolhapur — one of them runs a private training centre in Satara. Police said the suspects sold the fake question papers to 19 aspirants.

The action was taken after Saurabh Kurane of Kolhapur lodged an FIR with the Rajarampuri police station.

“The suspects had taken money from the 19 aspirants under the pretext of helping them sail through the recruitment exam. We have recovered fake question papers from their possession,” Kolhapur superintendent of police Abhinav Deshmukh told TOI over the phone on Sunday.

About 1,800 candidates had appeared for the examination — for all trades — at 109 Territorial Army ground in Kolhapur.

“We strongly suspect the owner of the academy has duped many others in a similar fashion. We will look into this and also verify how many others were involved,” Deshmukh said.

Over 100 private academies, mostly run by ex-servicemen, operate in Western Maharashtra. “Youths in this region are keen on joining the Armed Forces and join these academies. The operators charge each aspirant Rs3-5 lakh, claiming to provide the CEE question paper, assistance in clearing the medical, etc,” said a senior Satara police officer, who investigated a similar case in 2018, said.

Title: Maharashtra: Extra marks deadline now February 15
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The state education department has extended the deadline — for students excelling in classical art, drawing and participation in folk art — to claim extra marks in board examinations from January 15 to February 15 .

The department had issued a government resolution on November 24, 2019, stating that eligible students must submit their proposals by January 15. Now, students can submit their proposals by February 15, while schools must forward them to the divisional board by February 25, said Ashok Bhosale, secretary, Maharashtra State Board Of Secondary And Higher Secondary Education.

In 2016, the education department had reintroduced bonus marks for extracurricular activities for students participating in sports, art, culture, etc. Many students have since scored a perfect 100.

For instance, for students excelling in drawing, 5-15 marks are awarded on the basis of grades in intermediate drawing exams.

Title: Future plans: Ahmedabad's CG Road to get underground parking
Content:
AMC official said more than 100 cars and double the number of two-wheelers will be parked

AHMEDABAD: Even as the planners are on the verge of giving their finishing touches to the now re-imagined boulevard, CG Road , a concern for future parking needs has led them to make provisions for underground parking lots. The nature of the parking lots — mechanised or with a ramp — is yet to be decided.Right now, close to 15,000 people are employed with various establishments on the road. Prior to the revamp, there was on-street parking space for roughly 425 cars and 840 two-wheelers according to Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) estate department officials, which included employees’ parking too. This time, only visitors’ parking for 338 cars and 446 two-wheelers has been provisioned, while the establishments have been left to manage employees’ parking in the basements or hire space at Navrangpura multi-level parking. A copy of the detailed plan with TOI shows provisions for underground parking facility and large space below it for the metrorail. The idea of the street width is inspired by Regent Street, London, or Orchard Road, Singapore. When asked for the capacity of the underground parking facility, an AMC official said more than 100 cars and double the number of two-wheelers will be parked.It was in 2013 that the AMC had first proposed an underground parking lot along with a multilevel parking in the space where the municipal market stands today. “The SPV for undertaking development works on CG Road will be assigned with private stakeholders as partners in the construction of these parking lots,” said the estate department official.The locations of the underground parking lots are yet to be finalised added the AMC official. “The idea is to have no front or side setbacks. Better pedestrian space means better frontage to shops. Footpaths will become meaningful meeting spaces,” he added.

Title: Special train for passenger rush
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

In order to clear the extra rush of passengers after the Sankranti festival, a one-way special train will run between Bhimavaram junction and Secunderabad. Train No. 07255 Bhimavaram junction-Secunderabad special train will depart from Bhimavaram junction at 21.00 hours on January 20 and arrive at Secunderabad at 07.30 hours the next day. The special train will stop at Bhimavaram town, Akividu, Kaikalur, Gudivada, Vijayawada, Guntur, Piduguralla, Miryalaguda and Nalgonda.

Title: 23-year-old knitwear unit employee found murdered
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

TIRUPUR: A 23-year-old man was found murdered among bushes at Velliyangadu in the city on Sunday.

Police identified the deceased as K Arun Kumar of Pattukottaiyar Nagar, who was working in a knitwear unit. “He had left his house on Friday. Several injuries were found on the body,” a police officer said.

Preliminary investigations revealed that Kumar had left his house after someone phoned him. “His family members thought that he would have gone out with his friends and would return soon. We are yet to find the motive behind the crime,” said the officer. The Tirupur south police registered a case and are investigating the incident. The body was sent to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital for postmortem.

Title: 16,000 litres rectified spirit seized from farmhouse
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

PEWn police have seized more than 16,000 litres of rectified spirit from a farmhouse near Cheyur in Avinashi t... Read More

TIRUPUR: The district Prohibition Enforcement Wing (PEW) police have seized more than 16,000 litres of rectified spirit from a farmhouse near Cheyur in Avinashi taluk based on the intelligence inputs from the Kerala police.

According to an official source, Central Investigation Unit (CIU) officials from Salem and Tirupur PEW police conducted a raid at the farmhouse in Chinnakanur on Saturday based on a tip from the Kerala police that the house was being used to store rectified spirit.

“The Kerala police had a few days ago seized around 3,000 liters of rectified spirit near Chalakudy in Thrissur district. The accused told them that the spirit was taken from Cheyur,” the source said.

During the search, the team recovered 16,000 litres of rectified spirit and booked two people - farm house owner S Ganesan, of Annur in Coimbatore district , and his tenant Jagan alias Janarthanan, 57, of Alathur, in Palakkad district.

The source said Janarthanan was running a bakery in Annur. “He told Ganesan that he was involved in vegetable and fertilizer trading and rented the house to be used as a godown. The team seized 434 cans, each with 35-litre capacity, of rectified spirit from the house.”

While the team has arrested Ganesan, Janarthanan is on the run.

K Gunasekaran, additional superintendent of police, Tirupur PEW, said Janarthanan was already facing two cases for smuggling spirit into Avinashi in 2012. “Usually, spirit is smuggled into Kerala from northern states. It is either mixed with toddy or used to make alcohol. Due to tightened vigil, the smugglers transport the spirit in the guise of daily commodities and store it in Tamil Nadu districts bordering Kerala. It would then be taken to Kerala in small quantities.”

Title: Pune Municipal Corporation told to follow plan set by experts, replant 162 trees
Content:
The NGT has directed PMC strictly adhere to the tree plantation

PUNE: The National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) to strictly adhere to the tree plantation, re-plantation and cutting plan as mentioned in an inspection report furnished by an expert panel to facilitate a road widening project between Cummins College and Mahalaxmi Lawns in Karvenagar.Papillon Condominium, a society near Maharshi Karve Stree Shikshan Sanstha (MKSSS), had filed an application against the PMC’s move to cut 250 century-old trees along this stretch for road widening, without having a proper plan. It claimed the authorities were not serious about exploring options like an apt transplantation plan or freeing up the road stretch of encroachments to create space and avoid tree felling.The society pointed out that a significant number of these trees belong to the MKSSS and many of them were planted by its founder and great social reformer Maharshi Dhondo Keshav Karve.The felling of the trees would cause an irreparable loss to a vital green lung of the city, the society complained. The NGT had then assigned an expert panel, comprising members of the Tree Authority and the PMC, among others, for inspecting the site and submitting a report.In its report to the green tribunal, the panel stated, “..... inspection is carried out in accordance with the permission granted for cutting of 88 trees and replanting 162 trees at Mahalaxmi Lawns (Panand Road) 15mts DP Road, Karvenagar, Pune and planting 750 trees in lieu thereof and in view of interest of citizens, a report is hereby given that development of 15mts road is required with immediate effect by completing the process of tree plantation, tree replantation and tree cutting etc.”The NGT bench of Justice S P Wangdi and expert member Siddhanta Das disposed of the matter by stating in an order on January 16 (Thursday), “Considering the facts and circumstances in the report, we do not find any reason as to why we should not accept it. .... We direct the Pune Municipal Corporation to act strictly in accordance with the findings and observations contained in the report and the recommendations made therein.”

Title: PB keeps mum on UAPA arrests
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The CPM politburo (PB), which on Sunday prepared a long reply to the issues that came up in the three-day session of the central committee (CC), conveniently ignored the criticism against the arrest of two CPM workers in Kozhikode by the state police under UAPA charges.

The arrest of Allan Shuhaib and Thwaha Fazal and subsequent NIA probe was raised in the committee by a few members who are learned to have told about the complaints they received against the Pinarayi Vijayan government’s handling of the case. Though there were not many takers for the issue in the committee, the CC members expected a reply to the criticism levelled by the members from party general secretary Sitaram Yechury during the latter’s reply for the debate. However, Yechury didn’t touch upon the issue.

Sources in the CPM said that the PB meeting held in the morning decided not to respond to the issue as that would shift focus from the major agenda of massive protests being planned against the Centre. In fact, nobody in the PB wanted to offend CM Pinarayi Vijayan, who had been the host of this edition of CC meeting. With the NIA taking over the probe, party intervention would have no impact on the case either.

Later in the day, while addressing a news conference, Yechury claimed that the party’s position still is against UAPA, which is particularly draconian in nature. “It puts the onus on the accused to prove his innocence. But since the law is on the roll, there is no option but to obey,” Yechury said.

He said he was aware of the arrest of youths under the UAPA but insisted that the state government has little role in dealing with such cases. He added that the actions of state police need not to be analogous to CPMs policies. “Police are supposed to go by the law, not party policy,” he said.

Title: Locals protest against mushrooming of liquor stores
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: Ahead of the municipal corporation elections, Boduppal residents also raised concerns over mushrooming of liquor stores in the vicinity of residential areas.

According to residents, five liquor stores have been set up on a one-kilometer stretch ahead of the Boduppal Ambedkar Statue towards Hema Nagar.

Three months go, a massive protest was held by the residents seeking removal of the liquor stores being operated near a hospital and school. “A liquor store has been constructed illegally on a nala. Over the past few months, two new shops have been set up on the same stretch. A large number of people consume liquor on the road,” said a resident.

The issue plagues many colonies such as Veera Reddy Nagar Colony, Buddha Nagar Colony and Annapurna Colony. While multiple representations have been submitted by to the Boduppal Municipal Corporation, residents claim that little action has been initiated to shift or remove these liquor stores from residential areas. “@Rachakonda_tfc In Boduppal, in 1 sq km area, there are five wine shops/bar & restaurants. This area is predominantly residential, schools, temples and municipal office. Large number of people consume liquor & create public nuisance. Any action proposed?,” tweeted Suryanarayana M, a resident of Sri Sai Nagar Colony.

Title: 2,895 driving licences suspended for traffic rules violations
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: As Nagpur district witnessed 4.87 lakh traffic violations, the three regional transport offices in the district have suspended 2,895 driving licences for upto six months across Nagpur district for serious traffic offences like overspeeding, drunken driving, jumping signals and using mobile phones while driving in 2019. It translates to only 0.59% violators losing their licence.

With support from regional transport offices in the district, Nagpur city and rural traffic police have decided to come down heavily on repeat offenders, particularly for drunken driving, signal jumping, overspeeding and using mobile phone while driving.

According to data obtained from city, deputy east and rural regional transport offices, City RTO Dinkar Manwar’s office suspended highest number of licences at 1,512 for various offences. Rural RTO Shripand Wadekar’s office suspended 761 driving licences while east office headed by deputy RTO Vinod Jadhav suspended 622 licences.

Last year, both city and rural traffic police issued 4,87,530 challans for various violations. Over 22,484 motorists were challaned for drunk-driving and 44,075 for signal-jumping, while 21,566 penalised for using mobile phones while driving.

All three transport offices suspended 1,702 driving licences of drivers/riders caught for drunk driving, while 374 motorists faced suspension for signal jumping. As many as 275 and 120 motorists faced similar actions for using mobile phones while driving and overspeeding.

“These are serious offences and risk lives of fellow motorists. We started forwarding driving licences of motorists repeating these violations to RTOs for suspension. We want to send strong message that breaking laws won’t be tolerated,” said a senior cop from the office of deputy commissioner of police (traffic) Chinmay Pandit. As all e-challans are digitally stored, tracking down repeat offenders has become easy for police now.

Traffic activists stressed the need for round the clock drives against speeding, drunk driving, riding without helmets, using mobile phones while driving, signal-jumping and lane-cutting. “We must discipline motorists, as in most accidents, human error is the cause,” they said.

LICENCES SUSPENDED

Top Offences----City RTO------dy east ----------------------- Rural RTO

Drunk driving ---1,048---320----334

Overspeeding---51--47----22

Signal jumping---271---76---27

Mobile talking---142---93---40

TOP CASES

Offences---City Police commissionerate----Rural SP Jurisdiction

Overspeeding---682---557

Drunk driving---19,906---2,578

Red light jumping---44,075---00

Using mobile phone---19,370---2,196

Title: Uttarakhand schools to show live telecast of PM’s ‘Exam pe Charcha’ today
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

In Uttarakhand, schools have been ordered to show the live telecast on computer screens, TVs or projectors, wh... Read More

DEHRADUN: There will be 11 students from Uttarakhand present at Talkatora Stadium in New Delhi on Monday, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi will address students from across India before their board exams. The state education department has issued guidelines to all chief education officers to ensure all schools play the live telecast of the programme.

Mukul Kumar Sati, state additional project director (education) told TOI orders were issued to chief education officers of all 13 districts in the state to make arrangements for live telecast of the PM’s address.

“We want students of Class IX-XII to watch the live telecast of the programme. The expenditure incurred to make arrangements for the live telecast will be borne by the district level head of the education department,” said Sati, adding the live telecast will be shown in 2,317 government inter-colleges and schools affiliated with the state board.

The state has around 23,000 schools. Even Central Board of Secondary Education and other boards have issued similar guidelines to schools following their curriculum.

In Uttarakhand, schools have been ordered to show the live telecast on computer screens, TVs or projectors, whichever is available. Around 500 schools in the state, which have virtual classes, will show the same via live session organised by the education department.

“Schools which can’t make these arrangements have been ordered to use transistors,” said the official, adding that Uttarakhand education minister Arvind Pandey will follow the speech at a school in US Nagar, as the Union HRD ministry has asked education ministers of all states to participate in the programme by attending any school.

“Education minister Arvind Pandey will follow the ‘ Exam pe Charcha ’ event with 2,000 students at Udayraj Hindu inter-college in Kashipur,” he added.

Title: City zoo: Corporation gets last chance to comply with CZA guidelines
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

CZA has also directed the corporation to update the project developments regularly and warned of stern action ... Read More

COIMBATORE: A year after dereognising the VOC Park mini zoo in the city, the central zoo authority (CZA) has given the city corporation a chance to comply with its guidelines by submitting a detailed project report (DPR) before May 31.

CZA has also directed the corporation to update the project developments regularly and warned of stern action if it fails to comply with the norms, said a source familiar with the development.

The directions were passed during the recent meeting held in New Delhi after the civic body informed that it had acquired 29 acres for expanding the zoo.

The central government body has been directing the corporation to submit a detailed layout of the proposed site for zoo relocation and the year-wise plan of shifting the animals since 2007 after it was identified that the zoo was functioning in a very small space.

“But till date, the corporation has not taken any productive step to address the space crunch. It has only enhanced the suffering of the animals, birds and reptiles caged there.
