CZA had refused to renew the recognition to the zoo several times. But the corporation did nothing and sought more time to prepare the report,” said the source.

The source said that CZA had renewed the recognition twice – once in 2011 for two years and in 2016 for a year – giving a chance for the corporation to comply with the norms. As the corporation failed to follow its directions, CZA refused to grant recognition until the guidelines were met and taking it a step further, cancelled the recognition in November 2018.

As many as 34 violations pertaining to animal housing, display of animals and animal enclosures, veterinary and infrastructure facilities, acquisition and breeding of animals, healthcare of the animals, and visitors’ facilities were recorded, according to the report submitted by CZA’s technical committee. The report stated that some of the violations were recorded in 1996.

“Even though a year has passed since the violations were pointed out and the recognition was cancelled, the corporation has not corrected them,” the source added.

Meanwhile, a corporation official told TOI that the civic body has decided to develop the zoo on the prison campus land it owns and upgrade it under the smart city mission.

But city-based activists flayed the civic body for delaying the work, saying that it shows a lack of interest and proper guidance. “A lot of students and animal enthusiasts visit the zoo to learn more about the animals. If the corporation further delays the project, the chances are high that CZA might permanently close the facility. So, the corporation should speed up the process or they should hand it over to the forest department, which can run it efficiently,” said Ni Jalaludin, president of the Nature Conservative Society.

Title: Pune: 2.49 lakh kids administered new oral polio vaccine
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: As many as 2,48,685 lakh children under five years of age in the city received the bivalent oral polio vaccine (bOPV) under the mass campaign on Sunday. The vaccine provides protection against polio virus 1 and 3.

“We want to vaccinate 2.80 lakh children under five years of age in the city. We will focus on the unvaccinated kids in the city from January 20. Our staff will pay door-to-door visits. The high risk areas will be given special attention, including migratory population like nomads, brick kiln worker, construction site worker and slum-dwellers,” immunisation officer Amit Shah of PMC said. A total 4,351 ground health staff was involved in Sunday’s campaign.

Title: NIMS doctor dies of cardiac arrest in London
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Dr AK Meena

HYDERABAD: A senior neurologist from Nizam’s Institute of Medical Sciences (NIMS), Dr AK Meena, suffered a massive cardiac arrest while speaking at the Neurology Conference in London on Thursday. The 54-year-old doctor was given cardio pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) immediately after she collapsed and was rushed to St Bartholomew’s Hospital. She was kept on ventilator support and later declared brain dead on Friday.

In another incident, a 36-year-old gynaecologist, Satya Ramana, collapsed after completing a surgery in Nalgonda on Friday and succumbed.

The two incidents were reported within a span of 24 hours, raising questions about the health condition of doctors, which experts say is often ignored. Previous studies have shown that a major cause of death of doctors is cardiac arrest, followed by brain stroke and suicide. In both these cases, the sudden event is believed to have been triggered by stress and ignoring crucial symptoms.

“In the case of Dr Meena, the ischemic attack is possible only when there are existing clots. There have been previous cases of sudden collapse. In all those cases, stress has been a major factor. Apart from that, factors like doctors being blamed if anything goes wrong after a surgery also weighs on their mind. Commercialisation and corporatisation of hospitals and inadequate communication with patients add to the problem,” said Dr Sanjeev Singh Yadav, secretary general, Indian Medical Association (IMA), Telangana .

Many studies suggest that doctors tend to ignore their symptoms. A study by IMA showed that doctors died much earlier than an average citizen. While an average person lived up to 72 years, doctors lived up to 59 years on an average. The study had concluded that doctors died earlier because they neglected their health.

“Doctors work under very high levels of stress and often ignore their own health. Most doctors, in fact, die younger due to cardiac arrest,” said Dr Ashish Chauhan, preventive medicine expert, adding that the family and spouse of doctors have an important role in reducing their stress.

Title: Police find imitation jewellery at Goodwin shop
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: Nearly two months registering a case against the managing director, director and staff of Goodwin Jewellers’ Bund Garden Road outlet, the Pune and Thane police have jointly searched the premises, only to recover just imitation jewellery and silver ornaments.

The search was conducted on Thursday. The Koregaon Park police had sealed the shop on November 6, 2019, after booked Goodwin MD Sunil Kumar, his brother — and director — Sudheer Kumar, and some local staffers under the charges of cheating and criminal breach of trust. The matter was handed over to the economic offences wing (EOW), which has since received 380 complaint applications from people across the city, who had invested in the jewellery firm’s investment and fixed deposit schemes.

The city police’s action came after the Thane police registered a similar case. “As of now, the Kumar brothers have been remanded in the custody of the Navi Mumbai police in another cheating case,” ACP (EOW) Shivaji Pawar told TOI.

Thursday’s search operation yielded no genuine gold jewellery. “We seized imitation jewellery and some silver, totally worth Rs4,000,” Pawar said.

As many as nine complaints have been lodged with the Thane (rural), Thane (city), Palghar, Mumbai, Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad police. Nothing was found at the shop in Chinchwad either, police said.

Police told TOI that the jewellery from the shops was shifted months before the cases were registered. “We are trying to trace the ornaments,” Pawar said.

Title: Blind people demand promotion
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Coimbatore: Members of the National Federation of the Blind (NFB) are seeking promotions in reserved posts.

Blind people are getting promotions in reserved seats only sporadically and that too only after lengthy legal battles, NFB project director for south India P Manoharan said. “People with disabilities are given 4% reservation in government jobs, of which 1% is for blind people. The same applies for promotions also. But the majority of the people, who get government jobs through reservation, are not given promotions. According to the state government, reservation is only for the job and not promotions,” he said.

In addition to this, promotion exams for the blind people are not arranged easily with the excuse of unavailability of scribes, the official said. “NFB has been fighting for this legally.”

“There is no proper statistics from the state as to what is the actual number of blind people in reserved posts. According to statistics given by the state on the total number of government posts, there should be 2,500 blind people in reserved posts. But, as per our calculations, there are less than 1,000 people,” Manoharan said.

Title: Car collides with train, one dies
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The accident occurred at Mithoi in Jamnagar on Sunday

Rajkot: One person was killed and two seriously injured when their car was dragged along with a goods train after colliding with it while crossing an unmanned railway crossing in Mithoi village of Lalpur taluka in Jamnagar district on Sunday afternoon.

“They tried to cross the tracks despite seeing the train approaching. The car got dragged along with the train for nearly 200 foot,” said D S Vadher, sub-inspector with Meghpar Padana police station.

The victims were identified as Dharmadeepsinh Chudasma (21), Arjunsinh Jadeja (21) and Divyarajsinh Jadeja (14).

While Dharamdeepsinh and Arjunsinh were rushed to GG Hospital, Divyarajsinh was taken to a private hospital in Jamnagar. While Dharamdeepsinh succumbed to his injuries, Arjunsinh and Divyarajsinh are battling for lives.

Police found invitation cards for marriage from the car and concluded that the victims were going to distribute the cards among their friends and relatives.

Title: Bridge collapses into river in Dharchula
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

DHARCHULA ( PITHORAGARH ): Two persons were injured after the bridge over Dhauli River at Tawaghat on the Indo-Nepal border collapsed into the water . Connectivity in the area was disrupted due to the accident. The injured people are now said to be out of danger.

The incident took place when a truck carrying an excavator machine from Dharchula to Pangla was passing the bridge. The load proved to be too much for the bridge, as it gave way.

District information officer Girija Shankar Joshi told TOI that two persons, including the truck driver, were injured in the accident. While the driver was identified as 40-year-old Surendra Kumar from Punjab , his helper was identified as Naveen Singh, 32, a resident of Himachal Pradesh. “Both the driver and his helper were taken to Primary Health Centre, Dharchula, for first aid, from where they were taken to the district hospital in Pithoragarh. Their situation is out of danger,” Joshi said.

After the bridge collapsed, people built a makeshift bridge over the river as it has shallow water at this time of the year.

Title: Gwalior gharana exponent, singer Sunanda Patnaik dies in Kolkata
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Sunanda Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: Noted Indian classical singer Sunanda Patnaik , reverentially referred to as ‘Guruma’, passed away in Kolkata’s Salt Lake on Sunday. She was 85.

Sunanda, the daughter of poet Baikunthanath Patnaik, was born in Cuttack and began her singing career with All India Radio at the tender age of 14. She was known for her high-pitched renditions and melodious voice.

Trained by Kundala Adi Narayana and later by Vinayak Rao Patwardhan of the Gwalior gharana in Pune, she received a master’s degree in music in 1956. She also received a scholarship in music from the country’s first President, Rajendra Prasad.

Sunanda was as adept at singing bhajans in Hindi and Odia as she was in pure classical. Her Jagannath bhajans — particularly ‘jeevana patra mo bharichha kete, mate’, which was written by her father — still remain popular in the state.

The Cuttack-born singer has received countless awards including the Odisha Sangeet Natak Akademi award in 1970 and 1971, the Indian Lifetime Achievement award in 2009 and the lifetime achievement award from the Orissa Society of the Americas in 2012. She also received the Sangeet Natak Akademi award (Tagore Akademi Puraskar) in 2012. A film on her life — ‘Nilamadhaba’ — produced by the Films Division received the national award for best documentary in 2011.

Governor Ganeshi Lal, chief minister Naveen Patnaik, union ministers Dharmendra Pradhan and Pratap Sarangi and state ministers Jyoti Prakash Panigrahi and Ashok Chandra Panda expressed grief at her passing.

“I am deeply saddened by the death of noted singer Sunanda Patnaik. Her place will always be special in the field of classical music. I heartfelt condolences with the bereaved family,” the chief minister tweeted.

Sunanda, a spinster, moved to Kolkata in 1983, where she launched a music institute, Vishnu Vinayak Sangeet Ashram, to teach Hindustani classical to students.

Title: One more airline stops service from Trivandrum International Airport
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Trivandrum International Airport

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Even as the development plans of the Trivandrum International Airport are yet to take off, one more airline has decided to withdraw its services from the airport. Malindo Air, based in Kuala Lumpur, which operates three flights between Thiruvananthapuram and Kuala Lumpur, has stopped its reservation facility for the schedule beyond June 6. Fly Dubai had suspended its operations from the airport and Saudia had shifted its operations to Kannur International Airport last year. “The decision to withdraw services from Thiruvananthapuram is an internal matter. There are only three services from Thiruvananthapuram in a week, while there are daily services from Cochin International Airport. Demand is good from Thiruvananthapuram, but the airlines get more passengers from Kochi,” said a staff of Malindo Airlines. The Airport Authority of India, which had decided to outsource the airport’s management operations last year is yet to complete the process. While, the bids were opened in February 2019, the awarding of tender got delayed after protests were raised against the privatization of the airport and cases were filed. A group of airport users have begun an online petition requesting Malindo Airlines to not stop its services from Thiruvananthapuram. “Hundreds of Indians and Malaysians of Indian origin with ties to Kerala and Tamil Nadu will be deprived of direct access since Thiruvananthapuram airport caters to the southern districts of these states. It will also impact tourism traffic from and to Thiruvananthapuram and Kuala Lumpur. Hundreds of regular passengers using the route, including senior citizens and young families, will now be forced to take alternative routes such as Chennai and Kochi,” states the petition. Kollam MP N K Premachandran, who had taken up the matter of the privatisation of the airport with the central government, said there is a private lobby working behind the cancellation of flights from Trivandrum International Airport. “There is deliberate attempt to reduce the number of flight operations from Thiruvananthapuram and relocate these services to Kochi and Kannur. Trivandrum airport is profitable and major developments are proposed. The government filed a case before the high court against the tender for PPP development of the airport, which was a futile attempt after losing the bid. If the government had not filed the case, the tendering process would have been completed earlier,” he said. “I am informed that the process is on but the government is held up with other matters,” said S N Raghuchandran Nair, chairman of Airport Users Consultative Committee. According to an airport official at the operations wing, no official communication has been received from Malindo Airlines on the cancellation of services. “Presently, the airline is operating winter schedule. Airlines are likely to inform about change in services during summer three months before the schedule. We have not received any such communication,” said the official.

Title: IMC starts trial of SCADA system
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Indore: As part of plans to monitor and control supply of Narmada water through Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition ( SCADA ) system, Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) has now started trial of this system at nearly half a dozen overhead tanks. The list of these tanks includes overhead tanks of Ret Mandi, Chandan Nagar, Kila Maidan, Scheme 103 among others.

Narmada Project's superintendent engineer Sanjeev Shrivastava said that they have installed control valves and flow meters at these overhead tanks to record inlet and outlet supply of Narmada water, and their feed has also been linked with SCADA control and command centre to collect data on real time.

“We have started testing this system, which would take about a week or so. Once completed, this system which works on hydraulic modelling, would allow us to collect comprehensive data on flow of water in feeder and distribution pipelines,” he said, adding that supply of all these tank would be managed and operated from command and control centre.

He said that households that receive supply from these tanks are also being equipped with meters.

Shrivastava said that they are working on implementing the same system at around 200 centres, which includes 86 existing tanks, 27 new tanks, construction of which is underway, pump house at Mandaleshwar, Yeshwant Sagar, Bilawali Lake and Devdharam filter station.

He said that in total, they will be controlling water flow and collecting related data from about 200 locations.

“By January end, we will start collecting data from 40 overhead tanks and by end of February, we will have control and data collection system implemented at all these locations,” he said.

Officials said that this system will allow them to curb loss of water as well as revenue. “This will give us a fair idea about consumption and demand of water in each and every area of city. Besides, it will also allow us to control and regulate supply remotely,” they said.

Title: School education department collects details of Class V, VIII students
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: School education department officials have been collecting details of Class V and Class VIII students who would be appearing for board exams from the district, to be uploaded on the website of the directorate of government examinations (DGE).

The DGE had earlier directed the chief education officers in all the districts to collect the total number of students, who would write the board exams that would be held for the first time this year, and their details and upload them on its website within January 25.

Title: MSEDCL ups its price to woo solar power makers
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: In view of the poor response to its tender for buying 1,350MW solar power, state discom MSEDCL has increased the maximum price to attract producers.

The company had floated tenders for buying 1,350MW with a cap of Rs3.15 per unit but got bids for only 5MW. Now it has increased the cap to Rs3.30 per unit and floated the tender again.

The developers will have to set up solar projects, including the transmission and distribution network, up to the delivery point at their own cost. It will also include acquiring necessary approvals, permits and clearances.

The projects would be selected regardless of the technology used in the solar modules and irrespective of whether they come with trackers or not.

The last date for bid submission is January 29, 2020, and both the technical and commercial bids will be opened on the same date.

All bidders must submit an earnest money deposit (EMD) of Rs1 lakh per MW of quoted bid capacity.

Meanwhile, MSEDCL has floated another tender for buying 500MW. The ceiling price for this tender is Rs2.9 per unit. When MSEDCL didn’t get a response at Rs3.15 per unit, how was it expecting bidders at Rs2.9 per unit?.

The poor response to its solar tenders bodes ill for MSEDCL. Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC) has issued a draft policy announcing its renewable purchase obligation from 2020 to 2025. The solar targets mentioned in the policy draft will start at 4.5% in 2020-21 and go up to 13.5% over the next five years.

MSEDCL has protested stating that the commission’s proposal to revise the solar target to 13.5% by 2024-25 was quite stiff and that despite best efforts, it would not be able to achieve it. Total solar capacity of 12,500MW would be required by 2024-25 to achieve the target against the present capacity of 4,200MW. The competitive bidding process to expand the capacity takes a lot of time and there were many other factors beyond its control, the discom said.

While protesting the target, MSEDCL is doing its best to scuttle solar rooftop, which can help it in meeting the MERC target. The discom has proposed astronomical grid supply charge (GSC) on rooftop consumers, which will make solar unviable.

Title: Khan acting like Centre’s agent: Muneer
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kozhikode: IUML leader and the deputy leader of Opposition in the assembly, M K Muneer has said governor Arif Mohammad Khan has been intervening in various issues in an excessively political manner.

Speaking at a press meet here on Sunday, Muneer said, “Khan was speaking as if he is the representative of the central government alone and has nothing to do with the state of which he is the governor.”

Referring to governor’s criticism of the resolution by the assembly against the CAA, Muneer said it was well within the right of the assembly to pass a resolution against the controversial act which violated many provisions of the Constitution. “Many state assemblies in the country are planning to pass resolutions against the CAA,” he said.

Muneer pointed out that the assembly had earlier passed resolution in 2017 against a notification by the central government restricting the sale of cattle for slaughter in animal market.

Muneer added that CAA protests have transcended political and religious confines to become a mass movement in the country.

Muneer said he will undertake a 12-hour fast on Tuesday against the CAA in Kozhikode. tnn

Title: Gwalior gharana exponent, singer Sunanda Patnaik dies in Kolkata
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Sunanda Patnaik

BHUBANESWAR: Noted Indian classical singer Sunanda Patnaik , reverentially referred to as ‘Guruma’, passed away in Kolkata’s Salt Lake on Sunday. She was 85.

Sunanda, the daughter of poet Baikunthanath Patnaik, was born in Cuttack and began her singing career with All India Radio at the tender age of 14. She was known for her high-pitched renditions and melodious voice.

Trained by Kundala Adi Narayana and later by Vinayak Rao Patwardhan of the Gwalior gharana in Pune, she received a master’s degree in music in 1956. She also received a scholarship in music from the country’s first President, Rajendra Prasad.

Sunanda was as adept at singing bhajans in Hindi and Odia as she was in pure classical. Her Jagannath bhajans — particularly ‘jeevana patra mo bharichha kete, mate’, which was written by her father — still remain popular in the state.

The Cuttack-born singer has received countless awards including the Odisha Sangeet Natak Akademi award in 1970 and 1971, the Indian Lifetime Achievement award in 2009 and the lifetime achievement award from the Orissa Society of the Americas in 2012. She also received the Sangeet Natak Akademi award (Tagore Akademi Puraskar) in 2012. A film on her life — ‘Nilamadhaba’ — produced by the Films Division received the national award for best documentary in 2011.

Sunanda, a spinster, moved to Kolkata in 1983, where she launched a music institute, Vishnu Vinayak Sangeet Ashram, to teach Hindustani classical to students.

Title: Ram Jhula in dark for months as lighting fails in 3 days
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Installed at the cost of around Rs 70 lakh in August last year, the lighting system to illuminate city’s iconic twin bridges — the Ram Jhula— went off after working for just three days. Two Road Overbridges (ROBs) are awaiting illumination for want of proper power supply for the last five months.

Maharashtra State Road Development Corporation (MSRDC) that built the bridges had installed the illumination system as part of the project. It was on the lines of illumination of Howrah bridge.

The illumination was supposed to be there since its opening. One part of Ram Jhula was inaugurated in December 2014 and second part in January 2019. But Mumbai based company building it, Afcons Infrastructure, installed and commissioned the lighting system only in August 2019.

MSRDC sources told TOI two ROBs were illuminated for all of 3 days in August. “Afcons appointed two city-based agencies for supplying and installing lighting system. 128 LED lights were installed on cables of two ROBs. An automatic programme with a panel was set up in a room below Ram Jhula at the cost of around Rs 70 lakh. Lighting can be programmed in 12 colour combinations. Life of lighting system is 40,000 hours. That means illumination will last 12 years if used for nine hours every night,” sources said.

MSRDC sources added Afcons was yet to release payment of two agencies. An MSRDC official told TOI Afcons was responsible for operation and maintenance of lighting system along with other works on Ram Jhula for five years of defect liability period (DLP). “We will ensure problem is resolved from MSEDCL side and its continuous operation by Afcons,” the official said.

Afcons spokesperson told TOI, “Afcons completed and handed over Ram Jhula to MSRDC in January 2019. The illumination work was thoroughly checked and approved by MSRDC and consultant RITES. We had informed MSDRC only single-phase power supply was available for lighting system as against need for three-phase supply. Therefore, lights were turned off as safety precaution. MSEDCL later informed Afcons the single-phase power supply was temporary as three-phase connection was hindered due to Metro Rail construction at Santra market.”

However, MSEDCL spokesperson denied there was any problem from MSEDCL side. “We have not received any application or complaint from MSRDC or Afcons about power supply of Ram Jhula. Streetlight on Ram Jhula is continuously in operation,” he said.

BJP corporator Dayashankar Tiwari said power supply cannot be a reason for keeping illumination off. “I receive regular complaints about no streetlight on Ram Jhula after 11pm. I talked to officials of MSRDC, NMC and MSEDCL and ensured streetlights were working throughout the night. Ram Jhula witnesses huge traffic all the time so special care is required for its maintenance,” he said.

———————————-

IAN

* Lighting system was commissioned on Ram Jhula in August 2019

* It has 128 LED lights with 12 colour combinations and a programme to control it

* Illumination went off three days after commissioning

* Afcons says illumination requires 3-phase power supply but only single-phase is available

* MSRDC says MSEDCL citing problems of Metro Rail works

* MSEDCL says there is no application or complaint from MSRDC or Afcons

* MSRDC ensuring streetlights are on but cites power supply problem about illumination

Title: Farmer held for killing peafowls in Coimbatore
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: A farmer has been arrested for poisoning nine peafowls to death at his agricultural field near RG Pudur on Saturday evening.

The accused was identified as M Kanagaraj of RG Pudur near Chinniyampalayam. “He owns three acres of agricultural field and had sowed beetroot seeds on two acres a week ago. As the seeds were germinating, a flock of peafowls destroyed them. Kanagaraj sprayed pesticides and insecticide on the field on Saturday. Nine peafowls that ate the seeds died of poisoning. He tried to set the carcasses on fire on the field. Coimbatore forest range officer Siva, who got a tip-off about the incident, reached the field on Saturday around 5.30pm with his team and arrested the farmer,” a forest department official said.

The team also seized nine charred birds. Kanagaraj was booked under sections 2, 16 and 31 of the Wild Life Protection Act 1972, remanded in judicial custody and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

“Veterinarians have collected samples from the carcasses and they will be sent to the regional forensic science laboratory at Race Course to find out the type of poison,” the official added.

Title: Gujarat: Five of family, NRI couple killed in two road accidents
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Mangled remains of the SUV which crashed into a dumper killing five people on Sunday

RAJKOT: Eight persons , including an NRI couple , were killed in two separate accidents that happened within a span of just one hour on Limbdi-Ahmedabad highway early on Sunday morning.

In the first accident, five persons were killed when their SUV jumped the divider and crashed into a dumper coming from the opposite direction in the other lane of the highway. The accident happened near Devpara village of Limbdi taluka in Surendranagar district.

“It appears that the driver of the SUV dozed off while driving, following which the SUV lost control, jumped the divider and crashed into the dumper coming from the opposite direction in the other lane of the highway,” said Hitendrasinh Vala, head constable with Panshina police station.

The deceased identified as Bhavani Nagendra (42), Subramanyam Tambaram (52), his wife Rajeshri (49), Ganesh Subramanyam (22) and Akil Prasad (18) were from the same family. Five persons were also injured in the accident. Nagendra Prasad, a make-up artist with a Gujarati news channel in Ahmedabad, was taking his family members, who had come from Andhra Pradesh, on a pilgrimage to Somnath. Bhavani was his wife. The injured were taken to a private hospital in Ahmedabad.

The second accident was reported from near Mithapar village near Bagodara in Ahmedabad district where three persons were killed as their SUV rammed into the rear of a dumper just ahead of it.

“It appears that the driver of the ill-fated SUV could not spot the lights of the dumper and crashed into its rear,” said an official from Bagodara police station.

The deceased included two Kenya-based NRIs — Ketan Haria (55) and his wife Kundan (54). The driver of the SUV, identified as Hiren Doshi (49), was also killed in the accident. Ketan and his wife were natives of Machhuberaja village of Jamnagar’s Lalpur taluka. They had come here to attend some social function and were returning to Ahmedabad.

Title: Bengaluru: Palike flattens 300 huts of ‘illegal Bangladeshi immigrants’
Content:
Only children and the aged were in the sheds when BBMP men swooped down on the tenements

BENGALURU: Presuming that all residents of shantytowns in Kariyammana Agrahara and two other places in Bellandur were “illegal Bangladeshi immigrants”, BBMP on Sunday conducted a massive demolition drive and pushed at least 300 families to the streets. They included several people who had come to Bengaluru from flood-ravaged North Karnataka in search of a livelihood.BBMP officials confirmed 300 huts were demolished, which had come up on private properties. The eviction drive took the residents unawares. Scores of earthmovers arrived in front of their settlements in the morning when most had left for work. Only children, the infirm and the aged were there in many of the shanties, activists said.Parvathamma, who lived in one of the demolished huts, told TOI she is from a village in Kalaburagi district and came to Bengaluru three months ago. She said her family owned no land in the village and got no work on a regular basis, forcing her to move to Bengaluru with her husband and kids.Lekha Adavi, an advocate-activist, said, “It was an illegal drive; BBMP never consulted the dwellers. Did it conduct a survey to find out who was living in the area? There were residents of north Karnataka who had moved to the city after severe floods, and people from Bihar and West Bengal and other parts of the country. I am shocked how BBMP came to a conclusion that everyone were illegal Bangladesh immigrants.”A BBMP assistant executive engineer of Marathahalli sub-division had on Saturday written to police, saying the temporary sheds erected by illegal Bangladeshi nationals in Bellandur had to be removed and sought police protection. DCP (Whitefield) MN Anucheth said, “We got a requistion letter from BBMP to provide police protection and we gave it.”BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar appeared to be in the dark about the eviction drive and the correspondence between his officials and police. Kumar even claimed there was no such drive. “The Mahadevapura joint commissioner confirmed it to me; he is not allowed to conduct an eviction drive without bringing it to my notice. We are clear about it,” he said.Activists said no prior notice was given to residents before the evacuation drive. But police and BBMP officials on the spot claimed notice was given to the landowners and Bescom had cut off power connections, which were illegal in nature.On January 12, police and Mahadevapura corporators visited Kariyammana Agrahara to get details about undocumented Bangladeshi immigrants suspected to be living there. Mahadevapura MLA Arvind Limbavali had tweeted that some immigrants from Bangladesh had taken shelter in the locality and their sheds had become a haven for illegal activities. The MLA had said the authorities were instructed to act against the illegal settlement.In Video: Bengaluru: BBMP flattens 300 huts of ‘illegal Bangladeshi immigrants’

Title: Sportsman spirit should always prevail in politics: Scindia
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Indore: There should be no politics on playground, but sportsman spirit should always prevail in politics, said senior Congress leader Jyotiraditya Scindia, who inaugurated the newly renovated Scindia Pavilion of the historical cricket ground on Daly College premises on Sunday.

This 110-year-old pavilion has been revamped to international standards in a year.

“I am extremely proud to inaugurate this pavilion. It was built by my great grandfather Madho Rao Scindia-I in 1910. Although the pavilion has been renovated, the spirit is still the same. This pavilion has now been renovated and the ground quality is also extremely good now as a lot of investments have been done. I’m sure excellent players will come from this ground,” said Scindia, who is one of the patrons of Daly College.

A friendly cricket match was played between Daly College Board President XI and Madhya Pradesh Cricket Association XI. The 13-over match was won by Daly College Board President's XI. Senior Ranji players also participated in the match.

The match commenced with renowned cricket player and former headmaster of Daly College Vaman Jagtap ringing the huge brass bell at Scindia pavilion. Batting first, the Daily XI scored 126 runs for loss of three wickets in 13 overs. Sanjay Thakar scored 23 runs, Jai Singh Jhabua and Gajendra Singh contributed 20 runs each.

Murtaza and Pankaj Pandey took one wicket each for Madhya Pradesh Cricket Association XI. In response, MPCA XI managed to score 117 runs for loss of six wickets in 13 overs. Scindia played for MPCA team and managed to score four runs.

Scindia thereafter went to seek blessings of Acharya Vidyasagar, who has been in city since January 5.

Title: Pulse polio drive begins, target is to vaccinate over 5L kids of dist
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Indore: Health department on Sunday kick-started intensive pulse polio campaign in the district with aim to vaccinate 5.37 lakh children of four blocks.

Regional director health services Dr JS Avasiya began the campaign by flagging vehicle with the vaccine. During the campaign around 30 mobile teams and 22 transit teams will be used by department for administration of vaccine to children.

The department has prepared around 8000 vaccinators to administer around seven lakh dose of polio vaccine to children in blocks of district.

CMHO Dr Praveen Jadia said, “Every year the department celebrates National pulse polio day and this year it is being celebrated on Sunday.”

Children were vaccinated on Sunday by officials of department in around 3,585 booths. But, the officials from Monday will go door-to-door for vaccination of around 5.37 lakh children, said Jadia.

The department has deployed around 8000 staff of health, forest, labour, women and child development department and nursing students, said Jadia. “We aim to vaccinate 100% children in the campaign,” added Jadia.

Title: Congress-Shiv Sena divide widens over Savarkar
Content: NEW DELHI: Differences between Maharashtra allies Congress and Shiv Sena have sharpened over the past few weeks with a constant exchange of barbs between Sena MP Sanjay Raut and senior Congress functionaries over conferring the Bharat Ratna on right-wing ideologue Vinayak Savarkar, popularly known as 'Veer' Savarkar.In the latest exchange of barbs, while Congress repeated its criticism of Savarkar and argued against Bharat Ratna being conferred on him, Raut went to the extent of demanding that those opposing Savarkar should be sent to the same jail where he was lodged for 14 years.This is the second time in less than a week that Raut has stoked a controversy with his comments. Earlier, he had referred to former PM Indira Gandhi meeting yesteryear underworld don Karim Lala , a comment that triggered a sharp reaction from the Congress camp, and leading to a phone call from Congress's Maharashtra in-charge Mallikarjun Kharge , asking for Sena to stick to the common minimum programme for governance."Such statements are not good for the alliance. We should not speak the language of dividing each other. We have a common minimum programme of governance. We should talk about the CMP instead of past things. If we talk about past, so many things will come out," Kharge had said.Even though a section of Congress and Sena brass have laboured the point that the verbal crossfire has no bearing on the working of the Congress-Sena-NCP alliance government in Maharashtra, the repeated warring has embarrassed both parties, apart from dangling, like an uneasy sword, over an increasingly tenuous alliance.Yuva Sena president and state cabinet minister Aaditya Thackeray was among those who distanced themselves from Raut's statements, calling them his personal views. Thackeray also said one should not dwell on the past. Congress functionaries in Delhi, meanwhile, attempted to downplay Raut's comments as Sena's long-standing policy on Savarkar.A Congress functionary in New Delhi said the alliance dharma said all partners agreed to abide by the common development issues that brought them together and maintain a "studied silence" on all other contentious issues.

Title: Congress-Shiv Sena divide widens over Savarkar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

NEW DELHI: Differences between Maharashtra allies Congress and Shiv Sena have sharpened over the past few weeks with a constant exchange of barbs between Sena MP Sanjay Raut and senior Congress functionaries over conferring the Bharat Ratna on right-wing ideologue Vinayak Savarkar, popularly known as 'Veer' Savarkar.

In the latest exchange of barbs, while Congress repeated its criticism of Savarkar and argued against Bharat Ratna being conferred on him, Raut went to the extent of demanding that those opposing Savarkar should be sent to the same jail where he was lodged for 14 years.

This is the second time in less than a week that Raut has stoked a controversy with his comments. Earlier, he had referred to former PM Indira Gandhi meeting yesteryear underworld don Karim Lala , a comment that triggered a sharp reaction from the Congress camp, and leading to a phone call from Congress's Maharashtra in-charge Mallikarjun Kharge , asking for Sena to stick to the common minimum programme for governance.

"Such statements are not good for the alliance. We should not speak the language of dividing each other. We have a common minimum programme of governance. We should talk about the CMP instead of past things. If we talk about past, so many things will come out," Kharge had said.

Even though a section of Congress and Sena brass have laboured the point that the verbal crossfire has no bearing on the working of the Congress-Sena-NCP alliance government in Maharashtra, the repeated warring has embarrassed both parties, apart from dangling, like an uneasy sword, over an increasingly tenuous alliance.

Yuva Sena president and state cabinet minister Aaditya Thackeray was among those who distanced themselves from Raut's statements, calling them his personal views. Thackeray also said one should not dwell on the past. Congress functionaries in Delhi, meanwhile, attempted to downplay Raut's comments as Sena's long-standing policy on Savarkar.

A Congress functionary in New Delhi said the alliance dharma said all partners agreed to abide by the common development issues that brought them together and maintain a "studied silence" on all other contentious issues.

Title: Governor making a mockery of his post, says Kodiyeri
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: CPM state secretary Kodiyeri Balakrishnan has come out against governor Arif Mohammad Khan for his confrontational approach towards the state government. The role of a governor is not to insult a democratically elected government of a state, the CPM state secretary said in an article written in the party mouthpiece.

“To get into the good books of the Centre and the BJP, the governor is using his office and powers to insult a state government. The governor forgets the fact the state is having a democratically elected government,” he said.

The comments made by the governor against the state government was quiet unwarranted and it could have been avoided. He is making a mockery of the constitutional bodies like state government and the assembly, Balakrishnan said in the article.

The agenda of the Sangh Parivar is to bring all the constitutional bodies under their fist. This unforeseen danger is being witnessed by the country and the constitutional posts like governors are being misused for this by the Centre, he added.

The Constitution of the country and the democracy itself are facing a threat. The country is witnessing massive protests against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act. The amendment has taken back the right to live in the country which has been ensured by our Constitution. The Sangh Parivar’s attempt is to communally divide the country, he said.

Title: Indore: Two elederly couples decide to tie the knot, 16 in queue
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: Age is just a number proved two elderly couples, who in their second half decided to tie the knot whereas 16 elderly couples are considering another meet before making commitment at Jeevan Saathi Sammelan for elderly people, which was conducted in city at Jal Sabahgrah on Sunday.

Around 160 men and 47 women registered on spot to be a part of this meet.

Widower Deepak Sharma who is in his mid-sixties had come down from Ratlam for this meet found his life partner in Uma Goyal, who is in her mid-fifties and hails from Indore .

Another woman had come from Pune, in her mid-fifties, who wished anonymity gave green signal to city-based doctor who is in his mid-sixties after visiting his house post the meet got over.

“Even though there are around 16 couples that are now planning another meet before finalizing their decision, I am most certain about three to four couples that will be considering the option. I am happy with the way this meet turned out,” Natubhai Patel founder of this Ahmedabad based organization told TOI.

Jeevan sathi sammelan for the senior citizens attracted a good number of Indoreans who had come along with their friends, children and relatives to find a suitable life partner on Sunday.

An acid attack survivor of mistaken identity, Babita Jain who had come from Aurangabad was happy to be a part of this meet. “I had got to know about the meet through message and such meets should happen frequently,” she said.

Title: Gujarat: Class XI girl poisoned by father for wanting to study
Content:
Hiral

The accused, Maldev Solanki, forced pesticide down Hiral’s throat after beating her up with a wire

RAJKOT: Death of a 16-year-old girl in September last year , which was earlier reported to cops as suicide , has turned out to be a cold-blooded murder committed by her own father as he did not want her to pursue further studies.On Saturday, Prabhas Patan police in Gir-Somnath district arrested Maldev Solanki, who had allegedly poisoned his daughter Hiral to death in their native Inaj village of Veraval taluka on September 29.Solanki’s crime was exposed by the deceased’s sister Naina, a Class VIII student, who confided about the murder to her maternal uncle a few days ago.Police said Solanki forced pesticide down Hiral’s throat after beating her up with a wire. “Hiral, a Class XI student in Veraval Girls’ High School, wanted to study further. However, Maldev wanted to discontinue her studies. He used to often beat Hiral, her sister Naina and brothers — Dharmesh and Bhautik,” said G M Rathwa, inspector with Prabhas Patan police station.So fed up were Hiral, Naina and Dharmesh with the daily brutality that they consumed pesticide on September 14, However, all three survived due to timely hospitalization, Rathwa added.On September 29, Solanki again asked Hiral to drop out from the school. When she refused and her mother Kanchan intervened in her support, Solanki slapped the latter and then beat Hiral with a wire. He then picked up a bottle of pesticide and forced its content down Hiral’s throat.“Solanki threatened his family members that they would meet the same fate if they complained about the incident. He put Hiral to sleep in the bedroom. Next morning, when Hiral could not regain consciousness, Solanki took her to Veraval Civil Hospital where she was declared dead on admission,” said Rathwa.At the hospital, Solanki had told police that Hiral had committed suicide and that he was unaware about the reason.“However, Naina confided the incident to her maternal uncle who informed the cops. We recorded Naina’s statement before the magistrate. When Solanki came to know about this, he fled, but we nabbed him on the highway near Veraval,” added Rathwa.Solanki was working as a cleaner in trucks.

Title: Painter Biswaal recovers social media handle hacked from Turkey
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Well-known painter Bijay Biswaal has managed to recover his social media handle which had been hijacked by a hacker from Turkey a couple of days ago. The handle, having almost 83,000 followers, had digital prints of several of his highly priced paintings worth lakhs of rupees.

Bijay tweeted that his team, comprising son Sneheel and wife Meghana, had managed to recover the handle following relentless follow-ups with the parent company and it’s executives. The recovery, though partial, brought relief to the Biswaals and also their numerous friends and followers across the globe. The ace painter, who has also tweeted his gratitude to city police chief BK Upadhyay and TOI, is now likely to take up the case with Nagpur police cyber cell, which his wife had already approached.

Sneheel said around 257 paintings, out of 800, have been recovered along with some sketches but more are expected to be regained. “We managed to regain control of the social media handle with the help of a friend in the parent company, who sent us a link with the option to reset the passwords. The hacker had already started posting paintings of my father pretending he was the creator, but then our move left him stunned. The hacker has started to now block followers,” he said.

City police cyber cell officer API Ashwini Jagtap said official letters have already been sent to various social media companies and their replies are awaited, which are likely to give more details about the hacker.

Title: ‘Arrest builder, bring him before SCDRC by Jan 30’
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: In a rare judgment, the state consumer disputes redressal commission (SCDRC) has directed the police department to arrest an unethical builder and present him before the jury before January 30.

The builder, who took an advance from three flat aspirants, did not develop the scheme and neither did he refund their money despite orders by SCDRC and assurance given to the national consumer disputes redressal commission (NCDRC).

The SCDRC registrar (legal), through three letters issued to the commissioner of police BK Upadhyay on January 7, said, “Please find the bailable warrant of arrest of Suresh Burrewar, proprietor of Gruhlaxmi Construction and Land Developers arising out of the complaint decided on January 6, 2017. The bailable warrant of arrest be sent to the proper police station for execution. Return duly executed warrant on or before January 30 positively. Arrest Burrewar and produce him before SCDRC,” the letter said.

Advocate Arvind Waghmare, who represented the three complainants, Paresh Kukudkar, Milind Karmakar and Gattu Chakravarthy, all residents of Chandrapur, said, “SCDRC in its order dated January 6, 2017 had directed the builder to refund the advance amount with interest of 15% per annum, compensation of Rs5 lakh each towards loss sustained by complainants for not providing them residential flats with the sale deed, Rs1 lakh each for physical and metal harassment and Rs10,000 each for cost of complaint. The builder failed to comply with the orders. Later, the builder filed a petition in NCDRC where he agreed to pay all the outstanding amounts by October 2019. The builder is yet to fulfil his financial commitments. I pleaded before the SCDRC regarding the non-compliance of the orders following which SCDRC issued a bailable arrest warrant,” he said.

The order was passed by BA Shaikh, presiding member and Jayshree Yengal, member.

As per the details given in the petition, the builder had started taking advance for his proposed multistorey building — Gruhlaxmi Palace at Beltarodi. The three complainants had booked two flats each at Rs25 lakh per flat in 2013. Two complainants had paid an advance of Rs4 lakh each. The third one paid Rs2.75 lakh in 2013. An agreement was executed with the builder, but he did not start construction of the scheme.

On October 20, 2014, the three complainants sent a notice to the builder, but he did not respond. On November 3, 2016, all the three complainants filed a case with SCDRC. Waghmare said that till date, the builder has not begun construction of the scheme.

FLAT FIASCO

*Gruhlaxmi Construction and Land Developers proposed a flat scheme e— Gruhlaxmi Palace at Beltarodi and started accepted bookings

* Chandrapur-based three residents booked two flats each at Rs25 lakh per flat

*The trio paid an advance and executed an agreement in 2013

* Notice served to the builder as he failed to begin construction

* Petition filed with SCDRC in 2016

* SCDRC ordered builder to refund advance with 15% per annum interest, compensation of Rs6.10 lakh each

* Builder failed to comply with the order

* Builder filed a petition in NCDRC where he committed to pay the outstanding amounts by October 2019

* Despite the commitment, builder failed to make payment

* SCDRC asked police to arrest builder and present him before the jury on or before January 30

Title: Inspection to detect parking space violations in buildings
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: A joint inspection by police and corporation in shopping complexes and institutions, where parking spaces have been converted for other purposes, will begin on Monday. The inspection follows a decision taken at a traffic advisory committee meeting based on a note prepared by the corporation’s town-planning committee on parking violations in commercial establishments.

The corporation officials said 20 violations of major nature have been identified in wards under the main office, mainly on MG Road and Kowdiar-Kuravankonam road. The establishments, where private parking lots have been functional without mandatory licences will also come under the scanner.

Over the past few months, the engineering wing has been working on identifying parking violations in which spaces were altered and used either for storage or for other purposes. “We have done our ground work and it won’t be a random inspection. A timeframe will be given to the violators to clear the violations failing, after which their trade licence will be cancelled,” said Palayam Rajan, chairman of town-planning committee. The violators will be asked to furnish copies of original plan with allocated spaces for parking during the inspection. Unauthorised parking lots run by commercial institutions has always been a point of contention between corporation and shop owners.

Health and revenue officials will also take part in the inspection. The city corporation had passed a by-law for management of private parking lots. The by-law was passed by the corporation council in July 2018 in the wake of growing complaints about unauthorised collection of parking fee in private parking lots. As per the by law, parking fee as prescribed by city corporation shall be collected only for additional parking areas earmarked by the building owners.

A one-time registration fee of Rs 3,000 needs to be paid by the owners of private parking lots for one year, following which it has to be renewed.

Title: Medical College police walk the Janamaithri talk
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Thankamma and Medical College station house officer inaugurate the renovated house at Plamoodu

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Officers of the Medical College Janamaithri police station recently came to the rescue of a 75-year-old woman who was living in her dilapidated residence near Amayizhanjan Canal at Thekkumoodu Bund Colony near Plamoodu.

The Medical College police station, under the limits of which her house is situated, took up the renovation. Station house officer inspector Jayakumar along with Thankamma reopened the doors of her renovated house here on Friday morning in the presence of sub-inspector Sreekanth R S, Janamaithri beat officer C Babu, officers and residence association representatives.

According to Medical College police station Janamaithri beat officer and sub-inspector C Babu, Thankamma, who has been living on her own for a long time near the canal, was a frequent visitor to the Janamaithri meetings held at the police station.

Thankamma used to earn a small amount by giving tuitions to lower primary students. She also had a welfare pension of Rs 1,000.

“Her damaged house had a leaking roof and she had mentioned this in one of the Janamaithri meetings. With the help of residents and associations, who supported us with physical labour and funds, we completed the renovation of her house at an expenditure of around Rs 50,000. As she lives in a narrow lane next to the canal, where it is impossible for vehicles carrying the construction materials, officers and residents had to carry all materials up to the house. It took us around two months to complete the project,” said C Babu .

Title: Do we really need guvs, asks Yechury
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Questioning the relevance of the post of state governors , CPM general secretary Sitaram Yechury here on Sunday said the country should once again discuss whether the post should be abolished or not.

“It’s time to think over again whether we do really need governors in states where democratically elected governments rule. The Indian Constitution affirms that India is a union of states. Where does the role of a governor, who is a representative of the President comes in this context? It’s again time for us to think aloud the matter,” Yechury told reporters, when asked on the ongoing tussle between Kerala governor Arif Mohammmad Khan and the state government.

The governors were the representatives of viceroy in the colonial era. “Why should we have governors in this modern democratic era. His service comes handy only when a democratically elected government has to be dismissed. But we don’t want the Centre to dismiss any democratic government. Then what relevance does this post hold?,” Yechury said.tnn

Title: Govt planning import cut, export hike, says Gadkari
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Actor Nana Patekar, who was in the city on Sunday, paid a courtesy visit to Union minister Nitin Gadkari’s hom... Read More

Nagpur: City MP and Union minister Nitin Gadkari on Sunday said he has set a target of Rs5lakh crore to invest in infrastructure projects as there was no dearth of money but only lack of courage among bureaucrats to make decisions.

He also said that the government is trying to formulate a policy to cut imports for a $5 trillion economy. Gadkari once again took potshots at bureaucrats, saying they shouldn’t get involved in projects but help industrialists instead.

Gadkari, who is minister for road transport, highways, shipping and MSME (micro, small and medium enterprises), was speaking at the inaugural function of city-based Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology’s (VNIT) diamond jubilee celebrations.

On January 18, Gadkari had said that the $5 trillion economy was difficult but not impossible and the PMO was holding daily meetings to discuss measures for improving the infrastructure, transport and other sectors. The comments on bureaucrats come in the wake of the terse remarks made in Delhi on January 13. “These people (bureaucrats) are insensitive. They can’t make decisions. They make incorrect DPRs, keep squatting on files and don’t even let others make decisions,” Gadkari had said in Delhi.

At VNIT, the highways minister mocked at the functioning of babus. “I have set a target of investing Rs5lakh crore in infrastructure this year. There is no shortage of funds, but the only thing missing is courage in government officials to make decisions,” he said.

“In the last five years, I have approved investments worth Rs17lakh crore. Just the other day, during our high level meeting, bureaucrats were saying, ‘We will do this, we will do that’. I told them ‘Why would you do this or that? If you had the capacity to do it then why would you become an IAS officer and work here. You could have been industrialists. It’s not your job’,” he said, without specifying the projects that were discussed.

“I told the IAS officers to help those who can do it and not to mess things up,” Gadkari added.

On the economy, Gadkari said, “The government is trying to formulate a policy to cut imports and increase exports to make a 5 trillion economy.”

He reiterated his stand regarding imports. “Despite having enough resources and technology of our own, our imports are worth billions of rupees. The government needs support from institutions like VNIT and LIT for research and development pertaining to raw materials available in Nagpur and Vidarbha. We have a big coal block, but we are still importing coal. While paper mills are being shut, newsprint is being imported,” he said.

Regarding VNIT’s request for funding, Gadkari said the institute has generous and capable alumni who are ready to raise a corpus for its development. “Shortfall of any kind will be taken care of by the government,” he told the administration.

Title: Soldier killed in avalanche cremated with state honours
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Tributes paid to Dharmendra Singh before his last rites. He was among the four army personnel struck by the av... Read More

Kanpur: A 35-year-old soldier who was killed after being hit by an avalanche in Drass sector of Ladakh region, was cremated with full state and military honours at his native village in Ghatampur area of the district on Sunday.

The mortal remains reached the city on Sunday morning and then were taken to the soldier’s native place. The last rites were performed by his elder son Utkarsh.

Dharmendra Singh, a Havildar, was among the four army personnel struck by the avalanche at an army post in Drass sector of Ladakh region on Thursday.

A large number of residents from Singh’s Birahinpur village in Patara of Ghatampur and other neighbouring villages reached here to pay tributes to the soldier and bid a tearful adieu to the soldier.

Singh had joined the Indian Army in 1999, said the soldier’s family members.

UP cabinet minister Kamal Rani Varun paid homage to the soldier on behalf of the residents of the state.

Sub divisional magistrate Varun Pandey and deputy superintendent of police Ravi Kumar Singh, too paid tributes to the soldier on behalf of the district administration.

The soldier is survived by his wife Sunita, children Utkarsh and Rajvardhan and mother Shivdevi.

Title: Four booked for duping youth of 5L
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kolhapur: Rajarampuri police have booked four people for allegedly cheating a youth on the pretext of offering him a job in the Indian Army .

According to the complaint, the suspects promised the youth to help by providing him with question papers of the written examination for recruitment of jawan post in the Indian Army for Rs 5 lakh per candidate.

The complainant paid the money to the suspects money and received question papers in return.

It was when he appeared for the written test during recruitment, he found that the suspects gave him fake question paper.

Realising that he was duped, the youth lodged a complaint with the Rajarampuri police. Police said that they have not yet made any arrests and are investigating the case in details.

Title: BDDS cops deprived of ‘risk allowance’
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Cops from the bomb detection and disposal squad (BDDS) are an unhappy lot as their risk allowance has been discontinued after revision of their salaries post the seventh pay commission in April 2019.

While some units like city and rural police have withdrawn the special allowance for the risk involved in their daily work, others like Amravati city have retained the old payment for the special squads along with the pay-scale of the sixth pay commission.

TOI has learnt that the special allowance for high-risk units like the state anti-terrorist squad (ATS) and state anti-naxal operations (ANO), too, has been discontinued following implementation of the seventh pay commission.

The ATS did not even get their salary arrears after the revised pay package was implemented. They have so far just got the hike since April last year.

Sources in the police department said the risk allowance for the BDDS units were started since 1994 through a state government resolution (GR). It was a decision hastened by the bomb blasts and riots in Mumbai in 1993.

The allowance continued even after the implementation of the sixth pay commission but discontinued after the seventh one came into force on the grounds that there is a clause stating that separate clarifications would be issued for special units like the BDDS, ATS and ANO.

Joint CP Ravindra Kadam justified the move. He said there is already a substantial hike in the salaries of the police personnel following the implementation of the seventh pay commission. “There is a reference made in the seventh pay commission for the revision of these special pay packages which is now up to the state government to decide the scale. The state police has already have made a representation to the state government regarding the issue. A reply is awaited,” he said.

Even if the unit allows special allowances, it would be objected to by the treasury. “The state department has to take a call,” he said.

According to a senior officer from Amravati, the top brass is being misled by administrative officials because of vested interests. “There is no expressed clause in the seventh pay commission stating that the special allowances would be required to be rolled back. The state had started it after issuing a GR and did not repeal it since then. If there is a high risk in a special assignment then where is the motivation to work for it when the rest are getting the same returns with no threats to their lives,” he said.

Title: Gold chain worth Rs 80k snatched
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kolhapur: The Juna Rajwada police has booked unidentified people for allegedly snatching a gold chain worth Rs 80,000 from a woman while she walking in the Rajarampuri area of the city on Saturday.

The complainant, Sujata Vijay Joshi (62), a resident of Rajarampuri, lane no. 13 lodged a complaint in this regard.

“The victim was walking on a road behind a college in Rjarampuri area along with her daughter when two suspects riding on motorcycle approached her from behind and the pillion rider snatched her gold chain worth Rs 80,000 before fleeing from the spot. The women raised an alarm but before anyone could get to them, the duo disappeared,” said a police officer.

Title: Gujarat: Two doctors booked for death of four-year-old girl
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Clinic of Dr Milind Porecha

RAJKOT: Two doctors were booked on Sunday for causing death of a four-year-old girl while administering her with anaesthesia during surgery at a private hospital in Jamnagar .

Police said Dr Milind Porecha and Dr Neerav Kacha had allegedly caused the death of Mishri Bhanderi, daughter of Mitesh Bhanderi, a resident of Mayur Township on Ranjeet Sagar Road in Jamnagar.

Mitesh in his complaint alleged that his daughter had died due to negligence by Dr Porecha and Dr Kacha on February 6, 2019.

“Mishri was admitted to Ashutosh Hospital for removal of two steel rods in her left thigh. After surgery, Dr Porecha and Dr Kacha assured Mitesh that Mishri would regain consciousness within an hour. However, she could not come around and died instead. Mitesh alleges that his daughter had died due to an overdose of anaesthesia,” said an official of Jamnagar B division police station.

Mishri had suffered a fracture in her left leg in an accident. The car in which she and other members of family were travelling in had overturned by roadside in November 2018. Mitesh had taken Mishri to Dr Porecha’s hospital where her surgery was performed and two steel rods were placed inside her thighs. Dr Porecha said they would remove the rods in February 2019.

Title: Madhya Pradesh seeks report on tigress health
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

In December last year, NTCA had written to chief secretary Asit Tripathy, asking him to initiate her return as... Read More

BHUBANESWAR: With tigress Sundari’s return to Madhya Pradesh (MP) hanging in the balance, the Madhya Pradesh wildlife wing has sought a report on her health from the state.

The forest department in the central Indian state has written to the state’s principal chief conservator of forests (wildlife), H S Upadhyay, seeking a report on Sundari’s current behaviour and health pattern.

“We have received a letter from MP’s forest department. We will respond to it shortly,” Upadhyay said. After getting the response, forest departments of both the states will take a joint decision about moving the tigress to Kanha Tiger Reserve .

Sundari, who is currently lodged in a small enclosure in Satkosia Tiger Reserve, was brought from Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve as part of the first inter-state tiger translocation project in the country.

In December last year, the National Tiger Conservation Authority (NTCA) had written to chief secretary Asit Tripathy, asking him to initiate her return as she could not be kept in a small enclosure any longer.

“In the interests of tiger conservation, the translocation shall be withdrawn with immediate effect. The tiger translocation project at Satkosia shall remain suspended till the ground situation in the field improves as per our protocol,” the NTCA said in the letter. Though a month has passed since the NTCA had asked Odisha to move Sundari to MP, action in this regard is yet to be taken.

About 40 days after Sundari was brought from MP on June 29, 2018, she was released in the wild. But soon, she allegedly developed man-eating tendencies and killed two persons. She was then darted and brought to the enclosure again.

The NTCA had also said, “Pre-requisite conditions such as prey augmentation, creation of inviolate space, eco-development, capacity building of staff and enhancement of protection for the reintroduction of tigers in Satkosia couldn’t be achieved despite sufficient funds.”

Title: Cops to seek 30-day remand of Vishal Goswami
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Three members of Goswami gang including their leader Vishal Goswami, and Rinku and Ajay were brought to crime branch on a transfer warrant from Ahmedabad Central Jail on Sunday. Crime branch sources said the accused will be produced in court on Monday and the police will seek their 30-day remand under GujCTOC.

Crime branch officials said with GujCTOC applied (in its first use), the requirements to follow the procedure under 268 CrPC was no more applicable to the accused. The accused had been running their extortion racket from behind bars with the help of their associates outside. Their phones have been seized from inside the jail.

The gang has 28 cases registered against them in Ahmedabad including serious offences like murder, extortion, dacoity, and attempt to murder. The gang also operates in UP, Rajasthan, Goa, Karnataka and Madhya Pradesh , said a senior crime branch official.

Speaking about the four members of the gang, including a minor, who were arrested recently, senior superintendent of police, crime branch, Deepan Bhadran said, “Bijendra Goswami, Jaypuri Goswami, Vishal’s nephew (a minor) and Anurag Verma were arrested earler and are on police remand till January 24. They used to target businessmen and bookies identified by Vishal from inside the jail and usually demanded Rs 5 crore or more from each target.”

Title: International students cry foul over Gujarat University hostel hygiene
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kitchen at Block A in GU boys’ hostel

Ahmedabad: State education minister Bhupendrasinh Chudasama recently visited Kuwait as part of ‘Study in Gujarat’ initiative. He was accompanied by senior bureaucrats and representatives of the state’s universities. The aim of the visit was to attract foreign students to the state universities.

But Gujarat University (GU), the state’s biggest public university, is facing flak because it lacks basic amenities for the very students the government aims to attract.

GU had admitted 127 foreign students in 2019-20 including 100 males. The students come from Sri Lanka, Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Fiji, Nepal, South Africa, Kenya, Sudan, and Uganda. They are pursuing courses such as journalism, BBA/MBA, BCA/MCA, and doctoral studies.

“I have been staying at the hostel for the past one and a half years,” said a student from Uganda who requested anonymity. “I have written to the Indian Council for Cultural Relations (ICCR) and the Study Abroad Programme (SAP) of GU multiple times about issues such as access to clean drinking water and hygiene conditions on and around the hostel premises.”

Another student, from Sri Lanka, said that the hostel must have a functional kitchen for international students , as stipulated by ICCR norms. “But here, the kitchen is in a pathetic condition,” said the student.

Subhash Singh, the regional officer of the ICCR, said that the council has received multiple complaints about GU and has sent them to the university officials. He said that the university has been ‘positive’ in its approach.

Nirja Gupta, the international student advisor at the university, said the university has not received any complaint from foreign students over the past two months. “All amenities are in place and cleaning of the premises is also happening regularly,” she said.

Title: Warner fetes Rajkot police with his ‘man of the match’ trophy
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

V J Chavda receiving trophy of David Warner on Sunday

Rajkot: Australian cricketer David Warner was highly impressed with the tight security provided by Rajkot police during India-Australia one day cricket match on Friday. So impressed was he that the world-class cricketer gifted his ‘man of the match’ trophy, which he had received in Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai, to inspector V J Chavda of Rajkot police on Sunday.

“The Australian cricket team has been staying in Imperial Hotel for the past four days. The team members were highly impressed by the security we provided them at the hotel and at the stadium as well. When they praised us before Warner, Warner expressed his desire to felicitate us,” said an official from Rajkot police.

At a small gathering at the Imperial Hotel, Warner’s ‘man of the match’ trophy was given to Australian team security in-charge, Frank Dimasi, who handed the coveted trophy to inspector Chavda.

Title: Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj’s memorial will inspire generations for equality, democracy and modernisation: Sharad Pawar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kolhapur: Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj’s memorial would inspire the future generations for equality, democracy, modernisation and development, said NCP supremo Sharad Pawar .

Pawar was speaking at a programme organised for inaugurating the Shahu Samadhi Sthal—the memorial of Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj—at Dasara chowk on Sunday. Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has constructed the memorial at an estimated cost of Rs 6 crore. Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj wished to have his resting place constructed at Nursery Baug.

Addressing the gathering, Pawar said, “A number of kings and dynasties have ruled several parts of India over the ages but the country will always remember two great rulers. One is Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj, who set up the Hindavi Swaraj with the help of Mawalas, and the second is Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj, who despite being a ruler, was a social reformer who worked for the betterment of the downtrodden. These two rulers are not only an inspiration to people in Maharashtra but also to citizens across the country. Even the Uttar Pradesh government has named one district after Shahu Maharaj.”

Narrating the decisions taken by Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj when he ruled the princely state of Kolhapur, Pawar said, “He was the first ruler in India to have reserved 50% of the government posts for backward classes. This indicates his vision for the welfare of the people in the lower rungs of society.”

“Besides being a social reformer, Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj also constructed a dam to improve irrigation in the region and started power production to set up industrial units in the princely state of Kolhapur,” said the NCP chief.

The programme was presided over by Shahu Chhatrapati, a descendent of the Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj. Addressing the gathering, Shahu Chhatrapati said, “Rajarshi Shahu was a great social reformer, who gave direction to the growth and development of our country. His thoughts on equality and democracy spread across the country during pre-Independence period. We expect that in today’s world, there will be many followers of Rajarshi Shahu Maharaj who will carry forward the ideals set by him.”

Revenue minister Balasaheb Thorat said, “Shahu Maharaj’s work has been inspiring people since the last 100 years and will continue to do so. He did not just stop at thinking about the reforms he wanted to see in the society but also ensured that the reforms were strictly implemented and followed. His thoughts and work will motivate the government to work for the betterment of the common man.”

Title: Five bovines die after drinking ‘poisonous water’
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Five bovines were found dead after allegedly drinking poisonous wastewater of a cold storage on Sunday between Bharatwada and Laxmi Nagar area. Yuva Sena activists, the youth wing of Shiv Sena, filed a complaint in this regard with Kalamna police station .

Senior PI of Kalamna police station, Vishwanath Chavhan, said, “We have received a complaint but the reason behind the death of bovines is still unknown. The owner of the bovines has also registered complaint with us in this regard. Post-mortem of the bovines will be conducted on Monday and only after taking expert opinion, the reason of the death will be known.”

Yuva Sena activist Vikram Rathod said that the bovines died after drinking poisonous wastewater and material which came out from the cold storage in the area. “We will also be filing a complaint against the cold storage with the Nagpur Municipal Corporation,” he said.

Title: 14 rare idols stolen from two Tamil Nadu temples
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Police conduct an investigation at Aathiswarar Jain temple in Thanjavur, where 13 valuable idols have been sto... Read More

Title: Smart Cities Mission panel okays Cauvery riverfront development plan
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The civic body will develop bathing ghats along the river banks pursuing traditional style of architecture at ... Read More

TRICHY: The Trichy Corporation has obtained mandatory administrative and technical sanctions from a high-powered expert committee of the Smart Cities Mission programme for developing and beautifying a portion of the Cauvery river bank in the city.

The civic body will develop bathing ghats along the river banks pursuing traditional style of architecture at an estimated cost of Rs 2.94 crore.

Stating that there was a persistent demand from the locals to develop bathing ghats along the Cauvery river banks that separate Srirangam island from mainland Trichy, the corporation mooted a proposal to develop the ghats. A stretch between Thillainayagam bathing ghat and vacant space opposite to the Oyamari electric crematorium has been identified to develop bathing ghats for a 200m stretch as part of the riverfront development proposal.

The bathing ghats envisaged at making provision for locals to offer prayers during auspicious days such as Adi Perukku will be implemented in three separate packages, with each costing Rs 98 lakh. “Lighting arrangements will be provided in the stretch identified under the Cauvery riverfront development. Initially, bathing ghats shall be established. Further beautification proposals are yet to be drafted,” an official source with the corporation said.

The corporation will float a tender inviting contractors to launch the civil work within a month. “Construction work for bathing ghats will be completed within six months of launching the civil work,” the official added. Unlike the Uyyakondan canal riverfront development project which is under way at Rs 17.56 crore as part of the smart cities mission aimed at establishing public parks, walking tracks and recreational zones, the civic body said that Cauvery proposal will be plain as far as the amenities are concerned.

Title: UMTA still a non-starter for Trichy
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Traffic snarls near Palpannai junction in Trichy

TRICHY: Unified Metropolitan Transport Authority ( UMTA ), a statutory autonomous body to create a sustainable urban transport system by involving various stakeholders, proposed for Trichy city remains a non-starter for the past four years.

To tackle the transport challenges in the city such as lack of coordination between stakeholder departments, Ministry of Housing and Urban Affairs (MoHUA) under the National Urban Transport Policy (NUTP) selected around 10 cities including Trichy to set up UMTA, a professional body to address lapses in urban transport. With multiple stakeholders involved such as Railways, Airports Authority of India (AAI) and the regional transport department, UMTA was intended to serve as a common platform to implement proposals for improving the city’s urban mobility.

Though other cities selected for UMTA such as Chennai, Kochi and Hyderabad are at various level of progress in making use of UMTA, the proposal for Trichy remains only on papers. Despite the launch of operations document for Trichy UMTA in May 2016 and subsequent draft legislation prepared for introducing UMTA in the state assembly, no progress is made in materialising the regulatory body.
