UMTA for Trichy should have had the district collector as chairperson and officials from Trichy City Corporation , NHAI and TNSTC as members of the task force, but nothing has happened.

“UMTA can be definitely a solution for planning Trichy’s public transportation system. The present bus routes were poorly planned and need to be streamlined once UMTA is formed,” K Shyam Sundar, member, Trichy Intra-City Development Endeavours (TIDES), said. UMTA comprising at least 15 departments, including Trichy City Corporation and city traffic police, will find solutions through periodical meetings to achieve an improved city-suburban rail and road connectivity and better road infrastructure. Senior officials who were part of the discussions for UMTA Trichy since 2016 are not in service here, and several officials who are new in the stakeholder departments are not aware of UMTA proposal. When contacted, Trichy MP Su Thirunavukkarasar said, “Will study the prospects of UMTA Trichy to discuss with the relevant authorities and departments to implement it.”

Title: Jaysingpur theft case: Two arrested
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kolhapur: Ten days after mobile phones worth Rs 2.31 lakh were stolen by unidentified persons from the record room of Jaysingpur police station, police have succeeded in nabbing two people for their alleged involvement in the crime.

They have been identified as Raghunath Balaso Kadam (28) and his accomplice Pawan alias Vikas Patil (21) , both residents of Gandhinagar in Jaysingpur.

They were produced before a local court and remanded to police custody till January 23.

Both are criminals are on police record are have been involved in series of crimes such as theft and robbery, said police.

“On August 25, we had arrested Kadam for allegedly stealing cash from a co-operative society in Jaysingpur. During routine action against him, we had seized two mobile phones from him for investigation of the case. As per the court’s order, we returned one mobile phone to him and kept the other one with us for further investigation. Kadam told us that the mobile phone belongs to his girlfriend and asked us to return it. Police told him that they will return the phone once they get the court’s order,” said a police officer attached with the Jaysingpur police station.

“Kadam decided to steal the phone from the police station and return it to his girlfriend. He planned the robbery with his friend. On the night of January 9, he and his friend managed to sneak into the police station through the back door. That was the only place that was not covered by the CCTV cameras. The duo broke open the door of the record room where we had kept all the mobile phones, took them and fled from the spot,” the officer added.

“Following the incident, we had formed ten teams to investigate the case in details. We also received CCTV footage from shops located at the back side of police station and, based on it, we identified suspects and nabbed them,” he said.

The officer also said that the duo had put all the mobile phones in a sack and dumped it into the Krishna river from Arjunwad-Miraj bridge.

“We had launched a search operation in the river and recovered the sack containing mobile phones,” he added.

Title: Ahmedabad's Bapunagar diamond robbers arrested, include engineering graduate
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Accused in police custody

AHMEDABAD: In a joint operation, City Crime Branch and Bapunagar police nabbed two persons — Chatrapalsinh Solanki of Anjar in Kutch and Yashpalsinh Rana of Bhavnagar — for robbing diamond and cash from an Angadia employee at gun-point in Bapunagar on January 16.

SSP, crime branch, Deepan Bhadran, said a team led by inspector J P Rozia and N R Bhrambhatt recovered Rs 30,000, diamonds, two 9mm single action pistols and 11 live rounds from the duo.

“During interrogation Chatrapalsinh confessed to sending the remaining diamonds worth Rs 6 lakh to his friend Ravi Dangar in Surat. We have also recovered those diamonds,” Bhadran added. Rozia said that the accused will be handed over to Bapunagar police. Police said Chatrapal has done his bachelor’s in engineering.

According to crime branch officials, Chatrapal contacted one Ajayprakashsinh Rajput, who used to work with him in the same company in Kutch. He arranged weapons for them.

Title: Aurangabad hits snooze on nightlife
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Aurangabad: The state government’s decision to allow shops, malls, pubs and eateries to remain open 24X7 in non-residential areas from January 26 has failed to impress the stakeholders in Aurangabad. They said even when the move was introduced two years ago, it did not garner good response.

The previous state government had amended the Maharashtra Shops and Establishments (Regulation of Employment and Service Condition) Act, 2017, paving the way for round-the-clock functioning of malls and restaurants. The amendment had permitted all shops to remain open in three shifts with appropriate day-offs for their employees.

Different commercial establishments said they did not extend their work hours as they did not anticipate heavy flow of customers at night and there was also the burden of additional staff salaries to consider.

Shrimant Patil, proprietor of hotel Chaurangi in Jawahar colony, said a tier-2 city like Aurangabad would not have good business like Mumbai at night. “Arrangement of the staff to deliver services is part of the logistics required to remain operational at night,” he said.

As per the amended law, smaller establishments would not require licences, but will have to register online. Several establishments said such a procedure was not in place yet. Some establishments also accused the law enforcing agencies, especially the police, of enforcing a 11pm deadline.

Assistant commissioner of police (Crime) Nagnath Kode said establishments coming under the 2017 legislation and with more than 10 employees can operate round-the-clock, after getting a licence. “Just one or two establishments here have taken such a licence,” he said.

“Liquor-serving places have to work under the legal framework defined by the excise department. These establishments can serve food till 12.30am and liquor till 1.30 am. Bar-cum-hotels can serve food 24X7 after getting licences” he added.

Title: Neighbour bites, gropes woman
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ahmedabad: A 35-year-old man, who provides housekeeping services as a contractor, has allegedly bitten and groped a woman, 32, who lives in his neighbourhood, over a dispute between their kids on Saturday, states a complaint filed with Chandkheda police.

The woman said in her complaint that the accused not only groped her while thrashing her but had also bitten on her right hand and tried to drag her away in the secluded underground parking in the basement of their society in Chandkheda.

In her FIR, the woman, who works at a legal firm and is a mother of two children aged 12 and 10, said that her two kids and the accused’s one child had fought over getting their favourite seats in their school van. tnn

Title: In a first, 100 set to take diksha together in Surat on February 1
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

A diksha ceremony that took place at Vadi in Surat on Saturday

SURAT: Diamond City will create a record of sorts in asceticism when more than 100 individuals will take up monkhood on February 1. The events for taking vows for diksha are going to take place in different places in the city with the biggest of them being organized in Vesu .

Around 75 individuals will take diksha in Vesu to become Jain sadhus and sadhvis, sources said. The other events will take place in Adajan and Pal areas of the city on the same day. At Vesu, 75 individuals will take diksha under the guidance of Vijay Shreyanshprabhsurisswarji Maharaja; muhurat for 71 has already been decided while a few others are in the waiting.

“So far we have finalized muhurat for 71 diksharthi. The figure is likely to go up. These individuals have come from across the country — Karnataka, Rajasthan, Maharashtra and different cities of Gujarat — and also from varied backgrounds,” said Naresh Shah of Diksha Utsav Samiti.

The vows will be given by Vijay Shreyanshprabhsuriswarji Maharaja, Taporatnasuriswarji Maharaja and Kalyanratnasuriswarji Maharaja, he said.

In December 2014, in a mass diksha event had taken place in which 45 individuals had renounced the world in the city. So far, that was the biggest of such events. “The event organized by Jinagna Trust is biggest in the history of dikshas the country as well as in Jain religion when so many individuals are taking up monkhood,” Shah added.

A Varshdan Yatra – procession to celebrate the monkhood organized a day before the main event – will take place on January 31. Hundreds of devotees are likely to take part in it.

On the same day, 20 diksharthis are going to take monkhood in Pal in an event organized by Samast Shree Vavpanthak Shwetamber Murti Pujak Jain Sangh at Omkar Nagari. Five Diksharthis will take vows at Gururak Pavan Bhumi on the same day.

Title: Aam Aadmi Party opens office in Aurangabad
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

AURANGABAD: The Aam Aadmi Party has opened its city office in Cidco N-7 on Friday, ahead of the general elections of the civic body.

Party’s state convener Ranga Rachure has stated that AAP would contest for all the 115 seats in the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) elections.

Rachure said that by the second week of February the candidates for the AMC elections will be announced. “A rally of around 2,000 participants is planned in February. ” he said.

The party office will remain open from 9am to 9pm for common people to register their complaints. The party had appointed lawyer Subhash Mane as its city president and Isak Andewala as city’s working president.

Title: One dead, 24 hurt in Ariyalur jallikattu
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Around 4,500 people witnessed the first jallikattu organised under the supervision of the Ariyalur district ad... Read More

TRICHY: A 25-year-old bull tamer succumbed to injuries sustained in a jallikattu event organised at Kokkudi village near Keelapalur in Ariyalur district on Sunday. The victim has been identified as Bojiram, from Lalgudi. He was declared brought dead on arrival at the Thanjavur Medical College Hospital. Twenty-four bull tamers were injured during the event. While some were treated at the spot, others were referred to hospital.

Around 4,500 people witnessed the first jallikattu organised under the supervision of the Ariyalur district administration. Organised as part of Pongal celebrations in St Ignatius church in Kokkudi village, around 250 bull tamers participated in the event. The event was officially inaugurated after the passing of the bull belonging to the St Ignatius church. As many as 649 bulls from Trichy, Pudukottai and Perambalur districts took part in the event.

In another incident, a 46-year-old man from M Kovilpatti village near Tirupattur was gored to death by a bull during the Kandipatti manjuvirattu that took place in Sivaganga district on Sunday. The victim has been identified as C Vijayaragunathan, who was working in Kancheepuram. According to the local police, he had come to watch the proceedings of manjuvirattu organized by St Antony Church. One of the unregistered bulls, which ran through the crowd gored him. The bull’s horn pierced through his neck and came out the other side, killing him on the spot.

Title: Delhi: How relief on electricity bills is powering election campaigns
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: Before the 2015 assembly polls, bijli half paani maaf was a catchy promise of the Aam Aadmi Party . Voters are circumspect about election-time assurances, but this is one commitment, most city dwellers feel, that has been met. Last month, over 38 lakh consumers got electricity bills amounting to nil despite the December cold, according to the power distribution companies.Subsidised power became available after AAP came to power in 2015, and since August 2019, the state government has fully freed consumption up to 200 units of electricity and partly subsidised utilisation of 201-400 units. The government also offered a flat Rs 800 discount to those who consumed a maximum of 400 units of power. Right now, Delhi is the only state to have free electricity up to 200 units.Power and water, which is also free if consumption is under 20,000 litres per month, has left Delhiites happy. In Bhumiheen Camp near Kalkaji, shopkeeper Pramod Mandal contentedly reveals that more than 90% of the JJ colony’s households now get zero power bills. This is enough to make life easier in the damp and cramped quarters. “Living conditions may not be good, but we’ve seen some progress. Savings of even Rs 1,000 a month is a lot for a family here,” Mandal noted.For Bawana resident Rakesh Kumar too, there’s a little more money in the wallet at the end of the month. “Water is free. The power bill is minimal in summer and nil in winters. Medicines are free. Education of top quality is free,” the daily-wage earner said. “We just have to worry about food. What more can an aam aadmi struggling to eke out a living expect?”According to Tata Power Delhi Distribution Limited, 11.2 lakh users did not have to pay a paisa for energy in December 2019, while 9.1 lakh got the same benefit in November. After the August announcement of full subsidy, 4.9 lakh of Tata Power’s 17.2 lakh customers cashed in on the largesse in September 2019.In the capital’s areas serviced by Reliance-owned discoms BSES Rajdhani Power Limited and BSES Yamuna Power Limited, more than 10 lakh consumers got full subsidy in September, while 12.5 lakh got rebates of up to Rs 800. In October, 15.8 lakh availed of free electricity, and 12.7 lakh paid half the cost of units up to 400 they had utilised. In November and December, the number of full beneficiaries were 24 lakh and 26.8 lakh, respectively, while 8.9 lakh and 6.9 lakh consumers got subsidies under the 201-400 units category.More people benefit in the winter months. As a Tata Power official explained, “Consumers used ACs in September, but not in November and December. Using fewer units avails them the subsidy benefits. In summer, 27% of consumers limited use to 200 units, but this number is expected to have risen to around 65% in winter.”The power companies gets the subsidy reimbursed by Delhi government, which needs, therefore, to spend Rs 1,800-2,000 crore on this annually, according to a power department official. Something that gladdens the hearts of voters will never be accepted without a political murmur, so alleging that the power department had issued order to provide free power only till March 31, Delhi BJP president Manoj Tiwari asserted, “It is just an election gimmick.”According to Delhi government, however, official schemes are budgeted for every financial year. The free electricity scheme is a long-term one and its cost will be included in the new budget, it insisted.Not everyone, of course, gets free power. “The upper middle class does not get much from the scheme,” said B S Vohra, president, Federation of East Delhi RWAs. “Instead of lowering the power tariff and asking for a CAG audit of the discoms, the government is offering subsidies to win over the masses. The money for the power scheme comes by avoiding other necessary work such as repairing roads and potholes and so on.”But the popularity of AAP’s electricity subsidy scheme has prompted both Congress and BJP to promise similar — or even higher — relief if elected to power. While Congress has announced it will subsidise up to 600 units of electricity if its forms the government, BJP has assured “five times more benefits than what the Arvind Kejriwal government is promising”.Are the voters swayed? Md Ashfaz, 53, said in Seelampur, “All parties are now making tall promises only to get elected. We know who made the promises and also kept them.”

Title: Lankan navy arrests four Pudukottai fishermen
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Four fishermen from Jegathapattinnam of Pudukottai district were arrested by the Sri Lankan navy for allegedly fishing in Sri Lankan territorial waters in the early hours on Saturday night. A fishing trawler owned by Palraj was also seized from them.

The arrested have been identified as Barathi, 30, Ashokan, 28, Sakthi Kumar, 30 and Mani, 30. A total of 96 fishing boats ventured into the sea on Saturday night from Jegathapattinnam after long Pongal holiday. While they were fishing in the mid sea, a Sri Lankan mavy boat surrounded Palraj’s boat.

The boat along with the four fishermen were taken to Kangesan Port for interrogation. On December 29, 2019, 14 fishermen from Jegathapattinnam were arrested by the Sri Lankan navy. Three fishing trawlers were also seized from them.

MDMK leader and Rajya Sabha MP Vaiko and PMK leader S Ramadoss had condemned the arrest and demanded their release.

Title: Hotel Tamil Nadu to add 15 deluxe rooms, meeting hall
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Equipping itself with improved facilities to keep pace with the challenge posed by private hotels, Hotel Tamil Nadu will soon be adding 15 deluxe rooms and a spacious conference hall.

Owned by Tamil Nadu Tourism Development Corporation (TTDC), a three-storey building is being raised at a cost of Rs 4.1 crore. The work is expected to be completed in six months, according to TTDC officials.

Hotel Tamil Nadu presently has 30 rooms, a bar, restaurant and a conference hall. The new three-storey building raised after bringing down an existing building with 24 rooms will have facilities designed to suit contemporary needs.

The building will accommodate 15 rooms in which two will be suit rooms. Besides, it will have a conference hall with a seating capacity of 112 people.

Saying that more space is given to accommodate a conference hall in the new building, regional manager, TTDC G Sabesan said that it has been done after keeping in mind the demand for such conference halls.

The existing conference hall has a limited seating capacity of 80 seats. There has been an increase in business activities in the city and demand for conference hall with over 100 seating capacity has increased. This new facility will cater to this need, he said. “We have introduced flexibility in duration of occupancy of rooms to improve occupancy rate from an average 65 percent and we are getting good response,” said Regional Manager, TTDC G Sabesan.

Apart from offering rooms on 24-hour basis, we have started offering rooms for six hours during day time based on availability. This is benefitting people who come to Trichy for work and want room for short duration, he said

Title: Pudukottai bull Ravanan rules jalikattu events
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ravanan become a nightmare for bull tamers after its undefeated run in the recently-held jallikattu events at ... Read More

TRICHY: Ravanan , an eight-year-old jallikattu bull, from Pudukottai district has become a nightmare for bull tamers after its undefeated run in the recently-held jallikattu events at Avaniyapuram and Alanganallur .

Social media platforms are flooded with the video footages of Ravanan raiding the jallikattu arena after entering through the vadivasal as it finds only a few tamers on the ground. As Ravanan charges, bull tamers climb up on the metal grills to escape from its onslaught.

“Only a few bulls will go on a rampage chasing bull tamers in any jallikattu event. Most of the bulls run out of the arena if not tamed. Ravanan was unstoppable and majority of the bull tamers who kept away from Ravanan says he is so ferocious,” said S Anand, 40, a spectator at the Avaniyapuram jallikattu.

Ravanan was untamed in both Avaniyapuram and Alanganallur jallikattu events. It was also adjudged the best bull in Avaniyapuram and bagged certificate, trophy and few other prizes. In Alanganallur, it came second and received a cash prize of Rs 25,000.

P Anuradha, the owner of the bull who is a weightlifting champion and police sub-inspector in Pudukottai district, said that she expected that the bull would go untamed but never thought that it would become so popular.

The malai madu breed bull was gifted to her by a friend from Thanjavur after she won her first international medal last year.

This is the first season that Ravanan was taken to Jallikattu event. She said that there wasn’t any special treatment or training given to the bull. Ravanan will continue to take part in the upcoming jallikattu events as well, she said.

His brother P Marimuthu, 33, farmer in Nemmeli Patti village in Pudukottai district, said that except for cotton seeds, we do not give any special food to our bulls.

It is left to graze on our land apart from occasional swimming in the nearby lake, he said. He owes eight such bulls; one among them is named Asuran, which will be entering the jallikattu events soon.

Title: Kerala: Church warns laity of interreligious love affairs
Content:
Syro-Malabar Church

KOCHI: The Syro-Malabar Church on Sunday read a circular from Cardinal George Alencherry in its churches reiterating the decisions taken during the recently concluded Synod. The Church, which had claimed through a press statement that Love Jihad existed in the state, has used the words ‘ interreligious love affairs with bad intentions’ to refer to the issue in the post-synod circular written by the Cardinal.“It is a cause of concern that the inter-religious love affairs with bad intentions are increasing in Kerala that could affect the communal harmony and the peace of the society. It is a fact that such well-planned activities, targeting Christian girls are happening…Such love affairs shouldn’t be considered as an issue that can harm the friendship between religions. It should be considered as terrorist activity or as activity that can badly affect the society and necessary legal action should be taken against it,” the circular stated.Explaining the difference, Fr Antony Thalachalloor, secretary of the Syro Malabar media commission, said that the circular written by the Cardinal himself took a pastoral approach in addressing the laity and the media statement was a communication to the general public by the media commission.“The statement was written and undersigned by me and was meant for the civil society. However, when the Cardinal writes it as a circular to his laity and priests, the terminology got changed according to the audience,” said Fr Thalachalloor.Meanwhile, Riju Kanjookaran of the Archdiocesan Movement for Transparency, said that many churches in Ernakulam-Angamaly archdiocese ignored the circular due to difference of opinion towards its contents. “Only a handful of churches in our diocese read the circular. Those who read it, only read the part about the religious matters, like the bishop appointments,” said Kanjookaran.However, the media commission rubbished the claim. “Most churches read the circular on Sunday. Some of the churches are yet to read it during the mass as many were observing the feast of St Sebastian this Sunday. Some others were yet to receive it through post as well. To my knowledge, no one has not read the circular due to difference of opinion to its content,” said Fr Thalachalloor.The circular also talks about resolving confusions around the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, liturgy of the Church, attack towards Christians around the world, farmers’ crisis, discrimination against Christians in schemes for minorities, reservation for the backward sections in the developed communities and appointment of new bishops.

Title: Ahmedabad: Murder case shifted from Aslali
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Three months after detection of a gruesome murder, Aslali cops have realized that the jurisdiction of the case belongs to Gomtipur police as the murder had been committed in Gomtipur and the victim’s body parts left in Aslali. On Saturday, they shifted the case to Gomptipur police station. Inspector Sahil Tandel of Gomtipur police said they will be applying for police custody of the accused. “We still have to recover the severed head of the victim,” he added.

The murder had taken place in Ghatlodia on November 2, 2019. The body parts of the victim were packed in a gunny bag and dumped in Aslali.

Police arrested Mohammad Matlub Shaikh, 37, for killing his friend and business partner, Shakir Shaikh, 40, in a week.

Title: TSRTC driver tries to commit suicide
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A TSRTC driver tried to commit suicide by consuming poison on Saturday. G Praveen of Miyapur bus depot 1 is said to have taken this step allegedly due to harassment by the depot manager.

Speaking from the ICU of the hospital in Beeramguda where he is admitted, Praveen said, “I was asked to leave the job despite doing my duty.” The depot manager was not available for a response.

Title: Guides to help colleges get NAAC tag
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Altogether 350 colleges will hold preparations for the NAAC accreditation in the first phase

BHUBANESWAR: The higher education department has decided to engage resource persons, especially teachers from universities as guides, to help degree colleges prepare for accreditation by the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC).

Asoka Kumar Das, vice chairman of the Odisha State Higher Education Council (OSHEC), said, “The teachers of seven affiliating universities, who have a fair knowledge of NAAC accreditation, will guide colleges to earn this tag.”

Altogether 350 colleges will hold preparations for the NAAC accreditation in the first phase. A NAAC tag helps a college or university get recognition, funding and assistance from the University Grants Commission (UGC) and also from the Rashtriya Uchchattar Shiksha Abhiyan (RUSA) scheme.

Das said the colleges have to complete the preparation by March this year. “As the colleges have no substantial knowledge of the accreditation process, we have to engage some trainers to guide the college authorities. These guides will get honorarium for guiding the colleges,” he added.

Das said the guides have already received training for the same from a NAAC expert. “A guide will first visit his/her respective college and try to have an academic and administrative audit to know whether all documents are in place or not. He/she will train five teachers of the colleges’ internal quality assurance cell and help them file the application for the accreditation,” he explained.

For affiliated colleges, approximately 80 criteria, including 58 quantitative and 22 qualitative, should be filled up in detail before applying for the accreditation. Some of these criteria include student support, research, teaching learning process, curricular implementation, governance, infrastructure and library facilities, leadership and best practices. “The documentation should be very strong before the NAAC team. It should show how the institution has effectively maintained and developed educational quality,” said Das.

The guides will soon start helping the colleges in documenting and preparing reports for submission before the NAAC team to get the accreditation.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Rain spoils bumper harvest in delta districts
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Rain has flattened samba paddy crop in Trichy

THANJAVUR: Unexpected rain that lashed delta districts flattened thousands of acres of standing paddy crops that were to go for harvest in a few days, farmers said. The farmers were expecting a bumper harvest this samba season. Farmers have urged the state government to relax the maximum moisture content in crops fixed as 17% by the government for the harvest to be procured at direct procurement centres (DPCs).

Due to good monsoon and continuous flow of water in Cauvery and its tributaries, we, this year, took up samba cultivation in a larger area when compared to last year, farmers said. However, now that there are a few days to go for the harvest, the rain has played spoilsport in many parts of Tiruvarur, Thanjavur and Trichy , said S Murugesan, from Papanasam.

He had raised paddy on two acres and planned to harvest on Monday. However, due to the rain that lashed on Saturday made his entire standing crop flat. He has to wait until the rainwater to drain to harvest the crop.

The rain caused 30% to 35% loss to the farmers, secretary of Thanjavur district Cauvery farmers’ protection association Swamimalai S Vimalnathan said. “Due to rain, the moisture content would be more than 17%, which is permissible level by the government. So, TNCSC authorities will never accept our paddy with the moisture content of more than 17%. Considering this situation due to rain, the state government should relax the moisture level this season,” he added. Due to rain, the moisture content in the harvested paddy is 21 to 23% in many places. With harvest picking up at many places, farmers had to dry the paddy by spreading it on roads.

Title: Local bodies can’t impose illegal conditions, rules HC
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kochi: Local bodies cannot incorporate conditions not allowed as per rules on a business’ licence on the basis of unsubstantiated allegations by local residents , the high court has said.

Justice Devan Ramachandran ruled against imposing conditions not allowed as per rules while considering a petition by Brandstorm Events Management of Kochi through advocate S Nikhil Sankar.

Maneed grama panchayat had imposed a condition in the licence granted to the company’s godown within its limits that it should not be operated between 6pm and 6am. Petitioner’s counsel contended that the condition was imposed on the licence after the local residents forced the company to sign an agreement during a ‘mediation’ by two councilors that the godown won’t be operated during these hours. These are against the procedure and provisions of Kerala Panchayat Raj (Issue of Licence to Factories, Trades, Entrepreneurship Activities and Other Services) Rules, the counsel argued while pointing out that a division had held (in Anilkumar MK and Others vs Aiswarya Rice Mill and Others, 2015) that such restrictions are illegal.

The court pointed out that the division bench’s decision was that local body cannot impose any restriction on the basis of opposition by local residents without a report affirming it by the pollution control board.

Further, the court said the course adopted by Maneed panchayat does not augur to the statutory systems. If complaints of citizens are dealt with in this manner, there would be no requirement for elaborate provisions in the Kerala Panchayat Raj Act, the court said.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Congress inks pact, gives RJD 4 seats with sizeable Poorvanchali voters
Content:
RJD Delhi in-charge Manoj Jha

NEW DELHI: In an effort to bring together political parties against AAP, Congress on Sunday inked an alliance with Rashtriya Janata Dal. While Congress will be contesting from 66 assembly constituencies, RJD will fight from four seats that have a sizeable Poorvanchali population — Burari , Kirari, Uttam Nagar and Palam.RJD, which is a part of UPA, won one seat in the recently concluded Jharkhand assembly polls. Initially, when talks of an alliance began, RJD wanted to contest from seven seats, but it was scaled down to four. The list of candidates is likely to be released on Monday. The party is going to raise issues of the CAA-NRC, unemployment, disempowerment of Poorvanchalis , lack of quality higher education, among others.Lalu Prasad’s party has planned to attack AAP and chief minister Arvind Kejriwal over his lack of support to anti-CAA protests. Sources said Congress and RJD are eyeing the votes of people who are opposed to CAA and NRC. They feel they have good prospects, especially in the wake of the protests being widespread and not showing signs of abating.“Our party chief has always fought to protect the Constitution whenever it was under attack. He did not care about being opposed for doing so. We will fight the election with all our might and win,” said RJD Delhi in-charge Manoj Jha.The alliance will offer an interesting political battle in Burari constituency currently represented by AAP. The ruling and opposition parties of Bihar — JD(U) and RJD, respectively — will be fighting it out in Burari because JD(U) has got the seat in its alliance with BJP. AAP, which is leaving no stone unturned to retain the seat, has re-fielded sitting MLA Sanjeev Jha.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Congress inks pact, gives RJD 4 seats with sizeable Poorvanchali voters
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

RJD Delhi in-charge Manoj Jha

NEW DELHI: In an effort to bring together political parties against AAP, Congress on Sunday inked an alliance with Rashtriya Janata Dal. While Congress will be contesting from 66 assembly constituencies, RJD will fight from four seats that have a sizeable Poorvanchali population — Burari , Kirari, Uttam Nagar and Palam.

RJD, which is a part of UPA, won one seat in the recently concluded Jharkhand assembly polls. Initially, when talks of an alliance began, RJD wanted to contest from seven seats, but it was scaled down to four. The list of candidates is likely to be released on Monday. The party is going to raise issues of the CAA-NRC, unemployment, disempowerment of Poorvanchalis , lack of quality higher education, among others.

Lalu Prasad’s party has planned to attack AAP and chief minister Arvind Kejriwal over his lack of support to anti-CAA protests. Sources said Congress and RJD are eyeing the votes of people who are opposed to CAA and NRC. They feel they have good prospects, especially in the wake of the protests being widespread and not showing signs of abating.

“Our party chief has always fought to protect the Constitution whenever it was under attack. He did not care about being opposed for doing so. We will fight the election with all our might and win,” said RJD Delhi in-charge Manoj Jha.

The alliance will offer an interesting political battle in Burari constituency currently represented by AAP. The ruling and opposition parties of Bihar — JD(U) and RJD, respectively — will be fighting it out in Burari because JD(U) has got the seat in its alliance with BJP. AAP, which is leaving no stone unturned to retain the seat, has re-fielded sitting MLA Sanjeev Jha.

Title: Govt likely to announce probe into insider trading charges in Amaravati
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Amaravati: The government is likely to announce a high-level probe into charges of insider trading against TDP functionaries in the Amaravati region. The announcement is likely to be made at the three-day assembly session, which begins on Monday, on the basis of the preliminary inquiry report of the CID on the land scam in Amaravati. The government is likely to either opt for a CBI or Lokayukta investigation into the issue, according to sources.

The CID has allegedly gathered sufficient information to prove that former TDP legislators and ministers purchased large swathes of land in Amaravati even before it was announced as the capital. The CID has found several suspicious land deals in the capital city area that were made between June 2014 and December 2014.

YSRC has alleged that many TDP leaders had prior knowledge about the location of the capital and made massive investments in the specific area way before the official announcement was made. Subsequently, many of them sold the land at high prices when land rates rocketed. The land rates were around 10- 15 lakh per acre in Thullur region (Amaravati) before the announcement was made. After which the prices shot up to nearly 3- 4 crore per acre.

The YSRC leadership would like to highlight the alleged irregularities committed by TDP during the assembly session to defend their proposal to relocate the capital. The state government is also likely to ask the CID to handover the documents to the income tax and enforcement directorate for taking up further probe into the scam.

Finance minister Buggana Rajendranath Reddy had announced during the last session of the assembly that TDP functionaries were involved in the purchase of about 4,500 acres of land in Amaravati under benami names. He said the government would take a call on the issue.

Title: Worker dies due to gas leak in engg plant at Dahej
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Bharuch/Surat: One worker was killed due to gas leak at ISGEC Hitachi Zosen Limited's manufacturing plant at Dahej near here on Saturday. Tofik Khilji, who fell unconscious in the press vessel plant, was admitted to a private hospital in Bharuch on Friday. He died during treatment a day later.

Tofik was the only son of Aiyubbhai Khilji, a police constable, posted at Civil Hospital in Bharuch. Tofik had got married only four months ago. Dahej police have registered a case of accidental death and begun investigation.

Officials of director of safety and health department and Gujarat Pollution Control Board have started their separate investigation into the incident.

Title: Delhi assembly elections: JD(U), Akalis on board, BJP eyes pacts with LJP and JJP
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Manoj Tiwari meets autorickshaw drivers during a rally on DDU Marg on Sunday.

NEW DELHI: Bharatiya Janata Party on Sunday finalised pre-poll alliances with Nitish Kumar’s Janata Dal (United) and Akali Dal while talks were still on to take Ram Vilas Paswan’s Lok Janshakti Party and Dushyant Chautala’s Jannayak Janta Party on board.

JD(U) Delhi in charge Sanjay Kumar Jha confirmed that BJP had allotted it two seats — Burari and Sangam Vihar — with a seizable Poorvanchali population. Sources said the party could field former MLA SCL Gupta from Sangam Vihar and Shailendra Kumar from Burari.

“We will contest the election with all our strength and win both seats. The model of Bihar’s development under the leadership of Nitish Kumar is attracting people and they will vote for JD(U). In Bihar, the government has provided tap water to over 50% of the people and, by the end of this year, all households in Bihar will get drinking water. Even though Delhi is the capital of the country, not all households get drinking water in their taps. People are fed up with Arvind Kejriwal and are looking for an alternative,” Jha claimed.

Akali Dal has been offered four seats — Rajouri Garden, Hari Nagar, Kalkaji and Shahdara. According to sources, BJP has offered one seat, again with major Poorvanchali presence, to LJP, and another to JJP to target the Jat community. Till late into evening, talks were on to accommodate LJP and JJP. In the 2017 Rajouri Garden by-election, Akali Dal candidate Manjinder Singh Sirsa had contested on the BJP symbol and won.

Sources said BJP wanted to keep JD(U) and LJP in good humour ahead of the assembly polls in Bihar due towards the end of the year. Nitish Kumar was likely to campaign for JD(U) as well as some BJP candidates in Delhi, sources said. LJP’s chief Ram Vilas Paswan had recently locked horns with chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on the issue of water quality.

Meanwhile, chairman of Delhi Safai Karamcharis Commission, Sant Lal Chawaria, joined BJP and claimed that he was disenchanted with AAP. Delhi Commission for Safai Karamcharis was established in 2006 to safeguard the rights and interests of sanitation workers in Delhi.

Title: Cops serve notices under Sec 149
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijayawada: As tensions mount in the capital region with the special assembly session scheduled on Monday that is likely to give legislative nod to the three-capital proposal, the police have pulled out all the stops to prevent the situation from spiralling out.

Security measures across Krishna and Guntur districts have been stepped up. Section 144 of Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) has been imposed in the capital region and notices under Section 149 of CrPC have been served on functionaries of all political parties, which are part of the JAC, asking them not to participate in the ‘Assembly Muttadi’ and other protests.

Meanwhile, Guntur police have served notices on farmers and representatives of political parties in the district who have openly supported the Assembly Muttadi on Friday and Saturday. On Sunday, Vijayawada police served notices on MP Kesineni Srinivas (Nani), MLC Budha Venkanna, MLA Gadde Rammohan Rao, former MLAs Bode Prasad, Bonda Umamaheswara Rao and representatives from other political parties.

While opposition parties have criticised the government and police department for issuing notices, cops have justified their move citing procedures and directions of the high court.

A top official, on condition of anonymity, told TOI that notices under section 149 CrPC are not new and part of the procedure under section 144 CrPC. “Even the high court said in its recent directions that prior notices are to be given about section 144” the official said.

While farmers and political parties have proposed to gherao the assembly when it meets for the special session for three days, the Amaravati Parirakshana Joint Action Committee (JAC) has also given a call for Jail Bharo and lay siege to the collectorate.

Title: A day after woman’s death, cables yet to be removed
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Aurangabad: Cables on the road that were responsible for a woman's death in a road accident near Ram Nagar along Jalna Road are yet to be removed from the spot.

On Saturday, a 39-year-old woman, a resident of Kasliwal Purva, was riding her scooter on the road when she fell off her vehicle after it became stuck in cables in front of Sahyadri Hospital. She was run over by a truck before she could get up.

On Sunday evening, the cables could still be seen at the spot.

Aurangabad Municipal Corporation commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey said a drive would be initiated from Monday to remove the cables.

The problem of cables lying along roads in the city is not new. TOI had published reports about inconvenience caused to commuters in the area, but the AMC has been slow to react. Neighbourhoods across the city, including market areas of Old City such as Aurangapura, Gulmandi, Tilak Path, Shahgunj to Cidco and Hudco areas, have been affected by the problem.

The AMC is supposed to confiscate such cables and penalise offenders. But weak enforcement continues to jeopardise citizens' lives. Fifteen days ago, a drive by the electricity and the anti-encroachment departments managed to remove cables from roads through Zone 1, Zone 2 and Zone 5. But zones 3, 4, 6, 7, 8 and 9 were not part of the drive. Saturday's accident took place in zone 6.

Sangita Chavan, a resident of Rajiv Gandhi Nagar near Kamgar Chowk, said timely action by the AMC could've prevented tragedy.

The AMC commissioner said he visited the accident spot on Sunday. “Based on a High Court order, I had instructed civic officials to resolve the problem when I had joined in December," said Pandey. "On Saturday, I called a meeting of zone officers and HoDs to discuss the problem. The drive to remove the cables couldn't take place the next day because it was a Sunday. The civic body will start a drive to remove the cables on Monday."

Title: Hospital director booked for molestation
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: A 39-year-old woman has alleged molestation by the director of a high-profile hospital at Mankapur. Mankapur police have booked the director, identified as Suraj Tripathi, after a complaint lodged by the woman.

It is learnt, the director has been making undue advances towards the woman since their official trip to Oman in 2016.

The woman told police that the director would touch her inappropriately while travelling together. According to her, she had also approached the higher management of the hospital following which the director had tried to apologize but later continued with his objectionable behaviour.

The woman stated in her police statement that the director had tried to lure her under the influence of alcohol. He had also asked to share a room with him. She also told police that the director had tried to gift her expensive valuables on her birthday and also tried to stalk her.

Title: Odisha: Koraput panchayats turn unused land into vegetable farms
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The panchayat expects to gain at least Rs 10 lakh from the IMF hub

KORAPUT: Two months ago, 18 acres of land belonging to the panchayat in Koraput ’s Kamra lay unused and encroached upon. Eight weeks later, the Borigumma block administration, under which the panchayat falls, has successfully transformed the 18 acres into an integrated multi-farming (IMF) hub, which can not only provide round-the-year income to women’s self-help groups (SHG)s, but also provide a sustainable income to the panchayat for use in development work.

The project, which is seeing the slow but steady growth of agriculture in the tribal hinterland of Odisha, is the first of its kind in the state, and has been undertaken by the convergence of schemes such as MGNREGA, state finance scheme (SFC) and central financial scheme (CFC).

“Funds from the MGNREGA, SFC and CFC are mostly used in a scattered manner and on routine work like construction of ponds, roads and culverts in villages. We thought of doing something different that would have multi-dimensional benefits,” said Pranay Ranjan Behera, block development officer of Borigumma and the brains behind the scheme.

Thus, the panchayat land now has a pond measuring 150x200 feet for pisciculture, a poultry farm, a dairy farm, space for mushroom cultivation, floriculture, horticulture and a nutritional garden. It even has a vermi-compost pit. “We have planted 2,000, 3,000 and 500 units each of banana, papaya and coconut saplings. Vegetables will be grown in an organic manner and they will be supplied to schools to make mid-day meal,” said Behera

The panchayat expects to gain at least Rs 10 lakh from the IMF hub. Once completed, each unit of the IMF hub will be handed over on lease to women’s SHGs of the panchayat. “This will enhance their economy,” said Behera.

Kamra is not an isolated case; the block is developing similar IMF hubs on unused land between 10 and 18 acres in all its 31 panchayats. Work is under way in Malda, Kamra, Benasur, Hardoli, Nuaguan, Munja, Sasahandi and Borigumma panchayats. “Each project of an IMF hub requires an investment of Rs 40 to Rs 45 lakh and the SHGs would be properly trained in maintaining them before they are handed over to the groups,” said Satyanarayan Sethi, assistant engineer, Borigumma block.

The challenges are many. Being a tribal-dominated area, the people here have been engaged in traditional activities and will now have to be motivated to take up settled agriculture. Officials said it would also require work to convince panchayats to divert funds to the IMF project. “Initially, the panchayats were against diverting funds for the integrated farming hub. The concept itself was new for them,” Behera, adding that the panchayat representatives needed a lot of convincing.

The project has not only provided the panchayats a regular income, it has also beatified the area and saved land from encroachers. “We never imagined that farming could be done in such an integrated manner. We are happy to see the development and we hope to create more such units in the panchayats,” said Nadai Bhatra, a resident of Malda panchayat.

Title: Speaker warns of serious consequences
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijayawada: Assembly speaker Tammineni Sitharam on Sunday warned of serious consequences if anyone tries to hinder the assembly session. He directed the police to make arrangements so that the session can be conducted smoothly. Everyone has the right to protest but should not cross the limits,” said the speaker.

Sitharam criticised TDP for urging protesters to lay siege to the assembly. He said no one would be allowed to stall assembly proceedings. “Creating obstruction in assembly proceedings will surely land the agitators in trouble. Such actions mount to insulting the Constitution,” said the speaker, adding that the assembly would be within its right to summon those who create obstructions and take action against them.

He said people have the right to express their dissent and participate in agitation, but in a peaceful manner. He advised the protesters to stay calm and raise their issues peacefully. He suggested that farmers should discuss their issues with the government. tnn

Title: Polio vaccination campaign in district
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nashik: Over 10,000 health employees and workers administered pulse polio vaccine to children below five years of age on Sunday under the national pulse polio vaccination campaign.

Health employees and workers administered polio dose to the beneficiaries through hundreds of booths set up across the city and district, including bus stands and railway stations.

Civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale said that the target was to administer the vaccine free of cost to 4.54 lakh children from zero to five years of age across the district.

The pulse polio campaign was inaugurated at the district level by collector Suraj Mandhare at the Nashik civil hospital. Deputy director of health of Nashik division Ratna Raokhande, civil surgeon Suresh Jagdale and other senior officials were also present during the inauguration.

In his address during the inauguration, Mandhare appealed to people to ensure that they administered all the necessary vaccines to their children. He said that children were the nation’s most valuable asset. Hence, they should be administered the vaccine to safeguard them from polio which was a serious problem.

Jagdale, district health officer Vijay Dekate, Nashik Municipal Corporation health officer Nitin Ravate and other medical officers and health staff made best arrangements to ensure that every child under the age of 5 was given the polio dose.

Jagdale said that the percentage of children administered the dose on Sunday will be made available only on Monday, adding that the aim of the health officers, employees and workers was to ensure 100% polio vaccination in the district.

Title: 1.54 lakh children in Aurangabad administered polio drops
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: Around 1.54 lakh children between the age group of zero to five were administered polio drops in the pulse polio drive conducted in the city at 639 boots set up by the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation ( AMC ) on Sunday.

The drive was inaugurated at 8 am in the railway station premises by mayor Nandkumar Ghodele who administered polio drops to the first few children. AMC standing committee chairman Jaishree Kulkarni and house leader Vikas Jain were present too.

The municipal corporation had employed 35 reporting units, eight core committee medical officers, nine assistant medical officers, 1,878 health workers and 132 supervisors for the drive.

As many as 125 transit teams, 23 mobile teams and one night team were engaged. Apart from the urban health centres of the municipal corporation, the drive was carried out in schools, Central Bus Stand, Cidco Bus Stand and the Aurangabad railway station .

Under the guidance of municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey, AMC medical officer Nita Padalkar and programme officer Ujwala Bhamre had planned the drive with the target to vaccinate 2,00,906 children in the AMC limits between the age group of zero to five. The children who have not yet been administered the dose will be reached out through AMC’s door-to-door campaign in the next 8 to 10 days.

Title: Key MLAs stay away from TDP strategy discussions
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Amaravati: The TDP has demanded that the state government allow peoples in all the 175 assembly constituencies to vote on the shift of capital city from Amaravati. The party said it would not raise any further objection if a majority of the people support the government proposal.

TDP supremo Chandrababu Naidu chaired a legislature party meeting at the party’s central office in Mangalagiri on Sunday. Naidu discussed the strategy to be adopted in the assembly session to counter the state government’s plans to shift the capital out of Amaravati. Interestingly, at least five-six MLAs stayed away from the meeting, including Ganta Srinivasa Rao, Vallabhaneni Vamsi and Maddali Giridhar.

Speaking to the media after the TDLP meeting, senior legislator Nimmala Ramanaidu said neither Visakhapatnam will benefit from shifting of few government offices as it was already a big city, nor the relocation of the high court would benefit Rayalaseema region. The TDP believes that decentralisation of development is required to develop the under-developed regions but three-capitals will not help it, he said.

“We demand that the government conduct a fair peoples ballot in all the constituencies on the issue of decentralisation of the capital city. We will accept the peoples’ mandate whichever way it goes,” said Ramanaidu.

TDP issued a whip to all its legislators asking them to attend the assembly session and participate in the voting if required. The party asked the legislators to follow the instructions of the party during the voting and legislators who violate the whip might attract action. TDP is worried about a few legislators extending their support to the YSRC government in the assembly.

Title: No pomp and show: CM Arvind Kejriwal’s family goes door to door
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

CM Kejriwal’s wife Sunita and daughter Harshita campaign for AAP

NEW DELHI: Humility will always open more doors of support. This seems to be the mantra that has been adopted by the family of chief minister Arvind Kejriwal .

While the AAP national convener was out on Sunday publicising his “guarantee card” to people as a part of his campaign for the assembly polls, his wife Sunita, daughter Harshita and son Pulkit were going around the West Ansari Nagar constituency to take feedback from the electorate. And all this was being done by them as common party workers without advertising who they were.

The three family members were accompanied by four AAP workers without any pomp and show while going door-to-door at the doctors’ and staff quarters of AIIMS.

In F-Block, Sunita asked the residents, “How many voters are there in your household?” After getting an answer, she requested them to vote for AAP and handed over the party’s “report card”. Harshita and Pulkit apprised the youth about the good work done by the AAP government in colleges, schools and hospitals.

Pulkit said that he attended college from Monday to Friday and dedicated the weekend to campaigning for his father. “Massive changes have been done in Delhi government schools and, as a result, they have reached the top spots. I have been telling people about the good education being imparted by government schools in the capital,” he added.

Harshita said, “Most of the people I interacted with raised concerns about pollution. My father eagerly waits for us at home to tell him the feedback and suggestions given by people.”

“I will campaign on weekdays the entire day and my son and daughter will join me in the evening after finishing off their work and studies,” said Sunita.

At times, the volunteers let it slip that the three “workers” campaigning at people’s doorsteps were in fact the CM’s family members. This was when a flurry of activity ensued and people rushed to take selfies with the trio. A resident, Anjali Devi, said, “I had never imagined that a chief minister’s family could be so humble.”

CM Kejriwal’s wife Sunita and daughter Harshita campaign for AAP
