Title: Helpline fails to address civic issues, citizens upset
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Aurangabad: Barely 20 days after the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) issued a WhatsApp helpline to address civic issues, residents have expressed dissatisfaction over its usefulness, adding that several complaints have not been addressed through the helpline number.

In a public notice issued by the public relations department of the municipal corporation, the number 9607933541 was announced as the AMC helpline number. The notice stated that residents can send in their complaints about civic issues through Whatsapp on the number. The AMC had asked residents to send photos and videos related to the problem through the mobile app on the helpline.

According to Rahul Ingle, activist of Shahar Parivartan Aghadi, several complaints related to water pipeline and valve leakages, non-functioning streetlights, street dogs and waste collection were made on the helpline, but the complainants have not received any solution.

“I have personally made several complaints, but no official from the municipal corporation turned up to address the matter. Residents are worried about insect and snake bites while entering the Amrut Garden in the Cidco N-3 area due to lack of maintenance in the garden. A complaint in the regard was filed through the helpline number 15 days ago, however, there has been no response from the civic body,” Ingle said.

Prahlad Dandge from Mukunwadi had lodged a complaint about street dogs menace and Aman Timothy had lodged a complaint about drainage waste lying on roads in the Cidco N-5 area. Neither of the complaints have been addressed.

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey, who conceptualised the helpline, said that he had taken a review meeting regarding the functioning of the helpline last week and had encountered some problems.

Title: Cops creating panic in state: Buddha
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijayawada: TDP MLC Buddha Venkanna said they will ensure that ‘Chalo Assembly’ is a success.

Addressing the media, here on Sunday, Venkanna condemned the fact that notices had been issued to activists under Section 149 of CrPc. “Police were creating an atmosphere of panic . It seems there is an emergency-like situations prevailing in the state ,” he said. He called on the public to come on streets on Monday and protest in a peaceful way. tnn

Title: What sewage and water issues are you facing in your locality?
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Secunderabad: With local authorities gearing up to solve water and sewage problems in Sithaphalmandi, TOI asked readers about other areas facing similar issues

HMWS&SB supplies water every alternate day in most areas. However during summer, residents experience a torrid time due to low water pressure. Throughout the year, water pressure is uneven due to wastage of water on account of leaking pipelines. Despite several reminders, leakages have still not been plugged at all places. HMWS&SB authorities should take a concerted stand to disconnect all illegal water connections. With regard to the sewage, overflowing drains are a common sight. Despite residents articulating their views through print media and interacting with officials on several occasions, no substantial action has been taken — Srinivasan Ramaswamy

The government should not accord permission for fresh residential constructions till ground water level improves in all areas and supply of municipal water is stabilized. Though there is a limit on the depth to which you can dig a borewell, most of the borewells are dug illegally. The government must also work to increase the water supply. Developmental work in colony could be taken with the contribution of residents — Ravindranath Todehal

Most areas in Secunderabad face the issue of irregular water supply. The government and authorities should ensure strict supply of clean drinking water on alternate days. People should be educated on how to use water smartly. Most drainage systems need to be overhauled and the issue of encroachment should not be ignored. Strict vigil is the solution to contain encroachments. Most of the drains are blocked and this leads to inundation during monsoon. This is must be looked into — Deepesh Surana

Those visiting Niloufer Cancer Hospital are compelled to walk on sewage water overflowing from a drain adjacent to the hospital. Authorities must immediately fix this as an open drain is not just unhealthy but there have also been cases of people slipping of the sewage water and hurting themselves. Though authorities have been informed about the situation, no action has been taken — Syed Shamsuddin Maghrabi

The residents of Trimurthy colony, Mahendra Hills are facing severe water shortage issues. We only getting water once in three days. Sometimes due to problems with the supply system we have not received water even after four days. Why are we not being provided with water despite paying house tax and water charges promptly? I request the authorities to provide water to our colony on alternate days — Umesh Chandra Pandey

The problem of sewage and water shortage is common is several areas such as Lalaguda, Addagutta, Ambedkar Nagar, Nallagutta,Bhoiguda etc . I request the concerned authorities and local corporators to look into the problem and find a permanent solution to these long standing issues — Nandikanti Sai Kumar

Title: Karamsad rally for special status
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Around 500 residents participated in the protest rally on Sunday

Vadodara/ Anand: Karamsad town of Anand district on Sunday witnessed fresh round of protest with around 500 residents taking part in a rally demanding due recognition for the ancestral town of Sardar Patel.

The agitation per se is not new as discontentment had been brewing here since the last two years on the same agenda.

However, fresh fears of the town losing its identity were triggered after the merger with Anand Nagarpalika surfaced. The rally, which was organized by Mithilesh Amin, former councillor of Karamsad Nagarpalika, took place from Karamsad bus stand to Sardar House, the place where country’s first deputy Prime Minister and India’s Iron man had spent his formative days.

“Under the garb of development, the state government is proposing to merge Karamsad, Vallabh Vidyanagar and Anand,” said Amin, who now leads the Karamsad Nagarik Samiti. He added that the move is totally unwarranted as both Karamsad and Vallabh Vidyanagar are already developed. “Such a merger would only mean that Karamsad will lose its unique identity,” he said.

The rally on Sunday also witnessed the participation of religious leaders from temples located in the town apart from local people.

Amin, who had resigned from BJP on the grounds that the party did not fulfil its promise to give national status to Karamsad, alleged that there is no concrete plan on what kind of development is being planned for the town.

In 2018, Karamsad had witnessed a similar movement after a group under the umbrella of Sardar Hitrakshak Samiti had started an indefinite hunger strike demanding special recognition for Karamsad.

Rashesh Patel, a resident who has done research on Sardar Patel’s life, vowed to continue with the protest.

“If merging a town is the only solution, the state government should first merge Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s hometown Vadnagar with Visnagar which is a bigger town. Let’s see if Vadnagar ends up being just another part of Visnagar, or the merger brings development to Vadnagar. If the latter takes shape, a year later, they can talk of merging Karamsad with Anand,” Patel asserted.

Title: CAA protest violence: Mangaluru police issue notices to people in Kerala
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

File picture of police trying to control the situation during anti-CAA protests in Mangaluru on December 19

Title: Fog delays dolphin headcount along Ganjam coast by a day
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The 54-km-long coastal division has been divided into four sectors for enumeration of dolphins

BERHAMPUR: Dense fog coupled with high tidal waves in the sea played spoilsport during the annual dolphin survey off the Ganjam coast scheduled to begin on Sunday morning.

The Berhampur forest division was forced to reschedule the headcount to Monday in the coastal areas of the district. The survey in the Chilka Lake was conducted successfully.

“We were forced to put off the census along the coast owing to poor visibility,” the divisional forest officer, (Berhampur), Amlan Nayak, said.

The wildlife division of the state forest department had scheduled to conduct the dolphin survey along the coast and the Chilika Lake. “As per schedule, the survey teams reached the spots in different sectors along the Ganjam coast at 6am. But they could not venture into the sea owing to the fog as well as the rough sea,” the range officer of Berhampur, Raja Rao Subudhi, said.

The 54-km long coastal division has been divided into four sectors for the enumeration of dolphins . They are Prayagi to Purunabandh, Purunabandh to Gopalpur, Gopalpur to Markandi and Markandi to Patisunapur. At least five persons have been engaged in each sector for the enumeration using binoculars.

The division had successfully conducted the pre-survey of dolphins in the coastal area on January 9 when they sighted the congregation of different species. “We noticed bottlenose and humpback species of the dolphins off the coast,” the range officer said .

Last year, they had sighted 29 dolphins of two different species during the census off the Ganjam coast. There were 15 humpback dolphins and 14 bottlenose ones, an official said.

Title: Ayodhya cops can apply for leave through app
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

To ease pressure on junior police personnel and to address their grievance of never getting leave from work, A... Read More

AYODHYA: To ease pressure on junior police personnel and to address their grievance of never getting leave from work, Ayodhya police have introduced an electronic leave management system .

Sub inspectors and constables can now apply for leave through the Smart E Police app. They would not have to meet any officer to personally request them for leave. Launched in Ayodhya as a pilot project, the app will be introduced for other districts too.

Ayodhya SSP Ashish Tiwari said, “The Smart E Police app can be downloaded on any mobile phone. Sub inspectors and constables can apply for leave through this app and expect immediate response from their seniors.”

As soon as an officer applies for leave, the app will show the applicant’s leave history and availability of other personnel in their police station or unit on the said dates. Accordingly, the applicant will be granted leave.

Before going on leave, the applicant will get their ‘rawaangi’ (departure) registered on the app. On return, they will register ‘aamad’ (arrival) on the app. The information will automatically be sent to the applicant’s SHO, CO and ASP.

For an emergency leave, the applicant will choose the ‘emergency’ option in the app.

“When I took charge, I met a constable who had been running from SHO to CO then to ASP before coming to me in the evening to ask for leave. His mother had passed away but for 24 hours after he got the news, he had been running around for approval. I hope such a situation does not arise again,” said Tiwari.

Title: SFS High School’s 150th anniversary celebrations kick off from Thursday
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: St. Francis de Sales High School and Jr. College’s (SFS) 150th anniversary celebrations will kick off this Thursday with numerous other events planned for the entire year. The sesquicentennial (150 years) jubilee’s flagship event, a grand concert, will be held on November 7 for which Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde has consented to be the chief guest.

Fr Prashant, principal of SFS School, said, “Founded with a mere four students in 1870 in Kamptee, SFS has grown and expanded tremendously. Currently, we provide education, along with all-round development to over 3500 students in our school.”

Celebrations of this jubilee year will begin on Thursday by celebrating the Feast of St. Francis de Sales, the patron saint of the school, with the Holy Eucharist at 5:30 pm at the SFS Primary premises. Fr. Prashant said “The most reverend Elias Gonsalves, Archbishop of Nagpur, shall be the main celebrant and all the priests associated with SFS will be present for the mass. Moving onwards, we have planned year-long programmes, which will include cultural programmes, sports, debates, and essay competitions. The SFS Old Boys’ Association is working closely with us to ensure that the year-long celebration is a success.”

The school’s history is also available online at http://sfsschoolnagpur.com. To commemorate and to celebrate the joyous occasion of our sesquicentennial in 2020, the school is planning to publish a souvenir. This souvenir will be distributed to all our students – both past and present, our diocesan members and all our well-wishers. A soft copy will also be uploaded on our website. The sesquicentennial jubilee will conclude on the January 23, 2021 with a thanksgiving mass.

Title: AMC sits over rampant water wastage plaints
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Aurangabad: A damaged 700 mm water pipeline on the railway station road for the past three years is leading to rampant wastage of water and the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC), which is supplying water once in 6 days to residents, appears to be in no rush to plug the problem.

The water leaking from the pipeline percolates under the ground and flows out near the Labh Chambers shopping complex across the road, leading to waterlogging. Owing to this, the 13 shops in the shopping complex are being subjected to constant inconvenience.

These businesses have employed two 2-horsepower automated motors that 24x7 keep pumping out the water into the drain. However, if any of the two motors develop a snag, those vising the complex are in for major trouble. The shopowners are spending around Rs 2,000 every month for running the motor.

According to Bagyesh Mhaske Patil, owner of two offices in the complex, the problem is going on for the last 3 years. “We have made several representations to Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC). At first they were in denial that it is the water from the pipeline but after we presented them the test report, it was established that it was potable water. The engineers from the civic water department stated that they have sought permission from the AMC’s road department to dig the road to check and repair the leakage,” he said.

The shopowners have registered complaints with the AMC but inaction on part of the civic officials is not only leading to inconvenience but also wastage of water.

Municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey said he is not aware of the matter. “I will check with my officials and instruct necessary action,” he said.

Pandey had earlier rapped the civic officials for water wastage due to valve leakage in Hudco area.

Title: TDP files complaint against Boston Group
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vijayawada: TDP politburo member Varla Ramaiah and Mangalagiri party in-charge Ganji Chiranjeevi lodged a complaint with Mangalagiri rural police alleging that Boston Consulting Group ( BCG ) has resorted to cheating by giving a false report to the government on the capital.

TDP alleged that BCG in its report said Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Madras conducted soil tests in Amaravati and found the area was not suitable for constructions. Ramaiah said IIT Madras never conducted any soil test in Amaravati.

Ramaiah said BCG resorted to cheating by submitting a false report to the government based on which the state government is planning to shift the capital from Amaravati. tnn

Title: Seek fresh mandate on capital relocation: Cong
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Tirupati: The Congress has dared chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy to dissolve the government and seek fresh mandate on relocating the state capital.

The party’s newly-appointed working president Narreddy Tulasi Reddy on Sunday demanded that the YSRC government take a cue from the British ‘Brexit’. Speaking to the media at a function organised to felicitate him on his new role here, Reddy pointed out that the state cannot unilaterally announce such a major policy decision.

“The voters would have rejected YSRC had it announced its capital plan before the elections,” he said. tnn

Title: High crimes: Opioid-based drug worth crores seized, 3 arrested in Delhi
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: In a major drug haul, Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) seized a consignment of a staggering 7,24,840 tablets and 1,400 injections of opioid-based analgesic Tramadol worth crores of rupees. Three traffickers, including a wholesale medicine trader and a chemist, have been arrested till now.The module operated across north India and is suspected to be part of a bigger international syndicate trying to push the drug — which is getting extremely popular among teenagers — to school and college students in Delhi.While raids are on in Delhi, UP and Punjab and more arrests are likely, NCB is trying to reach to the source and kingpin of this syndicate. The arrested men — Manoj Kumar, Mohit and Gaurav Aggarwal — are natives of Agra. They were nabbed by a special team led by NCB zonal director KPS Malhotra.A few days ago, NCB had received inputs that a few people involved in the illicit trade of psychotropic drugs were getting delivery at a courier firm’s office.Teams comprising additional director Kuldeep Sharma conducted a raid and seized a parcel containing 50,000 Tramadol tablets. Another raid was carried out in Ludhiana, where the parcel was supposed to be shipped, and the receiver, Kumar, was arrested. Kumar, who runs a medicine shop, revealed that the parcel was sent by Aggarwal, who was subsequently apprehended. Mohit, the wholesale dealer, was arrested later and the entire consignment seized.“Kumar didn’t have a licence to trade narcotics and psychotropic medicines. He committed the crime owing to the huge profit margins in the illicit retail and wholesale trade of psychotropic medicines. He used to supply these medicines to various parts of the country,” Malhotra said.The drugs were diverted from lawful channels into the trafficking network, Malhotra said, adding, “The seized psychotropic medicines were produced by companies having a valid licence. We are trying to analyse the diversion from the manufacturing/logistics channel. The role of pharmaceutical companies, dealers and retailers is being investigated.”AIIMS professor Dr Lall said the seized drug is of schedule H/H1/X, which needs a doctor’s prescription to procure from a pharmacist. “The seized drugs are anti-anxiety, sedatives and painkillers, which are both habit forming and create dependence. They are used in both post-operative care and drug deaddiction centres. The effect of these drugs on the brain is similar to heroin/opioid-based narcotics and are administered to control withdrawal symptoms in patients at drug deaddiction centres,” he added.Tramadol is used in the treatment of moderate to severe pain, but misused by teenagers for mood enhancement and euphoria. WHO says the drug can produce physical dependence when used daily for more than a few weeks.

Title: Maharashtra: CARA advises special counselling sessions
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

PUNE: The Central Adoption Resource Authority (CARA) has directed all state adoption resource authority offices and adoption institutions to conduct special counselling sessions for “older”children put up for adoption.

In a recent directive, they have told all State Adoption Resource Authority (SARA) bodies across the country and the child care institutions to have special sessions to address adaptation or adjustment issues of older children placed under adoption.

In the last five years, over 1,000 cases of children above the age of eight years have been returned to the institutions across the country over adjustment issues. The state too had over 200 such cases as per data provided by the authority.

CARA officials told TOI that while they are placing older children in homes, adjustment issues need addressing. All state governments have to take it upon themselves to address this issue through their regional state adoption resource authority offices, the official said.

“There should be special counselling sessions and older children adoption issues have been an issue. Special counselling will help and we are working on it,’’an official from CARA said.

Data indicate that the highest number of children returning to institutions was in 2014-15_a total of 387 of the 4,362 adopted children. In 2015-16, a total of 236 of the 3,677 adopted children returned by adoptive parents.

In 2016-17, a total of 195 of 3,788 adopted children were returned while in 2017-18, a total of 153 of a total of 3,927 adopted children were returned by adoptive parents, the data shared by CARA stated. The 2018-19 numbers showed that a total of 133 out of 4,027 children were returned by adoptive parents.

A counsellor working in one of the adoption agencies told TOI that older children do face issues. The child care institutions must groom these children accordingly and ready them with proper counselling . Parents who adopt older children need a different strategy, she added.

A parent in her mid-40s, who adopted a slightly older child, had to attend counselling sessions with the institution and outside with her daughter so that they do not face adjustment issues. “My daughter had adjustment issues initially but we had to work on our relationship and be patient,’’ the parent told TOI.

At child care institutions, children are groomed in a different way. They have to be prepared and counselled for adoption so that they adjust with the new families, another official from a home care institution, said. “Their attachment to the institution and caretaker makes them want to come back,’’she added.

Title: 35 H1N1 cases in January, state says situation in control
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: With a drop in temperature, there has been a steady rise in number of swine flu ( H1N1 ) cases in the state. As many as 35 cases have been reported since the beginning of the year, most of them are from the city and its peripheral areas. Officials had sent out prior alerts of a possible outbreak in recent months and expect the number of cases to rise till February.

Currently, two patients are undergoing treatment at Gandhi Hospital while another is being treated at the Chest Hospital. The 35 samples which have tested positive are among 138 samples which tested for the presence of the virus. It is reported the virus may have mutated.

However, officials are not raising an alarm as there was no outbreak reported. “Most cases are reported from different areas of the city with many samples being sent from corporate hospitals. With the temperature fluctuation, this had been expected but the numbers are less than what they were during the same period last year. It is possible that a mutation may occur given the two-year trend of change in strain noticed so far,” said a senior official from the state health department .

In anticipation of an H1N1 outbreak, the health department had been issuing advisories since last two months. While district hospitals and tertiary centres have been advised to prepare and review their isolation wards, district-level officials have been asked to redirect all suspected cases to the tertiary centres in the city — Gandhi Hospital, Osmania General Hospital and Niloufer Hospital.

Title: Bizman killed, four injured in ORR accident
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: A 29-year-old businessman died while four others were injured when the car they were travelling in rammed into a truck on the Outer Ring Road ( ORR ) in the wee hours of Sunday. The group of friends were travelling towards Gachibowli from Andhra Pradesh’s East Godavari district.

The businessman, V Satyanarayana Reddy, died on the spot as a result of multiple injuries, including severe head injury. The four others sustained minor injuries and have been shifted to a hospital for treatment. “Reddy, who was behind the wheel, was speeding and rammed into the truck, which was moving in the same direction,” said Shamshabad sub-inspector N Sridhar. A case has been booked against the truck driver who was absconding. TNN

According to the recent NCRB 2018 data, as many as 7,110 people died in road accidents in Telangana with 425 victims in Hyderabad alone.

Title: Pune: Activists express concerns over doubtful citizenship tag in NPR
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Citizens protest CAA and NRC at Kauserbaug on Sunday

PUNE: Citizens and civic acivistis have expressed concerns over the chances of getting the “doubtful citizenship” tag during collection and verification of the National Population Register ( NPR ) data by the local registrar or the district collectorate.

They claimed that an individual or a family could be marked “doubtful” during the NPR process, though there were no rules defined in the statute to put anyone in the category.

“The Citizenship (Registration of Citizens and Issue of National Identity Cards) Rules, 2003, has not defined what is ‘doubtful citizenship’. In fact, it does not even exist in the main law — Citizenship Act of 1955. All it says in the sub-rule (4) of Rule 4 that the ‘local registrar’ will make such a marking,” a citizen said on condition of anonymity.

“If the discretion is left to the local registrars, then biases are bound to emerge. If a citizen is born in India, there should be no reason for him/her to prove the citizenship. While NPR has been showcased as a drive to ensure security, it will declare many citizens under the ‘doubtful category’ and categorize them as ‘non-citizens’,” People’s Union for Civil Liberties (PUCL) activist Manisha Gupte activist said on Sunday.

“The minority, women without proper documents in the rural areas and children born at home will suffer the most. The drive will put the minority in trouble,” she said.

Ramesh Awasthi of PUCL said, “Many members of my family won’t be able to prove their citizenship because my grandparents came from Lahore and Rawalpindi during the Partition. Whoever chose to stay in India after the Partition have proved their citizenship at the time of Independence. They should not have to go through it again.”

Activist Aslam Isak Bagwan said, “The new columns in the NPR demanding birth certificates and records of parents are unnecessary. This will unnecessarily put everyone in the ‘doubtful’ category and add to the children's’ woes.”

Alsaba Sheikh, also an activist, said, “When people have their voter ID card and passport, then why hold a drive such as NPR that will put many in the ‘doubtful citizenship’ category? We have been protesting against the drive for the last 10 days in Kausar Baug.”

The 2003 Rules provide for verification of the details in the population register by the local registrar, who will find out the cases of “doubtful citizenship” and conduct further enquiries. Once the enquiries are done, the local registrar will prepare a draft (Local Register of Indian Citizens) that will exclude people unable to prove their citizenship through documentary evidence.

Several activists and former bureaucrats have pointed out that it was at this stage that the experience of Assam’s citizens could cause apprehensions in the minds of those required to establish their citizenship, whether or not they profess any religion.

The NPR 2020, unlike NPR 2010, asks not only for the names of the parents of the residents, but also seeks to record their dates and places of birth. A person unable to furnish details for his/her parents or, for that matter, for himself/herself could well be classified as a “doubtful citizen”.

“People across the country are seen rushing to get their birth certificates. The problem is magnified in a country where the maintenance of birth records is poor. The highly inefficient birth registration system makes the matter worse,” an official said on condition of anonymity.

Title: Teachers’ associations demand immediate release of professor
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: Condemning the arrest of Osmania University associate professor Ch Kaseem over alleged Maoist links, several teacher unions, including United Teachers ’ Federation (UTF), Telangana Teachers’ Federation (TTF) and Telangana Progressive Teachers’ Federation (TPTF) have demanded the immediate release of the academic.

They said that it was unconstitutional to arrest Kaseem, who has been teaching and penning revolutionary writings for years now.

“False cases registered against Kaseem should be withdrawn and he should be released immediately,” Chava Ravi of UTF said, adding his arrest was unconstitutional.

The teachers questioned the reasons for the sudden arrest of Kaseem. “It’s not like he was absconding, he was very much at the varsity since 2013. Why arrest him all of a sudden in a false case that has been pending since 2016?” questioned E Raghunandan of TPTF.

They also took a dig at police for the way searches were conducted at the residence of Kaseem in the early hours and manhandling him. “They forcefully entered his house on the varsity campus and damaged private property. This is illegal and unconstitutional,” said Y Ashok Kumar, a teacher.

The members of Ambedkar Students’ Association, University of Hyderabad, also condemned the arrest of the OU academic and demanded his immediate release.

Kaseem joined the Telugu department at the Osmania University in 2013. Before joining OU, he had worked at Oriental College – Andhra Saraswatha Parishath. He also worked at Nizam College.

Title: OU academic case: Traffic curbs & preventive arrests
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: After producing him before Telangana high court Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan at his residence, Siddipet police took Osmania University faculty C Kaseem, who was arrested in an Unlawful Activities Prevention Act (UAPA) case, to Sangareddy jail for judicial remand. Cops cordoned off the areas surrounding the CJ’s house in Banjara Hills when Kaseem was present there and took into custody 10 persons who tried to go towards the CJ’s official residence to meet Kaseem.

After arresting associate professor Kaseem from his official quarters on the university campus on Saturday in the UAPA case registered at the Mulugu police station in 2016, Siddipet police produced him before the Gajwel court magistrate in the night. Kaseem was sent in judicial remand. As per the directions of the Telangana HC, police on Sunday morning produced Kaseem before the CJ at his official residence in Banjara Hills.

Banjara Hills police cordoned off the area surrounding the CJ’s residence on Road Number 7, Banjara Hills, from 9.30am till 2.30pm when Kaseem was taken back to Sangareddy prison. “We have diverted the traffic to parallel roads to prevent any kind of crowd gathering near the CJ’s residence,” Banjara Hills inspector (detective) Ravi Kumar said. “Those who were taken into preventive custody were shifted to Goshamahal stadium and they were released later,” the inspector said.

Police took 10 people, including members of Telangana Vidyarthi Vedika (TVV) and Viplava Rachayitala Sangham (Virasam ) into preventive custody when they tried to go towards the CJ’s residence to meet Kaseem.

Title: Enthusiastic Barodians enliven Happy Streets
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Vadodara: Braving the cold, enthusiastic Barodians added zest to peppy Zumba music with their energetic steps at the Happy Streets on Sunday. Organized by The Times of India on Sayajibaug Road, people turned up at the crack of dawn, on a stretch of road that is out of bounds for pedestrians on other days.

Kids, saw youngsters and adults matching steps to Zumba instructors who wooed the crowd with their innovative steps.

Children skated, teenagers cycled while some just jay walked on the street unhindered by speeding commuters. City police commissioner Anupam Singh Gahlaut too turned up at the Happy Streets. “It’s fantastic initiative by The Times of India family. Having vehicle-free streets in every corner of the city is need of the hour. It is heart-warming to see Barodians play games, stroll leisurely and reclaim the streets,” Gahlaut said.

People also clicked photographs with a minion mascot that strolled on the Sayajibaug Road. A group of children displayed their creativity by sketching on the road while awestruck parents stood admiring their wards’ efforts. Teenagers also played football amid loud cheers by passers-by.

Title: Hyderabad: Jagan Studio ordered to pay senior citizen Rs 70,000
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Image credit: @JaganStudion

HYDERABAD: A district consumer forum has directed Jagan Studios to pay Rs 70,000 to a senior citizen , who wanted to make a short documentary along with his friends, for failing to complete the work and handover the film in CD format.

The complainant, 73-year-old R Gopal Rao, submitted that he along with other friends had enacted in several dramas since childhood and now in their twilight years, wanted to shoot their talent and preserve it in the form of CDs for their grandchildren.

Rao said that he along with three of his friends had approached Jagan Studios in Kukatpally with a script for making a short documentary film in October 2015. After due discussions and negotiations, Rao said that he paid Rs 1.27 lakh to the studio to provide production and post-production services. He said that they have visited the studio several times and demanded the partners to complete the work, but they kept postponing it on one pretext or the other.

Representatives of the studio, in their version, said that at the time of quotation, they informed the complainant that the costs may go over Rs 1.5 lakh, which they accepted. They said that while Rs 1.27 lakh was collected towards shooting expenses for two days, they had to shoot for three days to complete the film and thus incurred additional expenses of Rs 60, 000 which the complainant failed to pay.

Title: All women anti-CAA, NRC, NPR protest rally in city
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Aurangabad: The city witnessed its first all women mega anti-CAA NRC and NPR protest rally on Sunday with women from different walks of life participating in lage numbers at the Delhi Gate where a massive stage was set up.

The event organized by Muslim Numainda Council, a social-religious and minority rights body, was completely managed by women organisers as well as volunteers.

High number of professionals, along with housewives, students and elderly women made it to the protest while holding placards, shouting slogans and demanding withdrawal of the NRC and NPR. Several groups of girl students were spotted reciting shayaris and raising Inquilab slogans while moving around the venue.

At the agitation venue, a group of women comprising law students and professionals were spotted briefing fellow women protesters as to how NRC, CAA and NPR put together would not only discriminate and harass Muslims, but also the backwards, downtrodden, tribal and majority of those belonging to reserved categories.

During the agitation that lasted for a little over three hours, praises were showered for the women at Shaheen Bagh as well as for the girl students from the Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) and Aligarh Muslim University (AMU) for their stand against the government’s move and inspiring others to not let the country divided.

The speakers appealed to the women to not to let the fascist forces make the on-going protests paint it as ‘only Muslim’ protest.

Title: SEZ land auction: Process to form committee begins
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: Goa Industrial Development Corporation (GIDC), after being nudged by the government, has commenced the process to auction off Special Economic Zone ( SEZ ) land by identifying members to be part of the committee that will oversee the auction process.Once GIDC finalises the names for the committee, the proposal will be sent to the government for approval, said sources. The SEZ auction can go ahead only after the committee is setup.The industries department issued an order to GIDC in the last week of December asking the corporation to go ahead with the auction of a fraction of the 38 lakh sqm SEZ land and submit an action taken report.“We are deliberating on the names and constituting the committee. It may be more than a three-member committee. Once the names are finalised, the draft on the committee will be shared with the government for final clearance,” a senior official said.Industries minister Vishwajit Rane has directed GIDC to appoint a consultant and go ahead with the auction process so that a Rs 200 crore loan taken by the corporation can be repaid as quickly as possible.Cash-strapped GIDC had taken the loan to pay and get back the land from the five SEZ promoters — K Raheja and Corporation, Peninsula Pharma Research Centre, Planetview Mercantile Co, Inox Mercantile Company, and Paradigm Logistics and Distribution.The committee will also have to be cleared by GIDC’s board, which is likely to meet later this month.Under-secretary A S Mahatme, in a letter to GIDC managing director S V Naik, said the government has taken a decision on December 30 to auction the SEZ land and desires an action taken report in the matter.Several months earlier, GIDC chairman Glen Ticlo had said that GIDC was paying a whopping Rs 1 lakh per day as interest payment for the Rs 200 crore loan taken from Oriental Bank of Commerce to get the SEZ land back.

Title: Pune: Victorious Kidss Educares gets model school tag by International Baccalaureate Board
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Victorious Kidss Educares celebrated its 24th Foundation Day on January 6, 2020

PUNE: The International Baccalaureate (IB) board recently accreditated the city-based Victorious Kidss Educares (VKE) with the ‘model school’ tag for maintaining international standards.

The school would also share its good practices at a global conference in March on the changes it made to attain the international standards.

Robbin Ghosh, the president of VKE, would be the keynote speaker at the global conference. Ghosh said, “At our schools we couple western education with the rich heritage of Vedanta of ancient India. With this balance and the best of east and west, the school was rated by the IB as a Model IB World School in Asia.”

Ghosh said, Victorious Kidss Educares was the largest and authorized IB school in the city for the primary years programme, middle years programme and diploma programme. It was one of the 28 fully authorized IB schools running all three programmes, from a total of 159 IB schools in India, he said.

Talking about the efforts the school took to make it a model education system, Ghosh said, “Towards Swami Vivekananda’s concept of ‘education for the character’ for the children, the school follows 10 principles of building students’ character profile and these are embedded within the curriculum. The programme encourages our children to be principled, have academic honesty, be knowledgable, a risk taker and be caring,” he said.

The students are encouraged to think independently. They are well equipped with scientific and technical knowledge imparted by their teachers, he said. In the past, the students had participated and won in international competitions such as Nasa Robotics, Robocon, LEGO engineering, among others.

The school celebrated its foundation day on January 6 as it entered its 24th year. It invited senior citizens from Sandhya Home, Eventide Old Age Home, and around 69 children Vanitashray orphanage. Music and dance events were a part of the celebrations. Long service awards were also distributed to employees who had completed five or more years with the organization.

Title: AAP's guarantee card a bid to deceive people, say BJP and Congress
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari

NEW DELHI: AAP government on Sunday came under fire from both BJP and Congress after chief minister Arvind Kejriwal released the party’s “guarantee card”.

Delhi BJP chief Manoj Tiwari likened the 10 guarantees to “10 new lies spoken to the people of Delhi” even as he asked the CM to explain the progress made on the 70 promises made in 2015. “There is a great difference between making promises and fulfilling them. The CM had made 70 promises to the people of Delhi, but when the time came for fulfilling them, he is making new promises to mislead the public,” he said.

Tiwari alleged that power companies had been given orders to supply free electricity till March 2020 only. “Kejriwal has also given a guarantee of removing the web of loose wires, but he must explain why this work was not done during the last five years. Had this work been done earlier, then the incidents of fire may not have taken place,” he claimed. “A CM who claims to have made revolutionary changes in education must answer where those 500 new schools and 20 new colleges are that he promised? He should also explain to the people why he has deprived them of the benefits of welfare schemes launched by the Centre, including Ayushman Bharat Yojana,” he added.

Tiwari also alleged that while the CM had created hindrances in the expansion of Delhi Metro, he was now giving a guarantee of providing public transport of international level. He credited the Centre for bringing down pollution by constructing eastern and western peripheral expressways. Tiwari said while the government was now guaranteeing the removal of mountains of garbage, the corporations had already installed machines for doing so.

Delhi Congress president Subhash Chopra claimed that fearing a certain defeat in the upcoming election, Kejriwal had come up with the 10 promises.

Calling it another “jumla” to fool the people of Delhi and divert their attention from AAP government’s failures in the last five years, he alleged that Kejriwal had wasted his time clashing with officials, central government, LG and municipal corporations of Delhi without fulfilling the promises he had made to the people.

Title: Two thieves arrested in Mangaluru
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: The Mangaluru city police have arrested two men in connection with a theft and recovered a laptop and 60 grams of gold from them in the Ullal police station limits.

The arrested are Taslim , 23, a resident of Madaninagar and Mohammed Haris, 23, a resident of Sundaribagh, both residents of Ullal. Another two accused, Anwar from Puttur and Siyal from Madaninagar, are absconding.

According to police, the duo had stolen a laptop belonging to an Infosys employee from an apartment in Bagambila. Earlier, the gang had committed a burglary at Uday Kumar’s house and fled with gold valuables. On December 15, they had targeted the house of Yatish Kumar near Subashnagar mosque, and stolen several gold valuables. Police arrested the accused on Saturday.

According to police, Taslim has criminal antecedents and was booked in an attempt to murder case of an autorickshaw driver, robbery, vandalism , attempt to robbery and many other cases. Mohammed Haris was earlier booked for damaging cars.

Title: Lucknow: Women brave chill, crowds clock big stir
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

With posters and flags, crowds of men, women and children continued their stir at Clock Tower on Sunday.

LUCKNOW: As strong as the 220-foot tall Husainabad clock tower, stood hundreds of women staging peaceful protest against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) on Sunday afternoon. Undeterred and unmoved, the women braved sweeping cold winds on a largely cloudy day, saying they were there for a “safer, secular India tomorrow.”

The nonstop protest that began on Friday afternoon, drew more support on Sunday as residents from across the city turned up to show solidarity. Some came with families and friends, holding posters in hand and chants on their lips. While women were allowed to enter the inner quadrangle, the area was cordoned off temporarily with ropes by protesters to restrict access of men. Late afternoon, the women formed a chain, holding hands to stall entry of unsocial elements.

“We have no leader . Volunteers are managing the crowd. Some are taking care of security, others taking note of speeches being made. We are making sure the protest remains peaceful. We are not Muslim women, but just women,” said Fauziya Rana, a protester.

Keeping an eye on those interacting with protesters, volunteers urged the latter not to share any information with unknown persons and ask for identity cards.

“After December 19 and subsequent police action, people thought no one will come out. But women drew inspiration from Shaheen Bagh protest. It is a secular protest, which is being attended by all those who want the country’s secular nature to remain intact,” said Veena.

After cutting off power and locking toilets, heavy police force was deployed. On Saturday night, Rapid Action Force (RAF) personnel were also stationed.

Lucknow police, meanwhile, denied allegations of seizing blankets and water bottles on Saturday night. Police officials said blankets were seized from NGO workers when those not part of protest started jumping in to take them.

Police also asked all food joints in Akbari Gate area to close by 11.30pm. “We have asked all shops to down shutters by 11.30pm. We will take action against those defying the order,” said ACP (Chowk) Durga Prasad.

Title: ACB recovers Rs 36 lakh in cash, 100gm of gold jewellery from PMC supervisor’s house
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: The state anti-corruption bureau (ACB) recovered Rs 36 lakh in cash and 100gm of gold ornaments from the residence of a supervisor working for the Pune Municipal Corporation . He was arrested along with a worker on Saturday for demanding and accepting a bribe from a coconut vendor in Yerawada.

Both were produced before a court on Sunday and remanded in police custody till January 22.

The ACB had arrested the supervisor, Sunil Ramprakash Sharma , 55, and Gopi Machindra Ubale, 32, both from Wadgaon Sheri for taking the bribe from a coconut vendor from Ahmednagar Road who approached the bureau. Sharma had demanded a bribe of Rs 1,000 from him. The vendor has a stall and Sharma threatened to take action against it.

The two settled for Rs 500 and the ACB officials set a trap on Ahmednagar Road ward office and the two walked into it.

Later in the night, ACB officials conducted searches at the residence of Sharma and found the cash and the gold ornaments. ACB officials told TOI that they are verifying the source of the cash.

Title: Shy homemaker behind Lucknow’s Shaheen Bagh
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Turiaganj resident Kausar Imran

LUCKNOW: Turiaganj resident Kausar Imran describes herself as a shy homemaker who would hardly speak up, let alone attend a protest. That was until Friday, when the 35-year-old began a massive protest at Husainabad’s Clock Tower — now being referred to as Lucknow’s Shaheen Bagh .

On Friday afternoon, the mother of three reached the iconic Clock Tower along with her children and 10 other women to launch an agitation against the Citizenship Amendment Act ( CAA ) and the National Register of Citizens (NRC). Over the next three days, hundreds of women joined the motley group of protesters. The growing numbers reminded many of New Delhi’s Shaheen Bagh, where local residents have been staging a 24/7 peaceful sit-in for more than a month.

Talking about what inspired her to launch the agitation, Kausar said, “My family was discussing what was happening in Shaheen Bagh while watching the news on Thursday evening. Listening to them, I wondered what homemakers like me could do here. My husband then drew similarity between me and the homemakers of Delhi who were participating in the protest. I was cooking dinner when I decided that we would have to do something to save the country.”

“My three children, aged six, eight and 13, and my niece who is 24 encouraged me and we stayed up all night making posters,” said Kausar, who has received formal schooling only till fifth standard.

The homemaker said that she and her children went door-to-door in her locality seeking support. “We literally begged women to come out. By Friday afternoon, we were some 15 people including the children who stood at the Clock Tower to protest against CAA and NRC.”

“We made posters which read ‘we reject CAA, no NRC’ and ‘we are Indians’ and came here after Friday prayers around 2.30pm. Not many people had turned up by then, but we still decided to go ahead,” said 24-year-old Safiya, Kausar’s niece.

Hiding the posters in the layers of her burqa, Kausar and others managed to sneak past the police to reach Clock Tower on Friday afternoon. The moment they brought out the posters, police ran towards them to stop them.

“I told them that I can tape my mouth and will even turn into a stone, but would not move from the spot. When they told me that I had no permission to protest, I said that I wasn’t creating any ruckus. The electricity supply was snapped in the area that night, but even my youngest did not cry or ask to go home. We sat there undeterred. Now, I feel overwhelmed by sheer number of women sitting with us,” she added.

Title: 18-year-old drowns after boat capsizes
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

MANGALURU: An 18-year-old student drowned after a boat capsized near Uliya , under Ullal police station limits, on Sunday. Another 20-year-old girl from Kalaburagi is critical, said sources.

Police identified the deceased as Renita , a resident of Miyapadavu and a commerce student. Renita, along with five other girls, had gone to a friend’s house to attend a church annual feast.

Locals rescue 4 girls

After being requested by the girls, George, the house owner, took them for a boat ride.

The boat capsized due to heavy winds.

While Renita drowned, Kavya is critical, said sources.

Locals managed to rescue four other girls who were in the boat. George, who fell into the water, managed to swim back to the shore.

Title: Committee formed for Pathri’s development
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

AURANGABAD: An action committee, involving eminent personalities from different walks of life, has been formed for the development of Pathri. Meanwhile, chief minister Udhhav Thackeray is slated to meet delegations from Shirdi and Pathri in Marathwada to diffuse the row over the birthplace of Saibaba.

The panel is scheduled to plan the future course of action for pursuing the demand to release the Rs 100 crore aid for Pathri as announced by the CM during his meeting on Tuesday.

Baba Jani Durrani, NCP MLC from Pathri who took the initiative to form the action committee, said a section of residents of Shirdi was opposing the development of Pathri out of fear of losing revenue associated with the tourist footfall.

“We have formed an action committee for constructive purpose. We will not give a call for any bandh or other extreme steps which will affect the devotees. The action committee will explore democratic and other legitimate ways for the development of Pathri,” he said.

Meanwhile, the trust that manages Pathri temple of Saibaba said a group of devotees from South India visited the shrine on Sunday owing to the call for bandh in Shirdi.

“Devotees from different parts of India visit Pathri to take darshan of Saibaba. A group of devotees from South India came to Pathri for the first time and told us that it was a fulfilling experience to visit the birthplace of the saint,” Sanjay Bhusari, trustee of the temple, said.

The trust has already said that those opposing development of Pathri temple were hurting the sentiments of Saibaba’s devotees. Asserting that it was already established fact Saibaba was born at Pathri, the trust has also condemned the call for shutdown of Shirdi highlighting that it affected devotees only.

The temple trust at Shirdi, however, has already distanced itself from the bandh. The daily routine activities at the trust such as pooja, arati and offering of prasad took place as usual on Sunday.

Among other political functionaries from Marathwada, PWD minister and former chief minister Ashok Chavan has already extended his support for the development of Pathri.

Title: Aurangabad: Woman-dad duo held for killing her ex-husband
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The police have arrested a 35-year old woman and her father on the charges of murdering her former husband.

The autopsy report by the forensic experts has nailed the duo.

The accused have been identified as Yasmin Shaikh and her father Shaikh Ahmed. They were produced before the holiday court, following which they have been remanded in one-day police custody.

Police said that on September 12, 2019, the 56-year old Mohammed Jawed was found hanging in his house. Not convinced that Jawed would commit suicide, his brother Mohammed Taher demanded an autopsy.

The forensic analysis report concluded that the man was strangled before being hanged.

MIDC Cidco inspector Surendra Malale said that after the death of his first wife, the ex-serviceman married the accused woman.

According to the police, after she found out that he had purchased some property in the name of his son from the deceased wife, she started pestering him for getting a property in her name too.

Somehow, the man managed to get another property in the name of the second wife, but this resulted in a deduction of a considerable portion from his pension.

The financial crunch led to tension between the couple, following which she divorced him.

Mohammed Jawed would go to her house and ask her to transfer back the property he had bought in her name, which often would result in a heated argument.

On September 12, Jawed reached her house inebriated and started asking her to transfer back the property, leading to an argument. Following which the woman and her father allegedly assaulted him, before strangling him.

Following his death, Yasmin contacted the deceased’s brother and made up a story saying that he has committed suicide at her house.

Title: Teachers of unaided schools feel left out
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Unaided schoolteachers feel that being an unorganized labour pool is leading to exploitation by not only the school management but also by teachers from aided schools who have multiple unions to represent them.

Vivek Ambekar, head of the English school unit of Maharashtra Rajya Shikshak Parishad (MRSP), says their counterparts from aided schools sometimes ‘bully’ the education department to get things done.

He says the pay disparity between teachers in aided and unaided schools is alarming. “Those teachers are earning more than Rs60,000 per month with seniors raking in almost Rs1 lakh under the seventh-pay commission. Here, even after working for a couple of decades, the senior most teacher will hardly draw Rs30,000 per month. The average salary for private schoolteachers is around Rs12,000 per month and no job security on top of that,” said Ambekar.

He added that despite having more students, the unaided schools are left out. “A majority of students are enrolled in private unaided schools in Maharashtra, yet the condition of our teachers is really bad. The government and private-aided schools maybe more in number, but their enrolment is negligible. There are so many ZP schools that have hardly 15 or so students overall,” said Ambekar. He believes that all these problems are because they belong to an ‘unorganized’ workforce. “There is a fear among our teachers of joining any organization because the management won’t appreciate that. Whereas, the aided schoolteachers have multiple unions to fight for them all the way to Mantralaya and get things done,” said Ambekar, who is based in Chandrapur.

In Nagpur, a group of ex-teachers are slowly rallying peers from other CBSE schools to come together and have a platform to speak from. The CBSE Schools’ Staff Welfare Association is demanding a school tribunal which will deal with problems of CBSE staff from across the country. Deepali Dably, who is spearheading this movement, said, “Across the country, there is no place where CBSE teachers can go and fight for their rights. We hope that authorities take up the issue seriously and ensure that the rights of CBSE teachers are secured.”

Title: Delhi assembly elections: Why contest is on a knife’s edge in this crime-hit middle-class segment
Content:
Rohini in north-west Delhi is perhaps the most urbanised constituencies among the 70 that make up the Delhi le... Read More

NEW DELHI: Rohini in north-west Delhi is perhaps the most urbanised constituencies among the 70 that make up the Delhi legislative assembly . Residents of this seat, carved out in 2008 during the delimitation exercise, are mostly businessmen and professionals. A handful of JJ clusters and two villages are also part of the constituency, but these are unlikely to leave a mark on the overwhelmingly middle-class electorate living in the 154 cooperative housing societies and DDA flats in the area.SP Mishra, a retired SAI table tennis coach and resident of Sector 9, pinpointed law and order as an issue that is of some significance to the affluent households. “Every other day, a snatching takes place. Police don’t do enough,” the 65-year-old alleged. “Other issues that engage voters elsewhere in the city don’t bother people here.”Most voters are caught in a binary dilemma of having to opt for either Aam Aadmi Party or BJP. “Rohini is inhabited mostly by middle- and upper-middle-class people. You know who they will vote for,” 30-year-old Sandeep Singh chuckled knowingly. But Sector 13 resident Ramesh Kumar, a 40-year-old professional, expressed the confusion of the constituents when he said, “All parties are making tall claims. AAP has made many things free and it has helped people. BJP has announced better terms and more relief if elected to power.”Considered a BJP stronghold, Rohini voted AAP’s Rajesh Garg to victory in 2013 only to send Vijender Gupta to the assembly from his home turf in 2015, though with a modest margin of 5,367 votes. Gupta is the leader of the Opposition in the outgoing assembly. Rohini was one of the three seats that BJP won amid a landslide victory for AAP in 67 out of 70 that year. In the Lok Sabha elections in 2019, Rohini assembly segment gave BJP a big lead of over 60,000 and BJP eventually won the North-West Delhi parliamentary seat by a huge margin.For many, the vote for BJP in 2019 was keeping in view the national situation. “We voted for Narendra Modi last year. This year, it will be for Kejriwal,” declared Priya Sharma, a Prashant Vihar resident. “A lot has changed for the better in the past five years. We get free bus rides, electricity and water. AAP deserves a second chance to advance the work that it has started.” Sooraj, 24, who overheard the conversation, stopped to press his case for AAP, or more specifically, for Arvind Kejriwal. “I hope there is an AAP government for the next five years too,” he said.However, sitting BJP MLA Vijender Gupta has a lot going for him in Rohini. Many feel that his approachability will tip the electoral scales in his favour. “All votes are for BJP here. The MLA lives nearby. We can approach him at any time with our problems,” asserted Ramdhan Chaurasia, 42, an Uttar Pradesh native who has made Delhi home now for two and a half decades. The owner of a shop in Sector 7 market added that everyone he knows in the area will vote for the incumbent.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: NREGA to propel Ganga Yatra in 26 districts
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Labourers will also build over 2,500 compost pits and 3,000 soak pits.

LUCKNOW: The proposed Ganga Yatra scheduled from January 27-31 is set to come as a boon for scores of unemployed labourers as they would be roped in by state government for construction of nearly 300 Ganga ‘maidan’ (grounds) and over 450 Ganga ponds across 26 districts under the Centre’s flagship Mahatama Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (MGNREGS).

According to a proposal moved by rural development department, as many as 291 Ganga grounds and 454 Ganga ponds are proposed to be constructed along 1,025 gram panchayats ahead of Ganga Yatra, which is being planned between Bijnor and Ballia in two phases and covering a distance of around 1,400 kms. The first phase, between Balawali in Bijnor and Kanpur would cover 329 gram panchayats, while the second phase between Mohali Ghat in Ballia and Kanpur would cover 697 gram panchayats in 13 districts.

Confirming the development to TOI, additional commissioner, MGNREGS, Yogesh Kumar said that the department would rope in MGNREGS workers as per the need of the projects around the Ganga. Besides, around 3,881 plots along Ganga would be taken up for planting saplings, Kumar added.

The department, officials said, has already identified nearly 800 workers who would be engaged in plantation of fruit yielding tree saplings.

Kumar said that the idea of constructing Ganga maidan is to ensure cleanliness, while Ganga ponds would help in conservation of water. “The ponds would also help in recharging of the Ganga,” he said.

The proposal said MGNREGS workers would also be engaged in construction of more than 2,500 compost pits and around 3,000 soak pits to ensure bio-remedial measures for cleaning up banks of the Ganga.

While the Ganga Yatra is being projected as Ganga awareness programme, it is also taken as the BJP’s move for public outreach to mark CM Yogi Adityanath’s third year in office.

Though there is no official confirmation, sources said that the yatra may not only see participation of CM Yogi but also some of the senior union ministers. The event is also seen as an extension of ‘Namami Gange programme’ which is being overseen by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The state government has also submitted a presentation with the Centre underlining the steps that have been undertaken to ensure cleanliness in Ganga.

Title: Second phase of Neugi Nagar bridge nears completion
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The bridge serves as a second entry point into the capital and primarily benefits students and teachers of Peo... Read More

PANAJI: Delayed by nearly a year, the second phase of the 103m-bridge linking Patto-Neugi Nagar is nearing completion. Goa State Infrastructure Development Corporation (GSIDC) officials said that Larsen and Toubro (L&T) is currently constructing the approach roads and will subsequently lay the asphalt.

The hotmixing work is likely to commence in the coming fortnight, GSIDC officials said.

The bridge serves as a second entry point into the capital and primarily benefits students and teachers of People’s High School, Mary Immaculate Girls High School and Lok Chetna Primary School, as well as residents of the government quarters located in Bhatulem.

“Some of the minor utility services are still being shifted but it will be completed soon. The contractor will start laying the bitumen soon and we want to open the bridge by summer,” the official said.

Conceptualised by former chief minister Manohar Parrikar as a means to decongest the city and decrease commute for residents of Mala and Bhatulem, the bridge has helped reduced entry into the city by at least 1.5 km, government officers said.

However, due to the delay in completing the bridge and the poor condition of the roads, Neugi Nagar junction has become chaotic and dangerous for motorists.

Officials said that there is a proposal to create a traffic island at the junction to streamline traffic.

Parrikar inaugurated phase I of the bridge over the Rua de Ourem creek in December 2017, while phase II of the bridge was taken up only after the water pipeline adjoining the bridge was dismantled. The pre-stressed bridge is being built at a cost of approximately Rs 25 crore and includes a 1.5m footpath and a utility service duct. Phase I of the project was built for Rs 8.5 crore by L&T.

Title: Why leave it to others, when you can DIY
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

I am a resident of Koradi and have been segregating waste for the last two years. I started this initiative because I am worried by the mountains of garbage being dumped in the landfills. Paper scraps and plastic products are certainly meant to be discarded, but we can do our bit by utilizing biodegradable waste in a fruitful manner.

In my locality, there are a number of stray cows. The vegetable waste collected from my kitchen is placed in a tub and the cattle graze on it.

The leftovers from the tub (like squeezed lemons) and garden waste (like fallen leaves and flowers) are piled in an earthen pot . This pot is perforated to allow aeration. Cow dung is added to the mixture in the pot, as it greatly aids the growth of garden plants.

I learnt through a video that putting paper in the compost increases the nitrogen level of the soil. Therefore, I add pieces of paper too. This compost is used for my plants at home.

Also, I have made it a point to hand over paper products to the scrap collectors for recycling. Plastic and metal objects go into a different dustbin, and are disposed of accordingly.

Everyone should adopt the practice of utilizing their kitchen waste in the household itself. This way, we do not add to the heaps of waste accumulated in landfills, and can help prevent the odour from spreading. If you restrict this waste to your house, it will not reach the junkyards.

We should not entrust the government with responsibilities that we can manage ourselves. Citizens should be made aware of the advantages of doing their bit through household waste management.

Title: Aurangabad: Civic body to start drive against properties sans Occupancy Certificate
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Aurangabad Municipal Corporation

AURANGABAD: The cash-strapped Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has decided to crack down on properties that are in use without obtaining the mandatory Occupancy Certificate (OC) from the civic body.

The drive is expected to expose several illegal constructions and unauthorized extensions of the buildings. While getting the Completion Certificate (CC) is one of the pre-requisites for obtaining OC, the former document ensures whether the building is complete as per the building approval plan and satisfies other building criteria among other compliances.

A senior civic official said that many property owners have still not obtained the completion certificate and the proposed drive against properties sans OC is bound to expose illegal constructions in the city as citizens will have to ensure different compliances for properties as per laws.

“The number of people obtaining the OC and CC in the city is pretty low. Residential, commercial and industrial properties are set to come under scanner in terms of both the documents soon,” he added.

According to the official, Gunthewari and HUDCO areas are believed to have a large number of properties having illegal or unauthorised extensions to buildings among other city areas.=

The local civic body under the guidance of new civic chief Astik Kumar Pande has announced 25% discount on penalty towards delay in getting the OC till March-end. “Those who fail to comply with the rules will face action during a large-scale crackdown mooted beginning from the next fiscal,” the official said.

In a latest public notification, the AMC has informed the citizens that use of properties without the OC is an offence and liable for penalty. “Property users must take benefit of this waiver and avail the necessary document within stipulated timeframe to avoid the action in future,” the AMC has said.

The AMC official did not have the information about the exact number of property owners that have already availed the OC. For getting the OC, one has to pay a processing fee of Rs 500 along with other formalities.

Aurangabad deputy mayor Rajendra Janjal said citizens should complete the desired formalities related to their properties and avoid any harsh action.

Title: Dakshina Kannada to get new buildings for 25 anganwadi centres
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

MANGALURU: Dakshina Kannada zilla panchayat is all set to construct 25 anganwadi centre buildings at an estimated cost of Rs 2.5 crore.

While Mangalore Refinery and Petrochemicals Limited (MRPL) will release a portion of the funds required for the purpose, the remaining amount will be adjusted through the National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme (NREGS).

At present, 252 out of 2,106 anganwadi centres in the district have no buildings of their own. While 1,854 anganwadi centres have their own buildings, 33 are functioning in the panchayat premises, 72 are given space in community centres, 25 in Yuvaka Mandala, two in Mahila Mandala, 69 in schools and 48 are in rented premises.

Zilla panchayat CEO R Selvamani said the new anganwadi centres will be constructed providing all basic facilities. Respective gram panchayats will be taking up the construction work with the help of MRPL, he said.

Deputy director of women and child development department A Usman said a request to sanction buildings for all anganwadi centres in the district has been submitted to the government. The government has agreed to consider the demand and do the needful, he said.

New buildings for anganwadis will be constructed at an estimated cost of Rs 10 lakh each. While MRPL will release Rs 5 lakh for each anganwadi, the remaining funds will be arranged through NREGS. The new buildings will have facilities for pre-school with toys, kitchen, storeroom and toilets. While 12 buildings will be constructed in Mangaluru taluk, six will be built in Bantwal, one in Sullia and three each in Puttur and Belthangady.

In addition to the construction of new buildings, the zilla panchayat also has decided to repair the existing ones. The zilla panchayat has reserved Rs 1.3 crore to repair 243 anganwadi centres, officials said, adding that the repair works have already been completed on 32 buildings.

Title: HPCL holds rally for awareness on petroleum conservation
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited ( HPCL ) organised a cycle rally to raise awareness about petroleum conservation as part of Sanrakshan Kshamta-2020 organised by the Government of India’s petroleum conservation research organisation in the city on Sunday.

The cycle rally was held at the RK Beach Road beginning from the YMCA building and culminating at Vuda Park. More than 200 participants took part in the rally which was flagged-off at 6am. Atchutakumar, chief regional manager-direct sales of HPCL administered a pledge on petroleum conservation. tnn

Title: India’s first mega science caravan to land in Delhi tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

A replica of Thirty Metre Telescope, coming up at Hawaii to observe cosmic objects, will be on display at Vigy... Read More

NEW DELHI: India’s first-of-its-kind science caravan showcasing the country’s contribution to the world’s big-ticket scientific projects like LIGO and CERN is going to halt in the national capital from Tuesday for two months after making stoppages in Mumbai, Bengaluru and Kolkata for the last nearly one year.

The last leg of ‘ Vigyan Samagam ’, which will be inaugurated in the city’s National Science Centre by Union minister Jitendra Singh to showcase replicas of multi-country projects, provides a common platform for all mega-science programmes of the world.

Talking to TOI, Atomic Energy Commission (AEC) secretary Arun Srivastava said, “The idea to organise Vigyan Samagam was conceived in August 2018 to showcase India’s contribution to the CERN project, which is the world’s largest accelerator laboratory located between France and Switzerland. Later, members of other global projects like LIGO (gravitational-wave observatory), FAIR (proton and ion research facility in Germany), INO (neutrino observatory in Tamil Nadu), ITER (thermonuclear experimental reactor in France), TMT (upcoming Thirty Meter Telescope to probe cosmos), Square Kilometer Array (hundreds of telescopes spread over two continents in Africa and Australia being set up for monitoring the sky in different radio frequencies) and MACE (world’s second-largest gamma ray telescope being set up in Ladakh) also chipped in.”

The AEC secretary added, “Development of spinoff technologies is the outcome of such big science projects. The birth of internet started from CERN, when project scientists wanted to communicate and transfer a huge amount of data to their counterparts in 140 countries. Today, nobody can live without internet. These mega projects may look expensive now, but in future, when our natural resources get depleted, these projects will provide an answer to other sources of energy in the universe.”

On target audience, Srivastava said, “The objective is to target students, academia and the industry so that students know what is there in science for them in future and for the industry, a hybrid of all those projects where they can participate. And the response for the event is huge. In Mumbai, the footfall was 1.4 lakh, 1.3 lakh in Bengaluru, 3 lakh in Kolkata and in Delhi, we are expecting 2-3 lakh people.”

All top scientists like LIGO-US associate director (operations) Fred Raab and director general of FAIR, nuclear scientist Anil Kakodkar, former Isro chief K Kasturirangan, former DRDO chief V K Saraswat, are participating in the project.

Title: 30 years in exile: We feel like refugees in our own country, say Kashmiri Pandits
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The protesters recalled their decades-long trauma at the protest march.

NEW DELHI: To mark the completion of their 30 years in exile , hundreds of Kashmiri Pandits gathered at Jantar Mantar on Sunday evening. The protest was part of “Holocaust Day”, being observed by the displaced community who were forced to flee from Kashmir to Jammu and other states in the early 90s soon after the outbreak of militancy.

“The government should immediately come out with a blueprint for the return of the community to Kashmir with honour and safety. The community should be declared internally displaced,” a 50-year old man, who didn’t want to be named, said. He said his house was burned down in front of his eyes and the women in his family were kidnapped and raped.

Talking of his trauma, he said his family had an ancestral bungalow in Kashmir and ever since they moved to Delhi in 1995, they had no option but to stay in a one-room rented accommodation. There are six remaining members in his family.

There were others in the gathering who said they had been scarred for life.

“We are educated people. Yet, we have jobs that pay us nothing more than Rs 20,000 a month,” said another protester, Ankur Kaul. “I was 13 when I saw my house being set on fire. We were told to leave Kashmir or face a worse fate. We were left with nothing,” he said, adding: “When my family realised that the women’s lives and dignity were at stake, we decided to move to Delhi. There is nothing worse than being a refugee in your own country.”

Anil Bhat was in his thirties when he came to Delhi. “Most of us are still in depression. We want to return to Kashmir, but that’s possible only if the government promises us security and rehabilitation,” he said. “We were asked to either convert or leave. We chose the latter,” he added.

Among those who were shouting slogans seeking their rehabilitation was Ritik Jotshi, whose family migrated from their ancestral Brahman Mohalla village in Anantnag district of south Kashmir. Jotshi said he was hopeful of making it back to his village to lead a life of dignity.

“This is the first time that I am joining a protest. We want the government to come out with a road map for our return and rehabilitation in the Valley without further delay,” Jotshi said. “I had visited my ancestral village for a few days after birth, but the desire in my heart to live on my land remains alive,” he added.

The protest was organised by All State Kashmiri Pandit Conference. A delegation, led by its president Ravinder Raina, later submitted a memorandum to LG of J&K, G C Murmu.

Several other organisations, including All Party Migrant Coordination Committee, Panun Kashmir, All India Pandit Conference and All Displaced KP United Forum, organised separate functions to commemorate the day.

Meanwhile, to show solidarity with Kashmiri Pandits, anti-CAA activists — on protest for over a month — observed two-minute silence at Shaheen Bagh on Sunday, an agency report stated.

Title: UPSMDC first PSU to be wound up seamlessly through NCLT
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Lucknow: In a first-of-its-kind case, a defunct UP public sector undertaking has become the only PSU in the country to be wound up under the purview of Companies Act through the National Companies Law Tribunal (NCLT). The case is unique as the closure did not happen under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), the route which most sick or defunct PSUs take.

Wholly owned by the state government, UP State Mineral Development Corporation ( UPSMDC ) has managed to not only repay its loan to the government and banks but also a part of the interest amount and all employee dues before being legally wound up.

The PSU was registered with Registrar of Companies in 1974. It suffered losses after the closure of mining operations.

Although the decision to wind up this company was taken in 2000, the state government, the 100% shareholder of the company, granted permission for legally winding it up under Companies Act in May 2018. The balance sheet for 2017-18 was audited by CAG-appointed statutory auditor.

After this, UPSMDC moved a petition before NCLT under Companies Law to be wound up.

If this process to clear all liabilities, loans, litigations and employee dues was not followed, the corporation would have had to take the bankruptcy and insolvency route under for closure, making it difficult to protect the government’s interest in terms of valuation and disposal of assets. Properties and cash worth more than Rs 100 crore were restored to the government which is incidentally more than the company’s paid-up capital.

The closure can be an example for other PSUs of UP lying defunct after being declared sick. Some of these are UPTRON, UP Chalchitra Nigam Ltd, UP Auto Tractors Limited, UP Instruments Ltd and UP Spinning Mills.

The PSU had authorized Madhukar Singh, one its general managers, to carry out the entire process.

“The process to legally wind up UPSMDC is a model of efficiency and transparency. Usually, such defunct companies take the short-cut route of declaring bankruptcy,” said Devraj Gupta, company secretary and a certified insolvency professional, who had filed the petition in NCLT.
