Title: JNU News: JNUSU says it will move court today over fee hike
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh at Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) campus in New Delhi. (ANI File Photo)

NEW DELHI: As registration at Jawaharlal Nehru University ends and the classes begin next week, the JNU Students’ Union (JNUSU) has asked students to continue boycotting classes and not register for the winter semester until they exhaust legal avenues. JNUSU will go to court against the hostel fee hike on Monday. Calling the hike illegal and against the constitution of the varsity, the JNUSU has asked students to continue with the strike that was started after October 28 last year.

In a statement to the JNU student community, the students’ union said that their call for boycott of registration still stands. “The union is filling a case in Delhi high court on Monday to quash the illegally passed Inter-Hall Administration (IHA) manual,” it said.

The union said that the petition will seek registration at old rates without late fines. “The matter would be heard on an urgent basis,” it said.

“The JNUSU also appeals the student community to boycott exams and classes until illegal modes of examination are nullified and a buffer time is given to complete the academic backlog of the monsoon semester 2019,” the statement added.

The union said it had deliberated with the JNU Teachers’ Association (JNUTA), who in the resolution passed in the January 17 council meeting spoke of a lecture series, and “nowhere does it mention exams to be conducted as per the schedule brought out by several centres. Any academic schedule shall only be brought through discussions between teachers and students.”

Title: MLA to officials: Make effort to get Blue Flag certification for beaches
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

MANGALURU: The administration and tourism department should make efforts to ensure Blue Flag certification for all beaches in the coastal district, said Mangaluru City North MLA Dr Y Bharath Shetty .

He was speaking at the valedictory ceremony of Karavali Utsav and Beach Festival at Panambur Beach on Sunday. “All departments, including tourism department, should make efforts to keep our beaches clean and thereby bring Blue Flag certification for all beaches in the district,” he said.

Shetty said beaches with Blue Flag certification are eligible for special central government grant. “Hence, all beaches (in the district) can be developed and thereby attract more tourists,” he said.

Shetty said the government will hold talks with New Mangalore Port Trust to get more land for the development of Panambur Beach. “Panambur Beach can be developed on par with international standards if more land is allotted by NMPT to tourism department on lease,” Shetty said.

The Phalguni River Festival will be held in Kuloor in February or March. The government has already started the process of handing over 18 acres of land from the revenue department to the tourism department to promote river tourism at Kuloor, he said. “The government has already sanctioned Rs 7 crore for the development of Tannirbhavi and Sasihitlu beaches, Shetty said.

He lauded the efforts of district administration and tourism department for making Karavali Utsav and Beach Festival successful. “Though the state government is in a critical situation of fund crunch due to the recent flood, the organisers of Karavali Utsav have made all arrangements to hold the festival successfully with the help of donors,” Shetty said.

Deputy commissioner Sindhu B Rupesh, additional deputy commissioner M J Roopa, Mangaluru City Corporation commissioner S Ajith Kumar Hegde and Mangaluru Urban Development Authority commissioner Shrikanth Rao and other dignitaries honoured senior journalist Manohar Prasad with the “Karavali Gourava Prashasti” on the occasion.

Thousands witnessed the beach festival and cultural programmes.

Title: Plastic ban fizzles out in coastal AP
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The menace of plastic is looming over the rural areas of north Andhra. This, despite the fact that Bobbili Municipal corporation imposed a ban on plastic bags and pouches more than a decade ago, making it one of the first municipal corporations in the rural areas of the state to do so.

Despite this, even today, most villages and panchayats in north-coastal AP are clueless about dealing with the plastic menace. Another issue is the rampant use of plastic covers that have a thickness below 50 microns.

Though sources in the pollution control board claim that there is a ban imposed, it is hardly being imposed. More dangerously, in the rural belt, there is rampantly dumping of plastic in water bodies, open areas and fields. Worst of all, plastic is being burnt in public places regularly on a large scale. Sources in the APPCB said that they do not have exact data as to how much plastic is being procured, dumped and burnt.

“The problem is that we are yet to formulate a plan of action to deal with plastic. However, the ban on single-use plastic is in place. We are trying to coordinate with all the panchayats in the district and chalk out an action plan to find a proper solution to the increasing menace,” said Dr P Prasad Rao, environmental engineer, Pollution Control Board, Visakhapatnam.

While PCB officials claim that a plan of action is being chalked out, the plastic menace is encroaching even on agency hotspots of the region. Take for example the earlier untouched Lammasinghi. Today, one of the most popular tourist destinations in Vizag has fallen prey to the plastic menace. K Raghunath, former sapranch of Lammasinghi said, “What was a pristine, untouched landscape barely a decade ago has now become a plastic dump.”

As for the volumes of plastic being burnt on a daily basis, there is neither a record nor data available.

Title: Muttamsetti lashes out at Naidu & Pawan
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: State tourism minister Muttamsetti Srinivasa Rao slammed TDP chief N Chandrababu Naidu for misguiding the farmers of Amaravati and fanning flames of violence in the region.

Talking to the media while participating in a pro-capital rally at Tagarapuvalasa on the outskirts of the city on Sunday, the minister alleged that the TDP chief was playing with the emotions of the farmers to whom he had made false promises.

The minister further said that TDP MLAs must resign so that the true public opinion regarding the capital would come out.

Regarding Jana Sena chief Pawan Kalyan, the minister demanded he apologise to the people of Gajuwaka and added that the JS chief was not a stable leader. tnn

Title: Chennai: Where is the promised daily bus pass, minister?
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: It has been two years since the government scrapped the Rs 50 daily passes for travelling on Metropolitan Transport Corporation (MTC) buses. When complaints poured in, transport minister M R Vijayabaskar soon promised that the scheme would be revived soon after fixing security issues (by adding QR code on printed passes), but nothing has materialised.

According to official data, around eight lakh passengers bought the daily and monthly passes (Rs 300-Rs 1,000) every month. This was almost one-fourth of MTC’ss daily footfall. Distribution of both these passes was suspended after the bus fare hike in January 2018. But Rs 1,000 worth monthly pass scheme was revived a month later and since then it's average monthly sale increased from 50,000 to 80,000 per month.

Sale of other monthly concession passes (Rs 320 for 10km and Rs 370 for 15km) was also on the rise as it helped people save on commute expense. And then the government scrapped it. V Baskar, a collection agent from Nanganallur, said the pass was a great relief for him. “My job is to collect dues and clear orders from customers in Tambaram, Guindy and Vadapalani. Given the nature of my job, I can’t commute by train and I have to depend on buses and autorickshaws. Instead of spending Rs 50, I end up spending double the amount every day and this is one-third of what I earn,” he said.

MTC also reduced the frequency of buses plying along some suburban routes on which daily ticket collection was below par. T Sadagopan, a civic activist from Avadi, complained that MTC has stopped operating buses along B70 (Pattabiram-Guindy) route, and passengers from Avadi have to get a bus to either Ambattur or Vadapalani to reach Guindy. Without daily passes, passengers spend Rs 80-Rs 100 per day. That too none of these buses (plying towards Tambaram) enter Guindy Industrial Estate to drop passengers at the Ekkaduthangal CIPET traffic signal. One has to walk at least a kilometre to reach the estate from this bus stop, he said.

When the matter was taken to him an MTC official said the daily pass was suspended after they found out many started misusing it by sharing it with their friends. “It hasn't affected our patronage much,” he said.

Title: Piligao locals want check on all migrants
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Bicholim: Piligao locals have unanimously demanded that the panchayat undertakes a thorough check of all migrants in the village. Sarpanch Pradeep Naik said there are about 225 migrants living in the village whose names are not yet registered with the panchayat. He assured the villagers that they will look into their registration, as well as other related issues. TNN

Title: Tamil Nadu: Emergency rooms on alert but trauma care needs healing
Content:
Since 2016, Tamil Nadu is among the top in the country in road accidents

CHENNAI: There has been a decline in road accident deaths in the state, but ambulances and emergency rooms are seeing more deaths. While ambulances recorded nearly 6,500 more deaths compared to 2018, nearly 100 more people died in the emergency departments of various state-run hospitals.Since 2016, Tamil Nadu is among the top in the country in road accidents. In 2019, the state counted 10,472 road accident deaths compared to 12,216 fatalities in 2018. During the same period, nearly 40,000 more trauma victims, including 2,650 more accident victims, were taken to government hospitals. While surgeries were done for more than three out of five patients and CT scans were done on two-fifths of the patients, at least 4% of patients admitted required blood transfusion .One of the reasons why there was increased work in emergency rooms is because many departments in the state worked together with organisations and institutions such as IIT-M to locate accident hot spots, identify faulty road designs and causes for accidents, said transport commissioner S Jawahar said at a meeting in New Delhi recently, where TN was given an award for bringing down accident deaths. Overall, the number of high velocity accidents has also declined in the state, he said.The state 108 ambulances outsourced to GVK-EMRI picks at least 100 cases of trauma every day from across the state. “Sometimes accident victims are inside the ambulance for more than an hour either because of traffic or because the nearest state facility is that far. Some die on their way to hospital,” said EVK EMRI state head M Selvakumar.An audit by the health department revealed that more than 70% of accidents happened on 8% of roads, particularly highways, and deaths happened because accident victims were not able to reach hospitals and receive basic first aid. To reduce travel time, the state has set up five seven bed emergency and trauma centres equipped with ventilators, defibrillators and other lifesaving equipment, besides doctors and nurses on duty round the clock. “These centres within 10 minutes of the accident spot acts as a hub before the patient is taken to a tertiary centre,” he said.At the tertiary care centre patients are given treatment free of cost. They can move to private hospital empanelled under the state health insurance scheme and continue free treatment.Officials at the EMRI and emergency medicine experts at government hospitals agree that they have to do more to bring down deaths. “As per the protocol, ambulance technicians must alert a staff nurse before arrival. This pre-arrival intimation helps us keep a team ready for the critically ill. On most days we don’t receive any such information,” said a senior doctor attached to Stanley Medical College Hospital.Senior neurosurgeons say improved trauma facilities, besides saving lives, will improve quality of organs that are retrieved in case of brain death.The state is also talking to private hospitals to expand its tertiary care network. As of now Sri Ramachandra Institute of Higher Education and Research, Raja Muthiah Hospital and Saveetha Medical College are a part of the state network.

Title: Architects’ body objects to revamp of Central Vista
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

NEW DELHI: A national body of architects has objected to the DDA ’s proposal of changing land use (CLU) of 80.5 acres for the Central Vista revamp, which includes concentration of more government offices in the area, claiming such a move violates Delhi Master Plan provisions. It also said there were no details of compensatory allocation of land for recreational/public and semi-public use, which would be “lost”.

Citing the Master Plan provision, the northern chapter of Indian Institute of Architects (IIA) claimed the policy document said no new central government office should be located in Delhi. It quoted the Master Plan, which says, “As per NCR Plan, no new central government and public sector undertaking offices should be located in NCTD. However, the issue of shifting existing government/PSU offices from Delhi as well as restricting the setting up of new offices would only be possible after a time-bound action plan is prepared together with suitable incentives and disincentives.”

In its letter to the DDA, which is responsible for CLUs, the IIA requested the authority to make the details public before going ahead. It claimed the changes “seem to be conflicting with the Master Plan of Delhi-2021”. It also sought details of any study done to assess the impact of additional pedestrian and vehicular traffic that the CLUs will generate.

The DDA’s CLU proposal indicates that the new residence of the PM is likely to come up on a 15-acre plot located north of Dalhousie Road near South Block. TOI on Thursday had first reported how the government may continue earmarking 7, Lok Kalyan Marg, the current resident of the PM, as PM’s House in addition to the proposed one considering security reasons.

Earlier, urban affairs ministry officials had said transport and traffic movement plan in this zone were being worked out. They had said the government may consider staggering office timings and even increase the frequency of Metro trains besides creating more public space after completion of the project.

Title: Former Uttarakhand Congress chief brother held in forgery case
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Sachin Upadhayay

DEHRADUN: Sachin Upadhyay, brother of former Uttarakhand Congress president Kishore Upadhyay and owner of an upscale club in the city, was arrested for not cooperating with the Special Investigation Team (SIT) probing a forgery case filed against him by his business partner Mukesh Joshi. The arrest was made after a district court issued a non-bailable warrant against Upadhyay.

Police sources told TOI that Sachin Upadhyay was produced before a magistrate, who sent him to a 14-day judicial custody. Later, he was taken to Rajpur police station for interrogation.

Confirming the development, Garhwal’s Inspector General (IG) Ajay Rautela told TOI, “Sachin Upadhyay was arrested after a district court issued a non-bailable warrant against him in a forgery case.” The official added that the name of Nazia Yusuf Izuddin (Upadhyay’s wife) has also come up in the investigation and she would also be called for questioning by the SIT.

Both Nazia and Sachin could not be reached for comments. However, when TOI asked Kishore Upadhyay about the developments, he said, “You must ask CM Rawat. Why an SIT was set up and why a non-bailable warrant was issued? And that, too, on a Sunday! Were we running away from the probe? No, but still my family is being hounded.” The Congress leader added that he has also been named in the complaint.

Meanwhile, state BJP leaders distanced themselves from the developments saying that the “law is taking its course” and that they won’t comment on the matter as it is sub-judice. Notably, Upadhyay and Joshi had set up a company “SM Hospitality” in Dehradun in 2006 but later had a fallout.

In an FIR registered in 2017, Joshi had alleged that Upadhyay forged his signature and transferred the company’s ownership to his wife Nazia. The couple also took a loan of Rs 35 crore from a bank on the basis of the forged ownership document, Joshi's complaint had alleged.

Title: Pongal cheers: Tasmac sales touch Rs 610 crore in 3 days
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Tasmac sold liquor worth Rs 175 crore on Kaanum Pongal

CHENNAI: It wasn’t just the Pongal pot that frothed over in Tamil Nadu last week when tipplers opened the bottle, taking Tamil Nadu State Marketing Corporation (Tasmac) revenue to Rs 610 crore in three days. This was a 10% jump in revenue compared to the 2019 Pongal season.

The state-owned marketing corporation registered record sales on January 14 and 17; January 16 was a dry day on account of Tiruvalluvar Day. Officials said Wednesday (January 15) registered the peak sale with liquor outlets across the state collecting Rs 250 crore. Tamil Nadu has about 5,200 Tasmac shops, 300 of them in Chennai. On Friday (Kaanum Pongal), Tasmac sold 175 crore worth of liquor, and on Tuesday (Bhogi) it garnered Rs 180 crore. It is higher than the usual weekend per day sales, which is between Rs 90 crore and Rs 100 crore. The value of weekday sale all over Tamil Nadu is pegged at Rs 60 crore.

Districts in Madurai and Trichy regions collectively recorded sales of Rs 250 crore in three days. The share of Chennai region comprising Chennai, Chengalpet, Kancheepuram and Tiruvallur districts was only Rs 105 crore during the period. “Sales and revenue increased at least by 10% his Pongal season over the last. Chennai registered lower sales probably because people travelled from the city to their native towns and villages during the festival,” said a Tasmac official.

The collective sale during this Pongal was higher than last year’s Diwali season as well. The corporation recorded a sales of ₹455 crore between October 25 and 27 in 2019.

Title: Devotees to get 1 free Tirupati laddu from today
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Tirupati: Starting Monday, one Tirupati laddu will be issued free of cost to devotees on pilgrimage to the sacred abode of Lord Venkateswara at Tirumala.

On December 31, 2019, the temple administration had announced that it would issue one laddu free of cost to every devotee visiting the temple, beginning January 20. This decision is being set into action with the launch of ‘one free Tirupati laddu for every devotee scheme’ at the Tirumala temple, from Monday.

Speaking to TOI, TTD’s additional EO AV Dharma Reddy said that a free laddu would be issued to every devotee, regardless of whether they were a VIP or common devotee. “All devotees are equal before the almighty and everyone will be entitled to receive one free Tirupati laddu once they complete darshan,” he said.

The additional EO also clarified that the temple administration was not hiking the price of the laddu. “The price for one laddu is still Rs 50. We have just decided to cancel the issuance of laddus at subsidised prices,” he clarified.

Till recently, TTD provided free laddus only to divya darshan devotees daily. For others, the laddus were sold at subsidised prices. With the new scheme, the temple administration will have done away with these subsidies, which had also led to a black market business thriving at the temple town.

According to temple sources, even after issuing one free laddu to every devotee, the temple administration will save Rs 250 crore per annum by removing the subsidies.

Additionally, availing additional laddus has also become easier. Devotees can now buy additional laddus from counters adjacent to where they get the one free laddu. TTD has set up 12 new additional laddu prasadam token counters, where devotees can purchase the additional laddus by paying Rs 50 per laddu.

Title: Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Intro: With parks doubling up as study zones for Secunderabad students, TOI asked readers what other facilities should be introduced in Secunderabad parks

Question: What other facilities should be introduced in Secunderabad parks?

Most of the parks lack drinking water, toilets and equipment to exercise. It is a good move by the GHMC officials to install permanent chairs for students preparing for various competitive exams, but due to lack of space, they cannot provide adequate number of chairs. I request the state government and GHMC to construct more parks. A few parks must be developed exclusively for students.

Nandikanti Sai Kumar

Maintaining the parks and attracting people must go hand in hand.

If we want to more kids, elderly and fitness-conscious people to visit parks, the authorities should maintain the green cover with timely pruning of overgrown shrubs and trees. A well-maintained walkway is also a must. Toilets have to be user-friendly and must also have a baby feeding room so that new mothers can use them. Parks with play area should have sand pits so that kids are not hurt while playing. All slides, see-saw and other equipment should be taken care of on a regular basis. Vigilance by security personnel is an add-on so that people do not tamper with public property and booked for wrongdoing. A small shop that can rent out balls, frisbees, rings, etc on a rental basis should be made available so that people can use the park for physical activity.

Yoga sessions and laugh clubs should be introduced in the mornings so that people can enjoy quality time with like-minded people in a beautiful ambience.

Deepesh Surana

Libraries, museums, community centres and performance sites open the doors to knowledge and ideas, culture and enjoyment. Medical facilities promote and protect health, and public transport offers access to transportation and other areas. Without them and other social services, life can be difficult, especially for those who cannot afford to travel.

Most communities, even small rural communities, have at least one public park and some other community facilities - a library, a hospital or clinic, a small museum or historic site. Improving these facilities can mean different things for different communities. For some, the problem maybe that proper parks or facilities simply aren't available, and they need to be built. For others, existing facilities may be outdated, and talk only about the needs of the community that has long since changed. Still others can find themselves with amenities that are appropriate in some ways, but they need to be revived. A less obvious situation is one in which the community facilities are in good shape and seem appropriate, but are not in use.

Syed Shamsuddin Maghrabi

Unlike Hyderabad, Secunderabad does not have many parks and needs more parks. When the authorities start redeveloping the abandoned areas, parks must be a top priority. Marredpally, Padmaraonagar, Seethaphalmandi, Sindhi Colony, Bowenpally and Kompally need more parks and bigger parks. The existing parks are small and cannot cater to the fast growing population in these places.

Cleanliness is top priority and much needed. Visitors must be educated to not dirty the place, with proper signboards and posters at the entrances. Good working equipment for Children to play safely and a proper infrastructure are required. Strict vigilance is also needed in the parks. All nefarious activities like youth consuming alcohol, prostitution, hooliganism, crime, are taking place. New Staff have to be hired and volunteers need to be deployed. The present staff of municipal authorities and other civic bodies is inadequate and cannot ensure the upkeep and above stated things.

Ramesh Vemuganti

The parks in Secunderabad are not only inadequate but many of them lack basic facilities, as a result, it has driven many of them to stroll on roads instead of relaxing in parks. As many places in Secunderabad earmarked for parks years ago are still lying in a shambles or have turned into a dumpyard in the absence of any maintenance work, the GHMC must not only take up on priority basis development of parks but specifically allot places for ‘children’s play area’ and a separate enclosure for outdoor games like shuttle, badminton and tennikoit. In addition, the GHMC can construct a small building and allocate separate rooms for indoor games besides establishing a small library for recreation. Above all, flowering plants all around the park and a landscape inside the park will not only enhance beauty of the park but ensure a serene atmosphere.

K R Srinivasan

Title: Sub-standard equipment postpone surgeries at Dehradun hospital
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Government Doon Medical College Hospital

DEHRADUN: Orthopaedic transplants and certain other operations are not being conducted in Government Doon Medical College Hospital (GDMCH) for three days now after GDMCH doctors found out that the medical equipment to be used in the surgeries were sub-standard in quality.

Sunil Verma (name changed) was supposed to be operated at Doon Hospital last Wednesday but his operation was postponed after the ortho-surgeon at GDMCH found implant instruments to be of sub-standard quality. Verma told TOI that he had come to Dehradun from Pauri especially for the operation.

“I came to Dehradun and arranged for an accommodation for my family. But my operation was postponed due to inferior quality equipment. I wasn’t even given another date for my operation. We have been left in the lurch,” he alleged.

Notably, GDMCH principal Dr Ashutosh Sayana has now tasked “Ayushman Mitras” with ensuring that all the equipment are approved by the doctor prior to an operation. According to GDMCH sources, around eight operations have been halted as doctors complained of sub-standard quality of equipment and implants.

Meanwhile, Dr Sayana told TOI that a meeting was held between doctors and the third party agency that supplies operational instruments and implants. In the meeting, it was decided that they will be taking a pre-approval of their product from the doctors before surgery. “The third party agency has been warned against supplying sub-standard equipment and Ayushman Mitras have been assigned the responsibility to coordinate with patients and doctors so that such incidents do not take place in the future,” said Dr Sayana, while adding that orthopaedic operations will be conducted at the hospital from Monday onwards.

A team of doctors and junior employees has also been constituted under the supervision of a doctor to keep strict vigil on touts and middlemen inside the hospital, the principal added.

Title: Philosopher’s birth anniv marked
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Guntur: Stating that Yogi Vemana is one of the greatest philosophers of India, district collector I Samuel Anand Kumar has said that students should be encouraged to read Vemana literature to understand the society better. The district collector inaugurated the Vemana birth anniversary celebrations at Kondaveedu fort on Sunday. He said that Vemana had fought with blind faiths through his poetry decades ago when the society was crippled with superstition.

State prohibition campaign committee chairman V Lakshman Reddy presided over the meeting jointly organised by Jana Vignana Vedika and Bala Bharathi at kondaveedu hill fort.

Addressing the gathering, the district collector said that they would organise Kondaveedu festival with the support of tourism department.

Former minister Mandali Budhaprasad said that Karnataka government is organising Vemana birth anniversary as state function and so should the Andhra Pradesh government.

Title: 10-day handicraft exhibition begins in Tirupati
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Tirupati: The Handicraft exhibition 2020, conducted jointly by the Union ministry of textiles and the state department of tourism and culture under the banner of The Andhra Pradesh Shilparamam Arts, Crafts and Cultural Society, began at Shilparamam (Urban Haat) here on Sunday.

The expo was launched by P G Neetha, in-charge assistant director (handicrafts), Union ministry of textiles, in the presence of B Jayaraj, chief executive officer of AP Shilparamam.

There are various handicraft items from seven states at the exhibition. Rosewood products from Karnataka are a hit among visitors, followed by Chennapatna wooden toys, a proud symbol of workmanship from the same state. Terracota earthen products brought by a team of artisans from Puducherry are sure to catch one’s attention.

Telangana is represented by Pochampally products known for their inimitable weaves, and the stall containing hand embroidery work from Delhi was mobbed by women.

The host state is represented by weavers and artisans of Pedana Kalamkari, Venkatagiri saris and Narsapur crochet lace work. These apart, the artificial jewellery stalls from Delhi and Tamil Nadu are hard to miss for the women, while those on stone craft, earthen art and brassware are a must-visit for connoisseurs of fine art.

“Such expos provide the right platform for the artisans to reach out to the art-loving citizens and the direct access to the right customer at a reasonable price. Our intention is to save our age-old cultural heritage from possible extinction and to pass on the traditional knowledge to future generations”, said Jayaraj.

The society has eight Shilparamam parks in Visakhapatnam, Tirupati, Kadapa, Pulivendula, Anantapuramu, Puttaparthi, Vizianagaram and Kakinada, while new parks are proposed at Guntur (under construction), Srikakulam, Kurnool, West Godavari, Krishna, Prakasam, Nellore, Vempalli and Idupulapaya (both in Kadapa). The existing parks would be upgraded and developed to transform them into vibrant tourist hubs, he added.

The expo ends on January 28.

Title: Maharashtra: Man robbed of pick-up vehicle he was supposed to deliver
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representtaive image

NASHIK: A 39-year-old vehicle transporter, en route to Malegaon from the Mumbai side, was robbed of his pick-up vehicle by three armed robbers in the Malegaon Chhavani area, about 100 km from Nashik, on Saturday morning.

The Malegaon Chhavani police said they have registered a robbery case against the three suspects. The police said the complainant is in the business of transporting new pick-up vehicles from Mumbai to various destinations across the country and even Bangladesh, Bhutan, Nepal etc.

On Saturday, the complainant was driving a pick-up vehicle, which he was supposed to deliver to a certain location in north India. At 7 am, the complainant stopped in Tehere village along the Mumbai-Agra highway near Malegaon. At the same time, three men in a silver van approached him. One of them told the complainant to take the other two men with him and drop them off in Malegaon. The suspect even took out a firearm and held it to the complainant’s forehead. His two accomplices slapped the complainant.

However, the complainant managed to snatch the firearm from the first suspect and started running towards a nearby petrol pump to seek help. He left his pick-up behind. The three suspects then decamped with the vehicle.

In his FIR, the complainant said that the new pick-up vehicle was worth Rs 5.50 lakh. The complainant said he also lost valuable kept in the vehicle — a cellphone and Rs 10,000 in cash. The vehicle also had insurance papers of 10 other vehicles, his Aadhar and PAN cards and other documents. The Malegaon Chhavani police said that they were investigating the case.

Title: Police cracks house robbery case, 4 held
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Roorkee: City police, on Sunday, claimed to have cracked a house robbery case that took place in the city on December 31. Four accused in the case have been arrested and all the robbed items have been recovered, said officials.

According to police, four unidentified miscreants barged into Vandana Mohan’ house (situated in Yadavpuri locality) at about 6 pm and conducted robbery at gunpoint. The miscreants took away a small safe containing gold jewelry and cash from the house.

"With the help of several CCTV footages, it was ascertained that a private car was used in the crime. Later, we did a physical verification of around 30 cars and zeroed in on a Modinagar (Uttar Pradesh) car. Acting on a tip off, our team arrested all four criminals and seized the car near Roorkee on Sunday," said SSP Senthil Avoodai K Raj.

The miscreants have been identified as — Raish Ahmed (42), Ayyub (38), Azharuddin (35), and Anish Ahmed (35). While Raish is a Modinagar resident, other three hail from Meerut. Besides gold and the safe, police also recovered three country-made firearms and some live cartridges from the possession of miscreants.

Police said several cases of murder and robbery have been lodged against the four criminals in various police stations of Uttar Pradesh.

Title: Bengaluru: Bus lane fading out within two months
Content:
Traffic police have booked only a few motorists for driving on the demarcated bus priority lane on Outer Ring ... Read More

TimesView That the much-hyped bus priority lane has all but vanished is a grim reminder of how mere enthusiasm is no substitute to perseverance. Setbacks are nothing new in ambitious civic initiatives, but more important is the lessons one learns. Thankfully, the agencies involved are determined to persist with the endeavor. They will hopefully pay more attention to the immediate needs: Strict enforcement and demarcation of lanes.

BENGALURU: The city’s first bus priority lane on Outer Ring Road appears to have all but vanished. With poor enforcement by traffic police and absence of a physical barricade along the busy stretch, buses are getting priority on the lane as a matter of exception and not as a rule.The ambitious project was rolled out by agencies like BBMP, BMTC , traffic police and the directorate of urban land on November 15. But in just about two months, the yellow marking demarcating the lane has faded away on several sections.Though BBMP had promised deployment of marshals on the stretch, hardly anyone is seen, prompting activists and experts to demand stringent action against violators.The road’s extreme left is reserved for BMTC buses on the 12-km ORR corridor between KR Puram and Iblur. Earlier, the bus lane was to run for 20km between SV Road near Byappanahalli and Central Silk Board Junction, but the 12-km stretch was implemented on a pilot basis.BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar said they will soon put up plastic bollards along the stretch. “We are planning to extend the bus priority lane till Byappanahalli. We are closely monitoring progress of the project and it will not fail,” he asserted.However, BBMP had earlier put up both plastic and metal bollards on ORR. While plastic bollards were damaged in an accident, metal bollards were removed after it was found that they could pose danger to two-wheelers at night. In December last year, a survey conducted by BMTC had revealed that the speed of buses had improved during both peak and non-peak hours, thanks to the lane project.“The average travel time in the corridor has reduced after the bus priority lane. The biggest improvement is seen during evening peak hours. Travel time has reduced by 60% from Tin Factory to Silk Board and in the opposite direction by 33%,” the report said, adding: “The ridership on ORR has seen a consistent increasing trend since its launch.”At the #NimbusExpress Bus Yatra, held to promote bus priority lanes, BMTC managing director C Shikha had said their daily ridership had increased by 12,000 and journey time had come down by 16 minutes during peak hours.Srinivas Alavilli from Citizens for Bengaluru, which has been backing the project for a long time said, “There is huge support from the public for this project to succeed but government agencies appear to have disappointed us. Installation of bollards has been delayed and enforcement against violators has been poor.”“There is a big scope to further increase the speed and ridership on ORR,” a BMTC official admitted.Those violating bus lane are fined Rs 500 for the first offence and Rs 1,000 for subsequent violations.Traffic police teams of KR Puram, HAL, HSR Layout and Madiwala are responsible for enforcement. BMTC is also recording violations by motorists. However, traffic police have slapped fine only on a few motorists and most violate rules with impunity. Joint commissioner of police, traffic, BR Ravikanthe Gowda was unavailable for comment despite repeated efforts.

Title: Bengaluru: Chasing quality, schools adopt Scandinavian pedagogies
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Educationists can vouch for Bengaluru’s openness to experiment with new pedagogies. Apart from hosting one of the highest number of international sc-hools in the country, the city now also has institutions that are trying to import the best pedagogies from places like Finland , Sweden and Denm-ark, whose education syste-ms enjoy global reputation.

Some schools in the city have adopted best practices from these countries even while sticking to Indian curriculum and boards in order to ensure the best of both worlds. The managements either source experts from these countries or send their school leaders there to understand the system and introduce it in their schools. The Delhi government, for instance, had sent its teachers to Finland.

Kunskapsskolan is an Indo-Swedish school off Sarjapur Road, which started in 2017. In collaboration with Swedish firm Kunskapsskolan Education Sweden AB, the school has adopted a methodology focusing on personalised education, where each student sets his or her own personal and academic goals. With help from a personal coach, a student is encouraged to find strategies to attain the goals. This allows the child to set his or her own pace for learning, a method practised in Sweden. The Swedish head of the school, Mats Rosen, coaches teachers to ensure the programme is implemented in its true spirit.

Chaman Bhartiya, a school that is expected to start in Bengaluru from the next academic year, has roped in a Scandinavian educationist, who draws inspiration from the schooling system in Denmark. “In Denmark, children are happy to go to school. Parents do not ask how well their children did in academics. Instead, they ask how kind the child was and does he/she socialise with other children, among others. However, Indian students are better in academics. So, in the new school, we hope to take the best of both worlds,” said Allen Kjaer Andersen, director for the project.

The management of PNC Cognitio School that is affiliated to Cambridge Assessment International Education sent its top school leaders to Finland. “Our school leaders realised the biggest strength of Finland was in its teachers. We also decided to invest more on our teachers with resource time for them every single day and also on two Saturdays a month... The happiness quotient in Finland’s schools and the trust quotient students have are major takeaways,” said Nagesh LS, director.

A group of experts, however, are sceptical and say it’s not possible for Indian schools to completely adopt and do justice to these foreign systems. “A few visits will not help teachers completely understand and emulate the system. It will be like taking an engine of a Rolls Royce and trying to fit it in an old car,” said one expert.

Title: Nothing smart about e-toilets in Taj city
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

AGRA: Following lack of proper monitoring, e-toilets set up at Purani Mandi and Basai Chowki in Fatehabad Road six months ago, under the smart city project, are yet to commence operations.

According to sources, miscreants have also stolen faucets, electric fittings, wash basins and other parts from the toilets at these places. The lock of one the toilets has also been broken at Fatehabad Road.

The e-toilets are portable, eco-friendly and hygienically maintained with a GPRS-enabled system. These toilets work on a sensor-based technology. They have a self-cleaning and water conservation mechanism. These are unmanned toilets with automated access control. Each block of e-toilet cost Rs 6 lakh. People were required to insert Rs 5 coin to use the e-toilet facility.

While the ones set up at Purani Mandi, Basai Chowki on Fatehabad Road and at Tajganj are yet to become operational, some of the e-toilets that were set up in Jalkal Land on Mughal Pulia, Trident crossing, Jaypee Hotel and Bijlighar do not function on a regular basis due to lack of full-time water supply.

According to locals, the e-toilets at Basai Chowki are being used by vendors to exhibit their products while the space around the ones at Purani Mandi are being used for parking vehicles, .

Nodal officer-in-charge of the Agra smart city project RK Singh said, “Due to some issues related to land and water connection, the operation of these e-toilets has been delayed. Now, the matter has been sorted out. The e-toilets at Purani Mandi and Fatehabad Road will be opened by January-end.”

Title: Dehradun woman found dead in Haridwar hotel
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

HARIDWAR: A 37-year-old woman from Dehradun was found dead inside a hotel room in Haridwar on Sunday morning. According to police, a liquor bottle was found inside the room and the deceased body has been sent to district hospital for autopsy.

Initial probe revealed that a local youth had reportedly booked the room for the woman. The woman ran a beauty parlour in Dalanwala area of Dehradun.

The deceased woman, who was married and had a child, was a resident of Dalanwala, Dehradun district . She reached Haridwar on Saturday evening and stayed in the room of a city-based hotel. Police are investigating the case from all angles. They have now informed her family.

SSP Haridwar Senthil Abudai Kirshna Raj S told TOI on Sunday, “The woman did not open the doors of the room on Sunday morning after which hotel staff called the police. We opened the room with duplicate keys and found her lying on the bed. A liquor bottle was also found inside the room. The body has been sent to the civil hospital for postmortem. We are waiting for the report to ascertain the case. Further probe is on.”

Title: ‘Banned’ Chinese manjha continues to pose serious threat to human, animals alike in Haridwar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Bird injured by Chinese manjha in Haridwar

HARIDWAR: Recent incidents, in which two wild owls suffered injuries and a man in Jwalapur received injuries in the neck and had to be admitted to ICU, have rekindled the controversy over sale of Chinese manjha in the district. Locals contend the abrasive kite strings made in China, which are non-biodegradable, have become a serious threat to humans as well as wildlife in Haridwar , as the district administration and police have failed to act against its sale, even after NGT banned it across the country in 2017.

Flying kites in winter is a popular pastime in Haridwar. Despite repeated complaints by locals, authorities are yet to clamp down on sale of the dangerous Chinese manjha, which is made of monofilament fishing line coated with deadly sharp glass shards. It is also non-biodegradable, making it dangerous for the environment, especially water bodies where it eventually ends up. Across Haridwar, Chinese manjha is selling openly.

Activist J P Badoni, himself a victim of Chinese manjha, told TOI, “Despite the ban, anybody can buy Chinese manjha from the market. I had complained to the city magistrate to issue an order against this, but after no action was taken, I filed an application with the district magistrate. He too is yet to take any action. The only option left before me is to file a suit in the court. It’s unfortunate our agencies are not performing their duties according to law.”

Domestic and wild animals and birds are among the biggest victims of Chinese manjha. Several birds have been rescued by the forest department recently bearing wounds from Chinese manjha.

Divisional forest officer, Haridwar, Akash Verma told TOI, “It’s very dangerous for wild animals and birds. We rescued several birds so far. Last week, we rescued two wild owls trapped in Chinese manjha, both of which lost their wings. We have no power to take action against shopkeepers who sell the deadly material.”

Contrary to the ground reality, police claimed action is being taken. Haridwar SSP Senthil Abudai Krishna Raj S told TOI, “We’re taking action against sellers of Chinese manjha as per rules. We also imposed penalty, and strict action will be taken against those violate the rules.”

Title: Cousins run over by truck in US Nagar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Rudrapur: Two cousin brothers were killed after a speeding truck hit the bike they were riding. The incident took place near Bahalla bridge in Bazpur, under jurisdiction of ITI police outpost, in Udham Singh Nagar district on Saturday evening. Both the men were killed on the spot.

The deceased were identified as Daan Singh (25), a resident of Jaitpur Ghosi village of Bazpur and his uncle’s son Ravi Kumar (35), a resident of Noorpur Dhakiya village of Kashipur.

The duo was headed to their cousin’s wedding in Jaitpur Ghosi village. On receiving information, police reached the spot and seized the truck. However, the driver managed to flee the spot. The bodies were sent for postmortem.

ITI police outpost in-charge, Kuldeep Singh Adhikari, said that the truck had been impounded and a case registered against the errant driver under relevant sections of the IPC. “Efforts are on to apprehend the driver soon,” Adhikari said.

Title: Five people die in seperate road accidents in rural district
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nashik: Five people — a young couple and their child and two elderly bikers — died in separate road accidents in the rural district between Friday and Saturday.

On Saturday evening, 27-year-old Nitin Gangurde, his wife Puja (22) and 4-year-old daughter Atharvi died in an accident in Chandwad, about 60 km from Nashik. The deceased were residents of the Jail Road area, Nashik Road. The Gangurde family had been to Satana to attend a wedding. They met with the accident on their way back, when a trailer hit their bike in the Chandwad Ghat on the Mumbai-Agra highway at around 7 pm. All three died on the spot. The trailer driver tried to flee the scene, but was nabbed by locals. The driver has been arrested for causing death due to negligence.

Earlier the same day, a 70-year-old biker died in an acident when his vehicle skidded near Pimpalgaon on Wani junction. The accident took place at 11 am. The deceased was identified as Narayan Tukaram Gavali of Shinde Mala, Chandwad.

On Friday, at around 7.30 pm, 60-year-old man Pandit Mhalu Sonawane was also killed in a road accident between Dugaon and Kokan Khede under the jurisdiction of the Chandwad police station. Sonawane was riding a bike, when a truck coming form the opposite direction knocked him down. Sonawane and a pillion rider suffered serious injuries and Sonawane succumbed. The Chandwad police have booked the truck driver Giridhar Dhudpu Salunkhe, of Kalambe in Dhule district, for causing death due to negligence.

Title: UT: Bar body under GST, will have to pay tax for parking fee, rent
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Association will be served notice to pay interest and apply for a GST number to run the parking lot, says UT e... Read More

Title: Virtually there: A 3D tour of Taj, Sun Temple in Delhi
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

NEW DELHI: If you want to see monuments like Kashi Vishwanath temple, Taj Mahal and Hampi temple without travelling to where they are located, then visit National Museum where their specially crafted 3D models will be on display for a month.

The interactive models of five important heritage sites titled “ViRaasat” have been developed by Vizara technologies, a startup at IIT-Delhi’s incubation centre. The installations are an exact replica of the original monuments developed through laser scan data. “We developed them by taking government data and creating 3D and digital models,” said Anupama Mallik, CEO and MD of Vizara technologies.

The five monuments include Kashi Vishwanath temple, Taj Mahal, Sun Temple of Konark , Vijaya Vitthala Temple of Hampi, Sita Ramachandraswamy temple at Bhadrachalam and Rani ki Vav at Patan.

“Along with a bird’s eye view, one can have a virtual walkthrough of the structures. You can use a laser pointer to draw a path on the physical model and a screen behind will show the camera movement, thereby giving a personal tour,” said Mallik.

Users can also take a tour through voice command. “You can ask Alexa to move in the pathway of the monuments, go up or down and change the time of the day. We have also provided a game controller or console for users to move around the monuments,” Mallik said.

In the Kashi Vishwanath model, a tablet has been placed to show a video of the chosen particular spot. Mallik said, “These miniature structures will excite tourists. The models give an aerial view of the monuments, which people generally don’t get to see. The beauty of the structures can be appreciated through these replicas.”

Visitors can also see 10-minute video shows of Taj Mahal and Kashi Vishwanath temple giving the history and an insight into the monuments.

Title: Uttarakhand: Wait for formation of Congress’ new panel continues
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Pritam Singh

DEHRADUN: With former chief minister Harish Rawat on a three-month break from active politics, state Congress unit will have to wait some more for the selection of party’s new committee.

A party insider told TOI that the new committee could not be selected as some leaders are accusing others of ignoring Rawat. “The party is yet to announce new district chiefs of Tehri and Udham Singh Nagar as well. These posts had become vacant around three years ago but they have not yet been filled. How can we become strong on grass-root level if such key positions remain vacant,” said a Congress functionary.

Earlier in December 2019, Congress had dissolved its committee and the new one was to be announced in January, 2020. Pritam Singh was heading the last Congress committee since party’s 2017 assembly poll debacle. However, Singh had to work with the team formed by his predecessor Kishore Upadhyay.

The previous committee had 28 vice presidents, 28 general secretaries, five secretaries, a chief spokesperson, 21 special members, and 21 executive committee members.

Meanwhile, former party spokesperson Mathura Dutt Joshi has denied all reports of internal bickering among senior state leaders. “The new committee has been approved and it would be announced soon. Our senior leaders, including Harish Rawat and Pritam Singh, have worked very hard to strengthen the party in the Himalayan state,” said Joshi.

Title: Aligarh lawyer, wife shot by nephews over property dispute
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: A 32-year-old lawyer was allegedly shot dead and his wife sustained serious injuries on her head after the couple was attacked and fired upon by nephews following a heated argument over a property dispute in Aligarh’s Karpuri Nagar on Sunday.

According to police, advocate Vedprakash died on the spot, while his wife, Kavita, 28, who tried to intervene sustained bullet injuries on the left side of her skull. She was rushed to JN medical college, where her condition is said to be critical.

Station house officer of Kawarsi police station, Vinod Kumar, said that the incident occurred around 10:30 am, when the deceased’s nephews, Himanshu and Dheeraj, reached their uncle’s house to reportedly demand their Rs 40,000 share in connection with the property, where he was staying.

After a heated argument, the duo, who were carrying pistols, fired two shots at Vedprakash and when his wife tried to save her husband, the accused shot at her too and fled from the house. Vedprakash’s body had two bullet injuries, one each at his back and right side of the face. His body has been sent for postmortem.

An FIR has been registered against Himanshu and Dheeraj under sections 452 (house-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint), 302 (murder) and 307 (attempt to murder) of IPC on a complaint filed by Vedprakash’s brother.

Himanshu and Dheeraj are still absconding and their house in Begum Bagh is currently locked, said the police.

SSP Akash Kulhary said that two teams have been formed to nab the accused and they will be arrested soon. He said a forensic team has also visited the spot.

According to local residents, Vedprakash was the youngest among five siblings and was staying with his wife and two minor daughters, Anshika (9) and Geetanjali (3). After the incident, people gathered and started shooting videos of injured Kavita while she was requesting them to take her to hospital or call an ambulance. She also disclosed that her brother-in-law’s sons, who stay in Begum Bagh, had shot them.

Title: 45,000 15-year-old vehicles to go off Agra roads on February 16
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The RTO has issues final notices to the vehicle owners concerned

AGRA: In a bid to curb pollution in the eco-sensitive Taj Trapezium Zone (TTZ), some 45,000 vehicles which are 15 years or more will be taken off the roads in Agra . The regional transport office (RTO) has decided to cancel the registration certificate of all these vehicles.

In this regard, the RTO has issued final notices to the vehicle owners concerned. The RTO is going to cancel the registration certificate of these vehicles on February 16. Thereafter, vehicles purchased before March 2004 found operating on the roads will be seized and dismantled as their emission levels are high.

According to RTO officials, no further extension of registration of these vehicles will be done. However, those who wish to transfer their vehicles to any other district in the country will be allowed to do so by taking a no-objection certificate (NOC) by February 15, they added.

Anil Kumar, regional transport officer (administration), said, “Soon registration of all vehicles operating since March 2004 or earlier will be cancelled. Final notices have been issued to the owners of the pollution- causing vehicles. After this, such vehicles found operating in Agra will be seized and dismantled. Besides, their owners will be penalized. There is no scope for any relaxation in the rule, especially in Agra district, a major part of which lies in the eco-sensitive Taj Trapezium Zone.”

In 2018, the Union ministry of road transport and highways, had banned operations of 10-year-old diesel vehicles and 15-year-old petrol vehicles in the National Capital Region (NCR) and TTZ, that spans a 10,400 sq km comprising over 40 protected monuments, including three World Heritage sites -- Taj Mahal , Agra Fort and Fatehpur Sikri. So far, the transport authorities have not been able to enforce the ban. The TTZ covers Agra, Mathura, Firozabad, Hathras and Etah districts in UP and a part of Bharatpur district in Rajasthan.

The registration series which is proposed to be cancelled include UP 80 A to Z, AA, AB, AC and AD, an RTO official said.

He added, “Owners of vehicles which are 15 years or more old have an option to transfer them to some other district by obtaining an NOC. Some of the locals have already got their vehicles registered in Mainpuri and Etawah or nearby states, where the rule is not applicable. Once the registration is cancelled, the vehicle will be of no use.”

Title: Chandigarh: Burglars strike at firm in Sector 26
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Thieves broke into a firm in Sector 26 and escaped with Rs 2.19 lakh on Saturday night.

Manoj Kumar, DGM (accounts), Indian Acrylics Ltd, Sector 26, said in his police complaint, “Burglars broke the glass door to gain entry. When the staff reached office on Sunday, they found the locker broken and Rs 2,19,670 missing.”

On being informed, Sector 26 police, along with a dog squad and a forensic team, reached the spot.

A case has been registered under Section 380 (theft in dwelling house or building) of the IPC. “We are scrutinizing the footage of CCTVs installed in and around the area to trace the accused,” said a cop.

Another theft case was reported hours later.

Balkiran Kaur, a resident of Sector 39, told the police that her purse was stolen from Sector 38 (West) gurdwara on Sunday. “I had gone to the gurdwara to attend a ‘satsang’. After it got over, I kept my purse and cellphone near me while wearing shoes. When I got up to leave, I found my purse, which contained Rs 6,000 and important documents, and cellphone missing.” The police have registered a theft case and are checking the footage of CCTVs installed in the gurdwara.

On January 14, Harjit Singh Sandhu, a resident of Sector 27, had lodged a police complaint that his house was burgled. Sandhu had gone to his ancestral house in Bathinda . When he returned, he found gold and silver jewellery, two LCDs and an LPG cylinder stolen from his house.

Title: Shirdi bandh suspended as CM Uddhav Thackeray assures dialogue
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

CM Uddhav Thackerey

NASHIK: The indefinite bandh that had been called by the residents of Shirdi — to protest against the state government announcing Pathri, in Parbhani district , as Saibaba’s birthplace — was called off temporarily after chief minister Uddhav Thackeray agreed to hold a dialogue on Monday.

“We did not object to the Rs 100-crore aid being given to Pathri village . Our objection was to terming the village as Saibaba’s birthplace. Therefore, the entire business community and the residents of the region had joined the protest. After the CM assured us of a meet on Monday, we called off the bandh,” Nitin Kote, who is spearheading the agitation, said. Kote, however, added that the outcome of Monday’s meeting would decide their future course of action.

Business establishments — including hotels, restaurants and shops — in Shirdi and 25 other surrounding villages in Ahmednagar district had remained closed on Sunday in response to the indefinite bandh called by the residents of the pilgrim town. In fact, Sadashiv Lokhande, the Sena MP from Shirdi, too had backed the bandh going against the party line.

“I am completely with the people of this town and pilgrims. I will speak to the chief minister (Thackeray) to find a solution to the issue,” he had said addressing a gathering on Sunday. Former MLA Snehalata Kolhe, Shiv Sena leaders Kamlakar Kote, Sujit Gondkar, Sena city unit president Sachin Kote and others were also present in the rally.

At 10 am, the Shirdi residents had taken out a ‘Sab Ka Malik Ek’ rally from the Dwarkamai temple. All shops, establishments and local autorickshaws joined the bandh and many pilgrims were even unable to buy offerings for Saibaba. “When we come here, we like to make offerings to Saibaba. We thought we would get them here, but because everything is closed, all we could do was visit the shrine,” said Shivkumar Reddy, a devotee from Hyderabad.

But the bandh did not affect the pilgrim numbers as the temple and its services remained open. The Shirdi Saibaba Sansthan Trust (SSST), which has 1,530 rooms, had full occupancy and there were many still looking for a place to stay. Office-bearers of the SSST said the number of pilgrims during the day was comparable to any given Sunday.

Commenting on the pilgrim situation on Sunday afternoon, the SSST officials said, “From Sunday evening onwards, the number of pilgrims staying in Shirdi usually drops. As of now, all the rooms are filled. However, more than 25% of the rooms will become vacant in the evening and we will be able to accommodate the pilgrims coming in.” The officials added that the SSST also provides meals to the pilgrims.

The Shirdi Municipal Council also tried to help out the pilgrims. “We have ensured that the pilgrims and tourists coming to the Shirdi town don’t face problems. We will provide free food to pilgrims till the government agrees to our demand,” said Archana Kote, president of the council.

Title: Sewage water causes road to cave in near Kharar
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Mohali: A road connecting Kharar with Bassi Pathana caved in after a sewer broke, leaving the residents on both sides disconnected, municipal corporation officials said on Sunday.

According to them, the sewage water being discharged from Kharar had been affecting the nearby villages for some time, after which the authorities decided to release the water. On Saturday, when the officials came with their JCB machines to check the underwater sewer and release it, the flow of the water became so much that it could not bear the pressure and the pipe burst, after which the road caved in.

According to the officials, the villagers there had deliberately blocked the pipe, due to which the water had reached the level of road. “To release the water on the other side and check the water flow, we went there with a JCB machine, but the pressure was so high that the underneath part of the road couldn’t bear it and the sewer burst,” said one of the officials.

“Within no time, part of the road caved in. Many fish are believed to have dies due to the contaminated water and the nearby villages are facing a tough time, also due to bad odour,” said Narinder, a resident of the nearby village.

Villagers said that now they would have to travel 6km more to reach Kharar via the Randhawa road. Incidentally, this is the shortest available route now. Police officials also rushed to the spot and closed to road to prevent any mishap.

Mohali DC Girish Dayalan said, “A committee has been constituted comprising officials from different departments concerned, including the Kharar MC executive officer, to assess the loss and repair cost, and to draft a plan to find a lasting solution.”

In December last year, TOI had reported that villagers of four affected villages — Shergarh Barha, Kajal Majra, Main Majri and Nandpur Kalaur — had been pressing the administrations of Mohali and Fatehgarh Sahib to find a solution to stop the flow of water from Kharar treatment plant into their fields. Row Political commotion over toxic water flowing into fields of four villages due to an illegal dam on Satluj Yamuna Link (SYL) Canal near Kharar was put to rest after demolishing the same, thus allowing the treated water to flow further into the canal.

Overflowing water was falling into Jainti Ki Rao and entering agricultural land of low-lying villages of Shergarh Barha, Kajal Majra, Main Majri and Nandpur Kalaur destroying the standing crop.

Title: Karnataka politics: Fresh tension as Amit Shah moots only six cabinet berths for defectors
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Amit Shah

BENGALURU: The suspense over chief minister BS Yediyurappa expanding his council of ministers is set to continue until after he returns from his trip to attend the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland.

Yediyurappa, who heads a 10-member delegation to the Swiss ski resort, left on Sunday. Prior to his departure, he told reporters cabinet expansion will happen only after his return on January 24. “I discussed the issue with [BJP] national president Amit Shah for 30 minutes or so. He has given a positive response and I will expand the cabinet within two days after my return,” Yediyurappa said.

But sources said Shah, during his visit to Hubballi on Saturday, had indicated the exercise is likely to be delayed further as the central leadership will be busy with the assembly elections in Delhi. “Indications are there is no possibility of expanding the cabinet until February 11 when the electoral process for the Delhi elections ends,” said a source.

The development has obviously left ministerial aspirants, especially defectors from Congress and JD(S) who were re-elected on BJP tickets last month, restive. Moreover, while Yediyurappa has promised ministerial berths to all MLAs who switched to the BJP from Congress and JD(S), sources say Shah is only in favour of inducting six defectors (11 of whom won MLA seats on saffron party tickets in the byelections) into the cabinet.

“Shah’s advice to Yediyurappa is to strike a balance between defectors and loyalists. His concern is loyalists should not be left disappointed, while justice should be served to the defectors as well,” said a BJP functionary.

Meanwhile, KS Eshwarappa, senior party functionary and minister for rural development, said the BJP would never let down the defectors. “The party is indebted to them and I am sure they will all be rewarded,” he said.

BC Patil, one of the defectors, said some of them had met Shah in one-on-one meetings in Hubballi. “It was more a courtesy call and the issue of cabinet expansion didn’t come up during the meeting,” he said.

Title: Bengaluru's Modi Masjid opens its doors to people of all faiths
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The organisers plan to hold a similar event in the city next month (Bangalore Mirror image)

BENGALURU: Dozens showed up at Modi Masjid in Tasker Town on Sunday morning after the 170-year-old mosque opened its doors to men and women of all faiths , inviting them to visit and learn more about Islam.

The visitors were taken on a tour of the masjid and various postures of prayer were demonstrated by the organisers. They were told about the teachings and practices in Islam and verses from the Quran were recited. A Q&A session where members of non-Muslim communities voiced their doubts, besides a meditation session, were also held as part of the event. Visitors were given a copy of the Quran to browse through.

The open invitation,‘Visit My Mosque’, to understand Islam better, was issued earlier in the week by Mumbai-based charitable trust Rahmath Group to non-Muslim communities, through social media. The group organised a similar event at the mosque in the past for students of a Christian college.

“The masjid doors were opened to all fellow Indians, on Sunday. We planned such an event to bridge the gap between Muslim and non-Muslim communities. To this day, there continues to be a lot of misconceptions about Islam. This event was aimed at empowering all communities with more information about the Muslim community and try to answer any questions they may have,” said Sadiqh Sailani of Rahmath Group.

“The most common question people raised was regarding the status of women in Islam. People asked questions about Muslim women’s attire and many were of the misconception that women are oppressed. The status of women in Islam is very high and the clothes are more of a religious practice than a social obligation — we explained this to them. A few others raised questions about jihad as well,” said Sadiqh.

The mosque was named after Modi Abdul Gafoor, a 19th century merchant. Apart from this mosque, there are two more mosques are in Bengaluru known as Modi Masjid.

The organisers plan to hold a similar event in the city next month.

Title: Goa: ‘Declare comunidades as public authorities for RTI to function’
Content:
The Goa State Information Commission has recommended that the government take immediate steps to issue a notif... Read More

PANAJI: The Goa State Information Commission has recommended that the government take immediate steps to issue a notification to declare comunidades as ‘public authorities’ for the efficient functioning of the RTI act, and in the interest of maintaining transparency and accountability.“The administrator of the comunidade can be appointed as the First Appellate Authority (FAA) (instead of the additional collector) and the PIO can be escrivao/clerk of the respective comunidade,” stated the order passed by Juino De Souza, the state information commissioner.The commission observed that most comunidades function in a “secret manner without any transparency and accountability”, where information is withheld from the shareholders of the comunidades.“These bodies cannot be allowed to be looted and plundered under the garb of them being ‘gaunkari’ (community-run) or private entities. Even components of the comunidade, namely gaunkars and shareholders, are kept in the dark about the managing committee decisions regarding allotments of plots, open spaces, serventia and permissions granted by the respective comunidades,” De Souza stated in his order.The observations were passed while disposing of an appeal filed by a shareholder of Calangute comunidade, who was denied information, under RTI, about the minutes of the general body, ordinary and extraordinary meetings held during the tenure of the present managing committee of Calangute Comunidade.The commission came to the conclusion that that the PIO was not at fault as the PIO had made repeated attempts to obtain information from the comunidade of Calangute, but was not successful, because the comunidade of Calangute “is unwilling to furnish the information due to its claim that comunidade bodies are not public authorities and the PIO has no jurisdiction to call for private information”.

Title: Chandigarh: In four years, driving licences of 8,685 offenders suspended
Content:
As per the data compiled by RLA, 2019 witnessed a massive jump in suspension of licences.

CHANDIGARH: Registering and Licensing Authority (RLA), Chandigarh, suspended the driving licences of 8,685 city residents for three to six months for violating traffic rules from January 1, 2016, till December 31, 2019.As per the data compiled by RLA, 2019 witnessed a massive jump in suspension of licences. As many as 3,040 licences were suspended between January 1, 2019, and December 31, 2019. The figure was 5,645 for the preceding three years (from January 1, 2016, to December 31, 2018).Violations like speeding and drunken driving led to maximum licence suspensions. In the past four years, 3,046 licences were suspended for speeding and 2,755 for drunken driving.The analysis of 2019 data, however, reveals that jumping red-light led to maximum (936) suspension of licences, followed by speeding (814) and drunken driving (566).Traffic police said under Section 19 of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1988, (read with Rule 21 of the Central Motor Vehicles Rules, 1989), it had recommended to RLA to suspend driving licences for three to six months of those using cellphone while driving, jumping red light, speeding and mixing drinking with driving.With the implementation of amended Motor Vehicles Act in September last, driving without helmet attracted a fine of Rs 1,000 along with suspension of driving licence for three months. Earlier, only Rs 300 was charged for the offence.An RLA official said licences were also suspended for violations such as overloading goods vehicles, carrying passengers in goods carriages, triple riding and using pressure horns.UT traffic police had started sending online recommendations to RLA for suspension of driving licences of offenders in 2018. Before that, the recommendations would reach the RLA in 10 days, delaying action.

Title: Goa: Goan seafarer abducted by pirates dies in captivity
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

MARGAO: Eighteen Indians held hostage by pirates off the coast of Benin in west Africa were released on Sunday. However, one among the four Goans — identified as Brito D’Silva from Ambelim—died in captivity. The other three Goans are reportedly safe, and are currently lodged in Lagos, Nigeria.

“It is being informed that Brito D’Silva one of the four #Goans seafarers from Ambelim kidnapped by #Nigerian #pirates dies under abduction. 18 seafarers have been released by pirates today. Demanding an inquiry into the matter,” commissioner for NRI affairs Narendra Sawaikar tweeted.

There’s no clarity about the circumstances leading to his death, Sawaikar told TOI. “One has to understand that he was among those held hostage by pirates. The (shipping) company was negotiating with the pirates for over a month for their safe release and I was being updated. However, we don’t know the nature or terms of those negotiations. I have demanded an inquiry, and I hope some clarity emerges,” he said.

Dixon Vaz of Goa Seamen’s Association of India told TOI that representatives of the shipping company had called on D’Silva’s family in Ambelim on Sunday morning and gave the tragic news.

D’Silva, Vaz said, was married just 7-8 months ago.

Demanding a thorough inquiry into D’Silva’s death, Vaz said that the family was informed that he died on December 23.

“We have learnt that all the kidnapped seafarers were kept confined at an isolated place deep in the forests. So how he died, whether he fell sick, etc, we don’t know. We are waiting for the arrival of the other three Goans who have been released today (Sunday) to reach home so that we get some clarity on the matter,” Vaz said.

The pirates had attacked the ship on December 15 in the international waters approximately 140 nautical miles from Lome, Tago.

Sawaikar had subsequently written to minister of external affairs S Jaishankar seeking his intervention for the expeditious release of the abducted seafarers. The Indian high commission in Abuja, Nigeria, had then written to Sawaikar stating that all the Indian nationals held hostage by the pirates off the coast of Benin in west Africa were safe and that contact had been established with the parties concerned to seek their early release.

Title: UP: Man accidentally shot dead
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AGRA: A 40-year-old man was accidentally shot dead after he was caught in a cross-fire between two groups in the main market of Iglas area in Aligarh on Sunday evening.

The man was identified as Safruddin. According to police, the incident occurred around 7:30pm when a clash took place between two groups. A bullet hit the deceased’s head while he was passing through the market to buy some groceries. He was rushed to the hospital, where he was declared dead.

Title: 41 students from district score above 98% in JEE mains
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nashik: Students from Nashik district performed exceptionally well in the Joint Entrance Examination ( JEE ) mains , the results of which were declared on Friday night.

Reports from various coaching classes and other sources indicate that as many as 41 students have scored above 98% in the exam conducted by the National Testing Agency (NTA).

With 99.99%, Aditya Kudre is the highest scorer in the JEE mains from Nashik district. Among other students who secured above 98% are Reedam Dhake (99.89%), Pawan Bodke (99.84%), Prathak Kurkure (99.78%), Samyak Jain (99.76%), Shubham Pednekar (99.74%), Rutvij Gondkar (99.72%), Harshwardhan W (99.69%) and Anita Warungase (99.69%).

Without discrediting the hard work of the students, coaching experts attributed their success to the role teachers and parents played in the lives of the students during their preparation time.

“Students should stay away from social media platforms like Facebook and Instagram and realise that these are the most crucial two years of their lives. Parents should avoid buying smart phones for their wards. I have seen that in many cases, having a mobile phone turns out to be the biggest reason for a student’s failure,” said Vishwas Jain from GravIITy Academy.

Another expert pointed out that while students should take their studies seriously to achieve good results, he also advised other students, whose scores have fallen, to not be disheartened as there were many more avenues for them to explore.

“Students need not be disheartened if the results were not up to their expectations. Instead, they should start looking out for alternate opportunities the education sector has to offer and explore the areas which they can master,” said the expert.

Title: Piyush Goyal: 1 million new jobs should not be at the cost of several million jobs
Content:
Commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal (File photo: PTI)

You will be representing India in Davos. What’s on the agenda?

You are scheduled to meet US Trade Representative. Has the trade deal with the US been sealed or will you be giving it finishing touches?

What time frame do you have in mind?

There are reports of President

Donald Trump

coming to India next month…

Will you meet your Malaysian counterpart in Davos?

Your comments on Amazon’s investment have generated a lot of controversy and a day later you said that the statement should be seen in proper perspective...

When Competition Commission of India (CCI) is already looking into the issue, was there a need for the government to comment, especially when we are seeking investment, both domestic and foreign?

What are the findings of the ministry’s investigations?

In Amazon’s case, you and your officers have had meetings with their India team. Have the violations been pointed out to them?

Since it’s still under discussion, wouldn’t it have been prudent for you to wait for this to get over before making that statement (on Amazon)?

But isn’t that a global phenomenon where you have traditional retailers competing against companies with technology…

You have talked about import substitution of non-essential imports and on other fronts as well, which is seen to be protectionist. Does it send the right signal to investors, some of whom you will meet in Davos this week?

Amazon has said that their $1 billion investment will create a million jobs…

Is there scope for a further review of the regulations?

There is a perception that you are paying more attention to imports that exports. Is that a fair perception?

What will be your message to investors in Davos and elsewhere? Is India open for business?

NEW DELHI: Commerce and industry minister Piyush Goyal has raised the heat on e-commerce companies such as Amazon and Flipkart and asked them to ensure that their operations are completely in line with Indian regulations. In an interview ahead of his visit to Davos, he tells TOI that he is not being protectionist in his policies. Excerpts:This year, we have chosen the theme, Power of India. We believe India reflects the power of democracy, the power of demography, leadership, opportunity and talent. It encapsulates the rising relevance in the business world as we move towards a $5 trillion economy. It is a cusp after which economies tend to take over. Once you cross the $3,500-4,000 per capita income level, the momentum drives the economy.
