I have over 50 engagements and we will be engaged in several dialogues around the investment opportunity, sustainability, industry and manufacturing potential and we will be talking to several international leaders to further explore further explore trade and business opportunities inter se our friendly nations.We have six-member trade negotiating team coming to India next week. In the meantime I will have my dialogue with Ambassador Bob Lighthizer and I am sure we can work out the first part of a long-term relationship which we are working on.Trade issues are very complex, one must not rush them.Am not aware of that.I don’t see it in my calendar.I had categorically said that we welcome all FDI into the country but they have to work within the law of the land. India has a very clear policy that FDI is allowed in multi-brand retail trade only up to 49%. In e-commerce, up to 100% FDI is allowed, but in business-to-business (B2B). As I became the commerce and industry minister and I saw the number of retail stores that were closing down, the concerns of small retail in India, which are similar to concerns that many stakeholders have in America, we started going into the detail.We found that large e-commerce companies are not necessarily within the ambit of Indian law in totality. While they have found some loophole to demonstrate that they fit into the parameters set by various government circulars, the spirit of the law has not been recognised by these companies. India has thousands of foreign companies working in the country and all of them have a very pleasant experience working in the country. We also have a very pleasant experience since they work within the ambit of the law. E-commerce companies should also work within the ambit of the law.We are seeking investment into sectors, which are permitted. CCI has its mandate to look at fair business practices. When they ordered an investigation, they said they could clearly see that there was a flouting of equal opportunity to all sellers on that platform, they also said that they could see some restricted practices by sellers on these platforms... Complaints also led to find if there is violation of FDI policy, which is the mandate of the commerce and industry ministry. Many of the e-commerce companies have actually thanked me that we have done the investigation within the ministry and are giving a full opportunity to all these companies to respond instead of letting the investigations get into another track.That’s work in progress but certainly some of the findings are not very good, which prompted me to once again say what I have been saying for the last three-four months on several platforms. We will appreciate if all e-commerce companies work within the ambit of the law and don’t use loopholes to break the law and indirectly get into multi-brand retailing along with anti-competitive measures.My job is to explain what is permitted and what’s not permitted. I don’t conduct investigations. But my officers have certainly pointed out, based on the findings on the marketplace, through questionnaires (on) what we believe are the lacunae. Some responses have been received, which have confirmed that there are certain irregularities. However, we are giving more opportunities to the companies to present their case before the officials and will take a view on it after all the investigations and responses are received. We will also be very happy to guide them in case they have inadvertently been on the wrong side of the law.One can have a view on that. My effort is to raise the urgency of the issue also to the e-commerce companies. This is in the best interests of the country and all businesses that what they are doing should be fair and proper and not to the detriment of small retailers. It may not happen that just responding to our questions, or our giving an opportunity to fit into the law, we end up losing millions of jobs in the country and small retailers start closing down. The reports that I am getting on mobile stores, for example, are extremely disturbing. It’s reported that may be hundreds, may be, thousands of small retail stores have shut operations as they are unable to compete against giants. How will a small retailer with a few thousand rupees compete with giants who have deep pockets with billions of dollars?Technology is welcome. That’s we have opened e-commerce for B2B transactions, it’s not been opened up for B2C transactions. Each country will have to look after its own. Globally, countries don’t have such large population as India does. We have 60-70 million retailers, who have to pay interest on what they borrow and capital is scarce against global pools of capital which are huge and nearly at zero cost. This unfair competition was what was sought to be protected when the policy was made 20 years ago. It was opened up under the clear and explicit understanding that it will be B2B. If you introduce companies in between to convert the platform into a B2B platform and then serve the consumer through intermediaries which are also related parties, then it’s certainly a matter of concern.I am not looking at stopping any imports. Many imports are sub-standard, which are circumvention of country of origin rules, there are many countries which give equal and fair access to Indian products. Over the years, we have let loose a very liberal import regime. We are only trying to align ourselves with global best practices. For instance, the US has over 8,000 technical barriers to trade and sanitary and phyto-sanitary regulations, India barely has 500. China and Brazil also have higher regulations. I would like Indian industry to also engage with world class levels of quality, upgrade itself. There is also the question of ‘others’ category, if one-third or one-fourth of the products are categorised as others, as a nation we can’t plan without having data on what is being imported.We value the one million jobs that are going to be created but that should not be at the cost of several million jobs that may be lost because their focus only being on the supply side. As government, we have to focus on supply as well as the retail. While they are saying we have added so many suppliers, we are very happy, but their job as an e-commerce platform is to only connect suppliers with businesses. The retail end of it, the connect with the consumer, is with the retailer and if our retailers lose millions of jobs in the garb of creating 7 lakh jobs, I don’t think the country can afford to lose millions of retailers’ livelihood.We have never changed the law but only come out with clarifications through press notes, even e-commerce companies recognise this. Sadly, our clarifications have sought to be misused and structures sought to be created around those clarifications. In 2017-18, Amazon has declared losses of nearly $900 million. In a marketplace, where you are providing a platform for sellers to come and buyers to buy, I wonder how you can make losses of $900 million, upwards of Rs 6,000 crore. Somebody will have to justify how a marketplace, which is a technology platform, is making huge losses when technology is already available with them. The loss is more than their total revenue in the fifth or seventh year of operation. Clearly, there is an element of pricing control or predatory pricing. Something is not looking right.Both are equally important. My exporters are not getting a fair opportunity to be able to export. For example, steel is not getting open access in Japan and Korea, whereas Japanese and Korean steel are coming into the country. Export and import go hand in hand. I believe in reciprocal trade. If some country creates non-tariff barrier or creates a problem for my exports, then I will have to reciprocate. The message is very clear, wherever there is fair trade, we welcome it and we accept that with open arms. But unfair trade practices will not be accepted.Nobody has expressed any concern except some of our Indian companies. In Davos also I will be saying the same thing as I am telling you. There are thousands of companies, they are all good companies, they are all contributing to India’s GDP and creating jobs in India. But they are doing it within the ambit of law. If anybody wants to come into India and break the law, certainly it’s my job to take care of India’s interests.

Title: Maximum temperature of 18.6 degrees C keeps Agra cold
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Agra: Cold winds swept across Agra on Sunday with maximum temperature at 18.6 degrees Celsius, 4 degrees below normal. A moderate fog engulfed the city in the morning. A mild sunshine spread some warmth in the afternoon.

The minimum temperature which was recorded 9.4 degrees Celsius, which was 0.3 degree Celsius less than Saturday.

Besides Agra, Firozabad, Mathura, Etah, Aligarh and Mainpuri also recorded low temperatures. . In Aligarh, the maximum temperature was recorded at 18 degrees Celsius, one degree below normal. Minimum temperature remained at 9 degrees Celsius in Aligarh.

According to the MET department, Agra region is likely to witness moderate fog with cloudy sky till January 23. Mild sunshine in afternoons is predicted. Mercury level is expected to dip by a degree or two on the minimum scale. Maximum temperature is likely to remain around 18 degrees Celsius.

To help street people keep warm, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) has installed gas heaters at various places and is operating them in evenings. Besides, people lit up bonfires at different places.

Meanwhile, Sunday’s air quality index (AQI) in Agra was recorded in ‘moderate’ category at 183. According to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), particulate matter 2.5 remained the prominent pollutant. AQI in ‘moderate’ category may cause discomfort to the people with respiratory and heart problems.

Title: NPR a procedural stage for NRC, says apex court lawyer
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Agra: Supreme Court lawyer Nizamuddin Pasha on Sunday said that the National Population Register (NPR) is nothing more than a procedural stage in the National Register of Citizens (NRC) for establishment of citizenship.

While delivering a lecture on CAA/NRC/NPR in AMU campus to educate its faculty members about the new law, he addressed the queries raised by AMU teachers and cleared their doubts. Pasha said that answer to the question whether it is constitutional or not can be decided only at the end when everything is done.

Explaining the Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA), Pasha said if non-Muslims from countries like Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan have arrived in India before December 31, 2014, they will be provided fast-track citizenship. This means that the person will just have to prove his/her presence by showing documents like electricity bill or telephone bill that establish their stay in India before December 31, 2014.

On the other hand, in Assam, people will have to prove that their ancestors were present in India prior to March 24, 1971. He said this highlighted lack of equality in treatment.

Organised by Aligarh Muslim University Teachers Association (AMUTA), the lecture was attended by a large number of teachers and the non-teaching staff. The varsity students and faculty rejected the CAA/NRC/NPR by dubbing it as ‘unconstitutional’ and demanded the government to withdraw the Act.

Title: Bengaluru: Man enters flat through window, tries to rape child
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: An unidentified man who entered the second-floor flat of an apartment on Haralur Road in Bellandur through an open window , allegedly attempted to sexually assault a nine-year-old girl who was asleep. He fled after the child raised an alarm in the early hours of Saturday.

Bellandur police launched a manhunt for the accused.

According to police sources, the incident took place at 4.30am when the man entered the flat through the window. After entering the room where the girl was asleep, he opened the wardrobes and eventually slept next to the girl. He tried to undress her at which point she woke up and screamed for help.

The child’s parents sleeping in the next room rushed to her help, but the man jumped out of the window and took to his heels. The girl was in a state of shock and consoled by her parents. Around 10.30am, her father filed a police complaint.

Cops said they registered case under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act, 2012 and have CCTV footage from the Bellandur apartment.

Police said though the room was ransacked, no valuables were missing from the cupboards. They suspect the intruder might have been familiar with the apartment.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Mahadayi dispute: Will Amit Shah’s word resolve issue?
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Amit Shah

BENGALURU: The government is hopeful the vexatious Mahadayi river water dispute with Goa, another BJP-ruled state, would be resolved during the budget session of Parliament commencing on January 31. The Supreme Court is also scheduled to begin hearing on the case the same day.

The hope stems from Union home minister and BJP national president Amit Shah meeting farmers of the river basin during his visit to Hubballi on Saturday. “The meeting assumes significance as it comes at a time when the Centre is seen to be favouring Goa for political reasons,” said Lokanath Hebsur, president of Mahadayi Kalasa-Banduri Horata Okkuta Kendra Samithi. “Shah’s meeting has definitely raised hopes.”

The Mahadayi tribunal had awarded 13.4tmcft water to Karnataka and had allowed the state to divert 5.5tmcft of it to the Malaprabha reservoir through Kalasa and Banduri canals. The state intends to use it to supply drinking water to Belagavi, Bagalkot, Dharwad and Gadag districts in North Karnataka . However, the award cannot be implemented until the Centre issues a gazette notification. The issue has been hanging fire for years now.

The state government hopes the Centre will get the Inter-State River Water Dispute (Amendment) Bill, 2019, passed in the Rajya Sabha during the budget session. This will automatically resolve several river water disputes, including the Mahadayi imbroglio, as it will remove the Centre’s role in implementing awards of tribunals. The bill has already been passed in the Lok Sabha.

“The bill could not be taken up in the winter session for various reasons. We will try to get approval of the upper house in the budget session,” said parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi.

Meanwhile, proceedings on the matter in the SC will also be keenly watched. While Karnataka has appealed for an additional 23tmcft of water, the state has also filed an interlocutory application seeking the court’s direction to the Centre to issue a gazette notification of the Mahadayi tribunal award.

“Issuing a gazette notification has nothing to do with the pending court case. Most of the work has been completed and the project can be implemented without delay,” said Lakshman Rao Peshwe, secretary to irrigation department. He said the government has already sent multiple reminders to the Centre on this. While civil work of Kalasa canal is almost completed, the government has to take up work of Banduri canal.

Meanwhile, advocate general Prabhuling K Navadagi has convened a meeting of lawyers and officials on January 27 in New Delhi to prepare for the court case. A senior lawyer said the priority is to get the court’s nod for gazette notification of the tribunal award.

Title: Madurai hospital opens department for fetal medicine
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: Meenakshi Mission Hospital and Research Centre (MMHRC) on Sunday opened a department exclusively for fetal medicine , with an aim to to provide special and comprehensive care to fetuses by specialists, including obstetricians and geneticists.

“Providing comprehensive care for high-risk pregnancy and supportive neonatal intensive care is the primary objective,” said Dr S Padma, head of department of Fetal Medicine. For diagnosis, advanced high-resolution ultrasonography, an ultrasound-based imaging technique, will be used to pick up structural defects, neurological defects and cardiac defects.

“We go for specialized tests and care for the fetuses identified as high risk. We also give competent counselling for mothers carrying fetuses with the potential for genetic disorders and malformations. This helps mothers to understand and to make informed decisions on the medical options,” said Dr T Mukuntharajan, HOD, interventional Radiology.

The facility will be useful for couples opting for Assisted Reproductive Technology (ART)-based fertility treatments. “These days more and more couples are going for it. ART can increase the cases of triplets (three babies), and quadruplets (four babies). These multiple pregnancies have a very high chance of getting aborted. For a better pregnancy outcome well-equipped tertiary care centres are important,” said Dr S Gurushankar, Chairman, MMHRC. Following the inaugural event, the hospital also organized a one-day Continuing Medical Education (CME) program on foetal medicine, in association with Indian Medical Association, Madurai. CME attracted about 100 doctors from South Tamil Nadu .

Title: Painted stork caught in ‘manja’ rescued, set free
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The bird was released in its natural habitat after its wounds healed well

AGRA: A painted stork which was caught in a deadly kite ‘manja’ (thread) for several hours here was rescued by Wildlife SOS Rapid Rescue Unit. The right wing of the bird was injured and after medical treatment, it was set free . The painted stork has been classified as “near threatened” by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) Red list of Threatened species. It is found across large marshes of the sub-continent. Human-induced factors have led to the decline in their natural habitats and hence their intrusion into inhabitated areas by man. According to Wildlife SOS members, they received a call on Friday on their helpline number about a wounded painted stork that had fallen into a restaurant courtyard. The stork had been circling above when a kite ‘manja’ cut through its wing. The bird was found by the restaurant owner, who immediately contacted Wildlife SOS for assistance. Two rescuers from the NGO rushed the spot and on examining the bird, found severe injuries on its wing. Shivam Sharma, owner of restaurant, said, “Kids were flying kites in the neighbourhood and we saw the bird flying straight into a ‘manja’. It fell right into our courtyard and a closer look at the bird revealed that its wing was bleeding.” Dr Ilayaraja, deputy director of veterinary services, Wildlife SOS, said, “There were multiple abrasions on the stork’s wing and the damage caused severe blood loss. As it was raining, we exercised extra caution to prevent infection of the wounds. Laser therapy with minimal handling helped to hasten the healing process. The bird was released in its natural habitat after its wounds healed well.” According to NGO members, recently the Government of India has banned the production, storage and use of Chinese manja, making these actions punishable under the Environmental Protection Act, 1986, because of the threat it poses to birds.

Title: Lakhs of children benefit from pulse polio vaccination drive
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Madurai: More than eight lakh children from Madurai, Dindigul, Theni, Virudhunagar, and Ramanathapuram districts were vaccinated for polio during the state-wide pulse polio immunisation drive held on Sunday.

Thousands of people queued up with their children below the age of five at primary health centres (PHCs), government hospitals and other special booths that were set up for this purpose. The respective collectors inaugurated the vaccination drives at one of the PHCs in their districts.

“We received good response this year, reaching out to more children than the target set. It could be because we reached a lot of migrant population who were here because of Pongal holidays and those visiting temples. We had teams covering high-risk areas as well with special care,” said Dr Priya Raj, deputy director of health services, Madurai.

Health workers, anganwadi workers, nursing students, social workers, and NGO volunteers administered the vaccines. Many transit and mobile teams were also arranged by the health department across districts to reach those at markets, temples, railway stations, toll gates, bus stations, refugee camps and slums.

Theekshna R, a resident of Vilakkuthoon took her 40-day-old child for polio vaccination. “We wanted to wait till next time as it would be difficult to carry the baby and wait in a queue. But, our doctor insisted on getting the vaccination done. Thankfully, when I went in the afternoon there was no crowd,” she said.

Title: BJP minority cell members resign
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nashik: The minority cell members of the Bhartiya Janata Party ( BJP ) has allegedly resigned with allegations of the party not listening to the community views over the passage of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and other related issues.

Imran Chaudhary, the regional vice president of the minority cell said they tried to bring to the notice of the party multiple times about the community was feeling alienated by the BJP in the backdrop of the CAA, National Registration Certificate (NRC) issues.

He along with the vice president Vajiullah has sent their resignations to Ejaz Deshmukh, the state unit president of the cell. “I have tried to put the message across the party and the leadership asking them to reconsider the demands and the feelings of the people of the community who feel the action by the central government was the anti-Muslim and less about the country on the whole,” he said.

He said the abrogation of Article 370 from Jammu And Kashmir and the division of the state was objected by the community. “The act making triple talaq a criminal act was seen as interference in the Muslim religion, the CAA excluded the Muslims from the neighbouring countries and the NRC were being seen steps towards isolation of the community,” he further said.

Attempting to justify his claim, Chaudhary said the abrogation of Article 370 from Jammu And Kashmir and the division of the state was objected to by the community, the act making triple talaq criminal act was seen as interference in the Muslim religion, the CAA excluded the Muslims from the neighbouring countries and the NRC were being seen steps towards isolation of the community.

Title: Battling odds, polio survivor braces for Class X exams
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Polio survivor C Arulperunjothi (R) with his father

MADURAI: Even as the state-wide pulse polio vaccination drive was in full swing on Sunday, a student from a corporation school in Madurai became a grim reminder of how polio can hamper lives and family.

Polio survivor Arulperunjothi C is a Class X student at the Elango Corporation Higher Secondary School in Madurai and is all set to write the board exams this year. “My wife and I had our son nearly 20 years after our marriage. We were not well educated. One day our boy seemed to lose the ability to walk. We went to a doctor but he said our child will soon learn to walk. But, it didn’t get better,” recalled Chinnakaruppuviru C, Arul’s father.

By the time the family found out about Arul’s condition, doctors told them that their son may start losing his speaking ability as well. “I had to take him to a hostel when he was in Class IV. We don’t even have ration cards to avail benefits. Finally, I managed to buy a television set for Rs 2,000 and made my son watch Ramayana and Mahabharata to learn Tamil. I taught him Thirukkural and I noticed that he was responding well,” said Chinnakaruppuviru. Though there is no cure for polio, Arul is exercising his legs as much as he can and was taught to do daily chores by his father. His father also encouraged him to improve his speech and learning ability.

However, Chinnakaruppuviru was unable to get proper treatment for his son as they could not afford it.

“I went to several doctors. While some said that my boy would gradually be able to recover by himself, others said that he would need to stop schooling. He was in Class VIII at that time. Stopping education was impossible. I could not study properly but at least my son should. I tried my best to keep him motivated to do any work be it at home or school,” he said.

Arul says that his favourite subjects are Tamil, science and social science. “I’m trying my best. I have support from my teachers and friends. I can draw well too though I’m not really that interested. I hope to study well to pass the exams,” he said, carefully stressing each word and adding a nervous laugh at the end.

Title: Calangute civic body not to hike taxes due to tourism slump
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

SALIGAO/CALANGUTE: Given the slump in tourism this year, Calangute panchayat has decided not to increase any fees or taxes .

Kundan Kerkar, a Calangute villager, said at the gram sabha on Sunday that the panchayat needs to study the reasons for the drop in tourism in the otherwise popular coastal village.

“People have invested all their money in tourism businesses, and if tourism here crashes then we will all suffer,” he said.

Usually, every year trade licences, house tax, garbage tax and other taxes are increased by 10%.

Calangute sarpanch Francis Rodrigues said, “The tourist season has been bad for the last two years, and bowing to the sentiments of the people, for the last two years the panchayat has not increased taxes. If we had to increase taxes by 10% last year and another 10% this year, it would have amounted to a 20% jump. This would have been an additional burden on the people.”

Garbage management and pimps harassing visitors were some of the other issues that dominated Calangute’s first gram sabha meeting of the new year.

The budget proposals for Calangute amounting to Rs 26.5 crore led to a few queries, with gram sabha member Anthony D’souza demanding to know where the scrap material which is collected along with garbage and other waste is sold, and how much income is generated from it, as used to happen in previous years.

Rodrigues said all the scrap is also sent to the garbage treatment plant at Saligao and not sold. Panch Shawn Martins clarified that earlier the panchayat had its own sorting place so the scrap was sold, adding that following directions from the National Green Tribunal, the panchayat is in the process of setting up a material recovery facility in Calangute.

Villagers also complimented the panchayat for taking giant strides in clearing garbage and maintaining cleanliness, but said some dark spots are still being used to dump garbage. Rodrigues said they clear all the dark spots daily despite which people keep dumping garbage at some places, and added though they have placed the spots under CCTV surveillance, it is not possible to eliminate it completely.

The meeting which started at 11am concluded by 11.30am causing consternation among a section of the members over the short duration. In the past, gram sabhas would witness heated exchanges and even go on all day, winding up in the night.

Title: Site identified for centre for excellence for jasmine
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Madurai: The site for the Rs 5 crore centre for excellence for jasmine, has been identified in Thiruparankundram in Madurai district.

The Tamil Nadu government had given the nod for establishing the centre in Madurai two years ago. However, finalising the site delayed the process.

The centre is to be established with 40% funding from the state and another 60% from the central government. As soon as the Tamil Nadu government allocated Rs 2 crore for the project, officials in Madurai got into the process of identifying a suitable place for setting it up.

Initially, it was decided to set up the centre in Poonchuthi near Melur but it was opposed by some people who went to court and stalled it. Efforts to establish it on an eight-acre site near Paravai also did not prove fruitful.

Deputy director of horticulture, Madurai G O Bhoopathy said that a five-acre site had been identified on the Thiruparankundram - Avaniapuram Road and the work would begin soon.

Centres for excellence for different flowers and vegetables would aim at developing facilities which would help the farmers reap the benefits of their cultivation without having to depend on middlemen.

Farmers would also be trained in techniques of cultivation and marketing. The centre would also help students have hands-on training.

Title: Adds 3,000 CCTVs, AI, 90 days’ storage await govt nod since a yr
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: To make the Safe and Smart City Project more effective, the Smart City special purpose vehicle — Nagpur Smart and Sustainable City Development Corporation Limited (NSSCDCL) — had proposed installation of an additional 3,000 CCTVs, artificial intelligence (AI) and extension of footage storage capacity to 90 days. The proposal is pending with the state government since one year despite the need for the technological infrastructure which is crucial to control law and order and traffic violations as well.

“Projects proposed in the interest of the city, especially the ones related to security, will be given top priority. Plans pending with the government will be verified and cleared as soon as possible,” said Maharashtra minister Nitin Raut.

Mayor Sandip Joshi said he would also take up the issue with the government. “I will talk to NSSCDCL chairman Praveen Pardeshi and the BMC commissioner. Leader of opposition Devendra Fadnavis had approved the project during his tenure as chief minister. I will discuss the proposed works with Fadnavis and approach the government by taking his help. The issue needs to be taken up seriously,” he said.

Fadnavis had approved Rs520 crore for the project. L & T was awarded the project on October 18, 2016 for operation and maintenance for five years. Around 3,700 CCTVs were installed at 660 junctions across the city. All CCTVs are connected with the optical fibre network of 1,200km range.

NSSCDCL developed City Operation and Centre at the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) head office where feed from all CCTVs can be seen simultaneously. It came to the notice of NMC, NSSCDCL and police that some more junctions, T-points situated between major squares also need to be covered under CCTV surveillance. Accordingly, a survey was conducted and the need arose to install an additional 3,000 CCTVs at 500 junctions. The cost for the implementation of this plan is pegged at Rs150 crore.

With the help of CCTVs, traffic police started trapping violators. But the hurdle is personnel having to to sit in City Operation Centre to identify them. The traffic police requested NSSCDCL to install AI so that traffic violations can be automatically detected and notice served to violators. The NSSCDCL, too, proposed this plan.

A huge quantum of feed comes from 3,700 CCTVs. The feed is proving to be beneficial in detecting crimes and identifying criminals. But the storage of footage is limited to just 15 days. Police and NMC suggested an increase in the storage capacity. Accordingly, NSSCDCL proposed to increase the storage capacity to 90 days. These installations are likely to cost around Rs50 crore.

NSSCDCL had submitted the proposals with the directorate of information technology (DIT) which is nodal agency for the Safe and Smart City Project. The government needs to make provision for funds to enable DIT to clear the plans.

Even smalls towns like Kamptee, Butibori and Hingna which are situated on the outskirts of the city are covered under the project.

Under the same project, the police is being provided five drones and mobile surveillance vehicles to maintain law and order during rallies, mass gatherings, winter session of the state assembly, riots and natural disasters.

Title: With 726 dengue cases, Goa sees three-fold rise in 2019
Content:
Representative image

PANAJI: In 2019, Goa registered 726 dengue cases. The number was highest in a decade. There was a steady rise in cases since 2017, but the number saw three-fold increase in 2019.Health department authorities say the exceptional rise in cases in 2019 was due to a spurt in other parts of the country. They feel that the scene in 2020 will not be as bad as last year if precautionary measures are taken ahead of monsoon.“We had more cases last year as there was high incidence of dengue across the country,” said Dr Anant Palekar, in-charge of national vector control programme in Goa.“It is not right to assume that we will have more dengue cases this year as well,” he said, adding, “with proper precautions, spread of dengue virus can be controlled”. Palekar said that post-November 2019, there were a few cases.“There has been sporadic prevalence, mostly in Vasco. We get one or two cases of dengue a week,” he said.Majority of dengue cases, including a death incident, occurred during monsoon. Quite a few cases were also detected in some upmarket areas of Panaji.Dengue mosquitos were found breeding in houses where people keep flower pots. In areas where there is no regular water supply, dengue mosquitoes breed.“We advise people to cover up water storage tanks, especially in those areas where there is irregular water supply and clean those once a week,” he said.Besides, improper disposal of waste can also be a source of dengue spread. “Used plastic cups, coconut shells or items that can hold water could be a source for dengue mosquito breeding. People must keep their surroundings clean,” he said.

Title: Rajasthan budget session from January 24, motion against Act on cards
Content:
Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR: The state government will bring a resolution against the Citizenship Amendment Act in the budget session of the assembly beginning on January 24.Parliamentary affairs minister Shanti Dhariwal on Sunday said, “The session is beginning on Friday because a bill to extend reservation to SC and ST candidates in Lok Sabha and state assemblies for another 10 years has to be ratified before January 25.”He said the government was also considering introducing a resolution against the CAA during the session.“The Congress is against CAA and hence a resolution is likely to be introduced in the assembly,” he said. During the session, the government will also approve giving a 10-year extension to reservations for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in the state assembly. The resolution could be introduced on the very first day of the session, said a source. The government may also bring bills pertaining to right to health and food adulteration amendment bill.CM Ashok Gehlot had earlier said the state would not implement CAA and NRC.The BJP, meanwhile, alleged that the session was convened in a hurry and the government's move to bring the resolution would be opposed. “We will oppose any such move of the government,” BJP state president Satish Poonia said.A committee has been formed under ACS Subodh Agarwal for preparing the keynote address of the governor.

Title: Madurai: Man held for ‘false’ Facebook post on slain SSI Y Wilson
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Kanyakumari district police on Sunday arrested Navas Shahul for projecting slain special sub-inspector (SSI) Y Wilson as responsible for the prime accused Abdul Sameem becoming a terrorist.

Wilson was shot and stabbed to death while he was on duty at the Kaliyakkavilai check post in the inter-state boundary of Kanyakumari district on January 8.

Shahul, a native of Thengapattanam coastal town identifies himself as the state coordinator of the minority unit of the Tamil Nadu Congress Committee on his Facebook page. On January 14, the day Sameem and his accomplice Thoufiq were arrested at the Udupi railway station in Karnataka, Shahul had a series of posts on his Facebook page.

In one of the posts, he said that Sameem of Thiruvithancode was good in studies. Several years ago, when he was chatting with his friends on the banks of the Amaravathi river, a police team led by Wilson, who was then serving at the Thuckalay police station spotted them and framed them on the charge of attempting to bomb the RSS office.

The Facebook post added that the boys were booked for their extremist act of conspiring the bombing, harassed them by taking them to several places and finally lodged them in jail. “Framed as a terrorist, he (Abdul Sameem) made friends with terrorists in the jail and became a terrorist,” the post added. His other posts also directly targeted Wilson and wanted the police to probe the angle of personal enmity between Sameem and Wilson.

Shahul was booked under Section 505(2) (statements creating or promoting enmity, hatred or ill-will between classes) of the Indian Penal Code (IPS) and under Section 67 (punishment for publishing or transmitting obscene material in electronic form) of the Information Technology Act by the Puthukadai police, based on a complaint from sub-inspector Elango.

He was arrested at the Thengapattanam bus stand around 5.30am on Sunday when he was waiting to board a bus. “He came from Thiruvananthapuram to meet his parents residing at Thengapattanam and was waiting for a bus when we arrested him,” Puthukadai inspector R Rajeshwari said. He was produced before a Kuzhithurai magistrate and remanded in judicial custody.

“He was booked and arrested for spreading false information,” superintendent of police (SP) of Kanyakumari district N Shreenath said.

On Monday, Sameem and Thoufiq will be produced before the Kuzhithurai judicial magistrate, when the plea by the police seeking custody of the duo for inquiry will be heard.

Title: 46-year-old man gored to death during bull race
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

A bull tamer is embracing a charging bull in an effort to tame it in Alanganallur jallikattu event

SIVAGANGA: A 46-year-old man from M Kovilpatti village near Tirupattur was gored to death by a bull during the Kandipatti manjuvirattu that took place in Sivaganga district on Sunday.

The victim has been identified as C Vijayaragunathan, who was working in Kancheepuram. He had come to his native village to celebrate Pongal. According to the local police, he had come to watch the proceedings of manjuvirattu organized by St Antony Church on the sidelines of the five-day Pongal festival on Sunday. One of the unregistered bulls, which ran through the crowd gored him. The bull’s horn pierced through his neck and came out the other side, killing him on the spot.

The body was shifted to Sivaganga medical college hospital, where a postmortem was conducted. Around 70 people suffered injuries and were taken to various hospitals. Most of the people, who suffered injuries, were spectators.

While 151 registered bulls were let out during the event, more than 500 bulls were let loose by owners amid the huge crowd that had gathered from various neighbouring districts.

According to police sources, a bull, which was let loose in the majuvirattu, died in a train accident. The bull, which was brought from Panaiyapatti village ran amok ended up being hit by a train bound to Mannargudi near the majuvirattu ring.

A large number of police personnel were deployed for security purposes.

Title: Goa Police book minister’s brother in ex-Merces sarpanch suicide case
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: Old Goa police on Sunday filed an FIR against Wilson Godinho, brother of panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho, for abetment of suicide in the death of former Merces sarpanch Prakash Naik. The police also booked one Tahir.

Both names were mentioned in a complaint lodged by the Naik family on Saturday night. “We filed the FIR under Section 306 (abetment of suicide) of the IPC, and investigation is in progress,” police said.

Outside the Old Goa police station on Sunday, Prakash’s brother Vinay told reporters that if Wilson is not called to the police station, other ministers’ relatives may also get involved in heinous crimes. He, however, said that the family would accept the body and conduct the final rites on Monday.

Naik, a serving Merces panch member, allegedly shot himself on Friday minutes after posting a message to a 200-member WhatsApp group that he was “under tremendous pressure” from two persons over a property matter that he could not handle.

The deceased had contested assembly elections in 2017 on the state’s oldest regional party MGP.

On Saturday, the Naik family said that they would not accept the body till the two named by him in the message were arrested. They also demanded that the case be moved from the Old Goa police to crime branch.

“Both the persons (named by Naik in his message) used to demand Rs 45 lakh from him, but we don’t know why,” a family member told reporters. “We do not believe that he committed suicide.”

Family members alleged that CCTV cameras at Naik’s residence had stopped functioning from January 15. They said that on Friday, the maid had noticed that the back door of his house was open. They claimed that his body was found covered with a sheet and that the gun was inside the sheet and his hand was on his chest.

An autopsy was conducted by a panel of doctors at GMC on Saturday. Police said the cause of death was “craniocerebral damage as a result of perforating firearm missile injury that was antemortem and fresh at time of death”. Naik’s body has been preserved at the GMC morgue.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Man on a green mission plants 2,500 trees in six years
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ukkrapandi (sitting third from right) at a sapling planting drive

MADURAI: V Ukkrapandi, 45, from Thankkankulam village on the city outskirts has planted and nurtured 2,500 trees in the last six years. He was 39 years old when he started planting trees in and around his village by organizing teams of students and youngsters.

Ukkrapandi, who runs a jewellery pawn shop, does not just plant saplings and leave them. For him, it is important to tend to every single sapling planted until the stage where it can survive on its own.

“I plant saplings, which are at least eight-foot-high and are produced in my own nursery. I spend a few hours in the mornings and evenings to tend the saplings and water them,” he said.

He said that he even chooses tree varieties according to the location. Neem for roadside, peepal and banyan for empty spaces near temples, jamun trees in vacant lands and flowering trees near houses since there is a misconception that roots of bigger tree varieties will damage the property.

Initially, Ukkrapandi watered trees by carrying pots on cycle. On observing his dedication, a Lions Club came forward to buy him a light commercial vehicle. He used to plant saplings only once or twice in a year and spent the remaining time taking care of them. He also made sure to set aside 15% of his yearly income towards planting trees.

He has now taken up work to plant 10,000 trees on 70 acres’ land in Kappalur Sidco industrial estate along with activists, industrialists, government officials and locals and has already planted 400 saplings in 6.5 acres so far.

Meanwhile, a private company employee, G Manivannan, 33, from Kalainagar in Madurai , if focusing on increasing green cover in rural areas. He has mobilized a group of people from Vandapuli village to start a movement called ‘Vanathukkul Vandapuli’ and has planted more than 150 trees in a few villages.

He along with green activists C P Ravi and Durai Vijayapandian have now launched ‘Olirum Madurai’, an organization to promote green cover and to help students in need of financial support to continue education.

“We three had successfully convinced authorities from the district rural development agency to provide manpower from MNREGA to plant and maintain trees in Miyawaki method. As a result, three Miyawaki forests have been created in the last three months,” said Manivannan.

Title: Kerala to reclaim land allotted for Coast Guard Academy
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: The state government is all set to take back the 148 acres of land that it had handed over to the Centre to construct Coast Guard Academy at Azheekkal in Kannur.

According to sources in the industries department, the state has sent a communication to the Centre seeking the status of the project and whether it is going ahead with the project. “The Centre had informed the Parliament that it is not going ahead with the project, but the state government has not received any communication in this regard. We need a formal communication from the Centre for which we have written to the Centre seeking the status of the project. Once we receive that, we will go ahead with taking back the land,” sources associated with the office of industries minister said.

Union minister of state for defence Shripad Naik had informed Rajya Sabha MP Elamaram Kareem in December that the project has been dropped following denial of coastal regulation zone clearance from the ministry of environment, forest and climate change. The ministry had denied the clearance as the proposed site for the project at Azheekkal fell within the CRZ- 1(A) area, where construction is not permitted.

The land

Meanwhile, Elamaram Kareem said that the BJP government’s policies and the former UDF government’s lackadaisical approach resulted in the state losing the project. “The project was sanctioned when the LDF government was in power in the state, by the then defence minister A K Antony. It was sanctioned after an expert panel of the defence team visited the site and reported that the land is most suitable for the project. There is no logic in citing CRZ rules in this regard as the Coast Guard Academy cannot be set up away from the sea. But the subsequent UDF government failed to take the project forward even when the UPA was in power at the Centre till 2014. The new NDA government has decided not to proceed with the project, seemingly due to political reasons,” Kareem said, who was also the industries minister in the state when the project was sanctioned.

In a similar manner, the Centre had decided to scrap the proposed rail coach factory at Kanjikode in Palakkad that was announced in the 2008 railway budget. The state government had acquired 239 acres of land for the project and in 2012, the then railways minister Dinesh Trivedi had also laid the foundation stone for the project.

Though the project is unlikely to come up, the land is still with the railways. The state government is exploring possibilities of setting up a coach factory in collaboration with global giants in the sector, as coaches for metro rail, semi-high speed rail, etc will be in demand in the coming years.

Title: Forest department to form panel to inspect Guruvayur tuskers
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

‘Valiyakesvan’ (in pic) and ‘Guruvayoor Padmanabhan’ have been restricted from taking part in temple functions

(By: Sandeep Thomas)

THRISSUR: Forty-five days after imposing restrictions on ‘ Guruvayur Padmanabhan ’ and ‘Valiyakesvan’, the two elephants of Guruvayur devaswom, the forest department has finally decided to constitute an expert committee to inspect the health conditions of the elephants. The department had on December 7 imposed restrictions on these elephants over participation in any functions due to age and health-related issues.

M N Jayachandran, a member of Kerala state animal welfare board, filed a complaint before the Thrissur assistant forest conservator stating that Valiyakesavan was suffering from tuberculosis and abscesses and 80-year-old Padmanabhan had foot rot. Following the complaint, the forest department had restricted the temple authorities from using the elephants during functions.

Thrissur assistant conservator P M Prabhu said, “After imposing restrictions we requested the district animal husbandry department officials to inspect the elephants. However, they said higher authorities from veterinary university will inspect them. Then we approached the veterinary university authorities, who said they are only referral agency to inspect the reports. Hence, I submitted a report to chief wildlife warden to constitute a special team to inspect the elephants.”

Chief wildlife warden Surendrakumar told TOI, “We will constitute an expert committee on Monday and the team will inspect the elephants soon.”

Speaking to TOI, Guruvayur devaswam deputy administrator Saisidaran said, “There are no health issues in these two elephants. An expert team in the Guruvayoor devaswom has already inspected the elephants and said they are healthy.”

Meanwhile, collector S Shanavas said he didn’t get any complaints from Guruvayur devaswom. “ I think there is no issue in using the elephants during rituals inside the Guruvayur Temple . When the devaswom officials submit a complaint I will take further action,” he said.

Title: Chaos and delays as Inner Ring Road toll plazas witness heavy rush
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Toll plazas on the national highway at Chittampatti and Kappalur witnesses about 20,000 and 30,000 vehicles re... Read More

MADURAI: Toll gates within and outside the city, which usually sees a heavy rush during the week, witnessed a worsened situation on Sunday, as many people began leaving after a long festival holiday. Many travellers had to wait for not less than 15 minutes at each of the three toll gates situated on the Inner Ring Road before leaving the city, especially with Fastags not working there as the gates come under the state highways, which are yet to be covered under the system.

To add to the woes of the vehicle users, the rude behaviour by the staff in all three gates results in arguments between them and the drivers. There are a very few police personnel posted in all these places.

A vehicle going from K K Nagar towards the airport can obtain a two-way pass for Rs 30 including the two toll gates at Vandiyur and Chinthamani. “When I entered the Inner Ring Road through the Ramnad Road, the toll gate employee at Chinthamani refused to give me a two-way ticket. This shows that these three toll gates were set up without proper planning,” said K Selvakumar of K K Nagar.

While disputes at the toll gates on the Inner Ring Road are a regular affair, it became worse this weekend when Chennai-bound vehicles from other districts resulted in even longer queues. “We left Tuticorin at 5am so that we could reach Chennai early, but were inordinately delayed at these toll gates,” said Ramkumar of Chennai.

Due to the queues, private buses, which ply on a time basis, violated the norms and entered the free lanes on the opposite side of the road before the toll gates, to beat the rush, making it extremely dangerous for upcoming vehicles on those roads. “Even the police at the toll gates seem to worry only about the ticketing and not violation by buses. They should be fined heavily,” said S V Pathy of Gomathypuram. He added that the Inner Ring Road has become a bane causing only delays, rather than speeding up a journey, for which it was actually meant for.

Meanwhile, toll plazas on the national highway at Chittampatti and Kappalur, which witnesses about 20,000 and 30,000 vehicles respectively crossing over daily, witnessed long queues during the long festival weekend in their cash-only lanes, while the Fastag lanes wore a deserted look.

A toll plaza manager said that they found that only about 30% of the vehicles were Fastag-enabled, one of the reasons for the piling up of traffic.

Title: Decision on AIADMK alliance for assembly election to be taken later, says minister
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

MADURAI: AIADMK ’s alliance with other parties which was formed last year for the Lok Sabha election, has continued for the rural local body elections, and will continue for the urban local body elections too, state information and publicity minister Kadambur C Raju has said.

However, a decision on forging an alliance for next year’s assembly elections would be taken by the party’s general body, executive committee and headquarters later, Raju said while talking to reporters in Tuticorin after kickstarting a pulse polio vaccination drive on Sunday.

Raju also came down heavily on Congress leader and Trichy MP Su Thirunavukkarasar for his remarks criticising AIADMK mouthpiece ‘Namadhu Puratchi Thalaivi Amma’. Reacting to a statement by fisheries minister D Jayakumar’s remark that knowledge will grow if one reads the AIADMK party organ, Thirunavukkarasar countered it by saying that those who read it would be destroyed. To this, Raju said that Thirunavukkarasar is a politician lacking clarity on where he belongs to, and only he can match himself in jumping so many parties in Tamil Nadu .

Title: Amar, Akbar and Anthony govt will break down soon: Danve
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nashik: Union Ministry of State Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution, MP Raosaheb Danve has taken a dig at the state government by referring them as “Amar, Akbar and Anthony” and “will break down at any moment”.

He further challenged the government to bring in more efficient and vibrant schemes for the welfare of the public instead of the closing down the earlier ones intended to help the people in the long run. “The current state government in Maharashtra is not a stable government. Amar, Akbar and Anthony have joined hands to form the government and they lack consensus on issues. I am confident this government will ‘break’ down any moment,” Danve said.

The former BJP state president said that the government had applied brakes on various projects by his BJP-led state government during the last five years. “Applying brakes on the public-oriented schemes by the earlier government is not a good idea as they will bear fruits after some time. The state government should in fact bring out bigger and better schemes to match the work done by the earlier government,” Danve said.

Meanwhile in Jalna, Arjun Khotkar from Shiv Sena, the competitor of Raosaheb Danve, during a public rally said that it was a mistake that he did not contest the Lok Sabha elections (in May 2019). As Shiv Sena and BJP were allies while contesting the parliamentary elections and Khotkar had to withdraw to allow Danve to contest elections.

When Danve was asked for his reaction on the same, he said, “Khotkar has not leveled any allegations against me. Whatever he said there has reference to the audience only.”

Danve said that the government wanted to the diver the attention of the masses from its failure on multiple fronts. Irrelevant issues like raising the height of the statue of Dr B.R Ambedkar, Shiv Sena leaders asking the family descendants to prove the same etc are the claims behind it.

“Such kinds of issues are raised only when the government does not want the people to focus on the important issues of the governance. The current government is unable to perform because their ideologies do not match,” he said.

Title: Rajasthan government allocates Rs 31 crore for locust-hit farmers in four districts
Content:
Over 3.6 lakh hectares hit by locusts in western Rajasthan

A woman with her family beating the utensils to scare away the locusts

A woman with her family beating the utensils to scare away the locusts

Farmers burning nad creating smoke to keep away the locusts

JAIPUR: After central ministers accused chief minister Ashok Gehlot of not providing financial assistance to locust-hit farmers , the state government completed assessment of crop damage in Jaisalmer , Barmer, Jalore and Jodhpur and allocated Rs 31 crore to farmers under the state disaster relief fund (SDRF).Out of the 10 locust-hit districts, damage assessment report was still awaited from Bikaner , Sirohi, Churu, Sriganganagar, Hanumangarh and Nagaur.Union jal shakti minister Gajendra Singh Shekhawat had criticised that state government for not conducting any assessment of the damaged crops since the attack began in May 2019. He asked officials to carry out a survey in three days.Similarly, minister for state for agriculture Kailesh Choudhary directed the state to provide relief to the affected farmers during a visit to locust-hit areas.“As per the crop damage report, the amount calculated for distribution to farmers is Rs 31 crore,” said an official.The number of beneficiary farmers and surveyed net cropped area have not been disclosed. In some cases, the officials have received submission of 100% damage of wheat, mustard and cumin seeds. Jaisalmer, Barmer and Bikaner were the worst affected till January 7. Officials said a fresh swarm had hit Sriganganagar, which is a fertile area. Locust menace, which was first reported on May 23, is still continuing, making it one of the longest attacks in the country.

Title: Prisoners in T get paid less, officials cite better facilities
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: When it comes to paying convicts for their work in jails, Telangana prisons are among the top three well-paying prisons in the country.

However, when it comes to those who are semi-skilled or unskilled, the payments are not on a par with many other prisons in the country, even though the convicts have put Telangana on top of the list in terms of value of sales. A convict is paid for whatever work he/she does in the jail.

According to the prison statistics for the country, in Telangana prisons, a skilled worker is paid Rs 170 per day. However, a semi-skilled worker gets only Rs 50 and an unskilled worker earns Rs 30.

Prisons officials said that some of the prisoners in the state may not be getting paid as much as prisoners in some of the other jails in the country because the facilities that are provided to them in the jails of Telangana are far better than what’s provided to prisoners in other prisons of the country.

“Not only do we have modern prisons with good amenities in Telangana, we also provide prisoners with proper food and clothing,” IG prisons B Saidaiah said.

The money that prisoners earn is deposited in the bank accounts that are opened for them.

The accumulated earnings can be withdrawn at the time of their release. Some amount is also given to the prisoners themselves in the form of tokens for them to buy what they want to from the jail canteen.

Title: India’s youngest, oldest sarpanchs are from Rajasthan
Content:
Asruni Khan

Vidya Devi

JAIPUR: Rajasthan has earned the distinction of having the youngest and the oldest sarpanchs in the country.While Bharatpur’s Asruni Khan (21 years and 18 days) is arguably the youngest sarpanch, Vidya Devi (97 years), who was elected from Puranabas gram panchayat in Sikar a couple of days ago, is the country’s oldest village head.Asruni, who won from Chulhera gram panchayat under Deeg panchayat samiti in Bharatpur, trounced her nearest rival Najma by a slim margin of 31 votes. While Khan polled 686 votes, Najma managed 655. The seat was reserved for OBC women.Vidya Devi had beat her rival Aarti Meena by a margin of 207 votes. Himachal Pradesh’s Jabna Chauhan, who became the village head at the age of 22 in 2016, was the youngest earlier. Also, prior to this, 94-year-old Gangubai Nivrutti Bhambure from Pune’s Bhamburwadi village was the oldest sarpanch.“The roads are in very bad condition in our village. There is no electricity or water as well. I want to work for the development of my village,” said Asruni, who has never had any formal education. She got married in December 2017.Asruni’s father-in-law, Ajim Khan, said, “There is a hospital in our village, but there are no doctors. There are no roads as well. She will work towards solving these problems.”Apart from her, there are two other sarpanches who are also aged 21 years.Rajshekhar Fouzdar (21 years 5 months) became the sarpanch from Iklahra gram panchayat under Deeg panchayat samiti in Bharatpur. He defeated Ravina, from an OBC seat, by a margin of 844 votes.“My father (Lakhan Singh Fouzdar), who passed away in 2016, had become sarpanch four times. He has been my inspiration in contesting the elections. There is a problem of water supply in my gram panchayat. My primary objective will be to solve this problem. I would also want to crack down on corruption in panchayat bodies,” Fouzdar told TOI. He studied up to Class XII.Kiran Rao (21 years and 11 months) is also one of the youngest sarpanches from Rajasthan, having won the election from Nadana Bhatan gram panchayat under Rani panchayat samiti in Pali by a margin of 300 votes.Rao (686 votes) defeated Soni Devi (368 votes) from a seat which is reserved for OBC category (women). She is pursuing MA in history from SPU College, Falna, Pali under Jai Narain Vyas University.“I am also preparing for RAS examination. My father (Shravan Singh), who is a BJP member, had inspired me to contest the panchayat elections. I feel the youth are politically and socially aware and hence, should actively participate in electoral politics,” Rao added.

Title: Revaluation: Class X, XII students to get fee refund if board at fault
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PANAJI: A Class X or XII student, who applies for re-evaluation of marks, will be eligible for a full refund of the reevaluation fees, if the students ’ marks change due to errors on the part of the examiner, Goa Board of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education has told schools. In case of discrepancies in marks caused by errors by the examiner by ‘not transferring marks, leaving question unassessed and by making mistakes in totaling marks’, the student will be eligible for 100% refund.

The board charges Rs 700 per subject as reevaluation fees. While the Class XII board exams are set to begin on February 26, the Class X public exam will be held from April 2 onwards.

Ahead of the exam, the board issued instructions to the heads of high schools and higher secondary schools giving clarifications on various processes related to the exam. “No refund is permitted after the re-evaluation is carried out irrespective of change in the marks/result, except, if change is due to discrepancies like transferring of marks, unassessed question and totaling mistake of marks (100% refund), 50% deduction for any other discrepancy,” the board told schools.

The board has said that if after the re-evaluation of marks, there is a wide variation observed in the original and re-evaluated marks by 10% or more, a second opinion from the reviewer will be sought. In this case, the scores allotted by the examiner, the re-evaluator and the reviewer will be compared. The average of the higher two of three scores will be considered.

“If the candidate is declared passed in the examination after the re-evaluation and had simultaneously applied for re-exam, the exam fee will be refunded after deduction of 50% as processing fees,” the board said.

The board has also said that students will not be provided photocopies of the re-evaluated answersheets under any circumstances.

Title: Nashik: Citizens to pay for smart parking from February 1
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Citizens will have to pay for 22 on-road and off-road smart parking spaces from February 1

NASHIK: Citizens will have to pay for 22 on-road and off-road smart parking spaces from February 1. Earlier, the smart city officials had decided to start pay and parking from November 1; however, they had to postpone the plan for a month owing to technical problems. At present, the smart parking spaces are operational on trial basis and citizens were allowed park their vehicles in these spaces free of cost since July 1. However, the situation is going to change from February 1 as these free parking spaces will be chargeable. Smart city officials said they have proposed commercial operations from February 1 and the proposal will be tabled in the board meeting scheduled for next week. There will be total 4,500 slots for two-wheeler and four-wheeler parking at these 22 spaces. The parking charges will be Rs 10 per hour for four-wheelers and Rs 5 per hour for two-wheelers. “Moreover, we also have a different proposal, under which parking at these said spot will be provided free for the first 30 minutes and then charged thereafter. The proposal was drafted following a huge demand from citizens who said that they often parked their vehicles on roadside for a few minutes due to some work. And, despite parking only for a few minutes, they will have to pay the charges, which according to some, is an unfair deal. However, nothing has been finalised so far. The issue is to be discussed at board meeting of Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL),” said sources from the smart city. “We had also put marking on these parking spaces. However, the markings at some spots have disappeared. We will immediately start working on the marking lines again,” added the sources from smart city. The Mumbai-based private company, Trigyn Technologies Pvt Ltd, won the bid for setting up total 33 smart parking spaces — 28 on-street and 5 off-street parking — across the city. Of these 33, 22 have been made operational. A special app — Nashik Smart Parking — has been developed to help riders check the online status of parking spaces and availability of parking slots. Motorists can even make pre-bookings of the parking lots online through the mobile app which can be downloaded from the Google Play store. Earlier, the charges for four-wheeler parking were Rs 30 per hour and Rs 15 per hour for two-wheelers. But, after public demand, the parking charges have been slashed at large. Now, the parking charges for four-wheelers would be Rs 10 per hour and Rs 5 for two-wheelers.

Title: Kerala: Missing teacher’s body found on beach
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

KASARAGOD: The body of a school teacher who went missing on Thursday was found on the Koyippady beach near Kumbla in Kasaragod district on Saturday.

B K Roopasree, 44, of Chigirpadav in Miyapadav near Manjeshwar was working as a teacher in SVHSS. According to police, she had attended a wedding of her colleague’s relative after school hours on Thursday. She had later visited her daughter’s school in Manjeshwar. But, when she failed to return home, her family members filed a missing complaint. Later, police found her scooter abandoned at Durgipallam near Hosangadi, however, she could not be traced. On Saturday, some fishermen spotted a body on the beach and informed police who called Roopasree’s relatives for identification. They identified her with the help of her wedding ring but suspected a foul play in her death. They said a colleague was troubling her and demanded a thorough investigation. Roopasree is survived by husband Chandrasekharan, and two daughters.

Title: CS, DGP review facilities for jatara
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Medaram (Mulugu): Chief secretary Somesh Kumar and Director General of Police (DGP) M Mahender Reddy inspected arrangements for the upcoming Sammakka Saralamma Jatara here on Sunday. The chief secretary directed officials to focus on traffic management.

Officials were also told to ensure that all roads leading to Medaram are in good shape. “Arterial junctions leading to the jatara must be geo-tagged,” he said. The CS also directed officials to wind up all civic works in two days and stressed the need for installing floodlights and signboards at all parking spaces.

“We will monitor the ground situation through teleconference every day,” Somesh Kumar said.— Shiva Kumar Pinna

Title: Painter rapes 11-yr-old in Parigi
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Hyderabad: A minor girl was allegedly raped by a 26-year-old painter at Parigi in Vikarabad district on Saturday night.

Around 9.30pm, the 26-year-old accused saw the girl standing alone near her housein Parigi. “The 11-year-old is a neighbour of the accused. He saw the girl was standing alone near the house and asked her to accompany him to a nearby grocery store,” Parigi inspector Y Mogilaiah said.

The girl, a class VI student accompanied the painter and he took her towards an isolated open ground behind their houses. “Behind the bushes in the open ground, the accused raped the girl. After the assault, her warned her not to tell anyone about the incident and let her go home,” the inspector said.

The girl, who suffered a bleeding injury in the assault, went home crying and informed her family members about the rape. The family members along with the neighbours caught hold of the accused near his house, thrashed him and handed him over to police.

“We have sent the girl for medical examination on Saturday night. Based on the complaint lodged by the victim’s family members, a case was registered under Section 376 (Rape) of the IPC, SC&ST (Prevention of Atrocities) Act and the POCSO Act,” the inspector said. tnn

Title: Financial dependence made them silent victims
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Malappuram: The Child Welfare Committee (CWC) authorities have said that financial insecurity was one of the major factors that led to the sexual abuse of four minor girls by their father near Valanchery.

Preliminary probe conducted by CWC and district child protection unit have found that since the accused was the sole breadwinner of the family, his wife and five children, including a 19-year-old youth, were unable to oppose the 47-year-old man’s sexual atrocity.

Valanchery police arrested the man on Saturday for abusing his four daughters aged 17, 15, 13 and 10. The children are sheltered in a child care institute (CCI). The incident came to light when the younger girl revealed the abuse to school authorities.

CWC chairman Shajesh Bhaskar said the family was reeling under financial crisis and the family members had no other way than depending on the accused. “The mother and children had to suppress many things as they would be in trouble if the person had left them,” he said.

“The accused was a headload worker and he was physically strong. The mother or children were unable to oppose any attempt of molestation from his part. He is also an alcoholic,” he said. TNN

Title: Four trains cancelled
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Secunderabad: Four trains in SCR zone were cancelled on Sunday due to poor patronisation and eight trains have been cancelled till the first week of February due to traffic blockade for commissioning of double line between Satulur and Perecherla stations. As per an official release by SCR, train no. 07192 from Secunderabad to Vijayawada was cancelled on Sunday and train no. 07193 from Vijayawada to Hyderabad, was scheduled for Monday, was cancelled. Trains from Kakinada town to Kotipalli Rail Bus and vice versa were cancelled on January 24 and April 23, respectively.

Accordingly, eight trains between four destinations of Kacheguda, Medchal, Guntur and Dhone were cancelled till February 5. Trains from Kazipet on February 2 were also cancelled to facilitate construction works at Nagpur station. Trains to Nanded from Hyderabad and Secunderabad division have also been affected as they were rescheduled for different timings on Monday. tnn

Title: Udaipur jail turns into ‘university’ for inmates
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Members of the jail’s music band during a performance

UDAIPUR: ‘Vasudev Kutumbakam - Hum ek hain, pyaare hain aur tumhare hain…’ when one hears 55-year-old Parmeshwar Bhai singing a self-composed Sufi song, tears well up in one’s eyes. Parmeshwar is a convict at Udaipur Central Jail but now he is an artist and wishes to remain one for the rest of his life.

Jarnail Singh, lovingly called Judge Bhai, is another singer of the jail band that specialises in Sufi and classical music. Both Parmeshwar and Judge Bhai are here in connection to biggest ever drug (mandrax) seizure case in India that was busted in November 2016.

The jail band members have been appreciated widely during their performances on several occasions, some even outside the prison. Now, they are excited to participate in the World Music Festival that will be held here next month. Looking at their enthusiasm, the jail administration has funded and purchased latest musical equipment worth Rs 90,000.

The central jail is not just a prison anymore. It is transforming into a learning place, a ‘jail university’, is what the teachers and learners here call it. An innovation in rehabilitation prison practice is being developed in Udaipur. The Swaraj Jail University was launched here in October 2018 by Shikshantar, Art of Living, Gandhi Ashram-Moved by Love, Edible Routes Foundation and Navgurukul in partnership with the Udaipur Central Jail.

This jail university has a computer and a music academy that run daily. Inmates learn web designing, sound mixing, graphic making here. Several inmates participate in daily yoga and mindfulness sessions. Based on the learning interests of the inmates, they have been participating in workshops related to photography, charcoal illustration, storytelling, basic counselling and listening circles and permaculture design-organic farming. There is also a team of inmates who are developing an organic farm and permaculture demo-centre in the jail with experts’ guidance. One can find keyhole garden, compost pits, banana circles, food forest here.

“I joined here in June 2018, after the project began, I’ve been witnessing a lot of positivity, repentance in the attitude of many inmates. Some 125 inmates are engaged in various projects. Most of them are more calm and composed than what they were earlier,” claims jail superintendent Surinder Singh Shekhawat.

Against the capacity of 950 inmates, Udaipur jail houses 1,450 prisoners. Some 125 prisoners have been involved in the first phase of project.

Indira Talreja, yoga trainer from Art of Living, has been tirelessly engaging with inmates in the jail for the past 12 years and sharing the transformative power of yoga and mindfulness with them. “We started the project with the purpose of prototyping a self-designed learning programme in the jail. The purpose is to help inmates explore their passion, gain practical skills, and re-ignite self-esteem and life vision in the face of the numerous challenges of incarcerated life. The inmates are invited to design their own personalised learning programmes based on their interests and needs. Everyone is a teacher and a learner here,” says Manish Jain, co-founder of Shikshantar.

Title: Nashik Municipal Corporation puts updates propery tax register on display
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nashik Municipal Corporation

NASHIK: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has made all the necessary entries of the existing properties on its property tax register — including the area and property tax levied.

Accordingly, the details of the properties in the current financial year (2019-20) have been carried forward in the new property tax register for 2020-21.

This property register has been put on display in all six divisional offices of the civic body. The civic body has invited objections from the property owners if they have by Monday evening. NMC will make rectification in the register if there are any valid objections raised by the property owners.

NMC has issued a public notice in this connection, urging property owners to check the information in the property register for the next financial year. “There are over 4 lakh properties within the limits of the municipal corporation. We have carried forward the details of the properties — area, use purpose, the tax levied and other details — in the property register for the next fiscal 2020-21. We have invited objections from the property owners by the evening of February 20. The objections we receive thereafter will not be considered,” said an NMC official.

There are new properties that got property tax bills for the first time during the current and last financial years. Owners of these properties will also have an opportunity to raise objections, if any, said the NMC.

NMC has set a property tax collection target of Rs 218 crore for the current financial year 2019-20. It has already collected Rs 120 crore so far. The property tax department of the NMC has introduced the amnesty scheme for tax defaulters, which is in effect upto February 10.

The NMC recovers a 2% fine per month on tax dues from the last day of paying taxes. Moreover, it also recovers expenses of notices and warrants issued to the defaulters. Under the amnesty scheme, tax defaulters who pay their entire dues in one go are given a rebate in penalty amount, warrant and notice fees. NMC has plans to auction off properties of other tax defaulters in the second half of February, said officials.

NMC give 1% concession to those who pay property taxes online. Moreover, concession in property tax of up to 5% is given to prompt property taxpayers who pay the tax in the first quarter of the financial year.

Title: State reels under intense cold spell
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Jaipur: Rajasthan continues to reel under intense cold conditions. The minimum temperature in Jaipur on Sunday was 10°C, 0.4°C more than the previous day. The Met department said the minimum temperature will remain the same in the city for the next two days.

“Intense fog like situation is expected at Shekhawat area and Barmer division. The low pressure over the Himalayas will cause a change in temperature in Northern Rajasthan,” said weathermen. Sikar with 2.5°C was the coldest in the state followed by Pilani at 4.5°C.

The intense cold waves impacted traffic at several places in the city. The intense weather has also dampened the mood of the morning walkers as majority of them preferred to remain indoors. City markets also closed down early. The vegetable market on Tonk Road which remains open till 10pm in summers shut down by sunset.

“Trains coming from North India arrived late by 30 minutes. Passengers are requested to board trains after checking the status,” said a railway official.

Title: Kerala: BJP names presidents for all districts, except four
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: BJP central leadership has announced a list of all but four district presidents of the party in Kerala. The districts for which presidents have not been announced are Kottayam , Ernakulam, Kannur and Kasaragod.

In Thiruvananthapuram, V V Rajesh , party state committee member and close confidant of Union minister V Muraleedharan, replaces the incumbent S Suresh.

Other district presidents are B B Gopakumar (Kollam), Asokan Kulanada (Pathanamthitta), M V Gopakumar (Alappuzha), K S Aji (Idukki), K K Aneesh Kumar (Thrissur), E Krishnadas (Palakkad), Ravi Thelathu (Malappuram), V K Sajeevan (Kozhikode) and Saji Sankar (Wayanad). Among these, Pathanamthitta, Palakkad and Wayanad district presidents got a second term in office.

According to sources, BJP was forced to reserve the list of four district presidents following hectic parleys by Muraleedharan and P K Krishnadas and also after intervention by RSS.
