The central leadership is yet to announce the new state president for the party. The delay for it is also attributed to factionalism as well as intervention by the RSS.

There were rumours in the party that Sadanandan Master whose legs were chopped off by CPM cadres in 1994 may be considered as a consensual candidate for the post of Kannur district president. He had unsuccessfully contested the Koothuparamba assembly constituency in last election.

Though party state general secretary K Surendran continues to be a frontrunner to the post of state president, state leadership of the RSS is yet to accept his candidature.

The party’s internal exercise was completed in 21 of the BJP’s 36 state and union territory units. The BJP constitution stipulates that its national president can be elected after hand of the total state units have coupled their organisatonal election exercise. The party national working president J P Nadda is all likely to occupy the party president post in a couple of days.

Title: Centre approves Rs 5 crore for repair of museum palace inside Sonar fort
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

JAISALMER: UNESCO world heritage site and the country’s only living fort — Sonar fort , has been facing continuous deterioration, while the state government and the ASI seem indifferent to its condition.

Meanwhile, To repair the museum palace , a proposal had been sent on behalf of former royals by the Jaisalmer Girdhar Smarak Trust to government of India’s art and culture ministry through the district collector, and the Centre has approved Rs 5 crore for it. After getting this amount, the condition of the palace of ex-royals would improve, but no big plan has been made to keep the Sonar fort safe.

Two years ago, a meeting was held at the Central level for conservation of Sonar fort, in which it was discussed to form an authority and in 2014, the site management plan was to be implemented. However, till date neither the authority has been formed nor the site management plan implemented, and the fort is continuously slipping into a bad shape. Museum palace, which is under the ownership of former royals, has also reached a dangerous condition, due to which tourists have stopped going to the rooftop as a preventive measure.

For quite some time now, there have been unchecked illegal constructions at the Sonar fort and commercial activities are taking place by tampering its original structure, due to which the 861-year-old fort is continuously getting deteriorated. Due to seepage of water, the stones are getting weak and are leaving their place and some of the stones are turning into sand due to the water seepage.

The new sewerage line that was laid by RUIDP was also not laid properly. Due to lack of proper monitoring by experts, there are mistakes in laying the line and its water is making the fort's foundation hollow. With the deteriorating condition of the fort, accidents can take place any time. Two years ago, empower committee of the fort took many decisions but the ASI, municipal council and other agencies failed to implement them. There is encroachment in the fort. Site management plan was the main parameter of the UNESCO heritage site, but this plan was submitted to ASI in 2014 but has not been implemented.

District collector Namit Mehta said that ASI is the main agency for conservation and maintenance of the fort and the district administration has no interference in it. A proposal was received from ex-royals for some part of the palace slipping into bad shape and they sent the proposal to the government of India.

Art & Culture official source said that Rs 5 crore has been approved for it.

Title: MahaMetro seeks state help to clear hurdles in starting feeder services
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

A Metro official said its consultant Urban Mass Transit Company Limited (UMTC) had submitted a report ‘Multimo... Read More

Nagpur: Ridership of Nagpur Metro will not increase unless feeder services are available at stations. However, there are several problems in providing feeder services. MahaMetro has, therefore, urged state government to help it in this regard.

A Metro official said its consultant Urban Mass Transit Company Limited (UMTC) had submitted a report ‘Multimodal integration along Metro corridor in Nagpur’ to it. “This report has been forwarded to the government. UMTC has outlined how feeder services should be provided at Metro stations,” he added.

The official further said land is the biggest challenge in providing these services. “We can’t provide land for parking at every station. Limited funds are available with us for buying land. If we buy more than what is mentioned in the detailed project report (DPR), we will not have funds for construction work,” he added.

According to the official, Metro can provide parking for three to four autorickshaws at most stations. “As the ridership will increase, 15 to 20 autorickshaws will be required but we don’t have land for parking. Only government can make available the extra land,” he added.

“Many people would like to reach Metro stations using own vehicles. There should be enough space at each station for parking them. As per the DPR, parking is to be made available at only a few stations,” said the official.

The official further said parking slots will also be needed at some distance from stations. “For example, if a small parking space is made available inside a commercial area near a station, then people can hire e-scooters or e-bicycles from the station, travel using them and then park the e-bikes at the mini-parking slot. Such type of facilities are essential,” he added.

Meanwhile, the state government is yet to take a decision on Metro’s proposal to provide it land at nominal cost instead of at ready reckoner prices. “The cost of the land calculated while preparing the DPR was as per the ready reckoner value in effect at that time. Now, the prices have increased significantly. Secondly, we had to spend extra money on buying private land. The DPR calculates the cost equivalent to ready reckoner rates. However, as per law enacted in 2013, the acquiring agency has to pay 2.5 times the market price. Hence, if we don’t get government land at nominal price, we will face funds crunch,” the official said.

Title: KWA to take strict action against water misuse, theft
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Kozhikode: The anti-theft squad of Kerala Water Authority (KWA) started initiating severe action against those unauthorized to use water supplied by KWA for construction and other purposes. They have started disconnecting water supply permanently and imposing hefty fines.

KWA officials started the action based on the complaints that many KWA consumers have started using supplied drinking water to water the buildings under construction and for other purposes. The incidents of misuse of water have increased in many areas with the end of the monsoon.

Action will be initiated on receiving complaints or information from public, said a KWA official. “We are also planning to carry out random inspections to check misuse of water,” the official said.

KWA has decided to strengthen action against water theft and misuse as summer season is nearing. The department is planning to end different types of water misuse to avoid the wastage of water.

Water theft from water taps at public places and the misuse of household connections for carwash and other purposes will also be under scanner. The officials are taking immediate action and disconnecting water supply on receiving complaints.

On the other hand, some of KWA consumers are demanding proper inquiry into allegations regarding water theft and misuse before disconnecting supply. In some incidents, the officials disconnect the supply without verifying the complaint causing inconvenience to consumers, consumers pointed out.

“Water supply to my house was disconnected based on a false allegation raised by a neighbour,” said Sangeetha Prasad, a resident of Puthiyangadi. “We are now struggling to get the connection and such situation should not be created,” she said.

KWA officials have also asked the squads to check for leakage of water. Water leakage from breaking old pipes and explosion on the distribution line due to increased water pressure are also common.

According to KWA officials, water theft and related issues can be curbed completely only with the support of people. “As KWA officials are unable to carry out inspection at every residential area we would be able to speed up action if the residents extend their support,” the official said.

Title: Students should stay away from social media ahead of exams
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

With exams round the corner, divisional secretary of Maharashtra State Secondary and Higher Secondary Education Office, Nashik division, Nitin Upasani tells TOI’s Pragya Jain about the tips and tricks students should keep in mind to keep exam stress at bay. Excerpts:

What steps are you taking to relieve students of examination stress?

We had brought in two programmes last year— copy free campaign and fearless examination campaign— to relieve students of examination stress. We prepared a module and trained our officials to talk to the students in all the schools of the division. The seminars and discussions were conducted at the divisional, district and block levels. We explained to the students that if they copy during exams, they will be less confident in their future prospects.

The unsuccessful students tend to attempt suicide at a young age. How do you tackle this proble m?

Last year, the fearless examination campaign was a real success. We called the teachers, students and parents to make them understand that securing high marks in examinations was not the ultimate goal in life. A student has to develop all-round character that will help him in every phase of his life. Thankfully, we do not have a single report of any student attempting suicide in 2019.

What measures should a student take so as not to be debarred from exams?

We have given directions to the teachers to ensure students use the extra time to read the instructions on the answer sheet before writing their papers. Many students have the tendency of writing pleas to the examiners asking for good marks. Some students tear the page of the answer sheet if they make any mistake. They should not tear the pages, instead ask the invigilator to sign on the sheet or replace the answer booklet. We have asked the headmasters of all the schools to talk to Class X students once a week and and tell them about the repercussions of doing anything that is prohibited during the exams. Girl students suffer the most as they are asked to work on the farms or get married if debarred. Last year, 900 students were debarred for writing unnecessary details on their answer booklets, like revealing their identity, threatening to commit suicide or tearing the pages of the answer booklets. We have held many awareness sessions this year.

How do you ensure effective counselling in the schools?

A teacher is the best counsellor for the students. By December-end, all teachers complete their syllabus. Thereafter, they have ample time to have one-on-one discussions with every student. The teachers are trained for counselling while getting their qualification degree and are the best judge of their students. We also keep formulating modules frequently to help teachers understand the psychology of students.

What is it that you think is affecting students’ studies most these days?

I would ask the parents to ensure that their wards stay away from social media. Because of social media, students get distracted and distance themselves from family values. Instead of investing time on social media, students should play in the grounds, go to the library and discuss about their personal matters with their friends and family.

Title: Two lakh tonne waste to be bio-mined in Ajmer to free 27 acre
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

AJMER: More than 2 lakh metric tonne waste will be bio-mined for the first time in Ajmer , so that 27 acre of land can be recovered at Makhupura, which is the dumping ground of the city at present.

The bio-mining project will be in public-private partnership mode, which will remove tonnes of garbage and cost Rs 14 crore.

Commissioner of AMC Chinmayee Gopal said that at present, the Ajmer Municipal Corporation is generating 250 tonne waste per day from 60 wards of the city. This includes residential areas, markets and urban slums and after collecting the garbage, it is dumped at Makhupura, on Nasirabad Road about 10km from the city, with an area of 318 acre. This dumping ground is in use since 1997 and before that, the garbage was dumped between Zanana Hospital and MDS University Road.

The report said that the Makhupura dumping ground is located on a hilly region and therefore, the surface is uneven with small hills and also valleys and therefore waste is dumped in haphazard manner and many large garbage piles have been formed, which can be seen from the main road. The Ajmer Smart City Ltd has prepared contour and topology maps to know the actual quantity of the waste. It was found to be about 3,60,542 cubic metre of solid waste.

The waste disposed at Makhupura is un-segregated and no treatment or processing of this waste is possible. It has been overly exposed to the elements over the years and natural decomposition has occurred. The present material has very low organic content as per the survey conducted in last December and the total waste dumped at Makhupura ground is 2,20,000 metric tonne and the physio-chemical analysis of the waste has also been done.

Therefore in one year, the whole quantity and its disposal will be done in a scientific manner as per the CPCB solid management rules in total 27.23 acre of land and will be reclaimed by bio-mining.

Title: Sing-On Group singers cast a joyous spell
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Singers of Sing-On Group cast a joyous spell on the audience who had gathered to witness the musical programme ‘Geetmala’ at Utkarsh Hall in Mor Hindi Bhavan, Sitabuldi, on Saturday. Sing-On organized the two-day musical programme titled ‘Ameen Sayani’s Geetmala’ to celebrate the journey of famous radio programme ‘Binaca Geetmala’.

On the first of day of the two-day programme, 26 Bollywood singles and duets were presented by 17 singers. In between the romantic and fun songs Mahesh Lalwani kept audience engaged with amazing mimicry of various Bollywood stars.

The musical evening started with the song ‘Ye zindagi usi ki hai' presented by A Meera Sharma. It was followed by a hit number from movie ‘Taxi Driver’ ‘Jaayen toh jaayen kahan’ by Yuvraj Choudhary. ‘Mera joota hai Japani’ from ‘Shri 420’ was sung by Sanjay Uttarwar, after which a duet ‘Aye dil hai mushkil' sung by Rupali Roy and Uttarwar, won the heart of the gathering.

Another duet ‘Zara saamne toh aao’ by Thosar couple — Madhusudan and Sudarshana — mesmerized . It was followed by Shrikrishna Patil’s fine presentation ‘Hai apna dil toh awara’. Thereafter, Mangesh Pawar and Ashiwini Bhave’s peppy duet ‘Hal kaisa hai janab ka’ evoked foot-tapping response from the attendees.

Single ‘Zindagi bhar na bhulegi’ by Choudhary and ‘Teri pyari pyari surat ko’ by MV Pardhe was well-received by the gathering.

Other hit songs like ‘Ehsaan tera hoga mujh par’, ‘Mere mann ki Ganga’, ‘Jis dil mein basa tha pyar’, ‘Baharon phool barsao’, ‘Dil vil pyar vyar’, ‘Bindiya chamkegi’, ‘Zindagi ek safar hai suhana’, ‘Yaari hai imaan mera’, ‘Kabhi kabhi mere dil mein’ were presented by Sunil Wadhwani, Patil, Raj Gwalani, Kishor Ganvir and Mahesh Lalwani.

Thereafter, duets like ‘Jo vada kiya woh’ by Choudhary and Sharma, ‘Sawan ka mahina’ by Uttarwar and Roy, ‘Dum maro dum’ by Mahesh and Bhawana Lalwani caught the attention of the audience. Towards the end ‘Baki kuch bacha toh mehangai’ was performed by multiple singers like Mahesh Lalwani, Sharma, Raj Lalwani and Jafar Bhai.

The first day’s musical journey ended with the song ‘Akhiyon ke jharokhon se’ performed by Anjali Wankhede. The musical event was anchored by Mahesh Lalwani and conceptualized by A Meera Sharma.

Title: 4,000 brave morning chill at Kidathon
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Off the block: The 3rd RCNV Kidathon event was organized by Rotary Club of Nagpur Vision for the children in t... Read More

Nagpur: Braving early morning chill in overcast conditions, around 4,000 children came out triumphs in the 3rd RCNV Kidathon held at Tirpude College ground, Civil Lines, on Sunday.

The event was held in two age categories 8-11 and 12-15. Chief guest and mayor Sandip Joshi flagged off the 6km 12-15 year group race after which guest of honour and ace mountaineer Bimla Negi Deosar flagged off the 4km 8-11 year group. Both groups commenced their run simultaneously after the formal flag off.

The flagship event of Rotary Club of Nagpur Vision (RCNV) was aimed at inculcating healthy lifestyle among the kids. Children from many schools of the city participated in the fun walk that was held in two categories. Among the participants were the students from Deaf and Dumb Residential School of Saoner who wholeheartedly participated in the programme.

Safety was the first priority of the organizers who had done a thorough recee of the route and deputed enough volunteers all through the path to look after the proceedings. At every 1km water stations were erected to quench the thirst of the young participants.

Besides the main sponsors ABC Cakes and Kingsway Hospitals, Kidathon 2020 was also supported by Tirpude Institute of Management Education, ICAD, Orange City Runners, Radio City, The Achievers School, UCN, Rotary Vision Society, Sunder Biscuits, Treat Ice Cream and Haldiram’s.

Along with the fun walk, various other activities were held simultaneously for parents and children that included free health check-up camp arranged by Kingsway Hospitals. ‘Dance 2 Fitness’ group kept the children engaged with Zumba.

Along with participation certificates and medals, goody bags that included savouries, sweets, coupons from various organizations and more, were given to children as a token of appreciation.

The club’s motto ‘Service above self’ was clearly evident in the manner in which RCNV meticulously conducted the event which is fast-gaining popularity just not in city but entire region.

(Reporting by Janhavi Dave)

Title: Planning a baby? 5 signs you are definitely fertile
Content: If you are planning to add a little member to your family, it is important that you understand how exactly ovulation works. Ovulation is just another normal function of our body and it occurs when the egg also known as an ovum, oocyte, or female gamete is released from the ovary. If your periods usually last around 28 days, you will be ovulating 14 days after the beginning of your menstruation cycle.It is important to remember that the ovulation phase of the menstrual cycle depends from woman to woman. However, unlike the tell-tale cramping, bloating and mood swings of PMS (premenstrual syndrome), the symptoms of ovulation aren’t that easy spot. So, if you are trying to get pregnant, here are five signs that signify that you are fertile:If you do not pay enough attention to your cervical mucus, it is important that you start keeping track of it. When you are ovulating, the discharge tends to become more watery, stretchy and begins to resemble the texture of an egg white. According to a lot of experts, the difference in cervical mucous is pretty noticeable and you may be able to stretch the fluid an inch or more between your fingers. To check for the texture of the discharge, use your clean fingers to examine the discharge down there.Some women tend to feel mild pain when the egg is released from the ovaries. It is also known as mittelschmerz (middle pain in German) and can be used to plan when to have sex if you are trying to get pregnant. While some women may experience little to no pain, others may experience a sharp twinge in their lower abdomen.Do you suddenly feel like getting hot and heavy with your partner? You can certainly blame an increased level of testosterone for the sudden desire to get it on. So, if you feel that your libido is on an all-time high, there is a huge chance that you are ovulating.If your body feels a little warmer than usual, with no obvious signs of a fever and flu, it is a sign that your body is ovulating. So, you can track your body temperature first thing in the morning after waking up to check your basal body temperature. When you begin ovulating, your basal body temperature starts increasing.If you experience a little bit of bleeding (spotting) in the middle of your menstrual cycle, it is probably your ovary releasing an egg. It is important to remember that not every woman experience spotting during ovulation. Spotting is a very light vaginal bleeding which usually lasts a day or two when you are ovulating.

Title: ‘Taal Utsav’ gives a musical treat to audience
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Nagpur: Music lovers enjoyed the musical treat at the inaugural function of the two-day programme titled ‘Sangeet Prabhakar Taal Utsav’, at Scientific Society Hall, Laxmi Nagar, on Saturday.

It was jointly organized by SCZCC and Taal Sadhana Samooh Sanstha. The music festival was a dedication to the prominent classical vocalist Pt Prabhakar Deshkar, Pt Prabhakar Khardenavis and tabla player Pt Prabhakar Desai.

The event was inaugurated by Mohan Parkhi, C Joshi, Raju Gujjar, Shyam Deshkar and Mangala Desai. The invocatory melody ‘Karu ya naman shardela’ by Madhuri Parsodkar, Janvi and Archana gave a perfect start to the event. Rajani Hudda, the anchor, gave an insight into the background of the classical musicians for whom the event was dedicated.

The first session of the evening was ‘Swar Jhankar’, a classical music fusion. Vocalist Aditya Sawarkar was accompanied by Ravi Satfale on the tabla, Pramod Deshmukh on the flute, Shrikant Pise on the keyboard, Nandu Gohane on the drum set and Nishikant Deshmukh on the violin. Solo performances by all the instrumentalists converged on a dynamic note when Sawarkar rendered ‘Main aau tore mandarava’.

The composition was presented in raag Madhuvanti, taal Addha and tarana Trital. The highlight of the evening was a jugalbandi between Satfale on the tabla and Gohane on the drum set. Both the musicians created a mood of complete euphoria and harmony as their performance was seamlessly beautiful and evocative. This session concluded with the melody ‘Yaad piya ki aaye’.

It was followed with a mesmerizing performance by Vivek Navre, from Khairagarh, on the sarod. He was accompanied by Harshal Thanekar on the tabla. With rhythm and melody at its core, their performance was a confluence of two streams of music in raag Bihag and madhya Trital.

The second day of the function presented three sessions of ‘Taal arpan’ by Ved Dhok, Atharva Shesh, Bhavesh Chavhan and Atharva Tekade, classical singing by Pt Keshav Talegaonkar from Agra and his students and tabla performance by Pt Nayan Ghosh and Ishan Ghosh from Mumbai.

Title: Cops claim new liquor policy a deterrent to drunk driving
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The restrictions on the sale of liquor and reduction of the number of liquor shops as part of the new liquor policy seems to be having an impact as the number of cases of drunk driving is witnessing a gradual decrease. Police are of the opinion that the number of cases will go down further if there is stricter enforcement.

Over 34,470 motorists were booked for driving under the influence of alcohol in 2018. In 2019, the number of cases came down to 30,500.

Traffic police officials say that this is the first time that there has been a decrease in the number of people driving under the influence in a year. The number of such cases was increasing every year over the last decade, according to a traffic cop.

Speaking to TOI, city police commissioner RK Meena said that the police regularly produce offenders in front of the courts and the courts have sentenced 1,540 people to jail terms.

A total of 1,160 motorists were convicted and had to serve jail terms, said the police chief while adding, “We have managed to instil fear among drivers and are hopeful that the number of drunken driving cases will come down further.”

Following the introduction of the new liquor policy, the consumption of liquor as well as drunk driving cases has gone down in the city, informed officials of the prohibition and excise department.

The state government’s new liquor policy has led to the number of liquor shops in the city to decrease from 401 to 313. Moreover, the liquor shops are being maintained by the Andhra Pradesh State Beverages Corporation Limited.

According to deputy excise commissioner, Vizag T Srinivasa Rao, the cases have come down because of the hike in liquor prices and also because the stores have to shut shop by 10pm.

Traffic cops said that they have observed that many are hiring cabs instead of driving under the influence.

“We are chalking out plans to conduct surprise visits in the morning, especially along Beach Road, Madhurawada and Gajuwaka,” a traffic police official said.

Title: Capital dreams: Three-layer transport plan in pipeline
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy having proposed Visakhapatnam as the executive capital , the state government is mulling a three-layer intra-city transport network for the Port City.

First, a metro rail stretch is supposed to come up through NH-16 connecting the steel plant located in the city’s outskirts to the proposed Bhogapuram Airport in the northern part. This metro line stretch will connect the city’s most significant and congested zones like Gajuwaka, NAD Junction, Madhurawada, Kommadi and Anandapuram.

The stretch, as per the plan, will have two triburaties: One from Gurudwara to Old Post Office and another from Tadichetlapalem to RK Beach.

Speaking to TOI, an official from the Amaravati Metro Rail Corporation (AMRC) said, “The proposed metro stretch in Visakhapatnam would be 80km long.”

Adding to this, the state government is planning to start three tram routes in less congested parts of the city. The proposed tram routes would connect Pendurthi to NAD Junction, Steel Plant to Anakapalli and Old Post Office to Bheemili. The three tram routes would have at least one crossover with one metro station.

“The total length of the three tram routes would be 60km. These would be battery-operated trams and would hence be environment-friendly,” added the official.

The third layer of transport network would comprise buses, auto-rickshaws and different types of cabs. “There are discussions about APSRTC considering procurement of eco-friendly electric buses which will be able to manoeuvre through the narrow city lanes,” a transport department official told TOI.

Officials believe that getting funds for both the projects will not be a major problem. The two-phased metro project is estimated to cost Rs 16,000 crore while the tram lines are estimated to cost between Rs 100 crore to Rs 120 crore per km. While the metro rail project is supposed to end by 2024, the tramline project is slated to come to life by 2029.

The AMRC official further informed that there is a proposal to rename ‘Amravati Metro Rail Corporation’ to ‘Andhra Pradesh Metro Rail Corporation’.

Title: Roundtable meet held on capital city proposal
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A section of activists and former bureaucrats organised a roundtable meeting in the city on Sunday wherein they welcomed the government’s proposal to shift the administrative capital from Amaravati to Visakhapatnam.

The meeting however concluded that the stated purpose of shifting the capital— that of decentralised development must be realised through this measure and the step should not create scope for land scams or other illegal activities.

Social activist and former civil servant EAS Sarma as well as former member of UPSC Prof KS Chalam spoke at the roundtable meet.

Sarma said that 40 per cent of Vizag ’s population lives in slums and the government should work towards developing their lives.

Prof Chalam said that the chief minister’s three-capital theory was proposed for decentralisation and the government should ensure that such decentralisation leads to all round development of the state.

Title: Over 97% get pulse polio drops
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: A total of 4,56,978 children was administered oral pulse polio drops in the district on Sunday out of a target of 4, 69,992 children, thereby achieving 97.23 % immunisation on the first day. A total of 3,786 vaccination booths have been set up and 15,144 vaccinators have been pressed into service, besides 379 supervisory staff.

District medical and health officer (DMHO) Dr S Tirupathi Rao said, “The remaining children will be vaccinated on January 20 and 21 during house-to-house visit by health workers in the rural areas and between January 20 to 22 in GVMC limits.”

On Sunday, tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao visited a pulse polio centre at Vidyutnagar and administered polio drops to children.

Title: Non-locals to sustain last leg of the tourist season
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With the tourist season in its final leg, sources in the tourism department expect that the number of non-local tourists will be more than local tourists this time.

According to sources in the department, this has always been the trend. Local tourist footfall comes down sharply after Sankranti, which marks the end of winter in these parts. Tourists from outside the state usually flock to the Agency during this last leg of the tourist season.

Sources informed TOI that the tourism department is expecting nearly 20 lakh tourists. Over 5,000 foreign tourists are also expected to visit the Agency area. The largest number of tourists come from West Bengal, said sources.

B Purnima Devi, district tourism officer said that this has always been the trend. “At the final leg, it is people from other states who sustain the footfall,” she said.

Title: Goyal suggests damages in case of delay in freight trains
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

NEW DELHI: Taking a cue from the IRCTC model of paying compensation for delays in its Tejas trains, railway minister Piyush Goyal urged the Dedicated Freight Corridor Corporation (DFCC) to give “a commitment of timely delivery”.

Speaking at the foundation day celebration of DFCC, the railway minister said, “Just like the Tejas trains have done in Delhi-Lucknow and Mumbai-Ahmedabad, we should be willing to give a commitment of timely delivery, penalise ourselves if we are delayed and insist on incentives if we do a good job. Let’s work on an incentive-penalty model even for our customers.”

Sources said this could be a possibility considering that there will be dedicated lines for freight trains once the eastern and western corridors of the DFC become operational by December 2021. The minister urged the DFCC management to ensure not a single additional day’s delay in commissioning of the two corridors beyond December 2021.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 2 held for gang rape of woman near Vellore Fort
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

Title: Pongal bird count: 3 rare migrants sighted in Tamil Nadu
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Siberian stonechat

CHENNAI: Siberian stonechat, black redstart and Isabelline wheatear are the three rare migrants sighted by birders during the four-day Pongal bird count that ended on Sunday.

K V Sudhakar, president of Madras Naturalists' Society, said recording of birds during Pongal holidays began in 2015 and this was the sixth year in which the bird count was completed. The data is fed to the site e-bird.org, he said.

Sudhakar said Siberian stonechat and Isabelline wheatear were sighted at Upparu in Tiruppur district. Siberian stonechat is a small bird resembling a house sparrow but can fly thousands of kilometres. It is found in Pakistan and migrates during winter. "This time the birds have come to peninsular India. These two birds were not recorded in the state in recent past," he said.

The black redstart is migrates from the Himalayas. This bird, also small in size, can easily cover thousands of kilometres. The redstart was sighted in Dharmapuri on Saturday, Sudhakar said.

Last year, 362 species of birds were sighted by birders. On an average, each participant spent more than seven hours in watching birds and recording them.

Title: Lack of sufficient parking facility at BRTS bus stops irks passengers
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

HUBBALLI: Among the most ambitious infrastructure initiatives in Karnataka , the Hubballi-Dharwad Bus Rapid Transit System (BRTS) has most certainly eased commute between the twin cities. The BRTS corridor, scheduled to be formally inaugurated by Vice-President Venkaiah Naidu on February 2, however is not without a few niggling issues, lack of adequate space for parking at the bus terminals being one of the major concerns.

In the case of Namma Metro in Bengaluru, many people who ride the train take their private vehicles to the station and leave it parked there and use them to return home. However, many Metro stations in Bengaluru do not provide sufficient space for parking, much to the chagrin of regular commuters. BRTS is facing a similar problem, with many passengers growing reluctant to take buses owing to the lack of provisions for parking at the terminals, which could lead to a decline in ridership.

Passengers are compelled to park their vehicles in front of houses along the corridor. There are also instances of people using the Chigari bus from the Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation (HDMC) stop parking their vehicles on the premises of the civic agency’s office or on the campus of the Chitaguppi Hospital. “This inconveniences people visiting the hospital and residents going to HDMC office,” said Bhairidevarkoppa resident Shivappa Mayakar.

Passengers boarding and disembarking the bus at the Unkal Cross stop face a similar problem. Passengers either leave their vehicles on the corridor’s bypass or in the open spaces in Muneshwar Nagar or roads leading to Timber Yard in Sainagar.

Provisions for parking have been made only at a few bus terminals along the corridor, which has as many as 32 stops. Sunaina Pattar, a private company employee, said that her brother dropped her at the Hosur Cross stop in the morning and picked her up again in the evening. Pointing out that although she was not greatly inconvenienced, Sunaina admitted to last-mile connectivity being an issue with BRTS. “BRTS was meant to increase the percentage of people using public transport but owing to many areas in the twin cities remaining off the circuit, the very purpose gets defeated,” said Sunaina.

Hubballi-Dharwad BRTS special officer Vivekanand Vishwajanya admitted to many stations along the corridor lacking sufficient parking space. “HDMC is presently scouting for land in the vicinity of the terminals, and we will ensure that this problem is fixed soon,” he added.

Title: BJP banners and flags nailed to trees irk residents
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

HUBBALLI: Residents of twin cities did not hold back in expressing their appreciation for Union minister for parliamentary affairs and Dharwad MP Pralhad Joshi after he slammed cops and other officials for felling trees at Nehru Stadium reportedly for Union home minister Amit Shah ’s rally. However, the citizens are now raging against workers and activists of the BJP for nailing buntings and flags to trees and damaging shrubs along several thoroughfares of the twin cities. The residents are also chafing at officials of the Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation (HDMC) and forest department for failing to act against BJP workers alleged to have damaged the trees.

Rajesh Inamdar, a Hubballi resident working in a private concern, has drawn the attention of officials of forest department to flags being nailed to shrubs on Gabbur Cross Main Road. “Regardless of whether it is the BJP, Congress or JD(S), political parties must take care not to damage the environment. I feel very bad to see our representatives killing trees, which sustain human life by producing oxygen,” Inamdar told TOI.

Lauding Joshi for criticising officials for the indiscriminate felling of trees, Inamdar said that senior members must educate workers and activists in the lower rungs of the party to be more eco-sensitive.

Social activist Deepak Shirolikar pointed out that both HDMC and the Regional Transport Office (RTO) had denied permission to hang banners and buntings on roads during the 2018 assembly elections, citing threat to safety of motorists. “But the officials in these agencies said nothing when BJP workers tied flags and buntings to trees and shrubs. Prime Minister Narendra Modi had affirmed his commitment to protect the environment, but his party workers appear not to be as concerned about the issue,” said Shirolikar.

Environmentalist Lingaraj Niduvani, meanwhile, pointed out that elected representatives of Dharwad, cutting across party lines, were sensitive about the environment. “However the workers at the grassroots are not as sensitive to the issues concerning the environment. This is the reason we find air and noise pollution levels soar when there are political rallies. Those at the top need to educate the workers about the environment,” he added.

Dr VB Nitali, also an environmentalist, said that trees must not be damaged for any cause or by any party.

‘Committed to protecting environment’

I thank the residents for bringing this issue to our notice. I think that this was a mistake not committed by our workers, but those the party had contracted to work for the rally. They were assigned the task of hanging banners and flags. But rest assured, we will ensure that even those workers hired on contract will not act in this manner henceforth. The BJP is committed to protecting the environment.

- Arvind Bellad | MLA and President, Hubballi-Dharwad BJP City Unit

Title: UAS, Dharwad selected for premier project, to get Rs 25 crore from World Bank
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

DHARWAD: Taking cognisance of the increasing number of graduates in agricultural sciences opting for jobs in seed and fertiliser companies, the Indian Council of Agriculture Research (ICAR) has decided to take action to arrest this trend. ICAR has chosen the University of Agricultural Sciences ( UAS ), Dharwad for the National Agriculture Higher Education Project (NAHEP) in order to cultivate a culture wherein more graduates opt to work closely with farmers besides helping them establish firms by themselves.

The National Institution Ranking Framework (NIRF) has recognised UAS, Dharwad as the seventh best varsity in the country, while the state’s committee for higher education has recognised the university as a five-start institution. These impeccable credentials have helped UAS get selected for NAHEP. Under the project, the varsity will receive funds to the tune of Rs 25 crore from the World Bank. The funds are to be utilised for devising entrepreneurship programmes. The deadline for this initiative is March 2021.

NAHEP is an initiative meant to familiarise UAS graduates with the nous of business and entrepreneurship, so that they can chart courses on their own.

UAS, Dharwad vice-chancellor Mahadev Chetti told TOI that as many as 120 students would be selected and sent abroad for a period of three months. “They will get hands-on experience working at agriculture firms,” said Chetti.

The VC said that, in addition to the students, 60 professors would also be a part of the project and travel abroad. “They will pay a visit to various universities abroad and return with knowledge on the latest advancements in agriculture, which will then be imparted to our students here,” added Prof Chetti, beaming at the prospect of UAS having chosen for the project.

Zero-budget farming

Furthermore, UAS, Dharwad has been sanctioned Rs 4.5 crore by the Karnataka government for implementing zero budget natural farming. Prof Chetti said that the varsity was presently in the process of etching out the modalities to carry out the project by experimenting with different crops, by comparing results produced through organic farming techniques and advanced methods.

Under the zero-budget farming project, 1,300 farmers from Haveri, Dharwad and Belagavi are being trained to implement what they learn at the varsity on their fields. The beneficiaries are being taken on field visits and are being encouraged to cultivate different crops. “The state government has also sanctioned Rs 16 crore for the varsity to come up with an inventory on land source and for a project involving hydrological monitoring in Gadag, Koppal and Vijayapura districts,” he added.

Plans for as many as 633 micro watersheds, mapping of soil resources and plans for water conservation have been drawn up and submitted to the watershed department to mitigate the impact of drought, said Prof Chetti.

Title: Congestion reigns near CBT at Bhandiwad Agasi in Hubballi
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

HUBBALLI: North West Karnataka Road Transport Corporation’s (NWKRTC) new Central Bus Terminus ( CBT ) at Bhandiwad Agasi in Hubballi was constructed at an estimated cost of Rs 17 crore to ease congestion and to ensure seamless entry and exit of buses from across the twin cities. However the new terminus appears not to have solved the problem, with passengers continuing to complain of the hassles involved in boarding and alighting from buses at the new five-storey facility.

Experts and residents attribute the persisting problem to the building being designed in an unscientific manner. The area around the bus terminus is often choked, making it a particularly harrowing process to enter and exit the bus stand. Residents and merchants around the bus stand have it worse; noise and air pollution have become a constant companion in their lives. The narrow roads leading to the terminus are often clogged with fumes.

CBT was completed after overcoming several technical problems in 2018. Buses to and from Ravi Nagar, Anand Nagar, Siddharoodha Mutt, Vishveshwar Nagar, Gopanakoppa and Dharwad are among those localities that use CBT as a docking point. Owing to the number of people who travel along these routes, the number of passengers using CBT is almost always high.

Former NWKRTC chairman Sadanand Dhanganavar said that the number of buses presently using the CBT was much higher than what existed when the terminus was planned and designed. “Traffic in and around the CBT too has increased sharply. The authorities need to think of something new to decongest the CBT by identifying a place closer to the terminus where some of the buses can be diverted to. A new bus stop has recently been set up near the Hubballi Railway Station for BRTS, and is some of the buses stopped there, which would reduce congestion in and around CBT,” Dhanganavar said.

Shafi M, a shopkeeper at Bhandiwad Agasi, said that they had to live amid dense fumes and dust throughout the day. “The roads in the locality are almost always choked because the buses are parked in an haphazard manner,” he added.

Title: Thane: Rappeller who discovered new trek route falls to death from Murbad fort
Content:
He was known in trekking circles for exploring various challenging trekking points across country

NAVI MUMBAI: A trekker from Goregaon fell to his death into a valley near Harischandragad , a fort in Murbad taluka in Thane district . While Arun Sawant (61) had fallen into the valley on Saturday evening, his body was retrieved on Sunday afternoon.Sawant and 29 others were rappelling at Konkan Kada, a point at the fort on a trek. Sawant, who had retired as a deputy manager from MTNL last year, was trekking on the 1,800ft-high Konkan Kada cliff. “He accidentally slipped and fell 550ft below into the valley around 7pm. He had his safety gear,” said Sachin Shinde of Nisarg Mitra who was among the rescuers.The rescuers located the body around noon and tried to extricate it from the thicket of green. “The terrain up there made it difficult to move fast with the body. Other members of the rappelling group were brought to safety. We took help from local villagers too,” said Shinde.Shinde said that a 21-member team of trekkers from various groups had started a search-and-rescue operation on Sunday morning.Sawant’s friend, Dahananjay Madan, said that Sawant had organised several rappelling and rock climbing events. “Also, he had trained thousands of people. It’s a great loss for the trekkers community,” said Madan. Sawant is survived by his wife and daughter.Gaurav Kadam, a trekker from Thane who was trained by Sawant, said, “Sawant was the trekker who first located the Konkan Kada rappelling point.” Assistant inspector S H Kharmate of Tokawade police station said an accidental death report has been filed.Founder director of the Guardian Giripremi Institute of Mountaineering, Umesh Zirpe, expressed shock at the news of Sawant’s demise. “In fact, the news has shocked the mountaineering community in the city. We looked up to Sawant as a very experienced mountaineer and trekker who had taken several initiatives to make climbing safe. He had also chalked out new routes at many forts across the state and had also explored new caves during his trekking activity spanning the last three decades,” said Zirpe.A post put out by the head of Explorers Treks and Tours, Anand Kenjale, read: “The death of Arun Sawant is a huge loss to trekkers... He is a big shot of adventure sports...He is responsible for doing something new for the trekkers and adventure sports persons.”Sawant had scaled Lohgad trekking point at age of 16. He was known in trekking circles for exploring various challenging trekking points across country including the Himalayan range.A member of the rescue team, Anand Gavde, said, “He was a guru to all of us.”(With inputs from Pradeep Gupta in Kalyan & Swati Shinde-Gole in Pune)

Title: Lone tusker tramples woman trekker to death in Tamil Nadu forest
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

P Bhuvaneshwari

Title: Tamil Nadu: Scolded by mother over long hair, boy hangs self
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A 16-year-old boy committed suicide at Valasaravakkam in Chennai on Sunday, after his mother scolded him over his hairstyle .

Srinivasan, a Class XII student, hanged himself in his bedroom, when he was alone at home. Police said the boy had been growing his hair for more than three months and had refused to cut it short. Despite his mother's repeated objections, he refused to obey her. Although the boy's father Mani tried to pacify the two, there was yet another verbal duel between Srinivasan and his mother on Sunday morning. He took the extreme step later in the day.

His body was sent to the Government Kilpauk Medical College Hospital (KMCH) for postmortem. Valasaravakkam police have registered a case and are investigating.

Title: Rs 350 autorickshaw fare for Mumbai's Andheri station to airport!
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Sunil Mehrotra clicked a photo of the auto’s registration number and sent it to the traffic police

MUMBAI: A Vasai resident, Sunil Mehrotra, had a bitter experience reaching the international airport from Andheri station early on Sunday. The autorickshaw driver demanded a fixed price of Rs 350 for the 5km ride, which is 7 times the normal fare, and when Mehrotra refused and threatened to complain to the cops, the driver 'dumped' him and his luggage some distance away from the airport and charged him Rs 50.

Before catching his flight to Lucknow, Mehrotra emailed a complaint to traffic police along with a photograph of the auto's registration numb- er. "An officer got back to me saying the registration number was a fake," he told TOI.

According to auto union sources, nearly 20,000 illegal autos ply on city roads, mainly between 12am and 6am. "A few years back, the transport commissioner's office had promised a dedicated squad to weed out illegal autos and drivers, but no action was taken," said Shashank Rao, leader, Mumbai Autorickshawmen's Union. Activist Anil Galgali demanded that RTO launch a 24x7 drive to weed out unscrupulous elements outside stations and airport areas, especially for the safety of women. An auto union member, adding that many of these autos have 'ghoda' meters, which run fast and show inflated fares.

Narrating his ordeal, Mehrotra said he took a local train from Vasai and reached Andheri at 4.40am. As he walked towards the auto stand, he was hounded by drivers who said they would drop him to T2 for a fixed price. "I refused as I wanted to go by the meter," he said. Just then, an auto driver drove close to him and said he would ply by the meter, so Mehrotra got in. "As he sped towards to the airport, I pointed out that he had not put the meter flag down," Mehrotra said. The driver started the meter, but it showed a reading of Rs 361. "I threatened to complain to the police control room, but the driver said the regular fare to the airport was Rs 350, assuming that I wasn't from the city. When I told him that the 5km trip would cost Rs 50-55, the driver said he would charge me Rs 100." As Mehrotra took a photograph of the registration number printed behind the driver's seat, he demanded Rs 100 more, but Mehrotra said he would pay Rs 50. The driver halted the auto at a distance from airport gate. After Mehrotra paid him Rs 50, the driver told him that he would drop him to the gate for Rs 10. Mehrotra ignored him. Traffic cops are looking into the complaint.

Title: Give proof of Osmania professor’s Red links in 4 days, CJ to cops
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

HYDERABAD: Telangana high court on Sunday directed the state government and the police to submit evidence within four days to establish their claim that arrested Osmania University associate professor Chintakindi Kaseem had links with Maoists.

“These days, police are arresting people in the name of being Maoist sympathisers. Now, even professors are not being spared. Is the state trying to crush dissent this way by using its eminent domain power?” asked Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan, who along with Justice Abhishek Reddy , was hearing a house motion moved by Telangana Civil Liberties Committee, seeking Kaseem’s production before the court.

On Saturday, police arrested Kaseem from his official residence inside the Osmania University campus. The CJ, taking serious note of the early morning police action, threatened to order a CBI inquiry against them if they failed to produce Kaseem on Sunday morning. Police brought Kaseem to the CJ’s residence for hearing.

Kaseem contended that he hails from a scheduled caste background and was never involved with any Maoist activity. The professor also said that his writings were critical of the state. Responding to the CJ’s query, Kaseem said police did not misbehave with him when he was there in their custody. He, however, added, “I never admitted that I participated in any Maoistrelated activity.”

The CJ, then, told advocate-general BS Prasad: “Show us evidence that he collected money from businessmen and used the same to propagate Maoist ideology. Provide us evidence about his alleged travel to Chhattisgarh to participate in Maoist meetings.”

Prasad told the court that there were six FIRs against Kaseem, including the current one and all those spoke about his involvement in Maoist programmes.

The CJ recorded Kaseem’s statement and then directed the authorities to consider the professor’s request to shift him to Cherlapalli jail from Sanga Reddy jail where he was remanded in after his arrest by a trial court.

At least 10 persons, including students, were taken into preventive custody when they tried to reach the CJ’s residence. Since October 4 last year, 17 people have been arrested in Telangana for alleged Maoist-links.

Title: Make in India to get Rs 22,000 crore boost from city gas expansion
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

NEW DELHI: The rapid expansion in city gas networks undertaken by the Modi government will open a Rs 22,600 crore ‘Make in India’ market for ancillary equipment needed for piping natural gas to households and refuelling CNG vehicles, say a clutch of government notes.

According to the notes, prepared for an oil ministry event on Thursday to showcase India’s CGD (city gas distribution) programme, the expansion of CNG and PNG services will also create nearly four lakh direct employment opportunities by 2027. The projections are bound to lift the mood as it come amid slowing economic growth.

Only 34 GAs (geographical areas, akin to licence areas across districts in a state) in the country had city gas distribution networks till 2014. Since then, government has given out 174 GAs for building city gas distribution networks. After 136 GAs are given out in the ninth and 10th rounds of auction, city gas distribution networks will cover 70% of the population and 53% of the country’s geographical area spanning 400 districts across 27 states.

The programme has an estimated investment potential of Rs 90,000 crore.

The number of households with PNG connections will rise to over 4 crore from 55 lakh, while the number of CNG stations will go up from 1,838 to 10,000 by 2024.

Such a scale of network expansion will need huge quantities of pipes, mechanical and smart meters, PNG regulators, compressors and boosters pumps etc, which will open up opportunities for domestic manufacturing. Similarly, the notes say there will be demand for 3.75 lakh skilled, semiskilled and unskilled manpower to run and maintain the networks. According to the government, 31% of this manpower requirement will be for skilled personnel, 56% for semi-skilled and 13% for unskilled workers.

Title: Chennai: After Santhome, 2 more parks for disabled kids to come up
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The Santhome park was the first sensory park in Chennai, built a year ago under the Centre’s Smart City progra... Read More

CHENNAI: The city corporation has planned to set up two new sensory parks - one at Valasaravakkam and another at Kotturpuram. Sensory parks are built specially for the convenience of differently-abled children. The first sensory park in the city was inaugurated at Santhome , a year ago under the Centre's Smart City programme.

Officials said the new parks will be built at Sakthi Nagar in Valasaravakkam and Kottur Garden near Adyar. It would cost around 3.5 crore, they said. "We have floated tenders and would start the project in a few months. There has been a positive response about the facilities at the sensory park in Santhome," an official said.

The facility at Santhome has already received accolades and the civic body was awarded by the Smart Cities council. Spread over an area of 1500sqm, the facility is built keeping in mind the needs of the visually challenged and disabled children. It includes sensory pathways, wheelchair-friendly play areas and play equipment. There's also a 150sqft wall painted with braille and embossed for touch and feel for the aid of visually challenged children, officials said. The idea behind such parks is to create an environment that encourages sensitivity towards differently-abled children, an official said. "Like the Santhome sensory park, the new parks will also have wheelchair-friendly sand pits, in which children can build sand castles.

While the park at Santhome was constructed at a cost of 1.3 crore, an official with the parks department said that the ones at Valasaravakkam and Kotturpuram will be built at an estimated cost of 1.6 crore and 1.85 crore respectively.

Apart from the usual flower and herb gardens and play equipment such as slide, swing, merry-go-round, these parks will also have wheelchair-friendly basketball courts, like the one in Santhome park. An outdoor gym for adults will also be set up.

Title: Two AC buses from Mumbai's Goregaon station
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

A file photo shows an AC Mini bus launched by BEST

MUMBAI: The BEST undertaking will inaugurate two AC bus services from Goregaon station (east) on Monday morning. While A-646 will ply to Nagari Niwara 1 and 2 via IT Park, A-447 will operate to Santosh Nagar (extension).

The first A-646 bus will leave at 6.35am and last one at 9.15 pm from Goregaon station, while the first A-447 bus service will leave at 6.05am and the last one at 11.35pm from Goregaon station, said sources.

Title: Kolkata: Man falls asleep with burning cigarette, dies
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

KOLKATA: Md Elyas (74), a resident of 34/1, Munshigunge Road in Watgunge, died at his residence after his bed caught fire on Saturday morning. Police suspect Elyas, a chain smoker, fell asleep while holding a burning cigarette in his hand.

He was rushed to SSKM hospital from where he was later shifted to MR Bangur Hospital. Sources said he succumbed to his injuries later in the afternoon.

No foul play could be found so far, said police. They have sent the body for autopsy to ascertain the actual cause of his death.

Title: Rs 25,000 crore projects by March 2021, Piyush Goyal promises J&K
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

JAMMU: Six Union ministers on Sunday embarked on the first leg of the Centre’s outreach in J&K, with commerce minister Piyush Goyal calling the erstwhile state “desh ka noor (jewel in the crown)” and promising “exemplary transformation after 70 years of deprivation”.

While Goyal was in Akhnoor , his colleagues V. Muraleedharan, Anurag Thakur , Arjun Ram Meghwal , Ashwini Choubey and RK Singh fanned out across other Jammu districts in a bid to convince the people that nullification of Articles 370 and 35A had paved the way for development of the kind the erstwhile state of J&K hadn’t seen.

“The central government is committed to fulfilling its promise of exemplary transformation in J&K as the people have joyfully accepted the new administrative set-up. This is just the beginning of a journey that will change your lives and trigger fast-paced development across the region,” Goyal, who is also the railway minister, told a large gathering in Akhnoor.

He inaugurated three projects there worth around Rs 6.7 crore. “Many more are on the way. J&K is going through rapid transformation. We will all see the golden glory of the region being restored,” he said, complimenting the people for “maintaining peace” during the transition from a state to a UT.

Goyal said that by March 2021, J&K would see at least 25 projects worth an estimated Rs 25,000 crore. “Employment opportunities are coming in sectors like irrigation, electricity, sports and tourism. Every languishing project has been cleared.”

The minister said the upcoming Jammu & Kashmir Investment Summit would be an opportunity for the UT to showcase its strengths, strategies and potential in different sectors.

Title: Fog in Delhi: Fog delays 100 flights, expect more of the same today
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Over 100 flights were delayed at IGI airport due to dense fog. (File photo)

NEW DELHI: The capital's minimum temperature on Sunday settled at 7 degrees Celsius, average for the season, with cold winds in the morning.

The maximum temperature was recorded at 16.7 degrees Celsius - three notches below normal - in the day, the weather department said.

Track the pollution level in your city

According to a Met official, at 5am, the visibility was down to 100 metres at Palam. "However, within an hour, due to strong winds to the tune of 18km per hour, the visibility improved. In the next couple of days, there might be moderate fog while on Tuesday, there might be dense fog at isolated pockets. A bit of drizzle is expected on Tuesday," he said.

Thanks to the foggy morning and the visibility dropping, over 100 flights were delayed at IGI airport.

On Monday, partly cloudy sky is expected with moderate fog in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures will be around 17 and 6 degrees Celsius, respectively.

The air quality index was at 277 on Sunday, in the 'poor' category.

Title: FASTag relaxed at 7 Bengaluru toll plazas
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

BENGALURU: Each of seven toll plazas in and around Bengaluru witnessing traffic pile-ups will have 3-4 lanes accepting cash payments and the rest will be FASTag lanes till Feb 14, says a directive from the ministry of road transport and highways to the National Highways Authority of India.

As per the document, 65 toll plazas in the country which have seen long queues due to a huge number of cash transactions have been directed to convert 25% of lanes to hybrid lanes to facilitate smooth flow of traffic.

The toll plazas in Bengaluru exempted from 100% FASTag mandate are Sadahalli (near KIA), Electronic City Elevated Road, Doddakarenahalli, Hoskote, Attibele Grade Section, Bellur and Bengaluru-Nelamangala section. The ministry's directive said the relaxed mandate will be in place for 30 days from Jan 15.

Despite FASTag rollout across the country, long queues continue at toll plazas in Karnataka. FASTag payments accounted for 56% of all transactions in Karnataka as of January 17.

Title: Four killed in mishap on Mumbai-Goa highway
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

A speeding ST bus rammed into a kaali peeli cab on Sunday

NAVI MUMBAI: A birthday party ended in tragedy as four persons were killed and two injured after a state transport bus rammed into a kaali peeli cab they were travelling in on the Mumbai-Goa highway on Sunday. All the victims are from Mumbai. The mishap between the Asiad ST bus and Eeco car occurred between Amtem and Koleti villages in Pen taluka of Raigad district.

The cab with six persons on board was travelling toward Mumbai, while the bus was plying from Nashik to Mahad (Raigad). The speeding bus driver lost control while plying wrongly on the Mumbai-bound carriageway and collided with the car.

Vadkhal police assistant inspector Ajit Shinde said, "The bus driver was speeding toward Mahad (in the direction of Goa), while the Eeco car was plying toward Vadkhal (Mumbai direction). The driver who was wrongly plying on the Mumbai-bound carriageway around 5 pm rammed into the Eeco."

Shinde said the deceased were Mankhurd resident Santosh Sakharkar (38) and Mahalaxmi residents Mangesh Goregaonkar (35), Anil Chandorkar (42) and Santosh Bhonkar (40). The injured are Nalasopara resident, Saiprakash Nadkar (38) and Lower Parel resident Jaysingh Kargutkar (28). The six had gone to celebrate Chandorkar's birthday at Karnali village in Raigad on Friday.

Locals blamed the national highway authorities for the delay in the highway work saying uneven carriageway crossing was being allowed, leading to confusion among drivers and mishaps.

Police have booked the bus driver, Kiran Nikan, who has been admitted to hospital with injuries. Following the mishap, traffic was hit on the Mumbai- bound carriageway and was diverted to the Goa-bound carriageway.

Title: Kolkata: Light rain today may pull mercury down
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The mercury is set to slide to 13-14 degrees by Tuesday. (ANI photo)

KOLKATA: A light early morning shower may hit Kolkata on Monday. But it will pave the way for a temperature drop over the next 24 hours, said the Met office. Kolkata recorded a minimum temperature of 15.7 degrees Celsius on Sunday which was two notches below normal.

With the northwesterly wind returning after a brief lull, the mercury is set to slide to 13-14 degrees by Tuesday, according to Regional Meteorological Centre (RMC) director G K Das. “But since we are in the second half of January, the northwesterly is unlikely to be stinging and could make the mercury drop by a couple of degrees,” added Das.

It is a patch of cloud from a western disturbance over Uttar Pradesh that is likely to leave the city on Monday morning. “A circulation has been formed but it is not a strong one is unlikely to have a strong impact on her weather in Kolkata,” said Das.

Title: With netas fishing in CAA troubled waters, fissures in federalism may cost India
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

In the land of the Mahatma, violence is on the throne today. Its victims, among others, are helpless passengers in trains, loyal workers in strike-bound factories, and innocent citizens on riotstricken roads when the bandh-mongers claim the freedom of the city.”

This is not a view on the present atmosphere in the country riddled with anti-CAA protests. This was said by Nani A Palkhivala, the unparalleled legal luminary, way back in 1982 referring to the situation prevailing in India then. But these words are apt for today’s India, embittered by violence and political games. Palkhivala’s description of the 1980s India continues to hold even now. “Not since abolition of thuggery by Lord William Bentick in the 1830s has violence characterised our national life on a scale so widespread and so unchecked as today. Our legal system has made life too easy for criminals and too difficult for law-abiding citizens. A touch here and a push there, and India may become ungovernable under the present constitutional set-up,” he had said.

Right to protest is undeniably a fundamental right. But this right does not extend to destruction of public property, or to laying siege to roads to violate right to free access of people and rendering India ungovernable. This right does not extend to incite communal feelings. Sadly, these are methods often adopted by protesters and their sympathisers. Worse, even state governments have lent support to such activities.

The Kerala government has filed a suit under Article 131 making the Citizenship Amendment Act a Centre-state dispute. Punjab intends to follow suit. Is this in consonance with the federal structure envisaged by our Constitution?

Law teachers often said ‘India is a federal republic with a unitary bias’. In state of Rajasthan vs Union of India [1977 AIR 1361], a seven judge SC bench explained, “A conspectus of provisions of our Constitution will indicate that, whatever appearances of a federal structure our Constitution may have, its operations are certainly judged both by the contents of power which a number of its provisions carry with them and the use that has been made of them, more unitary than federal.”

Constitution’s principal architect BR Ambedkar, considered India to be “both unitary as well as federal according to the requirements of time and circumstances”. Over the years, the SC has settled the law and most political parties will agree with Palkhivala, who had said, “We do need a strong Union. But a strong Union is in no way inconsistent with strong states. On the contrary, by definition, a strong Union can only be a Union of strong states.”

The Left parties and Congress traditionally have had seasoned legal brains. When not in office, these two parties sink their differences and sniff for brewing troubles. Then they do their best to fan it. Remember the unprecedented press conference of ‘senior’ Supreme Court judges led by Justice Jasti Chelameswar in 2018?

Left leaders took full advantage of the chinks in the judiciary. They roped in willing legal brains of Congress to peddle canards in active connivance with activist lawyers and intellectuals. Together, they left no stone unturned to ridicule the judiciary, chisel down its stature and make every judge an object of suspicion.

The protests against CAA, as long as there is absence of a design to destabilise India through perpetration of violence, must get due space. But what we are witnessing is worrisome as violence has invariably accompanied protests.

When India was on the path of industrialisation under Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru , the then Union government through Parliament enacted a law in 1957 to acquire privately held coalfields, most of which were in West Bengal, to increase coal production. The Bengal government, claiming sovereign control over its land and minerals, moved the apex court with an Article 131 suit challenging the law.

The Bengal government argued, “States have within their allotted field full attributes of sovereignty and exercise of authority by Union agencies, legislative or executive, which trenches upon that sovereignty is void.” Rejecting the state’s suit against the Centre [1963 AIR 1241], the SC had said, “The executive power of every state has to be so exercised as to ensure compliance with the laws made by Parliament and any existing laws which apply in that state, and not to impede or prejudice the executive power of the Union.”

In 2004, when Congress-led UPA was in office at the Centre, the BJP government in Madhya Pradesh had filed a suit under Article 131 in the SC challenging the validity of Parliament-enacted MP Reorganisation Act on the issue of division of electricity board assets and dues after carving out of Chhattisgarh from Madhya Pradesh.

Disapproving a state government challenging the validity of a Parliament-enacted law through Article 131, the SC in ‘State of MP vs Union Of India’ on August 17, 2011, had said, “Normally, for questions relating to validity of central or other laws, the appropriate forum is the extraordinary writ jurisdiction under Articles 32 and 226 of the Constitution of India in a writ petition and not an original suit filed under Article 131 which vests exclusive jurisdiction of this court as regards disputes enumerated therein.”

The Supreme Court will again decide whether suits under Article 131 filed by Kerala challenging CAA, and Chhattisgarh challenging the National Investigation Agency Act, are maintainable in our federal structure of governance.

Title: CAA: Governor Arif Mohammad Khan seeks report from Kerala govt on SC move
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Kerala governor Arif Mohammad Khan has sought a report from the state government for moving the Supreme Court against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act without informing him. The chief secretary has been asked to submit a detailed reply “immediately”.

“Article 166 (3) of the Indian Constitution specifies that the chief minister and his government has to inform the governor about the government business,” Khan told reporters later. The state government had on January 13 moved the top court challenging the act and had sought to declare it as unconstitutional.

“It is not a personal fight between me and the government. I am not important. But what’s important is the Constitution and the law of the land… In many of its decisions, the Supreme Court has made it clear that the constitutional powers given to the governor are mandatory,” he said.

Khan said he could not remain a mute spectator.

“I will act to protect the Constitution. I will see to it that the rule of business is followed. What the government has done is in contravention of the act,” he said. When it was brought to his notice that law minister A K Balan has said the government has not acted against the law, he said, “I am quoting the act. Let him quote the act and clarify.”
