Content: Art can create, art can heal. It can also help spread awareness and further a cause. It was this belief that motivated city’s leading artists to join hands with animal lovers to create 26 elephant figurines to spread the message of elephant conservation.Fiber glass figurines of the tuskers were presented to the artists by curator Nagesh Goud , who came up with the concept. The artists then created versions of the elephant figurine depending on their preferred medium and expertise.Fawad Tamkanat, one of the artists, said, “This was an attempt by artists to do something for those who cannot speak for themselves. It felt great to be able to do some good through my art.”Artist Chinthala Jagadish too echoed the same sentiment, “The proceeds from the sale of each of these pieces go towards the conservation of elephants. Being an animal lover myself, Ijumped at the opportunity to contribute to their conservation. It was an exciting show to be a part of not just for the cause but also because of the spirit with which artists came on board to contributed for a noble cause,” he said.Tollywood stars Lakshmi Manchu and Renu Desai were also spotted at the show that was attended by more than 100 people. The crowd was seen listening with rapt attention as the artists explained the inspiration behind their works. Discussions about art and wildlife conservation followed.

Title: Gurugram: Key slip road in a shambles, made worse by ‘repair’ work
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Dilapidated condition of one of the key slip roads in Sector 23 of Gurugram

GURUGRAM: Sector 23 residents have raised concerns about the dilapidated condition of one of the key slip roads in the area. According to residents, a 3-km stretch connecting Rezang La Chowk to Major Sushil Aima Marg and further to Old Delhi-Gurugram road has been neglected by the authorities.

Residents and commuters, especially those commuting on two-wheelers, complained of physical injuries and back pain on a regular basis due to the poor condition of the slip road. The road is full of big potholes and is usually waterlogged as the sewer line adjacent to it is choked, they said.

“I have tweeted about this issue a couple of times. This road has been broken for more than one year. There are numerous potholes which are over one foot deep. Water always accumulates in them whenever it rains or sewer lines get choked,” said Bhawani Shankar, a resident.

He added, “Last year, labourers poured concrete on one of the potholes during repair work, making a huge mound in the middle of the road that resulted in vehicles being damaged. It also made it difficult for two-wheelers to pass through. The problem will always remain as the road is at a lower level from both the connecting roads — Old Delhi road and Sushil Aima Marg. This entire part needs redesigning, especially because this road is soon going to have tracks for the RRTS line from Sarai Kale Khan to Manesar.”

Sector 23A RWA president Malkhan Singh said the responsibility of maintaining roads lies primarily with the Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA). “We have approached both the municipal corporation and GMDA over the matter. Sometimes, we are told that they plan to convert the divider into a green belt, but that is a minor issue. The drain running along this slip road is also choked and not levelled. Since it’s an important road in the sector, even officials of the administration travel through it every other day. They are very much aware of the issues residents are facing for over the past 1.5 years, but we have no clarity on who will repair the road and when,” he added.

Another resident, Devendra Kaushik, said he has never seen the road in a good condition. “Even when it isn’t raining, the road is always flooded. If one avoids going by this broken road, then they are stuck for a good 40-45 minutes at the intersection ahead. The slip road is important for traffic coming from both Kapashera and the Palam Vihar flyover,” he said.

GMDA officials refused to comment on the matter.

Title: Patna: One held in murder case, 3 still at large
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police on Sunday arrested one Bajrangi Pandey from Paliganj market for his alleged involvement in the murder of his cousin Pankaj Kumar (32), whose bullet-ridden body was recovered from a roadside near Katarhi village under the Rania Talab police station area in Patna district on January 4.

Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma said Pankaj's maternal cousin Avinash Pandey was the main conspirator of the murder. "Avinash had got job in the Army by producing fake documents and Pankaj had complained to the institution several times regarding the issue. Avinash is posted in Kashmir," he added.

The SSP said Avinash, Vishal Sharma, Tunnu Singh and Bajrangi were the four accused in the case. "Police will move court to procure arrest warrant against Avinash. Raids are on to arrest the others," he added.

Paliganj SDPO Manoj Kumar Pandey said while Avinash is a resident of Sabbalpur village under the Doriganj police station area in Chhapra town, Vishal hails from Dilawarpur and Tunnu from Lai village under Bihta police station area. Bajrangi, on the other hand, hails from Rohtas district.

"All the four accused are relatives of Pankaj. Investigations revealed that Vishal and Bajrangi killed Pankaj on Avinash's direction. Pankaj had taken money from Avinash by blackmailing him on multiple occasions over his fake certificate," he said.

The SDPO said Pankaj was shot dead by Vishal while he was on way to his home at Janpara from Sabbalpur. "Tunnu's bike was used in the crime," he added.

Title: Danapur jeweller's body exhumed in Champaran
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The body of Danapur jeweller Mukesh Kumar Gupta was exhumed at Motihari on Saturday night and handed over to his family members for performing last rites according to rituals.

Gupta was kidnapped from Saguna Mor under Danapur police station area in state capital on January 10. The kidnappers had strangled him and buried his body on the banks of river Sikrahna at Chiraiyyan in East Champaran district.

Police had preserved his body for 72 hours after conducting postmortem. The body was identified after police in Patna arrested Ramashish Kumar alias Ashish Yadav, Aman Kumar and Rajesh Kumar on January 16 and came to know that Gupta was murdered within hours of his kidnapping.

Ramashish had mortgaged some jewellery at Mukesh's shop. He was trying to get them back by paying money but Mukesh had asked him to pay more leading to the murder conspiracy.

Chiraiyyan police station SHO (incharge) Hulas Rai said police had received information about the body at around 10am on January 11. "Neither any cellphone nor purse was recovered from the body. There was ligature mark around neck giving rise to suspicion that the person was strangled by rope or something like that," he said.

Rai said the body was exhumed after seeking permission from Sikrahna subdivisional officer (SDO). "The circle officer was deployed as magistrate for the entire process," he said.

The SHO said Mukesh's family members on Saturday submitted a petition in the Sikrahna ACJM court, which asked the SDO to take necessary decision. He said the postmortem report was still awaited.

Meanwhile, Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma said one of the kidnappers was still evading arrest. "He had driven the SUV to Motihari from Patna for dumping the body," he said.

Title: Telangana civic polls: A fight for open spaces and fresh air
Content:
Liquor shops set up near residential area in Boduppal

HYDERABAD: Unlike other civic bodies, it is not poor roads or water supply that is plaguing the Boduppal Municipal Corporation (BMC) limits but it is problems of garbage, encroachment and pollution that has got the area’s residents worried.A total of 138 candidates are contesting the municipal elections for 28 wards in Boduppal. Over 1.20 lakh voters are expected to vote in the elections, which are scheduled to be held on January 22.On the last day of campaigning on Sunday, contesting candidates went all out to woo voters in the BMC limits. While the majority of candidates promised better roads and civic amenities, residents raised concerns over unsystematic garbage collection, rampant encroachment and pollution in the area, which they claim continues unabated.Boduppal has emerged as a major residential hub for many employees working in Nacharam and Mallapur Industrial Development Area (IDA). “There are many illegal constructions in the locality. While there is a mechanism to collect garbage from every house, heaps of construction debris lying on the roadsides and empty plots goes unnoticed by the municipal corporation,” said Rahul Adwant, a resident who has been living in Boduppal for the last eight years.Many have also complained over encroachment of land, public parks and the Boduppal Cheruvu, which members of various political parties have been promising to beautify for the past many years.“There are many public parks which have been encroached upon. There is absolutely no lung space in the Boduppal area. What’s worse is that even the lake bed is encroached by the slum dwellers who have constructed houses in the FTL limits, said Prashanth Mamidala, an activist in the area.It is not just water pollution but also air pollution that has affected residents of Boduppal. “@CPCB_OFFICIAL Please direct @TelanganaPCB to take action against defaulting pharma companies in Nacharam & Mallapur IDA, Hyderabad. There are releasing hazardous chemical gases in the air. Nearby Boduppal residential colonies are suffering,” tweeted Subbarao Nadendla, a resident who has been raising the issue with the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) for several months now.Apart from these problems, pig menace, lack of street-lights, public transportation connectivity and lack of educational institutions are among other developmental issues that plague Boduppal.

Title: Lucknow: Sun shines after 4 days, but moderate fog from next week
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Lucknow is likely to witness a clear sky with sunshine next week. (File photo)

LUCKNOW: The sun peeked through an overcast sky ending a four-day siege of clouds in the city late Sunday afternoon.

Clouds covered the city skyline during the first half of the day, however, sunshine brought relief from cold winds late afternoon. The maximum and the minimum temperatures were recorded as 15.1 and 11.7 degrees Celsius. The humidity levels continued to be 100% for the third consecutive day.

The city is likely to witness moderate to dense fog on Monday morning and the maximum and the minimum temperatures are likely to range between 17 and 19 degrees Celsius.

Meteorological officials said that city is likely to witness a clear sky with sunshine next week. However, there are chances of moderate to dense fog during morning and evening hours.

“Western disturbances led to rain and cloud cover in the city. The weather will improve in the coming week and the maximum temperatures are expected to rise by 3 degrees Celsius or so by the weekend. The rise in maximum temperatures will be due to a change in the wind pattern,” said state met director JP Gupta.

Title: Will FASTag switch cost us our jobs, ask wary toll staff
Content:
File photo used for representational purpose

GURUGRAM: The staggered transition to a fully automated highway toll collection system has turned into a cause of worry for those working the lanes and seeing its implementation through on the ground. The inevitable fallout, they fear, is a slow phasing out of their role.Jawan Singh had dropped out of school when he was in class VIII. "I had to work and support my family. But I am too old for casual labour now. I don't have enough farmland. My son was laid off two years ago and has been struggling to get another job. I can't afford to lose mine," said the 45-year-old toll operator from Rewari.Jawan's fears are founded on what at this point is conjecture but, he is certain, has to be the next logical step of the move. With FASTag , vehicles won't have to pay highway tolls in cash - the intent being faster, easier travel. There have been three deferrals to a complete switch till now, marked by longer tailbacks and shortening tempers. Management has been messy and the onus of enforcement, in most cases, has come down to toll operators and helpers. At Kherki Daula alone, 200 lane operators and helpers work in three shifts every day to manage vehicle flow through the toll plaza's 25 lanes. And end up doing more than what their job requires.Last year, Soni Kumari (22) was physically assaulted, twice, just for asking motorists to pay the Rs 65 toll. Since FASTag was rolled out, Soni said, her job has turned twice as demanding. "People have turned even more aggressive. It is a lot of stress and humiliation," she said, looking up from her computer screen in the cramped counter, when an SUV stopped at the toll gate. There wasn't enough balance in the vehicle's FASTag account. Soni told the driver his vehicle had been blacklisted and he responded with a string of abuses. It took three lane operators, a marshal and a policeman to calm him down.But leaving is not an option. "This job is my best shot at funding my education. If I can complete postgraduation, maybe I can get a government job. Otherwise, I will have to give up my studies," Soni said.Most toll operators share Soni's background - with limited qualifications or skills and very little flexibility of choices. "If I don't have a job, my family will marry me off. As long as I am financially independent, I can keep doing what I need to. I have a year to go before I finish my graduation. If I can keep my job until then, I can at least take tuitions or teach somewhere," said Roshni, a 20-year-old toll operator.Till now, there has been no official statement about what awaits those who work at toll plazas once they are automated, whatever the time it takes. And this lack of clarity has been disconcerting for many. But concessionaires of Kherki Daula, MCEPL and Skylark, said they would not let their employees go even if their roles turned redundant."There may be some restructuring and people could be accommodated in other roles. But first, it will take years for full automation, if at all. As of now, it is just a theory that lanes will be unmanned ... Helpers, especially, will definitely be needed - for lifting boom barriers, for using the handheld tag readers," a senior MCEPL official said. NHAI, too, said toll operation without human intervention is a long way off. "I am sure the (road transport and highways) ministry will come up with a solution if a fully automatic system is introduced. But instead of cutting jobs, it will create new kinds of jobs," an NHAI official said.And what would that entail? "Desk work. There is a lot of data that will be generated. We will need data operators, people to manage the records," the MCEPL official said. But this would need major reskilling. Something not every employee may be up to. "There is a limit to how much restructuring can be done," a Skylark employee said. The concern is borne out by Jawan: "I don't even know how to use a smartphone. How could I possibly become a data operator at this age?"

Title: Engineers red-flag paver blocks, cement around trees
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: The Council of Engineers, a body comprising techies from Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh, has filed a complaint with the chairperson of National Green Tribunal (NGT), the chief secretary of Punjab and the additional chief secretary of the state’s local government department against officials of the Ludhiana MC for covering areas around trees with concrete and paver blocks.

The council has described concretisation around trees as an “act of gross negligence” and said it would cause severe damage to the trees in future. COE president Kapil Arora said the city’s civic body had been continuously covering areas around trees with cement and interlocking tiles (paver blocks) without consulting horticulturists and experts.

Both sides of roads are being covered like this, he said. He added that practice stopping rainwater from seeping into earth and also causing the decay of such trees.

He said trees were at the receiving end of this practice in Sarabha Nagar, B R S Nagar, Kitchlu Nagar, Tagore Nagar and many more areas. “Such an act by the MC is not only a wastage of public money, but will also affect environment,” said Arora.

COE member Mohit Jain said roots of trees absorbed water, carbon dioxide and other nutrients. “Laying of concrete over an existing tree can result in its death. It takes decades to grow a tree properly, but instead of planting new trees, the MC seems to be interested in killing even the existing trees,” Jain said.

He said the act showed that the MC had no vision for providing clean air to residents. “If such act of gross negligence is allowed, a large number of trees in Ludhiana will die due to lack of water and nutrients,” he said.

Another member, Sanjay Verma, said the NGT, in 2013, had directed civic bodies in Delhi to leave a metre’s radius around trees. “Keeping this in view, we have requested the chairperson of NGT, and Punjab chief secretary and additional chief secretary (local government) to direct officials of MC to remove the concrete and paver blocks fixed around trunks of trees,” he said. He added the MC should instead use grass pavers/turf pavers.

Title: Rs 35k robbery story fake, delivery man of e-tailer behind bars
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: Police here arrested the employee of an e-commerce giant on Saturday for allegedly concocting the story of him being robbed of Rs 35,000 when he was returning to his company’s godown on Friday.

The employee had alleged that two men riding a motorcycle had robbed him near Arora Palace on Gill Road on Friday. However, when he was interrogate, the accused caved in to cross-questioning and he also helped the cops recover Rs 27,000 from the amount, said an official.

Arjan Singh (28), a resident of Gurnam Nagar, Jalandhar Bypass, has been arrested and a case registered against him on a complaint by Dharmjit Singh, who is the manager at the godown.

Sub-Inspector Ranjit Singh, who is the investigating officer, said Arjan had alleged that he was robbed in a phone call made to the police control room. Arjan had alleged that he had collected cash from customers, who had purchased goods through the website, and was near Arora Palace on Gill Road, when two men riding a motorcycle intercepted him. He alleged that the accused asked him to give them the money. When he refused, the men beat him up and snatched the bag containing the case, he alleged.

The official said they scanned footage of security cameras around the crime scene, but found nothing suspicious. The cop added that they also asked shopkeepers near the crime scene, but they said they did not find anything suspicious. As police started doubting the complainant’s story, police questioned Arjan. During interrogation, Arjan confessed to concocting the story, said the cop.

Arjan has told the police that he owed a loan to a money lender and that was why he decided to fake the robbery. A case under sections 406 (criminal breach of trust) and 420 (cheating) of the Indian Penal Code has been registered against the accused at Shimlapuri police station.

Title: 10-yr-old boy beaten up by teacher in govt school
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: Taking suo moto cognisance of a 10-year-old boy being beaten up by a government school teacher in Dhandari Kalan on Friday, Punjab State Commission for Protection of Child Rights (PSCPCR) have summoned district education officer (Elementary) Rajinder Kaur, teacher Shailja, and inquiry officer Dharminder Singh — Kanganwal police station ASI — on January 30.

PSPCR director Rajinder Singh said, “We will take suo moto cognisance of it. They have been summoned under Section 13 of CPCR (Commission for Protection of Child Rights) Act 2005. We have instructed the school and education department and investigation officers of the Commissionerate of Ludhiana to inquire into the matter and take action. Other steps too will be taken once we get a clear picture, and produce the action taken report on January 30.” Deputy director Rajwinder Gill said, “We have also told district child protection officer Rashmi to visit the school as well as meet the student and report on this at the earliest.”

The ten-year-old was brutally beaten up by the teacher of Government Primary School, Dhandhari Kalan, with a wooden stick on Friday. The student refused to go to school on Saturday morning. His mother Kavita got to know he was beaten mercilessly on Friday, as he — along with his other friends — were making a nuisance in the class, and when the teacher questioned them who was making noises, one of his friends named him. The teacher later beat him with a wooden stick for five minutes continuously. He had severe bruises on his left arm, right leg, and forehead. When we went to complain on Saturday, three more parents were present with the same complaint.

Kavita said, “My son narrated the whole incident. He refused to go to school on Saturday. We first approached the school, but the teacher was not present, and then we approached Kanganwal police chowki. They told us to get our son’s medical check-up done, and so we got it done from Sahnewal Civil Hospital as recommended by police officials. He was sobbing and said he would not go to school as long as the teacher was present. This is not the first incident, as he has been beaten up brutally a month ago by the same teacher. Now, I don’t want her to be suspended, but she should be transferred from this school to some other school.”

The boy, whose father is a security guard in a private firm, was studying in the same school for the past four years. Kanganwal police station ASI Dharminder Singh said, “They have been called on Monday in this matter, as the teacher was busy with TET (Teacher Eligibility Test) duties.”

Title: Punjabi poet Gurbhajan Gill’s ninth book of ghazals released
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: Punjabi poet Gurbhajan Gill’s ghazal book titled Mann Pardesi was released by SS Johl, economist and chancellor, Central University of Punjab, during a function held at Punjabi Bhawan. On this occasion, Punjabi Sahit Akademi president Ravinder Bhathal, senior vice-president Surinder Kailey, general secretary Surjit Singh, and former president Sukhdev Singh Sirsa were also present.

Speaking on the occasion, Gurbhajan Gill informed that his first book of ghazals titled Har Dhukhda Pind Mera Hai was published in 1985, after which he had penned books titled Do Harf Raseedi, Mann De Boohe Baarian, Mor Pankh, Tareyan De Naal Gallan Kardeyan, Gulnaar, Mirgawali and Raavi. He informed that Mann Pardesi is his ninth collection of ghazals, and 16th book in total.

This book has been published by Chetna Parkashan. SS Johl said Gill was capable of presenting complex topics of life in a simpler language, as his writings consist of language of our motherland. He said that Gill was not only an excellent poet, but also a far-sighted Punjabi, who was concerned about his motherland. Ravinder Bhathal said Gill had been promoting Punjabi language and culture for the past several decades.

He informed that Gill started his career as a professor of Punjabi language in 1976, and from 1983 to 2013, he served Punjab Agricultural University (PAU) Ludhiana as editor (Punjabi). Gill also remained the president of Punjabi Sahit Akademi from 2010 to 2014, as well as a senior office-bearer of Mohan Singh Memorial Foundation from 1978 to 2014.

Johl added, “Gurbhajan Gill was instrumental in establishing Maharaja Dalip Singh Memorial Trust at Bassian Kothi near Raikot, Punjab Bhawan at Surrey in Canada, and several other organisations. He is also the chairman of Punjabi Lok Virasat Akademi, besides being actively associated with Kila Raipur Sports, and Surjit Sports Association in Batala (Gurdaspur). In 2016, he was awarded fellowship by Punjabi University, Patiala, and by Punjabi Sahit Akademi in 2018.

Title: SAD leaders accuse Taksalis of joining hands with Congress
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

CHANDIGARH: The Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD) on Sunday accused “fake Taksalis” of joining hands with the Congress and their radical sympathisers in a desperate attempt to weaken Akali and Sikh religious institutions.

In a joint statement, Rajya Sabha members Balwinder Singh Bhunder and Naresh Gujral and leaders Prem Singh Chandumajra, Tota Singh and Maheshinder Singh Grewal said a “bunch of opportunists who were dancing to the tune of the Congress” by betraying Akali values could not challenge the leadership of party president Sukhbir Singh Badal “who had been democratically elected by 47 lakh strong members of the Akali Dal”.

Akali leader accused Taksalis of insulted the core Akali ideology by “sharing the stage with the Congress during an event in Delhi”. “The cat is out of the bag. Now, it is clear that all these fake Taksalis have become unofficial members of the Congress,” they alleged.

Chandumajra and Tota asked all Taksalis to first clear the air about their own conduct before pointing fingers at the SAD President. They said Sukhdev Singh Dhindsa’s own track record was such that he did not even contemplate resigning as secretary general when he lost the assembly election during an Akali wave in 1997. They said in direct contrast the SAD had performed splendidly in the past by winning back to back elections and forming a government for 15 out of the last 20 years.

Title: 2,293 self-help groups for urban poor families in Himachal Pradesh
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

SHIMLA: Under Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana, 2,293 self-help groups (SHGs) have been constituted for urban poor households in the state out of which 1,780 have been provided with revolving fund. As many as 103 Area Level Federation have also been formed, out of which 74 have been provided with revolving fund. For setting up small industries 1,646 beneficiaries, have been provided loan of Rs 22.15 crore at a low interest rate and 424 SHGs provided loans worth Rs 6.13 crore under this scheme while 4282 beneficiaries have been provided training in various trades and 813 beneficiaries have been given employment under this scheme.

According to a statement issued by the state government on Sunday, Deen Dayal Antyodaya Yojana-National Urban Livelihood Mission (DAY-NULM) has been very effective in socio-economic upliftment of urban poor households. Under this scheme these families are imparted training along with providing financial assistance for gainful self employment, so that they could live a respectful life.

Officials said this scheme has also proved to be a boon for urban street vendors. Under this scheme, a survey has been conducted for urban street vendors in all 54 urban bodies of the state. Almost 5,000 street vendors have been provided training in various trades and identity cards issued to 2,822.

Effective work is being done under this scheme for providing shelter to urban poor families. Six shelter homes have been constructed in various urban bodies and renovation of old shelter homes has also been undertaken under this scheme. As many as 4,032 homeless people have been provided shelter.

Title: AICTE urged to relax seat filling norms in Punjab
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: Punjab Unaided Colleges Association (Puca) has urged the All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) for relaxing the norms of filling seats in technical institutes in the state.

A Puca delegation met professor M P Poonia, vice-chairman of AICTE, and requested reform in the approval process handbook 2020. Puca president Anshu Kataria said reforms are must for saving the dying technical education institutes and self-financed colleges.

On this, Poonia assured that without compromising the quality of AICTE, changes will be brought.

Kataria, who is also the chairman of Chandigarh-based Aryans Group of Colleges, said AICTE norms should be applicable on the basis of seats filled instead of total seats sanctioned by it.

He added that to get the approval, huge infrastructure including land, buildings, equipment and machinery, furniture and fixture is required, but it all goes to waste when the seats are not filled.

Around 95% of colleges providing technical education are private. Puca senior vice-president Amit Sharma said there is 95% contribution of private institutions in providing technical education and in a way, these institutions are creating employment opportunities. AICTE can revive the dying educational institutions.

Puca general secretary Gurpreet Singh said AICTE should come up with new policies and norms so that surplus resources could be utilised. But these days, unaided colleges are facing financial crunch and should be bailed out.

Title: Sports enthusiasts throng Solang
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

The winter sports activities were organised by the International Ski Federation in Solang valley on Sunday

MANALI: With an aim to encourage snow sports among children and conserving the environment, the 9th World Snow Day was organised in Solang valley here on Sunday.

Children and youths in large numbers thronged the slopes to enjoy skiing and snowboarding for the whole day. They were given free lessons in skiing. Tourists too tried their hands on the sport. On the call of the International Ski Federation (FIS), the night edition of World Snow Day saw 363 events and sports action taking place in 45 countries on the day.

Ski and Snowboard India secretary general Roopu Negi said the occasion was celebrated at Solang in the presence of a an enthusiastic crowd under the aegis of Indian Olympic Association secretary general Rajeev Mehta. “We are encouraging children and their families to come and enjoy snow. India is performing well in winter sports. The world has now recognised our potential. Though we have not achieved much at international events but we are confident to get recognition among the top athletes of the world soon. Keeping in view that children are the future, snow day celebrations were aimed at encouraging them to show interest in winter sports,” he said.

Most of the ski resorts and clubs allowed free entry to enthusiasts on the occasion. Besides all the snowy fun, the children were apprised about the health benefits of winter sports and importance of saving the environment to preserve snow.

Himachal Pradesh Winter Games Association (HPWGA) president Ludar Thakur said FIS president Gian Franco Kasper had sent a message that all the skiing clubs, federations and state associations should take part in maximum events. “Kasper was excited to learn how celebrations exceeded all expectations and said it is a great achievement and testament to how important children are to snow sports.”

Title: Plan for higher water tariff key to Buddha Nullah rejuvenation
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Moving forward, the metered tariff will be vital to implementing the plan for rejuvenating Buddha Nullah.

LUDHIANA: An MC committee comprising councillors and government officials will be meeting this week to decide on a proposal which seeks to introduce metered water and sewerage tariff, and do away with the previous flat rates, in the city.

Moving forward, the metered tariff will be vital to implementing the plan for rejuvenating Buddha Nullah. This is because the higher revenue generated from the new rates will be used to maintain sewage treatment plants (STPs) which will be set up for treating waste water before it is discharged into the highly polluted drain.

The committee has been formed as when the proposal was listed as an agenda before the MC general house, councillors had deferred the item as they felt the new tariff charges would burden residents. However, as the water tariff is essential to rejuvenation of Buddha Nullah and the plan to implement canal-based water supply in the city, the mayor has formed the committee to give suggestions on the tariff plan.

For Buddha Nullah’s rejuvenation plan, the city body will require Rs 110 crore for mantenance of STPs which will be set up for treating water which is discharged into the train. The MC, which generates just about Rs 35 crore from water and sewerage charges, is hoping to generate more revenue from these charges and use it, even if partly, for maintaining the STPs.

The committee comprises senior deputy mayor Sham Sunder Malhotra, Congress councillors Mamta Ashu, Ashwani Sharma, Jai Parkash, Kuldeep Singh and Gagandeep Singh , SAD councillor Harbhajan Dang, BJP councillors Sunita Rani and Om Parkash Ratra, MC operation and maintenance cell superintending engineer Rajinder Singh, and DCFA Ravinder Walia.

Under the old tariff plan, houses built in an area of up to 125 square yards were exempted from paying water and sewerage bill. Houses which qualify for the exemption will, according to the proposal, be reduced to those which are built in an area of up to 50 square yards.

Though the charges suggested in the proposal are nominal, councillors said in the MC house’s meeting on December 31, 2019, that they were too high and it was decided that the committee would be formed to reach a conclusion. Parkash said the new tariff plan was also vital to implementing canal-based water supply as the new rates would help in implementing the plan. “Groundwater is depleting, so surface water is the need of the hour,” he said.

He said he was going to push for the implementation of the new charges on houses which are in an area of more than 50 square yards. Dang, who is also a member of the commitee, said he was going to push for higher charges for houses which measure more than 125 square yards and ensuring that commercial users pay up. "We should not be going after the poor for the money. Our government had given exemption to households up to 125 square yards from water and sewerage charges. Only after the meeting will I be able to comment on whether we will support the policy or oppose it,” he said.

Title: Manch holds rally in support, wants people to know law
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Advocate in the Supreme Court Monica Arora addresses the gathering

LUDHIANA: The Rashtriya Vichar Manch organised a rally in support of the Citizenship Amendment Act at Dana Mandi near Jalandhar bypass on Sunday. The rally was organized with an aim to clearing the doubts of general public regarding this Act. The speakers addressed the gathering and asked them to be aware about this act and it had nothing to do with Indian citizens. The Act has been made to give citizenship to non-Muslim refugees who had come from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan till December 31, 2014.

Advocate in the Supreme Court Monica Arora, who participated in the rally, said, “Indian citizens need not to worry about it as it will grant citizenship to refugees from Pakistan, Bangladesh and Afghanistan.” She further said, “India has always given shelter to people who have faced atrocities in the name of religion in other countries and there are certain communities which exist in India which were never given recognition in their own countries.

She said this Act was framed in 1951 and this law was supported by Dr Rajinder Prasad, Jawahar Lal Nehru and B R Ambedkar, while saying that India will give shelter to those non-Muslims who are being treated brutally for changing their religion and they are not getting justice.

Even at the time of Partition Mahatma Gandhi had said the Indian government would provide food and employment to those Hindus and Sikhs who do not want to live in Pakistan. She said but there were some people who did not want to know about the Indian Constitution and were opposing this Act through student unions and minorities.

Other speakers said in these three Muslim countries non-Muslim females were not at all secure as they were being abducted and kidnapped for getting married forcefully. A recent incident of Nankana Sahib is an example. In these countries nobody can celebrate festivals, get employment and participate in social activities freely. The states are not doing right by opposing this Act.

Title: Four two-wheelers torched at Giaspura
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

LUDHIANA: Some unidentified miscreants torched four vehicles, including three motorcycles and one scooter, in Giaspura flats here in the wee hours of Sunday just a few meters away from the police station at Daba. The miscreants also set heap of scrap collected by a scrap dealer in locality on fire.

Shivam (23) of Giaspura flats said he had parked his motorcycle on roadside. Around midnight his neighbours informed him that his bike was up in flames. He immediately rushed outside and found his motorcycle burning. He immediately doused the fire. He added that the motorcycle of two other residents Ashok Kumara and Rohit Kumar and a scooter of another resident were also set on fire.

Inspector Pavittar Singh, SHO at police station Daba stated that the police had got information about the incident, however, the residents have yet to lodge a complaint in this regard. The police will further proceed only after receiving a complaint.

Title: Ludhiana: ATM withdrawal at night? Be cautious
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Representative image

LUDHIANA: If you are planning to make an ATM withdrawal late in the night, be scared and be cautious. A Times of India reality check of nine ATM kiosks in the city on Saturday night revealed that eight of them did not have a security guard.

This is the case even though there have been instances where thieves have decamped with entire ATMs in the city. During the reality check, only one ATM, in Agar Nagar, was found having a guard. Moreover, there were no police teams found in areas around the ATMs either.

Most recently, on November 2, 2019, an entire automated teller machine (ATM) containing Rs 23 Lakh was stolen. The accused first broke open the shutter using gas cutter, then vandalised CCTV cameras, and later uprooted the ATM. Though police arrested three men in connection with the theft on November 13, they are yet to recover the money which was lost.;

Similarly, on December 23, 2019, thieves broke into the Green Field branch of Punjab & Sindh Bank. However, as they could not make their way to the safe, they could not take away in case.

There have been several other attempts made to steal ATMs.

The TOI team after 10pm visited an SBI ATM kiosk on Ferozepur Road near Ansal Plaza, Orient Bank’s ATM in BRS Nagar, CSB Bank’s ATM near Hero Bakery Chowk, Punjab National Bank ATM in Kochar Market, Indusland Bank ATM in Shastri Nagar, Bandhan Bank’s ATM in Feroze Gandhi Market, and IDBI Bank’s ATM in Feroze Gandhi market, but found no security guard.

On December 17, 2019, an attempt was made to decamp with Axis Bank’s ATM on Ferozepur Road, opposite Verka Milk Plant. When TOI visited the spot, it found the shutter of the ATM kiosk locked, but there was no security guard there.

A security guard was found at ICICI Bank’s ATM on Ferozepur Road, near Agar Nagar. The guard said he stayed there from 10pm to 6am. Ludhiana commissioner of police Rakesh Agarwal said they would hold a meeting with banks to ensure security arrangements, especially at night.

On October 23, a group of miscreants had tried to break open an ATM of Axis Bank in Haibowal, but could not. A similar failed attempt to break open an ATM had taken place at Bank of India’s branch at PAU on October 30.

Title: Dowry death in Khanna, man booked
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: Khanna police have booked a man for dowry death after his wife died under mysterious circumstances.

Abhinav Saggar, a resident Lalheri Road near Adarsh Cinema in Khanna, is yet to be arrested. In his police complaint, Ward 19 councillor Pomi Saini of Chota Kheda Ropar alleged that his brother’s daughter, Heena Saggar, married the accused on November 21, 2018.

He alleged that Heena was given her dowry, but her husband strated torturing her for dowry soon after the marriage. He alleged that Heena didn’t tell anyone about this and the torture continued. Around 8am on Sunday, Soni got a call from Heena and she asked him to take her home as her in-laws would kill her.

He alleged her phone was switched off after this. After this, Heena’s father-in-law informed her father that she had slipped in the bathroomand they were taking her to the hospital.

Later, a relative of the accused phoned them and told them Heena had died at the hospital. Khanna DSP Rajan Parminder Singh said they had booked the accused for dowry death at Khanna City-1 police station. tnn

Title: Ludhiana tops the state in cases of cognizable crime
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: The number of cognizable officences reported from Ludhiana commissionerate were highest in the state in 2018, according to the latest report released by the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB).

That’s not all, the number of such cases was two times more than the district which came in second in the NCRB list, Patiala.

Also, compared to 2017, the number of such cases in the district rose by 15%, according to the report released by NCRB last Thursday. Ludhiana commissionerate includes Ludhiana city and areas which are in its 10km radius. There is another police force for Ludhiana rural.

Crimes which are recognised as cognizable under the Indian Penal Code include murder, attempt to murder, culpable homicide not amounting to murder, causing death by negligence, dowry death, abetment to suicide, hurt, assault on woman with intent to outrage her modesty, kidnapping and abduction, rape and attempt to rape. There were 6,001 such cases in Ludhiana commissionerate in 2018. The chief minister’s home district, Patiala, came in second, with 3,228 cases, and SAS Nagar district and Jalandhar commissionerate were third and fourth with 2,690 and 2,209 cases, respectively.

The number of such cases in Ludhiana commissionareate was 5,217 in 2017. In 2017, Patiala district was at the second spot with 2,520 cases. The Amritsar commissionerate was third with 2,392 such cases, and SAS Nagar district was fourth with 2,371 cases.

There were more cases of murder in Patiala, 56, in 2018, and the number of such cases reported in Ludhiana commissionareate was 53. Ludhiana took the top spot when it came to number of cases of culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Ferozepur district was second, with 14 such cases. Tarn Taran district took the top spot with 78 cases of attempt to murder, Ludhiana was fourth with 57 such cases. Ferozepur and Amritsar rural (police district) were two and three with 63 and 59 cases, respectively.

Ludhiana had the highest number of dowry death cases in the state, with eight cases being reported in 2018. Bathinda had six such cases and took the second spot.

Ludhiana commissionareate took the first spot in cases of hurt too. In all, 609 such cases were reported in the commissionerate in 2018. Patiala and Bathinda districts came in behind it, reporting 494 and 401 cases, respectively.

There was one acid attack in Ludhiana commissionerate in 2018. There were three such cases in Ferozepur district and two in SBS Nagar district.

Ludhiana also recorded the highest number of theft cases in 2018, 1,335. Amirtsar and Jalandhar commissionerates reported 732 and 692 such cases, respectively. The number of robbery cases in Ludhiana were 14, while Jalandhar commissionerate had 18 such cases.

Ludhiana commissioner of police Rakesh Aggarwal said the number of cases did not hint at law and order. “We don’t pay heed to figures while controlling crime as this can affect registration of cases. Our focus is on providing a secure atmosphere to people and arrest criminals,” he said.

He added they had cracked most cases even as they were grappling with staff shortage.

RISING CRIME UNDER COMMISSIONERATE

2014 | 3,546

2015 | 4,012

2016 | 3,716

2017 | 5,217

2018 | 6,001

__

Cognizable crimes | Cognizable crimes include murder, attempt to murder, culpable homicide not amounting to murder, hurt, assault on woman with intent to outrage her modesty, kidnapping and abduction, offences against state, offences against public tranquility, offences against property, offences relating to documents and property marks and other IPC crimesYear Number of Cognizable

_

‘Focus on controlling crime, not figures’

We don’t pay heed to figures while controlling crime as this can affect registration of cases. Our focus is on providing a secure atmosphere to people and arrest criminals

Rakesh Aggarwal | Ludhiana commissioner of police

Title: RPF runs cleanliness drive, fines 37 offenders
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: After facing difficulties while maintaining cleanliness of railway tracks, the Railway Protection Force (RPF) swung into action on Sunday and ran a special drive against passengers who were throwing waste along the railway tracks and caught as many as 37 offenders during the single day drive here at the city railway station.

The RPF also imposed a penalty of Rs 1,000 on each of the offenders during the special drive and recovered Rs 37,000 and deposited the same in the railway treasury.

Apart from that, cleanliness department officials have been asked to depute the maximum number of cleanliness workers in the ongoing special drive with a view to uplifting the cleaning standards of the railway station. Besides, the higher authorities have asked the local cleanliness department officials to get bathrooms cleaned properly in winter when the footfall reaches 50,000 persons every day.

Anil Kumar, in charge of the RPF here, said, “After getting directions from the higher authorities of the division, we have constituted a special team of local officials, which had conducted a drive across the station premises on Sunday and caught several offenders indulging in activities of throwing waste on railway tracks. Moreover, we are creating awareness among the passengers for not throwing waste along the railway tracks as the RPF will impose heavy penalties on them. Besides, they should not be spitting tobacco containing products on the boundary walls.”

Moreover, the authorities have been making announcements for maintaining cleanliness at the Ludhiana railway station,” said the station director

Railway health inspector Hirdesh Bharti said, “New sweeping machines had been put in use to ensure more cleanliness at the railway station. Ludhiana railway station witnesses a huge footfall and it’s really a big challenge for the local authorities to maintain sanitation across the station.”

Title: Ludhiana News - Times of India
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

‘Agent’ cheats man of Rs 12.75 lakh

Heera Singh, a resident of Jawahar Nagar here, told the police that the accused, Gaurav Sood, and his wife Pooja Sood of Sarabha Nagar took Rs 12.75 lakh to send him to Canada. However, the accused neither sent him abroad, nor returned the money. The division number 5 police have registered a case in this matter.

2kg cannabis seized

Jamalpur police have arrested Jony Kumar of Mundiya Kalan and Deepak Kumar of Haibowal with 2kg cannabis from 33 feet road, following a tip-off. A case has been registered against him in this connection.

Title: 4,000 accounts opened for girl children
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: The Department of Posts in Ludhiana City has opened more than 4,000 Sukanya Samridhi accounts of eligible girl children by running a special drive. Senior superintendent of post offices Dr Amanpreet Singh informed that under the directions of VK Tiwari, chief postmaster general (Punjab), a special drive ‘Balika Shakti’ was run in the city from December 4 to January 18 for opening Sukanya Samridhi accounts of eligible girl children. The main motive was to cover maximum girl children from 0 to10 years under this government-initiated scheme. Other than this, the Sukanya Samridhi accounts were opened for all eligible girl children in 28 villages of the city, and all these villages were declared as ‘Sampooran Sukanya Gram’.

Sukanya Samridhi is an important financial scheme of the Government of India which ensures a bright financial future of girl children. Under this scheme, the parents or legal guardian of a girl child aged between 0 and 10 years can open an account in any post office, for which a minimum of Rs250 is required, and a maximum of Rs1,50,000 can be deposited in a financial year. The account holder gets 8.4% interest (from October 2019 onwards) on his or her money deposited, which is compounded annually. The money deposited in the account is free from income tax under Section 80-C. An account-holder has to deposit money in this account for 14 years from the date of opening of the account in which he/she gets the interest rate as prescribed by the Government of India from time to time.

Child Development and Welfare department, and Health department organised various camps in the anganwadis and dispensaries of the city, where Sukanya Samridhi accounts were opened. These villages are Garha, Khaira Bet, Burj Lambra, Burjman, Rasoolpur Bet, Rajapur, Gorsian Hakam Rai, Nurpur Bet, Rajapur Patti, Bholewal Jadid, New Bahadur Ke, Bonkar Dogran, Majara Khurd, Talwandi Kalan, Manju Phaggwal, Kapoor Singh Wala, Qutbewal Gujjran, Fatehpur Gujjran, Fatehpur, Ladowal, Bagga Kalan, Sujatwala, Chuharwal, Kakka, Rawat, Sasrali, Garhi Togar, and Khasi Khurd.

Title: Long queues in hybrid lanes at Karnal toll plaza
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Karnal: The relaxation given by the Union government to select toll plazas to have 25% hybrid lanes to allow vehicles both with and without FASTags has led to long queues at Bastara toll plaza in Karnal district.

Even as the deadline for using the radio frequency identification (RFID) tags to make payments at toll plazas on highways has already been extended thrice, around 45% vehicles are still crossing every day without FASTag, say officials at Bastara toll plaza in Karnal district.

A long tailback of vehicles was seen on either side of the toll plaza on Friday. The commuters in vehicles without FASTag could use on cash lanes. They found themselves stuck in long jams and had to wait for 15-20 minutes for their turn. Some of them were also seen trying to enter the lanes reserved for vehicles with FASTag, which caused chaos at the toll plaza, affecting the traffic movement. Arguments between commuters and the toll plaza personnel were also witnessed.

Toll plaza staff claimed that on an average 10 vehicles with FASTag smoothly cross every minute, which was a far cry from the tike taken in cash lanes. Manager of Bastara toll plaza Manish Kumar said there were 24 lanes at the site out of which 25% (or three each each on both sides) were converted into hybrid lanes. “As of now, around 55% of vehicles have been crossing the toll plaza with FASTag. To avoid inconvenience in the cash lane, the commuters should purchase the fastags at the earliest,” he said. He said the tag was available at all toll plazas along with various banks. “It is available on e-commerce sites as well,” he said.

Title: Punjab CM announces Rs 12 lakh, job to family of soldier killed in Siachen
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Amarinder Singh

CHANDIGARH: Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh on Sunday announced financial assistance of Rs 12 lakh to the next of kin of Havildar Baljinder Singh, who had lost his life in the line of duty at Siachen in Ladakh on Friday. The CM also announced a government job for one eligible member of the family, according to an official spokesperson.

Havildar Singh is survived by his wife Perdeep Kaur and minor twin sons studying in Tanda. Amarinder expressed grief at the loss and extended his sympathies to the bereaved family.

The CM said the eternal sacrifice of the valiant soldier at 19,000 feet altitude in harsh cold conditions would be ever remembered. During martyr’s cremation at his native village Zahura in Hoshiarpur district on Sunday afternoon, a guard from the Army conducted the ceremonial drill and gave military honours to the brave soldier. The cremation was attended by chief minister’s political advisor and Tanda MLA Sangat Singh Gilzian, along with other government officials.

Title: After March, civic bodies will have to pay up for waste management failure
Content:
The NGT has also fixed same rate and pattern of compensation scale for failure in case of commencing remediati... Read More

JALANDHAR: On learning that most statutory timelines have already lapsed and directions for compliance of Solid Waste Management Rules 2016 in Punjab, Uttar Pradesh and Chandigarh remain unexecuted, the National Green Tribunal (NGT) has ordered that for continued failure after March 31, the urban local bodies (ULBs) would have to pay monthly compensation and along with adverse entries in the annual confidential reports of the CEOs and senior officials concerned.Acting tough against the continued failure, the NGT has laid down the scale for the monthly compensation while also asking the chief secretaries of these states to remain present during the next hearing, tentatively on August 20, 2020, for further review.In its order on January 10, the principal bench of NGT headed by chairperson Adarsh Kumar Goel ordered that for continued failure after March 31, a ULB of population above 10 lakh would have to cough up Rs 10 lakh, while for 5 to 10 lakh population, it would pay compensation of Rs 5 lakh. Other ULBs have been told to pay Rs 1 lakh every month till compliance. The tribunal further directed that if the ULBs fail to bear the financial burden then the liability would be of the state government with liberty to take remedial action against the erring officials.“Apart from compensation, adverse entries must be made in the ACRs of the CEOs of the said local bodies and other senior functionaries in the department, who are responsible for compliance of the tribunal instructions,” the order reads.The NGT has also fixed same rate and pattern of compensation scale for failure in case of commencing remediation of legacy waste (old municipal solid waste). It has held that that legacy waste remediation was to commence from November 1, 2019, even though statutory timeline for completing the said step is till April 17, 2021, which remains unexecuted in most places. “Continued failure of every local body in commencing the work from April 1, 2020, till compliance will result in liability to pay compensation,” the NGT order said.The compensation would be deposited with the Central Pollution Control Board, which would spend the same on environment restoration.The NGT has also directed that chief secretaries would ensure the steps for compliance of earlier directions given by the tribunal about plastic waste, biomedical waste, construction and demolition waste and may also set up environment monitoring cells in their offices within a month of these directions for coordination and compliance.

Title: A day ahead of assembly session, Manohar Lal Khattar and Anil Vij put up a united front
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Manohar Lal Khattar receiving a floral welcome by Anil Vij (right) in Ambala on Sunday

CHANDIGARH: Despite their ongoing tussle, Haryana home minister Anil Vij on Sunday played host to CM Manohar Lal Khattar, during the latter’s transit halt at the Ambala cantonment. Vij received Khattar a day after skipping the meetings of his own departments — home, health and medical education — chaired by the CM at his residence on Saturday.

According to information, while on his way to New Delhi, Khattar, accompanied by Himachal CM Jai Ram Thakur, had a transit halt at the Ambala Cantonment Air Force station. Vij received both the CMs and stayed with them till the arrival of an aircraft for two leaders.

“He is my CM and, under protocol, it is my duty to receive him. He was here for few minutes and flew towards Delhi after boarding the flight,” Vij said afterwards.

He added, “We never had any issue with each other. My fight is against those corrupt officers who are using the CM as their shield. This will continue till it reaches its logical conclusion.”

Vij and Khattar have been at loggerheads over the control of Haryana Police’s crime investigation department (CID).

On Saturday, Khattar took a meeting of the major portfolios headed by Vij. What’s more, Khattar even put the recruitment process for the appointment of doctors in the health department on hold, while reviewing the functioning of police department as well CID wing of the police.

Vij had skipped the meeting of the officers, chaired by Khattar at his residence. The health minister confirmed that he had intimation about the meeting.

“My Saturdays are kept aside for the people from across the state, except Ambala, who wish to meet me in person at my residence. Since I was busy with them, I could not make it to the meeting. Were the people only from Ambala were to come, I would have postponed that and gone to Chandigarh,” said Vij.

Referring to the decision halting recruitment of doctors, Vij said, “The CM can take a decision on any issue. It was CMO only which had brought the recruitment of doctors out of the purview of HPSC. However, we do need doctors.”

Title: 4 long-route trains delayed due to dense fog
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: As many as four long-route trains heading towards to Kolkata and Uttar Pradesh were cancelled by the railway authorities in the wake of dense fog on the Northern Railway route during the early morning hours on Sunday. Apart from that, almost every train arrived with a minimum delay of five to six hours. Even premium trains coming from the national capital towards Amritsar witnessed a delay of at least one hour, as Shatabdi Express arrived at 1.20pm, instead of 12noon.

Maximum delay was witnessed by Lohit Express from Guwahati to Jammu Tawi, as it arrived seven hours late at 2.30pm, instead of 7.30am. Station superintendent Ashok Salaria claimed that following a dense blanket of fog early in the morning and late in the evening on the Northern Railway route, some long-route trains were cancelled by the railway authorities.

Inquiry officials at the station claimed that Shan-e-Punjab Express from Amritsar to New Delhi also reached Ludhiana late by one hour, twenty minutes at 1.45pm, instead of 12.25pm. Tata Muri Express from Tata Nagar to Jammu Tawi arrived late by about five-and-a-half hours at 10.32pm, instead of 5.05am. Even Malwa Express from Indore to Jammu Tawi, along with Shaheed Express saw a delay of around three hours.

Passengers seemed frustrated waiting for their trains on Sunday, as chilly weather made them restless. Many of them cried foul over the cancellation of Kolkata-bound trains, as they had booked their confirmed seats two to three months ago. Passenger Vishal Sharma, who was waiting for Chhatisgarh Express, said, “I had to face the problem of train delay again, as my train was running way behind schedule. I was here to attend a wedding with family members, but now I have to go back to the bus stand and use other modes of transport.”

Woman passenger Ankita Gehlot, waiting for Kolkata Express, said, “Women and children continued to struggle to catch trains in such unpleasant weather, but authorities have turned a blind eye to their suffering, as railway authorities have not increased the strength of the waiting rooms, and we have to sit on the floor in the case of delay of trains.”

Title: CICU holds workshop on lean manufacturing
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: Chamber of Industrial and Commercial Undertakings (CICU) on Sunday organised a workshop on lean manufacturing processes for city businessmen. The programme was organised at the Focal Point office of the association, where a large number of businessmen and representatives of various industries took part.

CICU president Upkar Singh Ahuja said, “Time and time again we have been organising seminars and workshops for the benefit and upgradation of skills of industry and trade sectors, as the role of top management has become extremely critical nowadays. As industry today is surrounded by a lot of challenges like shrinking profit margins, late deliveries, sub-standard quality of products, improvement of systems, and skill trainings of employees, it is necessary to increase profit margins by reducing manufacturing costs and improving product quality and productivity to remain competitive in the market. The workshop was a huge success, as more than 60 businessmen, top-level executives of reputed companies, and other staff attended this workshop.”

During Sunday’s programme, an interactive session too was conducted, which was presided over by trainer Rajesh Singh Solanki. He elaborated on the concepts of Lean Manufacturing, Kaizen, Kanban, Poka Yoke, and Problem Solving. He also presented case studies of the successful implementation of lean manufacturing practices in small and micro enterprises, and government initiatives to facilitate related benefits to the industry.

Meanwhile, CICU has also raised its voice against the problem of notices being sent by the office of zila parishad to some businessmen to pay new taxes. Giving more information, Ahuja said, “Recently, many industries received notices to pay charges for use of road by the office of zila parishad. This is the first time zila parishad has issued notices to industrial units, and it is really very shocking, as already industry has to obtain 23 clearances from different departments, and now to add to our pain, zila parishad too has jumped in and imposed a new kind of tax on us. But we will not tolerate these kind of atrocities, and we will take up this matter with the chief minister’s office, as the new tax is totally uncalled for.”

Title: Women power takes on CAA, NRC
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: Women from various communities, mostly Muslims, took out a rally to voice their anger against the ‘black law’ of Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and NRC here on Sunday. The protest rally started from Brown road, passed through Subhani Building area and Shahpur road before culminating at the Jama Masjid in Field Gunj. At the Jama Masjid, the stage was managed by Naib Shahi Imam Maualana Usman Ludhianvi. The protesters were holding placards against the CAA and NRC while some had ‘Hindu Muslim Sikh Isai, Aapas Main Hain Bhai Bhai, written on it.

Giving details, Maualana Usman Ludhianvi said student leader of Punjab University Kanupriya, Navdeep Kaur of a Sikh religious channel, apart from thousands of members from Hindu, Sikh, Christian communities participated in the protest rally. He added that women protesters after holding the rally presented a blood written resolution to Shahi Imam Punjab Maulana Habib-ur-Rehman Saani Ludhianvi.

The Shahi Imam said in the written resolution that the women protesters had vouched that they would strongly oppose the ‘black law’, made as part of a conspiracy to break the Constitution, till the last drop of their blood. He added that in the resolution women protesters have written that they were together in the freedom struggle and no one would be able to break the brotherhood, which reflects unity in diversity.

The protesters wrote that refugees were their brothers but not on the basis of religion but on the basis of humanity and ‘Bhartiyata’. They alleged that the government under the garb of refugees was trying to murder democracy but they would not allow it to do so.

Student leader Kanpuriya while addressing the protesters alleged that ‘divisive’ forces were trying to break communal harmony and integrity of the country but daughters, sisters and mothers of the country would not allow such ‘agenda’ of the Modi government to succeed. She added that those promising ‘roti, kapda and makaan’ were now asking for proof of citizenship from the people of the country.

Maulana Habib-ur-Rehman Saani Ludhianvi claimed that Modi government was avoiding the questions of daughters of India. He added that it was unfortunate that despite being in power, the Union government had to organise rallies in favour of law made by it and was hesitating in directly talking to people.

On this occasion, Rehnuma Khatoon recited a Nazm (verses) ‘hum dekhenge’ of Faiz Ahmed Faiz whereas Halima Ansari and Gul Afshan recited the poem ‘yeh desh hamara hai’. A protester, Nasreen Sultana, who addressed the gathering in Punjabi took potshots at the ‘wrong’ policies of the central government.

Title: Weather turns sunny on Sunday, but keep umbrellas ready tomorrow
Content:
This story is from January 20, 2020

Ludhiana: A day after cold weather prevailed in the city, it was sunny and warm in Ludhiana on Sunday. However, there is bad news for residents on the weather front, as the Met department has predicted rainfall in the city on Tuesday.

Even as it was foggy and cloudy in the city on Saturday, which brought back the chill, it was sunny and warm in Ludhiana on Sunday. As the sun shined in the city throughout the day, its impact reflected on the maximum temperature, which was recorded at 19.2 degrees Celsius (a degree above normal, and 3.6 degrees more than on Saturday). The minimum temperature on Sunday was recorded at 6.7 degrees Celsius (also a degree above normal, but 1.6 degrees less than the previous day).

Meanwhile, as very dense fog appeared in the city on Sunday morning, it brought visibility down to just 10 metres at 8.30am, which later improved to 1,500 metres at 11.30am.

For Monday, a Met department official in Chandigarh said it was expected to be generally cloudy, whereas for the next day (Tuesday), the weather forecast is ‘generally cloudy sky, with one or two spells of rain or thundershowers’. He added that the day temperature was expected to fall in the city in the next two days, but the night temperature may increase. As per the department website, the maximum temperature is expected to fall to 15 degrees until Tuesday, whereas the night temperature might rise to 9 degrees by the same day.

Meanwhile, residents enjoyed the sunny weather on Sunday. “The sun seems to be playing hide and seek with us for the past several days, as on one day, it disappears behind the clouds, while the next day, it appears. However, as it came out in the morning and shined throughout the day, it made our Sunday special. I enjoyed sleeping under it on the roof after a delicious lunch, and it felt like heaven,” said Manoj Kumar, a businessman from Chandigarh Road.
